Green Party of England and Wales.crime: The Green Party’s policies on crime and policing, outlined in the manifesto section titled "Bringing Justice to Crime and Policing," focus on transforming the justice system through prevention, community-based policing, and restorative justice, rather than relying solely on punitive measures like imprisonment. The party asserts that everyone has the right to feel safe, whether on the street, at home, or online, and that structural injustice must be tackled. Here is a summary of the Green Party’s policies on crime and justice: 1. Policing and Building Trust The party emphasizes that policing must operate by consent, which necessitates restoring trust with the communities served. • Tackling Institutional Prejudice: Police Services need to acknowledge and root out institutional racism, misogyny, homophobia, and disablism that have long dominated policing. • Accountability: Police Services should be accountable to elected local government and the communities where they work. • Stop and Search/Facial Recognition: Elected Greens will push for an end to the routine use of stop and search and an end to the use of facial recognition software. The use of traumatizing tactics like stop and search should become an exception, not routine. • Staff Training: Police Services must deliver ongoing fitness to practice assessments on diversity for all police officers and relevant civilian staff. • Youth Encounters: Safeguarding is the priority in encounters between young people and the police. The party advocates for youth workers, rather than police officers, to work with pupils in schools. Children and young people should never be strip-searched without an appropriate adult present, and only in very exceptional circumstances. 2. Restorative Justice and Sentencing Reform The Green approach is grounded in a belief that rehabilitation is the best way to reduce future offending. • Restorative Justice: The party will expand restorative justice when crimes occur to give victims a voice and help offenders take responsibility for the harm they have caused. • Presumption Against Short Sentences: The party would seek to break the cycle of reoffending by legislating for a presumption against custodial sentences under two years. Evidence shows that short prison sentences are especially ineffective and lead to higher rates of recidivism. • Focus on Prevention: They will focus on crime prevention by restoring funding withdrawn from youth services since 2010 and investing in community-based policing. 3. Ending Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG) Ending domestic abuse and violence against women and girls is listed as a Green Party priority. • Hate Crime: Elected Greens will push to make misogyny a hate crime across the UK. • Strategy and Training: They will develop and implement a new UK-wide strategy to tackle gender-based violence (including domestic violence, rape, sexual abuse, FGM, and trafficking). They will also ensure that domestic abuse and gender-based violence is a key measurable priority for all police forces, and that all police officers are trained to recognize and tackle domestic violence. • Funding Services: Local authorities must be funded so that domestic violence, rape crisis, and other support provision can meet local needs. • Sex Work: Elected Greens will push to decriminalise sex work. 4. Court System and Funding The manifesto addresses the "chaos" in the court system that currently lets down victims and the accused. • Investment: The party will invest £11 billion in restoring the Ministry of Justice budget over the course of the next parliament. • Court Repairs: They commit to repairing and renewing the court system with a £2.5 billion investment. • Legal Aid and Bar Funding: The investment would be used to restore legal aid budgets and ensure the Criminal Bar is sufficiently well funded. • Recruitment: They will push to recruit more judges and ensure they are representative of wider society. • Tackling Backlogs: Investment is needed in the criminal justice system so that defendants are brought to trial quickly in the interests of both the victim and the accused. 5. Drug Law Reform The party supports an evidence-based approach to drug law reform, arguing that current laws are counterproductive. • National Commission: Push for the establishment of a National Commission to agree on an evidence-based approach to reforming the UK’s drug laws. • Decriminalisation: Elected Greens will push to decriminalise personal possession of drugs. This is intended to divert people from the criminal justice system toward support for addiction, housing, and employment, thereby freeing up hundreds of thousands of hours of police time. • Diversion: They will ensure that diversion programs are in place for all low-level drug and alcohol-related offenses and for young offenders arrested for low-level offenses. This aims to move towards a legally regulated market that stops criminal supply and profiteering and reduces harm. 6. Public Health Approach to Violence The Green Party supports using a public health approach to reducing violence, drawing on evidence that this is compelling. • Violence Reduction Units (VRUs): They support the use of VRUs and the need for them to focus on multi-agency working, similar to the model that helped decrease violence in Scotland. • Local Control: They will push for more local control over public services to ensure effective joined-up working across public services to deliver violence reduction strategies. 7. Protecting Civil Rights The manifesto includes a commitment to scrap recent legislation that erodes rights and protest: • Scrapping Legislation: Elected Greens will push to scrap the Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Act, the Public Order Act, and other legislation that erodes the right to protest and to free expression. • Legal Aid: They will restore legal aid for public law cases so everybody can uphold their rights in court.
Green Party of England and Wales.healthcare: The Green Party’s manifesto, titled "Real Hope. Real Change. Manifesto for a Fairer, Greener Country," dedicates a significant section to Building a Fairer, Healthier Country and Caring with Fairness, Compassion and Dignity, committing to defend the NHS against privatization and fix the social care crisis. The party asserts that the NHS is currently facing the most serious crisis in its 80-year history due to deliberate Conservative under-funding and the risk of collapse, which paves the way for privatization. Greens are committed to a fully public health service and keeping the profit motive away from the NHS. Here is a summary of the key healthcare and related policies: 1. NHS Funding, Access, and Privatization The party proposes significant financial commitments to stabilize and expand the National Health Service (NHS). • Increased Funding: The NHS in England would receive additional annual expenditure of £8 billion in the first full year of the next parliament, rising to a total of £28 billion by 2030. • Capital Spending: An additional capital spending of at least £20 billion is needed in total over the next five years, including £12 billion for hospital building and repair. • Waiting Lists and Access: Elected Greens will push for a steady reduction in waiting lists. They would guarantee rapid access to a GP and same-day access in case of urgent need. • Anti-Privatization: Green MPs will back the NHS Reinstatement Bill to abolish wasteful competition within the NHS, re-establish public bodies and public accountability, and restrict the role of commercial companies. They will always stand against the marketisation and privatization of the NHS. 2. NHS Staff and Pay Tackling staff retention and low pay is a priority to address the crisis in the health service. • Fair Pay: The party would choose to treat and pay nurses, doctors, and NHS staff fairly, specifically to avoid losing them overseas. They will prioritize supporting NHS workers, including providing an immediate one-off budget increase to cover fair wage settlements. • Junior Doctors: Elected Greens will support the junior doctors’ call for pay restoration. • Valuing Professionals: NHS professionals should be valued with pay and conditions that reflect their essential skills and dedication. 3. Primary Care and Public Health The manifesto emphasizes investment in prevention and early diagnosis, arguing that this improves quality of life and reduces demand on the wider NHS. • Primary Care Investment: Funding allocated to primary medical care will be increased, with additional annual spending reaching £1.5 billion by 2030, targeted at areas of greatest need. • GP Support: Measures include reducing the administrative burden on GPs, for example, by allowing hospital doctors to make onward referrals without needing to go back to a patient’s GP. • Diagnostic Capacity: There would be expansion of diagnostic capacity in communities to ensure early diagnosis and better outcomes. • Restoring Public Health Budgets: Public health budgets would be restored to 2015/16 levels with an immediate increase of £1.5 billion. This money would properly fund services like smoking cessation, drug and alcohol treatment, and sexual health services. • Cross-Government Approach: Health would be a cross-government priority, supported by interventions across the manifesto such as improved food labelling, free school meals, active travel, and investment in sport. 4. NHS Dentistry The failure to properly fund NHS dentistry has led to scandals like patients pulling out their own teeth. • Guaranteed Access: The party commits to guaranteed access to an NHS dentist for everybody. • Investment: Additional investment in NHS dentistry is proposed, reaching £3 billion a year by 2030. • Children’s Dental Care: Campaign for funding for community hubs and primary care to provide a roll-out of free dental nursing for children and those on low incomes, focusing on preventative work. 5. Social Care and Welfare Greens believe that health and care services go hand in hand and propose significant investment to address the crisis in social care, which currently includes over 400,000 people awaiting care. • Free Personal Care: Introduce Free Personal Care to ensure dignity in old age and for disabled people, based on the Scottish Government’s approach. This includes fully funding personal care elements for those in residential settings. • Social Care Investment: Commit to investing £20 billion per year into the social care system. • Carer Support: Establish a career structure for carers, including national pay, terms, and conditions, increased pay rates, and a pathway to progression with training and qualifications. The party would also change the working visa system to end the exploitation of overseas workers in the care sector. • Gloria’s Law: Campaign for "Gloria’s Law," which gives everybody the right to at least one essential Care Supporter (relative or friend) when using health or care services. 6. Mental Health and Specialized Care The manifesto aims to achieve true equality between mental and physical health care. • Access to Therapy: Ensure that everyone who needs evidence-based mental health therapies can access them within 28 days. • Targeted Provision: Guarantee tailored and specific mental health provision for communities of color, children and adolescents, older people, and LGBTIQA+ communities. • School Counsellors: Provide a trained and paid counsellor in every primary and secondary school and every sixth-form college. • National Cancer Plan: Commit to a National Cancer Control Plan focused on reducing cases through public health interventions, meeting the target of 75% of cases diagnosed early (Stage 1 or 2) by 2028, and delivering treatment through publicly funded research. • HIV Prevention: Work towards ending new HIV transmissions by 2030 using proven actions, including access to the HIV prevention pill (PrEP) and renewing opt-out HIV testing programs in A&Es in high-prevalence areas. 7. Disability Rights and Other Health Measures The party commits to restoring the dignity and rights of disabled people. • Benefits Uplift: Restore the value of disability benefits with an immediate uplift of 5%. • PIP Reform: Oppose plans to replace Personal Independence Payments (PIP) cash payments with "vouchers," and reform intrusive eligibility tests in the long term. • Assisted Dying: Back changing the law on assisted dying, supporting a humane and dignified approach for the terminally ill, provided proper safeguards are in place. • Drug Laws: Push for a National Commission to agree on an evidence-based approach to reform counterproductive drug laws, aiming to move toward a legally regulated market that reduces harm. The Green Party views this comprehensive investment package as essential to lifting everyone up and ensuring that all citizens have access to the extra support and safety net they need throughout their lives.
Green Party of England and Wales.housing: The Green Party’s housing policies, detailed in the manifesto section titled "Providing Fairer, Greener Homes for All," aim to fundamentally change the view of housing from being merely an asset to ensuring everyone has a safe, warm, and affordable home. The policies prioritize the provision of genuinely affordable social housing, comprehensive insulation, and robust renters’ rights. Here is a summary of the key housing and homes policies: 1. Social Housing and Affordability The manifesto attributes the national housing crisis to forty years of treating houses as assets and neglecting social housing construction, noting that over 130,000 children are currently growing up in temporary accommodation. • Social Home Provision: Elected Greens will push to provide 150,000 new social homes a year. • End "Right to Buy": They will end the so-called "right to buy" to ensure that newly built social homes continue to belong to communities and remain available for those who need a secure, warm home. • Maintenance of Stock: Green MPs will push Ministers to ensure all social housing stock is brought up to and kept at a decent standard, with fair funding for Councils and Housing Associations to achieve this. • Empty Homes: Local authorities would be empowered to bring empty homes (estimated at around a million across the UK) back into use. • Buy the Supply: Legislation would be introduced to give local authorities, registered social landlords, and community housing groups the first option to buy certain properties at reasonable rates, such as private rental property that is left empty for over six months or fails to meet the decent homes standard or EPC C rating. 2. Fairer, Greener Homes Guarantee and Retrofit The manifesto introduces a Fairer, Greener Homes Guarantee to tackle fuel poverty and high energy bills caused by the UK having "the worst insulated homes in Europe". The cheapest energy bill, the manifesto states, is the one you don’t have to pay. • Retrofitting Investment: Elected Greens will invest £29 billion over the next five years to insulate homes to EPC B standard or above, as part of a ten-year program. ◦ This includes £12 billion to retrofit social housing stock and £17 billion in grants to retrofit privately owned homes. • Heating Systems: They will invest £9 billion over five years for heating systems (e.g., heat pumps) for homes and other buildings. • Climate Adaptation: A further £7 billion over five years will be invested to adapt homes to avoid over-heating in hotter summers. • Delivery Model: The party will introduce a local-authority-led, street-by-street or area-based retrofit programme to install non-fossil-fuel heat and adapt buildings to more extreme weather. • Financing: The program will be financed by ensuring that: ◦ Competitive bidding for the social housing decarbonisation fund ends. ◦ Homeowners can easily access property-linked finance. ◦ Private tenants have the right to insist their landlords access property-linked finance, with rent controls preventing the costs from being passed directly to tenants. 3. Planning and New Building Standards The party aims to transform the planning system to protect green spaces, reduce environmental impact, and support flourishing communities. • New Building Standards: Elected Greens will campaign to change building regulations so all new homes must meet Passivhaus or equivalent standards. New homes must also include solar panels and low-carbon heating systems such as heat pumps. • Infrastructure Support: Large-scale developments must be supported by new infrastructure, including GP surgeries, bus services, cycling and walking networks, and extra places at nurseries and schools, so residents do not have to rely on cars. • Green Space Protection: They are committed to protecting the Green Belt and ensuring everybody has easy access to a green space. • Construction Emissions: To lower carbon emissions from the built environment, they will require: ◦ Demolition to require a full planning application. ◦ All planning applications to include whole-life carbon and energy calculations. ◦ Increasing disposal rates for builders’ waste to incentivize material reuse. • Public Accountability: They will take back the power of building control from developers and invest in publicly accountable building inspectors to prevent the continued provision of dangerous and substandard homes. 4. Renters’ Rights The manifesto outlines policies to protect the rights of the millions of people who rent their homes. • Rent Controls: Elected Greens will empower local authorities to introduce rent controls if the local rental market is overheated, while allowing for maintenance. • Ending No-Fault Evictions: They will push to end no-fault evictions (Section 21) and introduce long-term leases to ensure private tenants are secure in their homes. • Efficiency Improvements: Renters will be given a new right to demand energy efficiency improvements from their landlords. • Dispute Resolution: Private Residential Tenancy Boards would be introduced to provide an informal, cheap, and speedy forum for resolving disputes before they reach a tribunal. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The Green Party’s housing strategy is designed to address the housing crisis by making homes more affordable through massive social building and empowering people to live in warmer, greener, and safer homes through mandatory high standards and deep retrofitting investment.
Green Party of England and Wales.immigration: The Green Party’s manifesto outlines immigration policies focused on adopting an "outward-looking approach", welcoming contributions from migrants and refugees, and ending the current punitive system. The party believes the UK has a collective responsibility regarding the climate emergency and a duty to support individuals displaced by changes in their home environments. Elected Greens will prioritize the following: Ending the Hostile Environment and Cruelty The core of the policy is dismantling the "hostile environment" approach, which has caused "immense suffering," including to the Windrush generation. • Abolish "No Recourse to Public Funds": Campaign to abolish the No Recourse to Public Funds (NRPF) condition, which currently exacerbates social, economic, and racial inequalities. • Abolish the Ten-Year Settlement Route: Campaign to abolish the ten-year route to settlement, which is seen as unfairly trapping people in poverty and hardship. • End Immigration Detention: Migration is viewed as "not a criminal offence under any circumstances". The party would end immigration detention for all migrants unless they pose a danger to public safety. • Free NHS Access: Access to the NHS should be free and comprehensive for migrants with visas. Asylum and Sanctuary The Green Party acknowledges the right to claim asylum as set out in the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights. • Safe Routes to Sanctuary: Push for the UK to collaborate with other countries to establish safe routes for those fleeing danger, persecution, war, or climate disaster. This allows people to arrive safely and make their case without risking their lives. • Fast and Fair Process: Advocate for a system of asylum and humanitarian protection that treats applicants fairly, humanely, and without discrimination. • Right to Work: Those seeking asylum and protection must be permitted to work while their application is being decided. • Climate Migration: Recognize that as the climate crisis worsens, more people may be forced to leave their homes. The party’s proposed significant increase in the overseas aid budget and support for lower-income countries is intended to help people stay in their communities, but policies will also ensure those forced to leave can do so safely and with dignity. System Reform and Visa Requirements The manifesto calls for structural reforms within the government and changes to visa rules affecting workers and families. • Dismantle the Home Office: Push to dismantle the dysfunctional Home Office and create a new Department of Migration alongside a separate Department of Justice. This separates functions around migration and citizenship from the criminal justice system. • Simplified Visa System: The system of visa applications should be simplified and processed swiftly, with empathy and intelligence. • Application Fees: Seek to end the exploitation of people for profit by only charging application fees at cost. • Family and Spousal Visas: Elected Greens will push to remove minimum income requirements from all applications, including spousal visas, so that all British citizens have the right to reside with their loved ones regardless of their income. • Family Reunification: Migrants, including students, should be allowed to bring family members to the UK who would normally live with them in their country of origin. • Voting Rights: All visa-holding residents should have the right to vote in all elections and referendums. The party emphasizes that they welcome the economic and societal contributions that immigrants and refugees make to British society and want to support migrants in putting down roots.
Green Party of England and Wales.defence: The Green Party’s policies on defense are primarily framed within the context of global peace, international law, disarmament, and reforming existing security alliances. The party believes the UK’s foreign policy should be based on shared commitments to democracy, peace, global solidarity, and the protection of human rights in an increasingly volatile world. Here is a summary of the Green Party’s policies on security and defense: 1. Nuclear Disarmament The most decisive defense policy proposed is the immediate dismantling of the UK’s nuclear arsenal. • Signing the TPNW: Elected Greens will push for the UK to sign the UN Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (TPNW). • Dismantling Trident: Following the signing of the TPNW, the party would immediately begin the process of dismantling the UK’s nuclear weapons, cancelling the Trident programme, and removing all foreign nuclear weapons from UK soil. • International Efforts: They would work with international partners to enlarge TPNW membership and ensure all states meet their commitments under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. • Savings: The cancellation of the Trident replacement is included in the manifesto’s statistical appendix as a source of savings. 2. NATO and Security Architecture Reform While recognizing the role of mutual defense alliances, the Green Party seeks significant reform within NATO. • NATO Role: The party recognizes that NATO has an important role in ensuring member states can respond to security threats and supports the principle of international solidarity through mutual defence alliances and multilateral security frameworks. • Reform Focus: They will work within NATO for a greater focus on outreach and dialogue to support global peacebuilding, based on democratic and inclusive values. • Specific Reforms: Crucial reforms to the way NATO operates that they seek include: ◦ A commitment to a "No First Use" of nuclear weapons. ◦ Ensuring that diplomacy and practical co-operation always take precedence over military action. ◦ Mandating that NATO must act solely in defence of member states. • European Security: They will also work towards reform of the European security architecture and disarmament, based on shared commitments to democracy and mutual transparency. 3. International Law and Conflict The party prioritizes the rule of law, including international law, which underpins rights and protects against state aggression and genocide. • International Law Enforcement: They want the UK to take the lead in upholding the right to self-determination and the enforcement of international law. • Support for Ukraine: They commit to continuing to support Ukraine as it resists Russian invasion. • Israel and Palestine: The party calls for an immediate and permanent bilateral ceasefire. They support the return of hostages and the recognition of the state of Palestine. They also push for an end to all UK arms exports to and military cooperation with Israel, arguing this makes the British government complicit in war crimes. They support the investigation and prosecution of war crimes and believe there is strong evidence supporting the submission to the International Court of Justice regarding Israel’s conduct in Gaza. 4. Other Related Policies • Military Animal Testing: They would end the use of live animals in military training. • Global Solidarity: In a world threatened by climate-driven instability, mass migration, and war, they stress the need for enlightened leadership and international solidarity.
Green Party of England and Wales.economy: The economic policies outlined in the Green Party’s 2024 General Election Manifesto, "Real Hope. Real Change. Manifesto for a Fairer, Greener Country," center on a green economic transformation funded primarily by taxing wealth and pollution, and bringing privatized utilities into public ownership. The manifesto argues that the solutions to the climate crisis align with those needed to end the cost of living and inequality crises, leading to a decarbonized economy with cheaper costs for heating, travel, and business operation. Here is a summary of the key economic policies and funding mechanisms: 1. Green Economic Transformation and Public Investment The Green Party commits to a significant, large-scale, long-term program of investment in a green economic transformation, alongside the private sector. • Investment Commitment: The plan requires an average investment of £40 billion per year over the course of the next parliament. • Climate Adaptation: This investment includes £7 billion annually on climate adaptation. • Investment Breakdown: The required spending (totaling £161 billion over the parliament, based on the statistical appendix) includes: ◦ £50 billion for electricity generation, transmission, and storage. ◦ £50 billion for retrofitting buildings, installing non-fossil fuel heating systems, and adapting homes for a climate-changed world. ◦ £30 billion for investing in a modern, electrified railway. ◦ £12 billion for water and sewage infrastructure. ◦ £30 billion allocated for the nationalization of water companies and the Big 5 retail energy companies. • Borrowing Strategy: The party rejects the "self-imposed straitjacket of conventional fiscal rules" and is prepared to borrow to invest. The overarching fiscal rule would be that public expenditure is only expanded as far as the economy has the capacity to absorb it without triggering dangerous levels of inflation. • Research and Development (R&D): Green MPs will seek to increase R&D investment by over £30 billion across the five-year parliament, focusing on areas tackling the climate and environmental crisis, such as energy storage, agroecological agriculture, and carbon-neutral construction. 2. Tax Reforms and Revenue Generation The manifesto proposes tax reforms designed to generate substantial revenue, estimated to raise between £50 billion and £70 billion per year by the end of the next parliament. These revenues are intended to rescue public services and fund climate protection. • Wealth Tax: A wealth tax would be introduced on the wealth of individual taxpayers. This would levy: ◦ 1% annually on assets above £10 million. ◦ 2% annually on assets above £1 billion. • Capital Gains Tax (CGT): Elected Greens would reform CGT by aligning the rates paid on taxable gains with the rates paid on income. • Investment Income: Tax rates on investment income would be reformed by aligning them with the tax and NIC rates on employment income. • National Insurance: The party would remove the Upper Earnings Limit that restricts the amount of National Insurance paid by high earners. • Carbon Tax: A carbon tax would be introduced on all fossil fuels (domestic or imported) to make polluters pay and incentivize decarbonization. ◦ The tax would start at an initial rate of £120 per tonne. ◦ It would progressively rise to a maximum of £500 per tonne of carbon emitted within ten years. ◦ This measure is estimated to raise up to an additional £80 billion by the end of the parliament before falling back as emissions reduce. • Windfall Taxes: Green MPs would support an increase in the rate of the windfall tax on oil and gas production, closing existing loopholes. They would also introduce a windfall tax on banks when excessive profits are being made. • Property Taxes: In the long term, the party aims for a Land Value Tax. In the next parliament, steps would include re-evaluation of Council Tax bands and the removal of business rate relief on various properties. • VAT Changes: Proposed changes include reducing VAT on hospitality and the arts, and increasing it on financial services and private education. 3. Public Ownership and Financial Regulation The manifesto seeks to reverse the failure of privatization by bringing key utilities back into public hands, arguing that the government can borrow and invest more cheaply than private companies. • Immediate Public Ownership: Commit to immediately bringing the railways, the water companies, and the Big 5 retail energy companies back into public ownership. • Financial Services Regulation: Green MPs would mandate companies holding a UK banking licence to present a strategy for divestment of current fossil fuel assets by 2030. • Bank of England Mandate: The Bank of England’s mandate would be changed to make funding the sustainability transition a central objective, alongside price stability. • Non-bank Institutions: UK pension funds, investment funds, and insurance companies would be required to remove fossil fuel assets from their portfolios and balance sheets by 2030. • Regional Mutual Banks: The party will back the creation of regional mutual banks, capitalized with a Co-operative Development Fund and an additional £10 billion of public money, to drive investment in decarbonization, SMEs, and community-owned enterprises. 4. Labor and Welfare Policies The economic platform includes substantial increases to the minimum wage and welfare benefits, funded by the proposed tax increases. • Minimum Wage: Introduce a minimum wage of £15 an hour for all, regardless of age, with costs offset for small businesses by increasing the Employment Allowance to £10,000. • Pay Ratios: Campaign for a maximum 10:1 pay ratio for all private and public-sector organizations. • Universal Credit (UC): Increase UC and legacy benefits by £40 a week. • Welfare Reform: Abolish the two-child benefit cap, end benefit sanctions, and scrap the bedroom tax. • Universal Basic Income (UBI): Push for the long-term introduction of a Universal Basic Income. Analogy The Green Party’s economic approach is akin to renovating an old, inefficient house (the UK economy). They propose securing the necessary funds by having the wealthiest occupants and polluters pay their fair share (Wealth Tax and Carbon Tax), and then using that capital to invest heavily in modern, efficient, and collectively owned infrastructure (renewables, public transport, and retrofitting). This comprehensive investment is intended not just to stop the leaks and damage (climate crisis), but to create a warmer, safer, and fairer structure for everyone who lives there (a fairer, greener country).
Green Party of England and Wales.education: The Green Party’s manifesto outlines policies aimed at transforming the education system to prioritize the love of learning, inclusivity, and lifelong support, while ensuring every child can reach their potential. The party views education as a common good that should be publicly funded and available free of charge at every stage of life. Here is a summary of the Green Party’s education policies: 1. Schools and Funding The manifesto addresses the negative impacts of over a decade of funding cuts, assessment targets, and a teacher recruitment crisis. • Increased School Funding: Elected Greens will advocate for an increase in school funding, with an £8 billion investment in schools, which includes £2 billion for a pay uplift for teachers. • School Buildings: They plan to ensure every school building is safe by investing £2.5 billion a year to tackle issues like the RAAC concrete scandal, and provide necessary funding for schools to be well-maintained and fit for purpose. • Curriculum and Assessment: They will review assessment targets so that arts and vocational subjects are treated equally within the curriculum. The party will also end high-stakes, formal testing at primary and secondary schools and abolish OFSTED to reduce stress in the education system. • Green Curriculum: Children should be supported to learn outdoors and learn about the climate and biodiversity crisis to prepare them for future challenges. They will ensure effective delivery of the new Natural History GCSE. • Privatization and Fees: Elected Greens would move academies and free schools into local authority control. They would remove charitable status from private schools and charge full VAT on fees, though private school places for children with special education needs would not be subject to VAT as an interim measure until public-sector capacity is built. 2. Special Educational Needs (SEND) and Child Wellbeing The party commits to ensuring adequate support for neurodivergent children and those with special needs. • SEND Investment: They will push for £5 billion to be invested in special needs (SEND) provision within mainstream schools. This funding aims to ensure all schools have fully accessible buildings and specially trained teachers. • Transport: They will make it mandatory for councils to provide free transport for 16–18-year-old pupils with Special Educational Needs and Disability. • Counselling and Medical Staff: They will provide a trained and paid counsellor in every primary and secondary school, and every sixth-form college. This will be supported through bursaries to train counsellors from underrepresented backgrounds. They will also fully restore the role of the school nurse, ensuring all schools have access to an on-site medical professional. 3. Early Years and Food Education policies begin at the earliest stages, with a focus on play and support. • Early Years: Pre-school education should be focused on play and supporting young children to safely explore the world. • Sure Start: They will advocate for £1.4 billion per year to be invested by local authorities in Sure Start Centres. • Childcare: In negotiation with the sector, they will seek to extend the outgoing government’s offer of childcare to 35 hours per week from nine months. • Free School Meals: They will ensure all children have a daily free school meal (made from nutritious ingredients and sustainable produce). They will also protect provision of free school breakfast clubs for all primary school pupils up to Year 6. • Food Education: Schools should involve children in growing, preparing, and cooking food as part of the core curriculum. 4. Post-16 and Higher Education The party aims to make education and training accessible for lifelong learning. • Further Education (FE): They will push for a £3 billion increase in funding for sixth-form education over the next parliamentary term, and a £12 billion investment in skills and lifelong learning for further education. • Financial Support (Post-16): They propose the restoration of the Education Maintenance Allowance to financially support young people to continue their studies after age 16. • Higher Education Funding: They would fully fund every higher education student, restoring maintenance grants and scrapping undergraduate tuition fees. Their long-term plans also include seeking to cancel graduate debt. • Teacher Pensions: Elected Greens will work with the higher education sector to address challenges posed by changes to employer contributions for the Teachers’ Pension Scheme (TPS). 5. Other Policies • Relationships, Sex and Health Education: They will retain a full, evidence-based, and age-appropriate programme of Relationships, Sex and Health Education, including LGBTIQA+ content and resources. • Sports Facilities: They support allowing access to school sports facilities by local clubs and teams outside teaching hours to ensure maximum use of a valuable resource. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- (Note: The sources indicate that education policy in Wales is devolved to the Welsh Government, and the Scottish Green Party is distinct, meaning these summaries primarily reflect policy intentions for England or the UK where powers are reserved).
Green Party of England and Wales.environment: The Green Party’s environmental policies, central to their manifesto "Real Hope. Real Change. Manifesto for a Fairer, Greener Country", focus on addressing the climate emergency with urgency, rapidly transitioning to a zero-carbon economy, and undertaking a massive effort to restore nature and tackle pollution. The party states that the solutions to the climate crisis are the same as those needed to resolve the cost of living and inequality crises. Here is a summary of the Green Party’s environmental policies across energy, nature, transport, and resource use: 1. Energy and Climate Action The Green Party asserts that the current UK commitment to net zero by 2050 is inadequate, and they plan to transition to a zero-carbon society more than a decade ahead of 2050. • Phasing Out Fossil Fuels: They will push the next government to stop all new fossil fuel extraction projects in the UK, including cancelling recently issued licenses such as Rosebank. They will also end all subsidies to the oil and gas industries. • Carbon Tax: A carbon tax will be introduced on all fossil fuels (domestic or imported), proportional to the greenhouse gas emissions produced when burned. This tax would start at an initial rate of £120 per tonne, progressively rising to a maximum of £500 per tonne of carbon emitted within ten years. This is designed to incentivize reducing emissions rather than paying the tax. • Renewable Energy Targets: They aim for wind power to provide around 70% of the UK’s electricity by 2030. Specific targets by 2035 include achieving 80GW of offshore wind, 53 GW of onshore wind, and 100 GW of solar. • Onshore Wind: They would end the de-facto ban on onshore wind. • Nuclear Power: They would cease development of new nuclear power stations and campaign to phase out existing ones, arguing that nuclear energy is too expensive, slow to develop, and a distraction from renewable energy. • Community Energy: They commit to a minimum threshold of community ownership in all sustainable energy infrastructure and would remove regulatory barriers to community energy. • Biofuels: They would properly regulate biofuels to end greenwashing, ensuring they provide genuine net carbon savings, and end the practice of importing wood for burning at Drax power station and end subsidies for biomass. • Infrastructure: They plan to significantly expand and improve the efficiency of the electricity grid and rapidly expand the capacity for energy storage. 2. Nature, Biodiversity, and Water The UK is described as one of the most nature-depleted countries in the world, with about half of its nature lost. The manifesto prioritizes restoring the natural world. • Rights of Nature Act: Introduce a new Rights of Nature Act to grant legal personhood to nature, ensuring it cannot be exploited for financial gain. • Protected Land and Sea: Plan to give 30% of UK land and sea back to nature by 2030, ensuring permanent protection. This includes re-wetting all peatland and increasing unharvested forest and woodland by over 50%. They would also make at least 30% of UK domestic waters into fully protected marine areas by 2030. • Water Companies: The privatization of water is called an "unmitigated disaster". The Green Party would take water companies back into public ownership to end pollution, fix leaks, and invest shareholder profits into rebuilding infrastructure. • Water Protection: They would push to restore rivers and take a nature-based solutions approach to prevent flooding and storm overflows. They would increase DEFRA’s budget by £1.5 billion to support environmental protection agencies and develop a soil health monitoring programme. • Pesticides and Farming: The Rights of Nature Act would phase out the most harmful pesticides immediately (including glyphosate) and introduce rigorous tests for all pesticides that demonstrate no harm to pollinators. They plan to nearly triple support for farmers over the next five years to facilitate the transition to nature-friendly farming. • Clean Air: They would push for a Clean Air Act to set new air quality standards and enshrine the right to breathe clean air in the law. 3. Sustainable Transport The party aims to shift the transport system away from reliance on cars and roads, noting that transport accounts for about a quarter of UK carbon emissions. • Public Transport Funding: They would increase annual public subsidies for rail and bus travel to £10 billion by the end of the next parliament. • Infrastructure Investment: Invest an additional £19 billion over five years to improve public transport, electrification, and invest in new cycleways and footpaths, partially by reallocating funding earmarked for road building. They would oppose all new road building plans. • Rail: They would bring the railways back into public ownership and increase investment in modernization and rapid electrification. • Electric Vehicles (EVs): They would push to end sales of new petrol and diesel fueled vehicles by 2027 and end the use of petrol and diesel vehicles on the road by 2035. They favor an extensive vehicle scrappage scheme to support the transition to EVs. • Aviation: They will campaign for a frequent-flyer levy to reduce the impact of the 15% of people who take 70% of flights. They also call for a ban on domestic flights for journeys taking less than three hours by train and a halt to any expansion of airport capacity. 4. Green Homes and Construction The manifesto emphasizes making homes warm, safe, and energy-efficient to tackle fuel poverty and reduce emissions. • Insulation and Retrofit: Implement a £29 billion investment over five years to insulate homes to EPC B standard or above, as part of a ten-year program. • New Building Standards: New homes must meet Passivhaus or equivalent standards and be required to include solar panels and low-carbon heating systems such as heat pumps. • Construction Emissions: They would require full planning applications for demolition, require whole-life carbon and energy calculations for all new applications, and increase disposal rates for builders’ waste to incentivize material reuse. 5. Circular Economy and Resource Use To respect planetary limits, the party advocates for moving away from the exploitation of resources for endless economic growth. • Circular Economy: Advocate for a circular economy that reduces waste. They would require manufacturers to offer ten-year warranties on white goods to encourage repair and reuse, and introduce a comprehensive "right to repair" to eliminate built-in obsolescence. • Single-use Plastics: Increase the scope of bans on the production of single-use plastics for packaging and disposable products. • Business Priorities: Campaign to amend the Companies Act 2006 so that company directors must prioritize the well-being of all living entities (including all species and future generations) and avoid negative environmental and social consequences.
Green Party of England and Wales.brexit: The Green Party’s views on Brexit, as detailed in their 2024 General Election Manifesto, are explicitly pro-European and focused on working toward rejoining the European Union (EU). The party unequivocally states that it opposed UK withdrawal from the EU and believes that the UK would be better off politically, socially, environmentally, and economically had it maintained its EU membership. They stress that a united international response to global issues is needed now more than ever, and that full membership of the EU remains the best option for the UK. Elected Green MPs commit to working toward specific steps related to Britain’s future in Europe: • Rejoining the EU: The long-term goal is to re-join the EU as soon as the domestic political situation is favourable and EU member states are willing. • Joining the Customs Union: As a first step toward full EU membership, the party proposes joining the Customs Union. They view this action as a way of resolving many of the worst problems resulting from Brexit. • Free Movement: They will work for a speedy return to the free movement of people between the UK and the EU, including reciprocal rights to work for both UK and European citizens. • Erasmus Programme: They commit to rejoining the Erasmus Programme, which enables students to study for a year in another European country. The party also seeks to ensure that musicians have access to visa-free travel to the EU through negotiating a reciprocal arrangement at the earliest possible opportunity. Furthermore, the manifesto notes that leaving the EU was one of the shocks that impacted food supply chains, leading to empty shelves and food price rises.
Green Party of England and Wales.entire manifesto: The Green Party’s 2024 General Election Manifesto, titled "Real Hope. Real Change. Manifesto for a Fairer, Greener Country," asserts that the solutions to the climate crisis are the same as those needed to resolve the cost of living and inequality crises. The manifesto aims to transition the UK into a greener, fairer country where citizens are safer, happier, and more fulfilled. The party believes successive governments have failed to prepare for the climate emergency with necessary urgency and ambition, stating that the current commitment to net zero by 2050 is inadequate. The manifesto proposes making political choices that facilitate a rapid shift to a decarbonized economy fueled by clean, green, and cheap renewables, leading to cheaper heating, travel, and business operation. Fairness is intended to permeate all proposed changes, from training a new workforce and investing in public services to establishing a compassionate welfare system. A summary of the manifesto’s key policy areas is provided below: Green Economic Transformation and Public Finances The Green Party commits to a significant investment program, averaging £40 billion per year over the course of the next parliament, to fund a green economic transformation. • Public Ownership: Commit to immediately bringing the railways, water companies, and the Big 5 retail energy companies back into public ownership. • Taxation of Wealth and Pollution: Implement tax reforms designed to raise between £50 billion and £70 billion per year by the end of the next parliament. ◦ Introduce a wealth tax that levies 1% annually on assets above £10 million and 2% on assets above £1 billion. ◦ Align the rates of Capital Gains Tax (CGT) and tax on investment income with the rates for employment income. ◦ Introduce a carbon tax on all fossil fuels (domestic or imported), starting at £120 per tonne and progressively rising to a maximum of £500 per tonne of carbon emitted within ten years. • Climate Investment: Allocate £7 billion annually on climate adaptation. Total investment includes £50 billion for electricity generation, transmission, and storage, and £50 billion for retrofitting buildings. Energy and Climate Action The manifesto prioritizes accelerating the transition to a zero-carbon society more than a decade ahead of 2050. • Fossil Fuels: Push for stopping all new fossil fuel extraction projects in the UK, cancelling recently issued licenses (such as for Rosebank), and ending all subsidies to the oil and gas industries. • Renewable Targets: Aim for wind power to provide around 70% of the UK’s electricity by 2030. Specific targets by 2035 include 80GW of offshore wind, 53 GW of onshore wind, and 100 GW of solar. • Nuclear Power: Cease development of new nuclear power stations and campaign to phase out existing ones, arguing they are too expensive and slow compared to renewables. • Community Energy: Push for a minimum threshold of community ownership in all sustainable energy infrastructure, allowing communities to benefit from profits by reducing their bills. Health, Social Care, and Welfare The party is committed to defending the NHS against privatization and fixing the social care crisis. • NHS Funding and Access: Increase annual NHS expenditure in England by £8 billion in the first full year, rising to £28 billion by 2030, plus at least £20 billion in capital spending over five years. Policies include guaranteeing rapid access to a GP and guaranteed access to an NHS dentist for everybody. • Social Care: Introduce Free Personal Care for dignity in old age and for disabled people, modeled on the Scottish Government’s approach. Commit to investing £20 billion per year into the social care system. • Mental Health: Ensure everyone who needs evidence-based mental health therapies can access them within 28 days. • Welfare: Increase Universal Credit and legacy benefits by £40 a week. Abolish the two-child benefit cap. End benefit sanctions and scrap the bedroom tax. In the long term, push for the introduction of a Universal Basic Income. Housing and Green Homes The goal is to move away from treating houses as assets towards providing safe, warm, and affordable homes. • Social Housing: Provide 150,000 new social homes a year and end the "right to buy" to ensure these homes remain communal assets. • Insulation and Retrofit: Implement a £29 billion investment over five years to insulate homes to EPC B standard or above. New homes must meet Passivhaus or equivalent standards and include solar panels and low-carbon heating systems like heat pumps. • Renters’ Rights: End no-fault evictions (Section 21). Empower local authorities to introduce rent controls in overheated local rental markets. Fairer Work and Rights The manifesto seeks to restore workers’ and trade union rights. • Wages and Conditions: Introduce a minimum wage of £15 an hour for all, regardless of age. Advocate for a maximum 10:1 pay ratio for all private and public-sector organizations. Support reduced working hours and moving towards a four-day working week. • Gig Economy: Legislate for workers to have full employment rights from day one, including gig economy workers. • Trade Unions: Repeal current anti-union legislation and replace it with a positive Charter of Workers’ Rights. Nature, Farming, and Animals The goal is to restore the natural world, recognizing the UK is one of the most nature-depleted countries. • Nature Protection: Introduce a new Rights of Nature Act to grant legal personhood to nature. Plan to give 30% of UK land and sea back to nature by 2030, ensuring permanent protection. • Water: Take water companies back into public ownership to end pollution and invest shareholder profits in infrastructure fixes. • Farming: Almost triple support for farmers over the next five years to facilitate the transition to nature-friendly farming. Encourage a reduction in meat and dairy production and implement new horticulture support. • Animals: Introduce a ban on all blood sports, including trail hunting and commercial shooting of game birds. Work towards an outright ban on all animal testing. Transport The party aims to shift the transport system away from reliance on cars and roads. • Public Transport Funding: Increase annual public subsidies for rail and bus travel to £10 billion by the end of the next parliament. Introduce free bus travel for under-18s. • Infrastructure: Invest an additional £19 billion over five years to improve public transport and invest in new cycleways and footpaths, partially through reallocating road building funds. Oppose all new road building plans. • Vehicles: End sales of new petrol and diesel fueled vehicles by 2027, with the goal of ending their use on the road by 2035. • Aviation: Campaign for a frequent-flyer levy and ban domestic flights for journeys that take less than three hours by train. Democracy and International Relations The Green Party supports transforming the political system to be more representative and inclusive. • Electoral Reform: Replace the first-past-the-post system with a fair and proportional voting system. Replace the House of Lords with an elected second chamber. Give 16 and 17-year-olds the right to vote. • International Stance: Work towards re-joining the European Union as soon as politically feasible, starting with joining the Customs Union. • Security and Disarmament: Push for the UK to sign the UN Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (TPNW) and dismantle nuclear weapons, cancelling the Trident programme. • Israel and Palestine: Call for an immediate and permanent bilateral ceasefire and the end of all UK arms exports and military cooperation with Israel. • Migration: End the "hostile environment" approach and abolish the No Recourse to Public Funds condition. Establish safe routes to sanctuary for those fleeing danger, persecution, war, or climate disaster. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The ambitious plans outlined in the manifesto are presented as not only possible but essential for a secure and happy future on a safe planet. The party sees these policies as necessary steps, given that the climate crisis is escalating faster than successive governments have addressed it.

Reform UK.crime: The Reform UK manifesto outlines a comprehensive plan to restore law and order, emphasizing zero tolerance policing, increased police presence, and harsher sentencing for criminals. The manifesto addresses policies concerning Policing, Justice, and immediate actions to be taken in the first 100 days. Here is a summary of the key policies on crime and justice: Policing and Law Enforcement Reforms Reform UK intends to focus on increasing police presence, enforcing stricter standards, and adopting a "common sense" approach to law enforcement. • Increase Police Numbers: The plan commits to increasing the UK’s per capita police numbers to 300 per 100,000 population. This equates to 40,000 new front-line officers to be recruited over a 5-year parliamentary term. • Zero Tolerance Policing: The party plans to commence zero tolerance policing, clamping down on all crime and antisocial behavior. This includes substantially increasing the use of Stop and Search. • Mandatory Life Sentences for Drug Crimes: Drug dealing and trafficking will receive mandatory life imprisonment. A new offense of Substantial Possession of Drugs will also meet heavy fines. • Focus on Frontline Policing: Policies aim for More Bobbies on the Beat, ensuring police return to the street, utilizing better technology, and reducing time wasted on paperwork. • New Police Leadership and Recruitment: There will be a strong preference for ex-military officers and personnel in recruitment. High standards of fitness and presentation will be required for front-line officers. • End "Woke" Policing: The plan includes scrapping all Diversity, Equality and Inclusion (DE&I) roles and regulations to prevent two-tier policing. Chief Constables who permit two-tier policing will be sacked. • Reform the Police Oversight Body: The Independent Office of Police Conduct (IOPC) will be overhauled to make the police complaints system more accountable and functional for the law-abiding public. • De-Politicise the College of Policing: This includes prioritizing crime prevention, discipline, public service, and high standards of strength and fitness among trainees. The plan also involves replacing degree-standard entry with an entrance exam and requiring officers to complete a 2-year probationary period. Judicial and Sentencing Reforms The manifesto targets judicial reform to ensure criminals face justice and the public is kept safe. • Mandatory Life Sentences for Repeat Offenders: An Urgent Sentencing Review will be launched, implementing automatic life imprisonment for violent repeat offenders. Those committing a second violent or serious offense will receive mandatory life sentences. • Increase Criminal Justice Budget: The budget will be increased from £10 billion to £12 billion to ensure more high-caliber staff are available to cut court delays. • Expand Prison Capacity: The plan involves the immediate start of building 10,000 new detention places to expand the capacity of state-built and managed prisons. Disused military bases may also be commissioned if needed. The goal is to ensure that "life means life" for those who endanger the public. • Reopen Local Courts: Local magistrates’ courts will be reopened to clear the case backlog. • Reform Hate Crime Definition: The definition of hate crime used by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) and police will be changed, asserting that members of the public should not be investigated because "any" person "perceives" that a hate crime has been committed, due to the existing definition leading to systemic bias. • Tackle Child Grooming Gangs: This policy includes deporting offenders holding dual citizenship, making child grooming an aggravating offense, improving safeguarding for victims, and implementing no bail for grooming gang offenders. • Youth Crime: High Intensity Training Camps will be reopened for young offenders to teach basic education, teamwork, and values. Critical Reforms from Other Policy Areas Impacting Crime Immigration and constitutional changes also contain provisions directly related to crime and security: • Immediate Deportation of Foreign Criminals: Foreign nationals are to be deported immediately after their prison sentence ends. Citizenship will be withdrawn from immigrants who commit crimes, excluding some misdemeanor offenses. • Leaving the ECHR: The plan includes leaving the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and commencing reform of the Human Rights Act to prioritize the rights of law-abiding people. • Anti-Corruption Unit: An Anti-Corruption Unit for Westminster will be launched with legal powers to investigate past and future scandals, ensuring public officials face sanctions, including prison, if they break the rules. The total cost estimated for the Policing pledges is £3 billion per year, and for Justice pledges, the cost is £2 billion per year. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The overall approach to crime and justice in the manifesto is akin to a reset button on law enforcement. It aims to shift resources from administrative and diversity roles to the frontline, combine severe punitive measures (like mandatory life sentences and increased deportations) with expanded physical infrastructure (prisons and training camps), and ensure the police force and justice system operate under a mandate of "zero tolerance" and high discipline.
Reform UK.healthcare: The Reform UK manifesto outlines significant reforms for the National Health Service (NHS), aiming to achieve zero waiting lists while maintaining healthcare free at the point of delivery. The key policies focus on staff retention, improving efficiency, utilizing independent healthcare capacity, and cutting administrative waste. Here is a summary of the key policies regarding the NHS and healthcare: Core Pledge and Objective The central commitment related to healthcare is: • Imagine No NHS Waiting Lists: Healthcare will remain free at the point of delivery. Reforms will be implemented to improve outcomes and achieve zero NHS waiting lists. • The strategy involves cutting back office waste to dedicate more money to the frontline, and offering tax breaks for doctors and nurses to address the staffing crisis. Staffing and Recruitment Reforms To address chronic staff shortages, Reform UK proposes immediate financial incentives and changes to training: • Zero Basic Rate Tax for Frontline Staff: All frontline NHS and social care staff will pay zero basic rate tax for 3 years. This measure aims to retain existing staff and attract those who have left to return to service. • Student Fee Write-Offs: Student fees will be written off pro rata over 10 years of NHS service for all doctors, nurses, and medical staff who commit to the service. • End Training Caps: Training caps for all UK medical students will be ended. Utilizing Independent and Private Healthcare The manifesto proposes integrating independent services to relieve pressure on the NHS: • Tax Relief on Private Healthcare: Implement Tax Relief of 20% on all private healthcare and insurance. This is intended to grow independent healthcare capacity rapidly, provide competition, reduce costs, and, crucially, relieve pressure on the NHS to improve care for all who rely on it. • Harness Independent Capacity: The plan includes harnessing independent and not-for-profit health provision in the UK and overseas. • NHS Voucher Scheme: Later reforms will include putting patients in charge with a New NHS Voucher Scheme. NHS patients will receive a voucher for private treatment if they cannot see a GP within 3 days, a consultant within 3 weeks, or receive an operation within 9 weeks. Efficiency, Waste Reduction, and Management Policies are aimed at increasing productivity and cutting bureaucracy: • Cut Waste and Unnecessary Managers: Operating theatres must be open on weekends, and rotas must be planned further in advance. • Financial Scrutiny: Review all NHS Private Finance Contracts for significant savings potential. • Charge for Missed Appointments: Charge those who fail to attend medical appointments without notice. • Abolish NHS Race and Health Observatory: This specific body will be abolished. Primary and Emergency Care Steps to manage pressure on emergency services include: • Save A&E: Launch a campaign of "Pharmacy First, GP Second, A&E Last" to cut waiting times. • Tax Incentives for Pharmacies: Offer tax incentives for new pharmacies and those who employ more staff to assist in relieving pressure on A&E. Public Inquiry into Excess Deaths The plan also includes a specific investigation: • Excess Deaths and Vaccine Harms Public Inquiry: A public inquiry will be launched because excess deaths are currently nearly as high as they were during the Covid pandemic, with young people being over-represented. Financial Commitment The total annualized cost of the NHS pledges is estimated to be £17 billion. The overarching goal is a reformed NHS focused on "Patients first. Rapid care. Cutting waste".
Reform UK.housing: The Reform UK manifesto addresses the housing crisis with policies focused on boosting housebuilding, particularly on brownfield sites, reforming the planning system, and adjusting tax and tenancy laws for the rental market. The housing pledges are estimated to be cost neutral. Here is a summary of the key policies on housing: Planning and Construction The core of the housebuilding strategy revolves around reforming planning to accelerate development and incentivizing new technology. • Review the Planning System: The manifesto calls for a review of the planning system. • Fast-track Brownfield Development: Reform UK plans to fast-track planning and provide tax incentives specifically for the development of brownfield sites. • "Loose Fit Planning": They propose a "loose fit planning" policy for large residential developments, which would involve pre-approved guidelines and established developer requirements. • Incentivize New Construction Technology: The party will incentivize innovation to speed up building, specifically mentioning modular construction, digital technology, and building sites that improve efficiency and cut waste. Rental Market and Landlord Reforms The policies aim to encourage smaller landlords into the market by adjusting the tax system and overturning existing legislation. • Scrap Section 24 for Landlords: Reform UK intends to scrap Section 24, which refers to tax rules that currently penalize smaller landlords. They plan to restore landlords’ rights to deduct finance costs and mortgage interest from tax on rental income to encourage participation in the rental markets. • Abolish the Renters’ (Reform) Bill: The manifesto states that the existing Renters’ (Reform) Bill was inadequate. Instead of this bill, they plan to boost the monitoring, appeals, and enforcement processes available for renters who have grievances. Social Housing and Residency Priority Reform UK plans to prioritize local citizens in the social housing allocation system: • Reform Social Housing Law: The policy is to prioritize local people and those who have paid into the system for social housing. • Foreign Nationals in Queue: Foreign nationals must go to the back of the queue for social housing, "Not the front". Property Taxation and Leasehold Reform Policies also include changes to taxes on property transactions and protections for leaseholders. • Cut Residential Stamp Duty: Although this policy is listed under "Economy - Personal," it directly impacts housing affordability. Reform UK intends to cut Residential Stamp Duty to 0% below £750k. It would be cut to 2% from £750k - £1.5m and to 4% over £1.5m. This is intended to substantially boost economic activity and housebuilding. • Protection for Leaseholders: The party plans to ensure all potential charges for leasehold or freehold residents are clearly stated and consented to. They will enforce Section 106 agreements and ensure it is cheaper and easier to extend leases to 990 years and buy freeholds. The manifesto notes that the unprecedented population explosion in the UK has contributed to the existing housing crisis. Reform UK’s commitment to freezing non-essential immigration is listed as a core pledge intended to "end the housing crisis".
Reform UK.immigration: The Reform UK manifesto places a strong emphasis on drastically reducing immigration, securing borders, and implementing stricter controls on who can enter and remain in the UK. The document states that record mass immigration has damaged the country, leading to crises in housing, benefits, crime, and NHS waiting lists, while also damaging British culture and identity [2 states that record mass immigration has damaged the country, leading to crises in housing, benefits, crime, and NHS waiting lists, while also damaging British culture and identity. The immigration plan is encapsulated in a Core Pledge and a series of Critical Reforms intended for the first 100 days of a Reform UK government. Core Pledges The manifesto summarizes its position on immigration into two core pledges: 1. Smart Immigration, Not Mass Immigration: This involves freezing all non-essential immigration to boost wages, protect public services, end the housing crisis, and cut crime. 2. No More Small Boats in the Channel: The policy dictates that illegal migrants who come to the UK will be detained and deported. If necessary, migrants in small boats will be picked up and taken back to France. Critical Reforms (First 100 Days) The following specific policies are detailed to be implemented rapidly: Immigration Freeze and Exceptions • Freeze Non-Essential Immigration: Strict limits on immigration will be imposed, with essential skills, mainly those concerning healthcare, being the only exception. This is intended to relieve pressure on housing and public services, increase wages, and protect culture, identity, and values. Stopping Illegal Migration ("Stop the Boats") • 4 Point Plan: This plan is designed to stop the small boats crisis : 1. Leave the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR). 2. Ensure zero illegal immigrants are resettled in the UK. 3. Create a New Department of Immigration. 4. Pick up illegal migrants out of boats and take them back to France. • Secure Detention and Asylum: All asylum seekers arriving illegally from safe countries will be processed rapidly, potentially offshore. Those entering from a safe country will be barred from claiming asylum or citizenship. • No Legal Aid: Non-citizens will be provided with no legal aid. Rejected asylum seekers will be returned. Financial and Benefits Controls • Employer Immigration Tax (EIT): The National Insurance rate will be raised to 20% for foreign workers. This is meant to incentivize businesses to employ British citizens (whose National Insurance rate would remain at 13.8%). Essential foreign health and care workers, and businesses employing five staff members or fewer, would be exempt. This tax is projected to raise over £20 billion over five years to fund apprenticeships and training for young Britons. • Stop Health Tourism and Immediate Access to Benefits: A requirement of 5 years residency and employment will be imposed to claim any benefits in the UK. Student and Criminal Immigration • Bar Student Dependents: New visa rules for international students will be introduced to bar dependents. • Skills Retention: Only international students with essential skills will be allowed to remain in the UK. • Close Abusive Schemes: Fake courses and immigration schemes that abuse the rules will be closed down. • Immediate Deportation for Foreign Criminals: Foreign nationals are to be deported immediately after their prison sentence ends. The party plans to withdraw citizenship from immigrants who commit crime, excluding some misdemeanor offenses. Financial Implications The Immigration pledges are projected to result in annual savings ranging from £5 to £10 billion. The Employer Immigration Tax is projected to raise an additional £4 billion per annum. The total projected annual savings from Immigration is £9 billion to £14 billion.
Reform UK.defence: The Reform UK manifesto outlines policies aimed at strengthening the armed forces, improving support for servicemen and women, and increasing defense spending to ensure Britain’s security and global standing. Here is a summary of the key defense policies: Investment and Spending Reform UK plans a significant increase in defense spending over the coming years : • Increase Defence Spending: Defense spending will be increased to 2.5% of National GDP by year 3, and then further increased to 3% within 6 years. • Purpose of Increased Funding: This increase is intended to boost the size and capacity of the armed forces, ensure the UK’s leading role in NATO, improve equipment, enhance the quality of life for service personnel, and boost morale in military communities. • Cost: The total annualized cost of the Defense Pledges is estimated at £14 billion. Personnel, Recruitment, and Support Policies are focused on better compensating, protecting, and supporting service members, both during and after their service. • Urgent Pay Review: An urgent pay review will be introduced to increase basic pay across the armed forces to boost both recruitment and retention. The manifesto notes that it is "unacceptable that a private soldier is paid less than an Amazon worker". • Recruitment: The party plans to recruit 30,000 for the army. Military national service for young people is explicitly stated as "not the answer". • New Armed Forces Justice Bill: This bill will be introduced to protect servicemen and women on active duty both inside and outside the UK from civil law and human rights lawyers. • Armed Forces Watchdog: The bill will also create an armed forces watchdog to fast-track complaints and appeals related to housing and welfare. • Dedicated Veterans Department: A new, dedicated Ministerial Department for Veterans will be established. This department must be "properly funded and resourced" to guarantee that "no veteran goes without" and that former service members play a leading role in society and the economy. • Education: Free education both during and after service is considered vital to ensure a successful return to civilian life. Equipment and Procurement Reforms are planned to improve the procurement process and regenerate the UK’s defense industry. • Reform Defence Procurement: A Joint Acquisition Corp will be launched to ensure world-class procurement. The Ministry of Defence must prioritize listening to soldiers on the front line to ensure they receive the equipment they need. • Regenerate UK Defence Industry: Incentives and tax breaks will be introduced to boost the UK defense manufacturing and technology sector. • Improve Self-Sufficiency: The goal is to improve equipment self-sufficiency and manufacture world-class products for export. Constitutional and External Military Independence The manifesto also addresses independence from external military forces, specifically concerning the EU : • Independence for Britain’s Armed Forces: Reform UK plans to ensure independence for Britain’s Armed Forces. The government has signed up to the EU Horizon programme, meaning the UK sends money to the European Defence Fund and is part of the EU’s military mobility project, which the manifesto views as risking the UK Armed Forces being "sucked into an EU Command and Control Force".
Reform UK.economy: The Reform UK manifesto presents a wide-ranging plan for economic reform, centered on reducing taxation, slashing government waste, eliminating regulations perceived as detrimental to growth, and ending Net Zero policies to secure cheap energy. The overall objective is to "make work pay" and restore "real economic growth". The economic policies are structured across measures relating to personal finances, businesses, and government spending. 1. Taxation and Personal Finance (Economy – Personal) The core pledge here is to lift the Income Tax starting threshold to £20,000 per year. • Income Tax: Lifting the starting point to £20,000 frees up to 7 million people from paying Income Tax and saves every worker almost £1,500 per year. The basic tax rate remains at 20%, and the higher rate should begin at £70,000. • Energy Taxes: Policies aimed at beating the cost-of-living crisis include saving households over £500 per year by scrapping VAT on energy bills and abolishing environmental levies. • Fuel Duty: Fuel duty will be lowered by 20p per litre for both residential and business users. • Property Tax: Residential Stamp Duty will be cut to 0% below £750k (2% between £750k - £1.5m, and 4% over £1.5m) to substantially boost economic activity and housebuilding. • Inheritance Tax (IHT): IHT will be abolished for all estates under £2m, covering approximately 98% of all estates. The rate above £2m will be 20% tax, with the option to donate to charity instead. • Tourism: The VAT Tourist Tax (the VAT refund scheme for tourist shopping) will be abolished, which the sources claim has cost the economy over £10 billion and deterred up to 2 million tourists. These personal tax pledges are estimated to cost £70 billion per annum. 2. Business and Corporate Reform (Economy – Business) Reform UK intends to back "risk takers and wealth creators" by simplifying the tax system and reducing corporate burdens. • Corporation Tax: Over 1.2 million Small and Medium Sized Businesses (SMEs) will be freed from Corporation Tax by lifting the minimum profit threshold to £100k. The main Corporation Tax Rate will be reduced from 25% down to 20%, and then to 15% from Year 3. • Self-Employment: The party plans to Abolish IR35 Rules to support sole traders. • VAT and Business Rates: The VAT Threshold will be lifted to £150,000 to free small entrepreneurs from red tape. Business Rates will be abolished for high street based SMEs, offset by a new Online Delivery Tax at 4% for large, multinational enterprises. • Entrepreneurs’ Tax: Entrepreneurs’ tax will be cut to 5%. • Regulation and Planning: The party will slash red tape to boost industry and exports, including scrapping thousands of laws that hold back British business, such as employment laws, to make it easier to hire and fire. They also plan to reform the planning system and fast-track new housing on brownfield sites and infrastructure projects. These business pledges are estimated to cost £18 billion per annum. 3. Government Waste and Savings A major component of Reform UK’s economic plan involves significant cuts to government spending to fund the tax reductions. • Quantitative Easing (QE) Reserves: The most substantial saving is projected from requiring the Bank of England to stop paying interest to commercial banks on QE Reserves, which Reform UK estimates would save around £35 billion per year. • Departmental Savings: Every government department must slash wasteful spending, cut bureaucracy, and improve efficiency to Save £5 in every £100, projected to save £50 billion per year without touching frontline services. • Foreign Aid: Foreign Aid will be cut by 50%, saving £6 billion from the £12.8 billion budget. • Regulations and Brexit: The party plans to cut unnecessary regulations, noting that Britain still retains over 6,700 EU laws, and government red tape is estimated to have cost the UK economy £143 billion since 2015. • Tax Collection: Improved competence at HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) is expected to collect "£ Billions" in unpaid tax due to understaffing and bad management. Total potential savings from slashing government waste are projected at £91 billion per annum. 4. Energy Policy and Economic Growth Policies focused on energy and climate are central to the economic strategy, framed as necessary to restore growth and beat the cost-of-living crisis. • Scrap Net Zero: The party will Scrap Net Zero policies and related subsidies, potentially saving the public sector over £30 billion per year. • Renewable Subsidies: Annual £10 billion of Renewable Energy Subsidies will be scrapped. • Energy Production: Cheap, secure energy will be pursued by fast-tracking licences for North Sea gas and oil and granting shale gas licences. • Growth Assumption: Reform UK projects that its economic reforms will create 1% to 1.5% extra growth per annum. This extra growth is assumed to yield £10 billion per annum of extra tax revenues. Financial Summary Reform UK projects that the combined potential savings (including the Employer Immigration Tax and transport savings) and extra growth total £160 billion per annum. This figure exceeds the total estimated cost of all pledges, which is £141 billion. The sources note that the UK economy is currently being wrecked by record high taxes, record high national debt, wasteful government spending, and nanny state regulations.
Reform UK.education: The Reform UK manifesto outlines several key policies for education, focusing on curriculum reform, banning certain ideologies from schools, providing incentives for independent education, and overhauling the university loan system.
