The goal is to ensure young people are taught the skills, character, and values necessary to succeed in life while being proud of Britain. The education pledges are estimated to cost £5 billion per annum. Curriculum and Ideology The party plans to introduce fundamental changes to what is taught and discussed in schools: • Patriotic Curriculum: A Patriotic Curriculum will be introduced in primary and secondary schools. ◦ Any teaching about British or European imperialism or slavery must be paired with the teaching of a non-European occurrence of the same to ensure balance. ◦ The History and social science curriculum will be reviewed and audited regularly to ensure balance. ◦ Children must be taught about their heritage. • Ban Transgender Ideology: Reform UK plans to ban Transgender Ideology in primary and secondary schools. ◦ This means no gender questioning, social transitioning, or pronoun swapping will be allowed. ◦ Schools must have single-sex facilities. ◦ Parents of under 16s must be informed about their children’s life decisions. • Permanent Exclusions: The number of Pupil Referral Units (PRUs) will be doubled to ensure schools can function safely by enabling permanent exclusions for violent and disruptive students. Best practices will also be spread across PRUs. Independent Education and Universities The manifesto includes policies designed to support parents who choose private schooling and reform higher education financing: • Support for Independent Education: Tax relief of 20% on all Independent Education will be implemented, and there will be No VAT on Fees. This is intended to incentivize parents who can afford to pay more to choose independent schools, thereby significantly easing pressure on state schools and improving education for all. • Student Loans: The policy proposes to Scrap Interest on Student Loans. ◦ Loan capital repayment periods will be extended to 45 years. ◦ Undergraduate numbers will be restricted well below current levels, as the sources note that "too many courses are not good enough and students are being ripped off". ◦ Minimum entry standards will be enforced. • Free Speech at Universities: Funding will be Cut to Universities that Undermine Free Speech. The manifesto criticizes the government’s Free Speech Act as "toothless" and states that allowing political bias or cancel culture must face heavy financial penalties. • Two-Year Undergraduate Courses: Universities must provide the option of 2-year undergraduate courses to reduce student debt and allow earlier entry into employment. Overall, the policy direction seeks to inject common sense and patriotic values into the school system while simultaneously utilizing private capacity and fiscal reforms to tackle systemic debt and lack of standards in higher education.
Reform UK.environment: The Reform UK manifesto’s core environmental policies are defined by its commitment to scrapping Net Zero targets and focusing instead on energy security, affordability, and traditional conservation methods. These policies are centralized under the heading "Net Zero". Here is a summary of the key policies on the environment and energy: Core Policy: Scrap Net Zero The party asserts that Net Zero is crippling the economy and is responsible for pushing up bills, damaging British industries like steel, and decreasing national security. • Scrap Net Zero and Subsidies: The manifesto mandates scrapping Net Zero policies and all related subsidies. Ditching Net Zero is projected to save the public sector over £30 billion per year for the next 25 years. • Scrap Renewable Energy Subsidies: The party plans to scrap the annual £10 billion of Renewable Energy Subsidies by achieving equivalent taxes on them. The sources note that current high bills have increased dramatically in line with the huge rise in renewables capacity over the last 15 years. Energy Production and Affordability The primary goal of energy policy is to secure cheap, stable energy for Britain and beat the cost-of-living crisis. • Unlock Oil and Gas Reserves: Reform UK will unlock Britain’s vast oil and gas reserves to unleash real economic growth. • Fast-track Licences: They plan to start fast-track licenses for North Sea gas and oil. • Shale Gas: The party will grant shale gas licences on test sites for two years, enabling major production when safety is proven, alongside local compensation schemes. • Cleaner Energy from New Technology: The manifesto supports fast-tracking clean nuclear energy with new Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) built in Britain. They also advocate for increasing and incentivizing ethical UK lithium mining, combined cycle gas turbines, clean synthetic fuel, tidal power, and exploring clean coal mining. Environmental Protection (Non-Climate Related) While rejecting the Net Zero agenda, the manifesto proposes alternative ways to protect the environment: • Conservation Focus: The party states that the environment can be protected through measures like more tree planting, more recycling, and less single-use plastics. • Country Sports: They support protecting country sports, arguing that they increase investment and help with conservation of the environment. Impact on Farming and Infrastructure These policies also directly impact land use and transport: • Scrap Climate-Related Farming Subsidies: Productive land must be farmed, not be used for solar farms or rewilding. Current subsidies will be replaced with direct payments. • Stop the War on Drivers: Scrapping Net Zero means there will be no more bans on petrol and diesel cars and no legal requirements for manufacturers to sell electric cars. • Infrastructure: The party plans to simplify infrastructure funding streams by overhauling the National Infrastructure Commission and the Infrastructure Bank and scrapping Net Zero objectives. The overall financial commitment indicates that the "Net Zero Pledges" are projected to generate £30 billion per annum in savings. The party views existing Net Zero targets as pushing the UK to "impoverish ourselves in pursuit of unaffordable, unachievable global CO2 targets".
Reform UK.brexit: The Reform UK manifesto emphasizes the necessity of doing what the Conservative government has failed to do: "grasp the huge opportunities of Brexit". The core objective is to fully realize the promise of taking back control of Britain’s borders, money, and laws. Here is a summary of the key policies related to Brexit: Legislative and Regulatory Independence The primary policy focus is the rapid removal of retained European Union (EU) law: • Scrap EU Regulations: Reform UK pledges to Legislate to Scrap EU Regulations with Immediate Effect. The manifesto notes that Britain still retains over 6,700 retained EU laws, which the party intends to rescind. • Key Law Areas Affected: British laws on State Aid, Competition, Employment, Net Zero, and the Environment are still based on EU regulations, and these areas will be targeted for legislative independence. Northern Ireland and the Windsor Framework A critical policy is the abandonment of the current agreement governing Northern Ireland’s relationship with the EU: • Abandon the Windsor Framework: Reform UK plans to Abandon the Windsor Framework, arguing that it is "worse than the original Northern Ireland Protocol". • Partition and EU Law: The party states that the UK has been partitioned down the Irish Sea, and that Northern Ireland remains in the EU’s single market for goods. This situation is deemed "unacceptable" because British citizens in Northern Ireland are being ruled by EU laws. Future Trade and Military Independence The manifesto also addresses future relationships with the EU regarding trade and defense: • Renegotiate the Trade and Cooperation Agreement: Reform UK intends to Prepare for Renegotiations on the EU Trade and Cooperation Agreement. The manifesto states that the so-called EU "level playing field" requirements are currently holding the UK back. • Independence for the Armed Forces: The party will ensure the independence of Britain’s Armed Forces. The manifesto criticizes the government for signing up to the EU Horizon programme, which results in the UK sending money to the European Defence Fund and being part of the EU’s military mobility project. This involvement is seen as risking the UK Armed Forces being "sucked into an EU Command and Control Force". Fisheries A separate section is dedicated to seizing the opportunity to renew the fishing industry, which was a core issue during the Brexit referendum: • Stop EU Fishers Taking UK Quotas: The party will End automatic access to UK waters for EU fishers. • Licensing and Policing: Every foreign fishing vessel must pay for a licence to gain access to the UK’s 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). The Royal Navy Overseas Patrol Squadron will be expanded to properly police this EEZ. • Ban Supertrawlers: Foreign supertrawlers will be banned from UK waters. • Rebuild UK Processing: Tax and other incentives will be introduced to ensure that all fish caught in British waters are landed and processed in the UK. The sources confirm that Brexit provides an "opportunity of a lifetime" , and the aim of Reform UK’s policies is to fully unlock these "major opportunities". The overall economic reforms outlined in the manifesto, including those specifically linked to Brexit, are projected to contribute to an extra £10 billion per annum in tax revenues from increased economic growth.
Reform UK.entire manifesto: The Reform UK manifesto, "Our Contract with You," outlines a comprehensive plan focusing on significant reforms across various sectors, often prioritizing measures to cut taxes, curb immigration, overhaul public services, and reduce government waste. The document begins by summarizing its plan into Five Core Pledges : 1. Smart Immigration, Not Mass Immigration: This involves freezing all non-essential immigration to boost wages, protect public services, end the housing crisis, and cut crime. 2. No More Small Boats in the Channel: The policy states that illegal migrants arriving in the UK will be detained and deported, and migrants in small boats will be picked up and taken back to France. 3. No NHS Waiting Lists: While remaining free at the point of delivery, healthcare will undergo reform to achieve zero waiting lists, cut back office waste, and offer tax breaks for doctors and nurses to address the staffing crisis. 4. Good Wages for a Hard Day’s Work: This aims to lift the income tax starting threshold to £20,000 per year, saving the lowest paid £1,500 annually and taking 7 million people out of Income Tax to incentivize work. 5. Affordable, Stable Energy Bills: This pledge involves scrapping energy levies and Net Zero policies to slash energy bills (saving each household £500 per year) and unlocking Britain’s vast oil and gas reserves to promote economic growth. Key Policies and Critical Reforms (First 100 Days) The manifesto details critical reforms across many policy areas, many intended for the first 100 days of a Reform UK government. Immigration and Borders • Freeze Non-Essential Immigration, with essential healthcare skills as the only exception. • Implement a 4 Point Plan to Stop the Boats, which includes leaving the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), ensuring zero illegal immigrants are resettled in the UK, creating a new Department of Immigration, and taking migrants back to France. • Require 5 years residency and employment to claim any benefits in the UK, aiming to stop health tourism and immediate access to benefits. • Introduce an Employer Immigration Tax, raising the National Insurance rate to 20% for foreign workers (excluding essential health/care workers and small businesses), intended to boost wages for British citizens and fund apprenticeships. Economy and Taxes • Personal Taxation: Lift the Income Tax start point to £20,000 per year, while starting the higher tax rate at £70,000. • Energy Costs: Scrap VAT on energy bills and abolish environmental levies. Lower fuel duty by 20p per litre. • Property: Cut Residential Stamp Duty to 0% below £750k. Abolish Inheritance Tax for all estates under £2m (covering 98% of estates). • Business Taxation: Reduce the main Corporation Tax Rate from 25% down to 20%, and then to 15% from Year 3. • Free over 1.2 million Small and Medium Sized Businesses (SMEs) from Corporation Tax by lifting the minimum profit threshold to £100k. • Abolish IR35 Rules for sole traders and lift the VAT Threshold to £150,000. Government Spending and Waste • A major policy is requiring the Bank of England to stop paying interest to commercial banks on Quantitative Easing (QE) Reserves, which Reform UK estimates would save around £35 billion per year. • Save £5 in every £100 across government departments by slashing wasteful spending and cutting bureaucracy, projected to save £50 billion per year. • Cut Foreign Aid by 50%, saving £6 billion. Health Service (NHS) • Offer all frontline NHS and social care staff zero basic rate tax for 3 years to improve retention and recruitment. • Introduce tax relief of 20% on all private healthcare and insurance to relieve pressure on the NHS. • Write off student fees pro rata for doctors, nurses, and medical staff who commit to 10 years of NHS service. • Review all NHS Private Finance Contracts for savings and charge those who fail to attend medical appointments without notice. • Launch a Public Inquiry into Excess Deaths and Vaccine Harms. Energy and Climate • Scrap Net Zero and all related subsidies, potentially saving the public sector over £30 billion per year. • Scrap £10 billion of renewable energy subsidies. • Start fast-track licenses for North Sea gas and oil, and grant shale gas licences. Law, Order, and Justice • Increase police numbers to 300 per 100k population, amounting to 40,000 new front-line officers over 5 years. • Commence Zero Tolerance Policing, substantially increasing Stop and Search. Drug dealing and trafficking will receive mandatory life imprisonment. • Scrap all Diversity, Equality and Inclusion (DE&I) roles in policing. • Introduce mandatory life sentences for those committing second violent or serious offences. • Start building 10,000 new detention places. Education and Culture • Implement a Patriotic Curriculum in schools, ensuring balanced teaching of history, including pairing examples of British or European imperialism/slavery with non-European occurrences. • Ban Transgender Ideology in primary and secondary schools (no gender questioning, social transitioning, or pronoun swapping). • Provide tax relief of 20% and no VAT on fees for independent education. • Scrap interest on student loans. • Reform the BBC by scrapping the TV licence. Infrastructure and Transport • Scrap HS2, saving £25 billion. • Stop the War on Drivers by legislating to ban ULEZ Clean Air Zones and Low Traffic Neighbourhoods. Financial Summary Reform UK claims its plans are fully funded, projecting significant savings and costs over a 5-year electoral term. • Total Potential Savings (including extra growth assumptions of £10 billion pa from economic reforms) are estimated at £160 billion per year. • Total Annualized Cost of the pledges is estimated at £141 billion. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The policies laid out in "Our Contract with You" can be seen as an effort to dismantle existing environmental regulations, significantly cut personal and business taxation, halt mass immigration, and overhaul public institutions like the NHS and the Civil Service.

Labour Party.crime: The Labour manifesto outlines a comprehensive plan under the mission "Take back our streets" to halve serious violent crime and raise confidence in the police and criminal justice system to its highest levels. The party aims to stop the "Conservative chaos" and return law and order to the streets. Key policies and measures focused on crime, policing, and justice include: 1. Policing and Neighbourhood Safety • Neighbourhood Policing Guarantee: Labour will introduce a new Neighbourhood Policing Guarantee to restore patrols to town centres by recruiting thousands of new police officers, Police and Community Support Officers (PCSOs), and special constables. • Named Officers: Communities and residents will have a named officer to contact when issues arise. • Funding for New Recruits: These new recruits will be funded by tackling waste through a new Police Efficiency and Collaboration programme for England and Wales, which will establish nation-wide standards for procurement and shared services to drive down costs. The plan allocates £400 million (annualized) from this efficiency program to fund 13,000 additional neighbourhood police and community PCSOs, as well as specialist domestic abuse advisers in 999 control rooms. • Failing Forces: His Majesty’s Inspectorate of Constabulary, Fire & Rescue Services will be given "new powers to intervene with failing forces". • Professional Standards: The manifesto commits to raising standards by introducing mandatory professional standards on vetting, checks, and misconduct for individual officers. • Misconduct: Stronger training on racism and violence against women and girls will be implemented, and anyone with a history of violence against women and girls will be barred from the service. Furthermore, automatic suspensions will be introduced if officers are investigated for domestic abuse and sexual offences. 2. Tackling Antisocial Behaviour and Shoplifting • Respect Orders: New Respect Orders will be introduced to ban persistent adult offenders from town centres, aiming to stamp out issues like public drinking and drug use. • Restorative Justice: Fly-tippers and vandals will be forced to clean up the mess they have created. • Shoplifting: Labour will scrap the effective immunity for some shoplifting introduced by the Conservatives and create a new specific offence for assaults on shopworkers to protect them from threats and violence. 3. Knife Crime and Youth Intervention • Halving Knife Crime: The manifesto sets the goal to halve knife crime in a decade. • Tough Consequences: Labour will end the practice of empty warnings by ensuring that knife carrying triggers rapid intervention and tough consequences. • Mandatory Plans: Every young person caught with a knife will be referred to a Youth Offending Team and receive a mandatory plan to prevent reoffending, potentially including penalties such as curfews, tagging, and custody for the most serious cases. • Bans on Weapons: To get knives off the streets, Labour will ban ninja swords, lethal zombie-style blades, and machetes. Rules will be strengthened to prevent online sales, and executives of online companies flouting these rules will be personally held to account through tough sanctions. • Young Futures Programme: A new Young Futures programme will be created, featuring a network of hubs in every community. These hubs will provide youth workers, mental health support workers, and careers advisers to intervene earlier and stop young people from being drawn into crime. • Funding Youth Support: Youth workers and mentors will be placed in A&E units and Pupil Referral Units, funded by the full recovery of the cost of firearm licensing (reallocating £20 million annually). • Criminal Exploitation: A new offence of criminal exploitation of children will be introduced to target gangs luring young people into violence and crime. 4. Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG) • Specialist Teams: Labour’s landmark mission is to halve violence against women and girls in a decade. To achieve this, there will be specialist rape and sexual offences teams in every police force. • Targeting Perpetrators: The most prolific and harmful perpetrators will be relentlessly targeted, using tactics typically reserved for terrorists and organized crime. • Fast-Tracking Cases: Labour will fast-track rape cases with specialist courts at every Crown Court location in England and Wales to address shamefully low prosecution rates and long delays. • Victim Support: Domestic abuse experts will be introduced in 999 control rooms so victims can speak directly to a specialist, and a legal advocate will be present in every police force area to advise victims from report to trial. Legal advocates will be funded by redirecting PCC grants for victims’ services (reallocating £5 million annually). • Addressing Root Causes: Schools will be required to address misogyny and teach young people about healthy relationships and consent. • Stalking and Spiking: Labour will strengthen the use of Stalking Protection Orders, give women the right to know the identity of online stalkers, and introduce a new criminal offence for spiking. 5. Criminal Justice System and Prisons • Solving Crime: Labour aims to reverse plummeting charge and prosecution rates by reducing barriers to bringing charges, cutting bureaucracy, and improving collaboration between police and prosecutors. • Detectives: A direct entry scheme for detectives will be rolled out to boost investigation skills. • Courts Backlog: Associate Prosecutors will be allowed to work on appropriate cases as an initial step to address the courts backlog. • Sentencing Review: A review of sentencing will be carried out to ensure it is up to date, particularly for offences against women and girls. • Prison Crisis: Labour will use all relevant powers to build the prisons needed to address overcrowding and chaos. They will also act to reduce reoffending by improving offenders’ access to purposeful activity (like learning) and ensuring pre-release plans are created, linking ex-offenders with local employers and the voluntary sector. • Probation: A strategic review of probation governance will be conducted, considering the benefits of devolved models (as pioneered by Labour Mayors, like in Greater Manchester) to ensure better coordination with housing and health services. 6. Serious and Organised Crime • Fraud: Given that fraud accounts for almost two in five crimes, Labour will introduce a new expanded fraud strategy to tackle online, public sector, and serious fraud, and will work with technology companies to prevent their platforms from being exploited. • Cybercrime: The police will be enabled to invest in specialist capabilities, such as digital forensics, and more effectively tackle cross-border issues like serious organised crime. 7. Border Security and Small Boats While categorized under "Secure Borders" (a strong foundation for good government), these policies are crime-related and target criminal gangs : • Border Security Command: Labour will create a new Border Security Command with hundreds of new investigators, intelligence officers, and cross-border police officers. • Funding: This Command will be funded by ending the "wasteful" Migration and Economic Development partnership with Rwanda, and the Command will be supported by new counter-terrorism style powers to pursue and disrupt those responsible for the vile trade of people smuggling. • Asylum Backlog: The party will hire additional caseworkers to clear the backlog of asylum cases and end the use of asylum hotels, saving billions. New measures to clear the backlog are funded by reallocating £155 million (annualized). • Returns and Enforcement: A new returns and enforcement unit will be set up with an additional 1,000 staff to fast-track removals of people who do not have the right to stay here, and Labour will negotiate additional returns arrangements with safe countries. In essence, Labour aims to shift policing back toward visible, preventive community presence while applying tough, specialized enforcement measures against serious crimes like knife crime, sexual violence, and the criminal organizations driving border chaos.
Labour Party.healthcare: The Labour manifesto outlines its healthcare policies under the mission to "Build an NHS fit for the future that is there when people need it". The party emphasizes that the NHS must remain publicly owned and publicly funded, but investment alone is not enough; it must go hand-in-hand with fundamental reform. The central goals are to address the immediate crisis of long waiting lists and transform the NHS from a "sickness service" to one focused on prevention and long-term care. Core Mission and Waiting Times • NHS Fit for the Future: The mission aims to ensure the NHS is available when people need it, with fewer lives lost to major killers, and ensure people live well for longer. • Cutting Waiting Lists: Labour’s immediate priority is to get a grip on the record waiting lists. ◦ They aim to return to meeting NHS performance standards, meaning patients should wait no longer than 18 weeks from referral for consultant-led treatment of non-urgent conditions. ◦ Extra Appointments: As a first step, Labour will deliver an extra two million NHS operations, scans, and appointments every year in England, equating to 40,000 more appointments every week. ◦ These appointments will be scheduled during evenings and weekends, paid for by cracking down on tax avoidance and non-dom loopholes. ◦ Resource Pooling: Resources will be pooled across neighboring hospitals to introduce shared waiting lists, allowing patients to be treated quicker. ◦ Independent Sector: Labour will use spare capacity in the independent sector to ensure patients are diagnosed and treated more quickly. Modernizing Equipment and Technology • Doubling Scanners: Labour will introduce a new "Fit For the Future" fund to double the number of CT and MRI scanners. This is intended to help catch cancer and other conditions earlier, saving lives. This fund is costed at £250 million (2028-29). • Digital Transformation: The party seeks to harness the power of technologies like AI to transform the speed and accuracy of diagnostic services. • NHS App: Labour plans to transform the NHS app, putting patients in control of their own health to manage medicine, appointments, and health needs. This includes providing performance information on local services, vaccination and health check notifications, and medical guidelines so patients can hold services accountable. • Life Sciences Strategy: The party will develop an NHS innovation and adoption strategy in England, reforming incentive structures and speeding up regulatory approval for new technology and medicines. They also aim to maximize the UK’s potential to lead the world in clinical trials, especially for conditions like dementia, by making the process more efficient via the NHS app. • New Hospitals Programme: Labour is committed to delivering the New Hospitals Programme, recognizing that NHS estates are in disrepair. Primary Care and Dentistry • Neighbourhood Health Service: The manifesto calls for a shift toward a Neighbourhood Health Service, with more care delivered in local communities to spot problems earlier, and a long-term shift of resources to primary care and community services. • The Family Doctor: Labour will work to bring back the family doctor by incentivizing GPs to see the same patient, effectively dealing with ongoing or complex conditions. • GP Appointments: They will train thousands more GPs, guarantee a face-to-face appointment for all who want one, and deliver a modern appointment booking system to end the "8am scramble". • Pharmacy and Opticians: Pressure will be taken off GP surgeries by creating a Community Pharmacist Prescribing Service, granting more pharmacists the right to prescribe common medicines. Other professionals, such as opticians, will be allowed to make direct referrals to specialist services or tests, expanding self-referral routes. • Dentistry Rescue Plan: Labour will tackle the immediate crisis in dentistry by providing 700,000 more urgent dental appointments annually. ◦ This plan is costed at £125 million (2028-29). ◦ Long-term reform includes shifting the dental contract to focus on prevention and the retention of NHS dentists. ◦ A supervised tooth-brushing scheme will be introduced for 3- to 5-year-olds, targeting the areas of highest need. Mental Health and Prevention • Mental Health Staff: Labour will recruit an additional 8,500 new staff in its first term to treat children and adults. These new staff will be specially trained to support people at risk of suicide. This policy is costed at £410 million (2028-29), funded by closing the carried interest tax loophole. • Young Futures Hubs: Mental health services will be provided through the new Young Futures hubs, offering open-access support for children and young people in every community. • School Mental Health: Access to specialist mental health professionals will be provided in every school. • Modernizing Mental Health Act: Labour will modernize mental health legislation to give patients greater choice, autonomy, enhanced rights, and support, and address the disproportionate detention rates of Black people and the treatment of those with autism and learning difficulties. • Public Health: Prevention is a key focus. Labour will introduce public health measures to tackle the biggest killers: ◦ Smoking: Ensure the next generation can never legally buy cigarettes and integrate "opt-out" smoking cessation interventions into routine hospital care. ◦ Vaping: Ban vapes from being branded and advertised to appeal to children. ◦ Obesity: Commit to banning advertising junk food to children and the sale of high-caffeine energy drinks to under-16s. • Health Inequalities: Labour aims to tackle the social determinants of health and halve the gap in healthy life expectancy between the richest and poorest regions in England. Social Care Reform • National Care Service: Labour will undertake a programme of reform to create a National Care Service, underpinned by national standards, ensuring consistency of care across the country. • Home First: Services will be locally delivered, built on a "home first" principle to support people living independently for as long as possible. • Workforce: A Fair Pay Agreement in adult social care will be established as a sector collective agreement, setting fair pay, terms and conditions, along with training standards. • Rights and Integration: Guarantee the rights of those in residential care to be able to see their families and improve local partnership working between the NHS and social care on hospital discharge. Women’s and Children’s Health • Maternity Care: Trusts failing on maternity care will be robustly supported into rapid improvement, and thousands more midwives will be trained as part of the NHS Workforce Plan. • Maternal Mortality: An explicit target will be set to close the Black and Asian maternal mortality gap. • Child Health: Labour will digitize the "Red Book" record of children’s health and enable vaccinations for babies and children as part of health visits. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The Labour healthcare plan seeks to rebuild the NHS by addressing immediate bottlenecks (waiting lists, equipment shortages) while simultaneously implementing deep structural reforms in primary care and social services to create a system that proactively supports lifelong health, rather than just treating illness. This systemic overhaul is like repairing a fractured pipe network: not only fixing the leaks (long waiting lists) but also upgrading the pump station (prevention and primary care) and replacing aging pipes (scanners and outdated systems) to ensure reliable flow for the future.
Labour Party.housing: The Labour manifesto includes detailed policies aimed at tackling the housing crisis, which it identifies as one of the country’s biggest barriers to growth, under the mission to "Kickstart Economic Growth". The overall goal is to "Get Britain building again" and make housing more affordable. Here is a summary of the key policies on housing, land use, and renting: 1. Home Building Targets and Planning Reform • 1.5 Million New Homes: Labour aims to build 1.5 million new homes over the next parliament, creating jobs across England. • Restoring Mandatory Housing Targets: Labour will immediately update the National Policy Planning Framework to reverse "damaging Conservative changes" and restore mandatory housing targets. • Funding Planning Officers: To support local authorities and ensure Local Plans are up-to-date, Labour will fund additional planning officers. This funding will come from increasing the rate of the stamp duty surcharge paid by non-UK residents. • Intervention Powers: While local communities will continue to shape housebuilding, Labour will not be afraid to make full use of intervention powers where necessary to ensure the needed houses are built. • Strategic Planning: New effective mechanisms for cross-boundary strategic planning will be introduced, requiring all Combined and Mayoral Authorities to strategically plan for housing growth in their areas. Combined Authorities will receive new planning powers and greater freedom over grant funding. 2. Land Use and Green Belt • Brownfield First: Labour will take a "brownfield first approach," prioritizing brownfield land wherever possible and fast-tracking the approval of urban brownfield sites. • Preserving the Green Belt: The party is committed to preserving the green belt. • Strategic Release of Land: While maintaining the general extent and purpose of the green belt, Labour will adopt a more strategic approach to land designation and release for housebuilding needs. The release of lower quality "grey belt" land will be prioritised. • Golden Rules: "Golden rules" will be introduced to ensure that development benefits communities and nature. • Compulsory Purchase: Labour will reform compulsory purchase compensation rules to improve land assembly, speed up site delivery, and ensure landowners are awarded fair compensation rather than inflated prices based on the prospect of planning permission. • New Towns: In partnership with local leaders and communities, Labour will build a new generation of new towns, alongside urban extensions and regeneration projects, to form a series of large-scale new communities across England. 3. Social and Affordable Housing • Biggest Increase in Social Housing: Labour commits to delivering the biggest increase in social and affordable housebuilding in a generation. • Affordable Homes Programme: Changes will be made to the Affordable Homes Programme to ensure it delivers more homes from existing funding. • Building Capacity: The party will support councils and housing associations to build their capacity and make a greater contribution to affordable housing supply. • Social Rented Homes: Labour will prioritise the building of new social rented homes. • Right to Buy: The manifesto commits to better protecting existing social housing stock by reviewing the increased Right to Buy discounts introduced in 2012 and increasing protections on newly-built social housing. 4. Supporting Buyers and Renters • First-Time Buyers: Labour will work with local authorities to give first-time buyers the first chance to buy homes. They will also end the practice of entire developments being sold off to international investors before houses are even built. • Mortgage Guarantee Scheme: A permanent, comprehensive mortgage guarantee scheme will be introduced to support first-time buyers who struggle to save for a large deposit, aiming for lower mortgage costs. • Private Renters’ Security: Labour will immediately abolish Section 21 "no-fault" evictions. They plan to overhaul the regulation of the private rented sector, empowering renters to challenge unreasonable rent increases and extending "Awaab’s Law" to the private sector to decisively raise standards. • Ending Leasehold: Labour will take decisive action to finally bring the "feudal leasehold system to an end". They will enact Law Commission proposals on leasehold enfranchisement, the right to manage, and commonhold; ban new leasehold flats; ensure commonhold is the default tenure; and tackle unregulated and unaffordable ground rent charges. They will also address the injustice of "fleecehold" private housing estates and unfair maintenance costs. • Building Safety: Labour will take decisive action to improve building safety, including reviewing how to better protect leaseholders from costs and accelerating remediation, while ensuring those responsible for the building safety crisis pay to fix it. • Homelessness: Building on past lessons, Labour will develop a new cross-government strategy to put Britain back on track to ending homelessness. 5. Sustainability and Quality • High-Quality Homes: Labour will ensure the building of more high-quality, well-designed, and sustainable homes and create places that increase climate resilience and promote nature recovery. • Nutrient Neutrality: Solutions will be implemented to unlock the building of homes affected by nutrient neutrality without weakening environmental protections. The commitment to making housing more affordable is central to Labour’s plan to support resilient family finances and tackle the underlying causes of the cost-of-living crisis.
Labour Party.immigration: The manifesto addresses immigration and border control as one of the Strong Foundations necessary for good government: Secure Borders. The policies focus on ending the chaos in the asylum system, tackling criminal people-smuggling gangs, and managing net migration responsibly. Here is a summary of the key policies on immigration and border security: Secure Borders and Tackling Criminal Gangs Labour characterizes the current situation as "chaos in the Channel" fueled by dangerous criminal gangs. • Border Security Command: Labour will stop the chaos by going after the criminal gangs driving the small boats crisis. They will create a new Border Security Command with hundreds of new investigators, intelligence officers, and cross-border police officers. • Funding the Command: The Border Security Command will be funded by ending the "wasteful" Migration and Economic Development partnership with Rwanda, which has already cost hundreds of millions of pounds. The sources note that even if the Rwanda scheme got off the ground, it could only address fewer than one per cent of the asylum seekers arriving. • New Powers and Cooperation: The new Command will work internationally and be supported by new counter-terrorism style powers to pursue, disrupt, and arrest those responsible for the "vile trade" of people smuggling. Labour will also seek a new security agreement with the EU to ensure access to real-time intelligence and lead joint investigations with European counterparts. Asylum System Reform The goal is to restore order to the asylum system so that it operates swiftly, firmly, and fairly, with rules properly enforced. • Clearing the Backlog: Labour will hire additional caseworkers to clear the Conservatives’ "perma-backlog" of tens of thousands of asylum seekers. • Ending Asylum Hotels: Clearing the backlog aims to end the use of asylum hotels, which currently cost the taxpayer millions of pounds every week, thus saving billions of pounds. New measures to clear the backlog are funded by reallocating £155 million annually. • Returns and Enforcement: A new returns and enforcement unit will be established, staffed with an additional 1,000 staff. This unit will be tasked with fast-tracking removals to safe countries for people who do not have the right to stay in the UK. Labour will negotiate additional returns arrangements to speed up removals and increase the number of safe countries failed asylum seekers can swiftly be sent back to. • Addressing Upstream Issues: Labour will also act "upstream," working with international partners to address the humanitarian crises that cause people to flee their homes and strengthen support for refugees in their regions. Managing Legal Migration and Workforce Labour recognizes that people who come to the UK to work make a substantial contribution to the economy, public services, and communities. However, the manifesto notes that the UK economy has become overly dependent on foreign workers to fill skills shortages, leading net migration to reach record highs. • Reducing Net Migration: Labour states that the overall level of migration must be properly controlled and managed, and commits to reducing net migration. This reduction is necessary to avoid reducing incentives for businesses to train locally. • Reforming the Points-Based System: Labour will reform the points-based immigration system to make it fair and properly managed, including appropriate restrictions on visas and linking immigration and skills policy. • Tackling Abuse: Employers and recruitment agencies who abuse the visa system or flout employment law will be barred from hiring workers from abroad. • Joined-Up Policy: Migration decisions to address skills shortages must now trigger a plan to upskill UK workers and improve working conditions in the UK. The manifesto states that the days of a sector languishing endlessly on immigration shortage lists with no action to train up workers will end. • Strengthening Advisory Bodies: Labour will strengthen the Migration Advisory Committee and establish a framework for joint working with skills bodies and the Industrial Strategy Council. • Sectoral Workforce Plans: Labour will end the long-term reliance on overseas workers in certain parts of the economy by bringing in workforce and training plans for sectors such as health and social care, and construction. The approach aims to create a system where legal migration is properly managed and linked to domestic skills training, while forcefully targeting the criminal elements responsible for the small boat crossings.
Labour Party.defence: The Labour manifesto highlights defense and national security as one of the three Strong Foundations of good government. The party commits to strengthening the armed forces and protecting national security in an increasingly volatile world. Here is a summary of the key policies on national security and defense: Core Defense Commitments • Nuclear Deterrent: Labour’s commitment to the UK’s nuclear deterrent is absolute. • NATO Commitment: The party maintains its unshakeable commitment to NATO as the cornerstone of European and global security. ◦ A NATO test will be applied to major defense programmes to ensure the UK meets its obligations in full. • Defence Spending: Labour will set out the path to spending 2.5% of GDP on defence. • Strategic Defence Review (SDR): A Strategic Defence Review will be conducted within the first year of government to assess the threats the UK faces and the capabilities needed to address them. Armed Forces and Veterans • Armed Forces Covenant: Labour will strengthen support for Armed Forces communities by putting the Armed Forces Covenant fully into law. • Armed Forces Commissioner: An independent Armed Forces Commissioner will be established to improve service life. • Veteran Support: Labour will ensure veterans have access to the mental health, employment, and housing support they need. • Visa Fees: The party will scrap visa fees for non-UK veterans who have served for four or more years, and their dependents. This policy is costed at £10 million (UK wide) in 2028-29. Defence Industry and Procurement • Defence Industrial Strategy: Labour will bring forward a defence industrial strategy to align security and economic priorities. • Supply Chains: The strategy will ensure a strong defence sector and resilient supply chains, including steel, across the whole of the UK. • UK Business Prioritization: Labour will prioritise UK businesses for defence investment and reform procurement to reduce waste. • Leadership and Efficiency: To improve leadership and efficiency, Labour will establish a fully functioning military strategic headquarters and a national armaments director. Countering Threats and Hostile States • Hybrid Warfare: Labour recognizes the growing threats from hybrid warfare, including cyber-attacks and misinformation campaigns. • Hostile States: The approach used for dealing with non-state terrorism will be adapted to deal with state-based domestic security threats. • Terrorism: Labour will introduce "Martyn’s Law" to strengthen the security of public events and venues. • Counter-Extremism: The party will update rules around counter-extremism, including online, to prevent radicalization. • Intelligence: The police and intelligence services will be ensured to have the powers and resources needed to protect against terrorism and hostile espionage. International Security and Alliances • Ukraine: Support for Ukraine will remain steadfast (military, financial, diplomatic, and political). Labour backs calls for a Special Tribunal for the Crime of Aggression and will work with allies to seize and repurpose frozen Russian state assets to support Ukraine. They will also play a leading role in providing Ukraine with a clear path to NATO membership. • AUKUS: Labour is fully committed to the AUKUS trilateral security partnership with Australia and the United States, aiming to maximize its economic and security potential. • Sovereignty: Labour will always defend the sovereignty and right to self-determination of the British Overseas Territories and Crown Dependencies, including the Falklands and Gibraltar. • Security Pacts (EU): Labour will seek an ambitious new UK-EU security pact to strengthen co-operation on shared threats. In essence, Labour’s defense policy centers on a dual approach: guaranteeing traditional security via absolute commitment to nuclear deterrence and NATO, while conducting a full strategic review to modernize capabilities and funding, alongside concrete measures to support service personnel and veterans.
Labour Party.economy: The Labour manifesto positions economic policy as the foundation for national renewal, focusing on achieving Economic Stability as a "Strong Foundation" and launching the mission to Kickstart Economic Growth. The plan is described as fully costed, fully funded, and built on start Economic Growth. The plan is described as fully costed, fully funded, and built on fiscal responsibility. Here is a summary of the key economic policies: 1. Economic Stability and Fiscal Responsibility Labour’s economic approach is based on sound money and will govern every decision the government makes. • Tough Fiscal Rules: Labour will commit to two firm fiscal rules : 1. The current budget moves into balance, meaning day-to-day costs are met by revenues. 2. Debt must be falling as a share of the economy by the fifth year of the forecast. • No Tax Increases on Working People: Labour will ensure taxes on working people are kept as low as possible and will not increase National Insurance, Income Tax (basic, higher, or additional rates), or VAT. • Fiscal Oversight: Labour rejects the ideology that tax cuts pay for themselves and will not sideline the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR). Every fiscal event making significant changes to taxation or spending will be subject to an independent OBR forecast. • Monetary Policy: Labour will keep mortgage rates as low as possible with a strong, independent Bank of England that continues to target stable inflation of 2%. • Tackling Fraud and Waste: The party will appoint a fixed-term Covid Corruption Commissioner to recoup public money lost in pandemic-related fraud and will not tolerate fraud or waste anywhere. 2. Revenue Generation and Tax Fairness Labour commits to funding public services by tackling unfairness in the tax system. • Abolishing Non-Dom Status: Labour will abolish non-dom status and replace it with a modern scheme for people genuinely in the country for a short period. Revenue from closing these loopholes will help fund additional NHS appointments and other services. • Offshore Trusts: Labour will end the use of offshore trusts to avoid inheritance tax. • Private Equity Loophole: The party will close the capital gains loophole for private equity performance-related pay. • Tax Avoidance: Labour will modernise HMRC, increase registration and reporting requirements, strengthen powers, and invest in new technology to tackle tax avoidance by large businesses and the wealthy. • Private Schools: Labour will abolish the VAT exemption and business rates relief for private schools to invest in state education. • Windfall Tax: A time-limited windfall tax on oil and gas giants will be used to fund the Green Prosperity Plan, including Great British Energy. 3. Kickstarting Economic Growth (Mission 1) The mission is to secure the highest sustained growth in the G7—with good jobs and productivity growth in every part of the country. Labour calls this new approach Securonomics, which relies on a dynamic and strategic state working in partnership with business and trade unions. Investment and Industrial Strategy • Industrial Strategy Council: Labour will introduce a new industrial strategy, focusing on long-term policy, and establish an Industrial Strategy Council on a statutory footing to provide expert advice. • National Wealth Fund (NWF): The NWF will be capitalized with £7.3 billion over the next parliament. It will support Labour’s growth and clean energy missions, aiming to attract three pounds of private investment for every one pound of public investment. Allocations include : ◦ £1.8 billion for ports and supply chains. ◦ £1.5 billion for new gigafactories. ◦ £2.5 billion to rebuild the steel industry. ◦ £1 billion for carbon capture deployment. ◦ £500 million for manufacturing green hydrogen. • Pensions Investment: Labour will adopt reforms to ensure workplace pension schemes take advantage of consolidation and scale to deliver better returns for UK savers and greater productive investment for UK PLC. Business Taxation and Regulation • Corporation Tax: Labour will cap corporation tax at the current level of 25%—the lowest in the G7—for the entire parliament. • Business Rates Reform: The existing system in England, which disincentivizes investment and burdens high streets, will be replaced. The new system will raise the same revenue but in a fairer way, leveling the playing field between the high street and online giants. • Regulatory Innovation Office: A new office will be created to bring together existing functions across government, helping regulators update regulation and speed up approval timelines for new technologies. Infrastructure, Transport, and Digital • Infrastructure Strategy: A ten-year infrastructure strategy will be developed to guide investment, align with industrial strategy, and address the crumbling infrastructure. • Planning Reform: Labour will slash red tape, set out new national policy statements, and ensure communities benefit directly from development to make major projects faster and cheaper. • Digital: A renewed push will be made to fulfil the ambition of full gigabit and national 5G coverage by 2030. • Potholes: Labour will maintain and renew the road network, fixing an additional one million potholes across England annually, funded by deferring the poor-value A27 bypass. • Railways: Labour will overhaul Britain’s railways by bringing them into public ownership as existing contracts expire or are broken through failure to deliver, without costing taxpayers compensation. 4. Workforce and Labour Rights • New Deal for Working People: Labour will implement its plan to "Make Work Pay: Delivering a New Deal for Working People" in full, introducing legislation within 100 days. ◦ This includes banning exploitative zero-hours contracts and ending fire and rehire. ◦ Basic rights (like parental leave, sick pay, and protection from unfair dismissal) will be introduced from day one. • Minimum Wage: Labour will change the remit of the Low Pay Commission so that it accounts for the cost of living and will remove discriminatory age bands, ensuring all adults are entitled to the same minimum wage. • Skills and Training: The Apprenticeships Levy will be reformed into a flexible Growth and Skills Levy. Skills England will be established to coordinate training with the Industrial Strategy Council and Migration Advisory Committee. 5. Housing and Economic Growth The housing crisis is addressed as a major barrier to growth. • 1.5 Million Homes: Labour will get Britain building again, targeting 1.5 million new homes over the next parliament. • Land Use: They will adopt a "brownfield first" approach and take a strategic approach to greenbelt land designation and release, prioritizing lower quality "grey belt" land. • First-Time Buyers: Labour will introduce a permanent, comprehensive mortgage guarantee scheme to support first-time buyers with lower mortgage costs. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Labour’s economic plan acts as a strategic overhaul, aiming to move away from short-term "chaos" by implementing tough financial rules (the foundation) and using targeted public investment through the National Wealth Fund (the engine) to drive long-term, sustained growth, particularly in clean energy and infrastructure, thereby linking fiscal stability with wealth creation across the UK.
Labour Party.education: The policies on education are summarized under the fourth National Mission, "Break Down Barriers to Opportunity," with the aim of reforming childcare and education systems to remove the "class ceiling" on the ambitions of young people in Britain. Labour plans to transform the education system to ensure young people are prepared for life, work, and the future. Key policies and funding sources include: 1. Teachers and School Standards • Recruitment and Retention: Labour will recruit an additional 6,500 new expert teachers to address shortages, particularly in shortage subjects. They will also tackle retention issues and support areas that face recruitment challenges. • Teacher Training: The party will ensure any new teacher entering the classroom has, or is working towards, Qualified Teacher Status. They will introduce a new Teacher Training Entitlement to ensure teachers stay up to date on best practice with continuing professional development. This increased teacher and headteacher training is costed at £270 million (2028-29). • School Support Staff: Labour will reinstate the School Support Staff Negotiating Body to help address the acute recruitment and retention crisis in support roles. • Leadership and Support: A new Excellence in Leadership Programme (mentoring framework) will be created to expand the capacity of headteachers and leaders. New Regional Improvement Teams will be introduced to enhance school-to-school support and spread best practice. 2. Funding and Private Schools • Abolishing Tax Breaks: Labour will abolish the VAT exemption and business rates relief for private schools to invest this revenue in state schools. ◦ The revenue generated from applying VAT and business rates to private schools is estimated at £1,510 million in 2028-29. This revenue will fund the new teachers, training, and other educational policies. 3. Curriculum, Assessment, and Opportunity • Curriculum Review: An expert-led review of curriculum and assessment will be launched, working with staff, parents, and employers. The reforms will aim to deliver a curriculum that is rich, broad, inclusive, and innovative, building on existing knowledge-rich syllabuses. The review will consider the right balance of assessment methods while protecting the important role of examinations. • Creative Subjects: Labour will support children to study a creative or vocational subject until they are 16 and ensure accountability measures reflect this. • Literacy and Numeracy: Labour will improve the quality of maths teaching across nurseries and primary schools and fund evidence-based early-language interventions in primary schools so every child can find their voice. Early language development interventions are costed at £5 million (2028-29). • Arts and Culture: The arts and music will no longer be seen as the preserve of a privileged few. The party will launch a new National Music Education Network (a one-stop shop for courses and classes) and require publicly funded national museums and galleries to increase the loans they make to communities across the country. • Physical Education: Time for physical education will be protected, and the role of grassroots clubs in expanding access to sport will be supported. 4. Early Years and Child Poverty • Childcare Expansion: Labour will expand the childcare and early-years system. As an initial step, they will open an additional 3,000 nurseries by upgrading space in primary schools to deliver the extension of government-funded hours. This is costed at £35 million (2028-29). • Free Breakfast Clubs: To confront rising child poverty, Labour will fund free breakfast clubs in every primary school, accessible to all children. These clubs aim to support parents through the cost-of-living crisis, improve behavior, attendance, and learning. This policy is costed at £315 million (2028-29). • Parental Leave: Labour will review the parental leave system to ensure it best supports working families. • School Costs: The party will bring down the cost of school by limiting the number of branded items of uniform and PE kit that schools can require. 5. Mental Health and Support • School Mental Health Professionals: Labour will provide access to specialist mental health professionals in every school, ensuring every young person has access to early support. This support is costed at £175 million (2028-29). • Young Futures Hubs: This complements the plan for Young Futures Hubs in every community, offering open-access, drop-in mental health support for children and young people. Funding for these hubs is costed at £95 million (2028-29). • SEND: Labour will take a community-wide approach to Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND), improving inclusivity and expertise in mainstream schools while ensuring special schools cater to those with the most complex needs. 6. Post-16 Education and Skills • Skills England: Skills England will be established to coordinate training with business, training providers, unions, and government to ensure the highly trained workforce needed for Labour’s Industrial Strategy. Skills England will formally work with the Migration Advisory Committee to ensure training accounts for the overall needs of the labor market. • Growth and Skills Levy: Labour will reform the Apprenticeships Levy into a flexible Growth and Skills Levy, consulting on eligible courses to ensure qualifications offer value for money. • Technical Excellence: Further Education colleges will be transformed into Specialist Technical Excellence Colleges, which will work with business and local government to provide better job opportunities. • Youth Guarantee: A youth guarantee will be established to ensure all 18- to 21-year-olds have access to training, an apprenticeship, or support to find work. • Work Experience and Careers: Labour will guarantee two weeks’ worth of work experience for every young person and improve careers advice in schools and colleges. The cost for delivering work experience and careers advice for all young people is £85 million (2028-29). • Higher Education: Labour will continue to support the aspiration of university attendance for those who meet the requirements. The party will work with universities to create a secure funding future for higher education and address the current funding settlement. 7. Accountability • Ofsted Reform: Labour supports school inspection but recognizes the current regime is broken. They will enhance the inspection regime by replacing a single headline grade with a new report card system to clearly inform parents of school performance. • Trust Inspection: Multi-Academy Trusts will be brought into the inspection system, and a new annual review of safeguarding, attendance, and off-rolling will be introduced. Ofsted reform is costed at £45 million (2028-29). Labour’s strategy is designed to create a secure foundation for children’s learning from early years through to employment, essentially treating education and skills as critical national infrastructure for sustained economic growth.
Labour Party.environment: The manifesto summarizes its environmental policies under the second National Mission: "Make Britain a clean energy superpower", recognizing the climate and nature crisis as the greatest long-term global challenge. The goal is to generate growth, tackle the cost-of-living crisis, and achieve energy independence through a transition to clean energy. The plan emphasizes public investment through the Green Prosperity Plan to leverage private funding, create jobs, cut bills, and accelerate the transition to net zero. 1. Clean Energy and Energy Security The mission is to deliver cheaper, zero-carbon electricity by 2030. • Great British Energy (GBE): A new publicly-owned clean power company called Great British Energy will be created. ◦ GBE will partner with industry and trade unions, co-investing in leading technologies and deploying local energy production. ◦ It will be capitalized with £8.3 billion over the next parliament. ◦ Scotland will be the powerhouse of this mission, and GBE will be headquartered there. • Energy Generation Targets: Labour will work with the private sector to double onshore wind, triple solar power, and quadruple offshore wind by 2030. • Fossil Fuels and Windfall Tax: To fund the Green Prosperity Plan, Labour will implement a time-limited windfall tax on oil and gas giants. ◦ This involves extending the sunset clause in the Energy Profits Levy until the end of the next parliament, increasing the rate by three percentage points, and removing generous investment allowances. ◦ Labour will not issue new licences to explore new oil and gas fields because they will not reduce bills, enhance energy security, or prevent the worsening climate crisis. ◦ They will ban fracking for good and will not grant new coal licences. ◦ A phased and responsible transition will be ensured in the North Sea, recognizing the ongoing role of oil and gas in the energy mix and managing existing fields for their lifespan without jeopardizing jobs. • Other Clean Technologies: Labour will invest in carbon capture and storage (£1 billion allocated through the National Wealth Fund), hydrogen (£500 million for green hydrogen manufacturing), and marine energy, and will ensure the UK has the necessary long-term energy storage. • Nuclear Power: Labour will end the "dithering" on nuclear power, ensuring the long-term security of the sector by extending the lifetime of existing plants and completing Hinkley Point C. New nuclear power stations, such as Sizewell C, and Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) will play an important role. 2. Energy Efficiency and Bills • Warm Homes Plan: Labour will invest an extra £6.6 billion over the next parliament, doubling existing planned government investment, to upgrade five million homes to cut bills for families. This program is costed at an annual average of £1.1 billion. ◦ The plan will offer grants and low-interest loans for insulation, solar panels, batteries, and low-carbon heating. ◦ Homes in the private rented sector must meet minimum energy efficiency standards by 2030. • No Forced Boiler Rip-Outs: The manifesto assures that nobody will be forced to rip out their boiler as a result of these plans. • Grid Modernization: The national grid is recognized as the biggest obstacle to deploying cheap, clean power. Labour will work with industry to upgrade national transmission infrastructure and rewire Britain. • Energy Regulation: Labour will ensure a tougher system of regulation that puts consumers first. They will work with the regulator to reduce standing charges on bills, hold companies accountable for wrongdoing, block executive bonuses for polluters, and impose automatic customer compensation for failure. 3. Nature, Water, and Pollution • Cleaning up Water: Labour will put failing water companies under special measures to clean up our water. ◦ Regulators will be given new powers to block bonuses to executives who pollute waterways and bring criminal charges against persistent law breakers. ◦ Automatic and severe fines will be imposed for wrongdoing, and there will be independent monitoring of every outlet. • Protecting Nature and Biodiversity: Labour will deliver for nature and work to meet Environment Act targets. ◦ New habitats will be expanded, including wetlands, peat bogs, and forests. ◦ They will create nine new National River Walks and establish three new National Forests in England. • Circular Economy: Labour is committed to reducing waste by moving to a circular economy. • Addressing Flooding and Erosion: Labour will improve resilience and preparation across various stakeholders (government, local authorities, emergency services) to adapt to risks posed by flooding and coastal erosion. 4. Climate Governance and Finance • Institutional Framework: Labour will ensure the institutional framework for policy making reflects commitments to reach net zero and carbon budgets. • Bank of England Mandate: The Conservative decision to prevent the Bank of England from giving due consideration to climate change in its mandates will be reversed. • Green Finance: Labour aims to make the UK the green finance capital of the world by mandating UK-regulated financial institutions (including banks, asset managers, and pension funds) and FTSE 100 companies to develop and implement credible transition plans aligned with the 1.5°C goal of the Paris Agreement. • International Leadership: Labour will restore strong global leadership on climate action. They will create a new Clean Power Alliance, a coalition of countries at the cutting edge of climate action, to accelerate the energy transition and enhance clean energy supply chains. • Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM): Labour supports the introduction of a CBAM to protect British industries as the UK decarbonizes, prevent the dumping of lower-quality goods, and support climate objectives. This environmental strategy is fundamentally tied to economic growth, using investment in clean power as a mechanism to create jobs, reduce household costs, and regain international influence.
Labour Party.brexit: The sources address the party’s position on Brexit within the context of rebuilding relationships internationally and being "confident in our status outside of the EU". Here is a summary of the policies concerning Brexit and the UK’s relationship with the European Union (EU): Maintaining Status and Rejecting Reversal • Staying Outside the EU: Labour explicitly states that Britain will stay outside of the EU. • No Return to Past Divisions: The party is focused on making Brexit work and resetting the relationship, not reopening the divisions of the past. • Red Lines: There will be no return to the single market, the customs union, or freedom of movement. Deepening Ties and Improving Trade Labour will seek to deepen ties with European friends, neighbours, and allies to seize opportunities ahead. • Trade and Investment: The party will work to improve the UK’s trade and investment relationship with the EU by tearing down unnecessary barriers to trade. • Veterinary Agreement: Labour will seek to negotiate a veterinary agreement to prevent unnecessary border checks and help tackle the cost of food. • Professional Qualifications: They will aim to secure a mutual recognition agreement for professional qualifications to help open up markets for UK service exporters. • Touring Artists: The plan includes measures to help touring artists. Security and International Cooperation • Security Pact: Labour will seek an ambitious new UK-EU security pact to strengthen cooperation on shared threats. • European Allies: Relationships with key European allies, including France and Germany, will be rebuilt through increased defence and security cooperation. • NATO and Global Security: This enhanced security cooperation is seen as strengthening NATO and keeping Britain safe. Governance and Northern Ireland • Intergovernmental Relations: Labour commits to resetting the relationship between the UK government and devolved governments (Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland). They will strengthen the structures of intergovernmental working to improve collaboration on policy. • Windsor Framework: Labour is committed to implementing the Windsor Framework in good faith and protecting the UK internal market, which is vital for Northern Ireland’s stability and economy. In essence, Labour’s policy on Brexit is to accept the decision to leave the EU as final, commit to major "red lines" (no single market, customs union, or freedom of movement), and focus instead on pragmatic, sector-specific agreements (like a veterinary agreement) and security pacts to manage the relationship and reduce economic friction.
Labour Party.entire manifesto: The manifesto outlines its key policies based on three Strong Foundations and five National Missions for change, emphasizing ending "Conservative chaos" and pursuing national renewal. The plan is described as fully costed, fully funded, and built on a foundation of fiscal responsibility. Strong Foundations Labour intends to restore the foundations of good government: national security, secure borders, and economic stability. • Economic Stability: Labour’s approach is based on tough fiscal rules, requiring the current budget to move into balance (day-to-day costs met by revenues) and debt to be falling as a share of the economy by the fifth year of the forecast. ◦ Labour commits to not increasing taxes on working people, including National Insurance, Income Tax (basic, higher, or additional rates), or VAT. ◦ Key revenue generation measures include abolishing non-dom status and replacing it with a modern scheme, ending the use of offshore trusts to avoid inheritance tax, and closing the capital gains loophole for private equity performance-related pay. • Secure Borders: The party plans to stop the chaos by going after criminal gangs driving the small boats crisis. ◦ They will create a new Border Security Command (funded by ending the Migration and Economic Development partnership with Rwanda). ◦ Additional caseworkers will be hired to clear the asylum backlog and end the use of asylum hotels, aiming to save billions. • National Security: Labour’s commitment to the UK’s nuclear deterrent is absolute, and the party maintains its unshakeable commitment to NATO. ◦ A Strategic Defence Review will be conducted within the first year to set out the path to spending 2.5% of GDP on defence. ◦ Labour will introduce "Martyn’s Law" to strengthen the security of public events and venues. Five National Missions 1. Kickstart Economic Growth The mission is to secure the highest sustained growth in the G7. • Housing and Infrastructure: Labour will get Britain building again, targeting 1.5 million new homes over the next parliament. This includes prioritizing brownfield sites first and taking a strategic approach to greenbelt land (prioritizing the release of "grey belt" land). • Business and Investment: They plan to introduce an industrial strategy and establish an Industrial Strategy Council on a statutory footing. • A National Wealth Fund will be established and capitalized with £7.3 billion to leverage private investment for growth and clean energy missions across the country. • Taxation: Corporation tax will be capped at the current 25% for the entire parliament. The business rates system in England will be replaced to level the playing field between the high street and online giants. • Workers’ Rights: Legislation will be introduced within 100 days to implement a New Deal for Working People, including banning exploitative zero-hours contracts, ending fire and rehire, and introducing basic rights (like parental leave and protection from unfair dismissal) from day one. • Transport: The manifesto commits to maintaining and renewing the road network, including fixing an additional one million potholes across England annually. It will also overhaul Britain’s railways by bringing them into public ownership as existing contracts expire or are broken due to failure to deliver, without compensation costs to taxpayers. 2. Make Britain a Clean Energy Superpower The goal is to cut bills, create jobs, and deliver cheaper, zero-carbon electricity by 2030. • Great British Energy: A new publicly-owned clean power company (Great British Energy) will be created, funded by a windfall tax on oil and gas giants. • Energy Generation: Labour will work with the private sector to double onshore wind, triple solar power, and quadruple offshore wind by 2030. • Fossil Fuels: The party will not issue new licences to explore new oil and gas fields and will ban fracking for good. • Warm Homes Plan: An extra £6.6 billion will be invested over the next parliament to upgrade five million homes with insulation and other improvements to cut bills and fuel poverty. • Water Companies: Failing water companies will be put under special measures to clean up water. Regulators will gain new powers to block executive bonuses for those who pollute waterways and impose automatic, severe fines for wrongdoing. 3. Take Back Our Streets The mission is to halve serious violent crime and raise confidence in the police and criminal justice system. • Policing: A new Neighbourhood Policing Guarantee will restore patrols to town centres by recruiting thousands of new police officers, Police and Community Support Officers (PCSOs), and special constables. • Antisocial Behaviour: New Respect Orders will be introduced to ban persistent adult offenders from town centres. Fly-tippers and vandals will be forced to clean up their mess. • Knife Crime: Labour aims to halve knife crime in a decade. Key measures include banning ninja swords, lethal zombie-style blades, and machetes. • Youth Support: A new Young Futures programme with a network of hubs will be created, offering youth workers, mental health support, and careers advisers. • Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG): Specialist rape and sexual offences teams will be established in every police force, and rape cases will be fast-tracked with specialist courts. 4. Break Down Barriers to Opportunity This mission focuses on reforming childcare and education to remove the "class ceiling". • Education Funding: Labour will abolish the VAT exemption and business rates relief for private schools to invest in the state education system. • Teachers: An additional 6,500 new expert teachers will be recruited. • Childcare: An additional 3,000 nurseries will be opened by upgrading space in primary schools to deliver the extension of government-funded hours. • Child Poverty: Free breakfast clubs will be funded in every primary school, accessible to all children. • Curriculum: An expert-led review of the curriculum and assessment will be launched, alongside ensuring a creative or vocational subject can be studied until age 16. • Higher Education: The Apprenticeships Levy will be reformed into a flexible Growth and Skills Levy. Specialist Technical Excellence Colleges will be developed from Further Education colleges. • Pensions: Labour will retain the triple lock for the state pension. • Renters: Labour will immediately abolish Section 21 "no-fault" evictions and overhaul the regulation of the private rented sector. They will also bring the feudal leasehold system to an end. 5. Build an NHS Fit for the Future The mission is to ensure the NHS is there when people need it and is fit for the future. • Waiting Times: Labour will deliver an extra two million NHS operations, scans, and appointments every year (40,000 more appointments weekly, during evenings and weekends). These extra appointments will be paid for by cracking down on tax avoidance and non-dom loopholes. • Equipment: The party will introduce a new "Fit For the Future" fund to double the number of CT and MRI scanners to catch cancer and other conditions earlier. • Primary Care: They will train thousands more GPs and work to bring back the family doctor by incentivizing GPs to see the same patient for ongoing or complex conditions. • Dentistry: A Dentistry Rescue Plan will provide 700,000 more urgent dental appointments annually and reform the dental contract to focus on prevention and retention of NHS dentists. • Mental Health: Labour will recruit an additional 8,500 new mental health staff (adults and children) and provide open-access mental health services through the new Young Futures Hubs. • Social Care: A program of reform will be undertaken to create a National Care Service, underpinned by national standards. Governance and International Policy • Government Standards: A new independent Ethics and Integrity Commission will be established to ensure probity in government. Labour will support an immediate ban on MPs taking up paid advisory or consultancy roles. • Constitutional Reform: The party will bring about immediate modernization of the House of Lords by introducing legislation to remove the right of hereditary peers to sit and vote, and introducing a mandatory retirement age of 80. Labour is also committed to eventually replacing the House of Lords with an alternative second chamber more representative of the regions and nations. • Voting Rights: Labour plans to give 16- and 17-year-olds the right to vote in all elections. • International Relations: Labour will seek to deepen ties with the EU, including negotiating a veterinary agreement to prevent unnecessary border checks and secure a new UK-EU security pact (while maintaining no return to the single market, customs union, or freedom of movement). • Middle East: Labour is committed to recognizing a Palestinian state as a contribution to a renewed peace process resulting in a two-state solution. • Development Aid: Labour is committed to restoring development spending to 0.7% of gross national income as soon as fiscal circumstances allow. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The manifesto functions like a renovation plan for an old, structurally sound house, focusing on reinforcing the foundations (security, borders, economy) and then modernizing the key living areas (NHS, education, energy, and justice) to ensure long-term functionality and security.

Conservative and Unionist Party.crime: The key policies of the Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2024 concerning crime and justice are detailed under the section titled "Our plan for safer streets and justice for victims of crime". The plan emphasizes increasing police presence, implementing tougher sentencing, and supporting victims. Here is a summary of the manifesto’s key policies on crime: 1. Policing and Security The Conservative Party pledges to boost police numbers and provide enhanced tools and powers to law enforcement: • Increased Police Recruitment: The party commits to recruiting 8,000 more full-time, fully warranted police officers dedicated to neighbourhood policing, ensuring a new police officer for every neighbourhood. • Backing the Police: They will support the police by giving officers new powers and tools, including technologies like facial recognition and powers to seize knives and track down stolen property. • Restoring Trust: Measures will be introduced to restore public trust in policing, including legislating to ensure officers are appropriately vetted during their service, and those who fail can be sacked. They will also license police officers for specialist roles. • Counter-Terrorism: The party commits to urgently introduce Martyn’s Law, in tribute to Martyn Hett, to ensure that premises are better prepared for terrorist attacks by requiring them to take proportionate steps to mitigate risks. 2.
