Sentencing and Justice Reform The manifesto outlines tougher measures for offenders and focuses on justice for victims: • Toughening Sentencing: They will toughen sentencing for the worst offenders. This includes making life imprisonment without parole mandatory for more of the most heinous murderers. • Sexual Offenders: The manifesto states that rapists and other serious sexual offenders will be required to spend the whole of their sentences behind bars. • Domestic Abuse Murders: They will toughen sentencing for murders in the context of domestic abuse with new aggravating factors (such as coercive and controlling behaviour) and introduce a 25-year prison term for domestic murders, regardless of whether a weapon was used. Those who kill their domestic abusers will not face the same starting point. They will also introduce an aggravating factor for murders that occur in the context of "rough sex" to prevent it from being used as an excuse for a lighter sentence. • Prison Capacity: They plan to build four new prisons, completing their programme of 20,000 new prison places by 2030. They will also make it easier to build prisons by scrapping legacy EU rules and streamlining the planning system. • Foreign National Offenders: They will remove more Foreign National Offenders by increasing removals under the Early Removal Scheme and negotiating more Prisoner Transfer Agreements. • Repeat Offenders: They will prioritize further measures to crack down on hyper-prolific offenders. • Joint Enterprise: They will stand firmly behind the legal doctrine of joint enterprise, ensuring those who assist in crimes (like getaway drivers or weapon suppliers) can be held accountable. • Rape Prosecutions: They will ensure rape victims receive justice and support, building on a 56% increase in rape prosecutions since 2010. This includes a new investigatory model for police and prosecutors and pre-recorded cross-examination for victims in all Crown courts. 3. Tackling Anti-Social Behaviour and Fraud The party aims to increase community safety through visible policing and addressing modern crimes: • Anti-Social Behaviour (ASB): They will fund every police force to roll out Hotspot Policing, which has been shown to cut anti-social behaviour by up to 50% in some areas. • Social Tenant Eviction: They will legislate to evict social tenants who repeatedly disrupt their neighbours. • Community Sentencing: They will toughen up community sentencing by increasing the use of community payback and electronic tagging. • Fraud Reduction: They plan to keep turning the tide against fraudsters, building on a 13% reduction in fraud in the last year. Key actions include banning SIM farms (used for fraudulent texts) and banning cold calls on financial products to prevent people from being duped into fake investments. 4. Supporting Victims The manifesto commits to upholding justice for victims of crime: • Victims and Prisoners Act: They will deliver the commitments of the Victims and Prisoners Act, which ensures victims are protected and supported, including by providing a permanent Independent Public Advocate for those affected by major disasters. • Grooming Gangs: They will design a redress scheme for victims of child sexual abuse in institutional settings, ensuring this includes victims of grooming gangs, and will issue a national apology to grooming gang victims. • Sex Offenders: They will ensure sex offenders cannot evade justice or conceal their identity by restricting sex offenders from changing their names. The overarching goal is to deliver a justice system that is fair to victims and ensures offenders repay their debt to society.
Conservative and Unionist Party.healthcare: The Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2024 outlines its key policies for healthcare and social care under the section "Our plan to deliver better health and social care". The plan focuses on increasing funding, expanding the workforce, modernizing facilities, leveraging technology, and reforming primary and social care services. Here is a summary of the key policies on healthcare: 1. Funding, Staffing, and Capacity The party pledges sustained investment and significant workforce expansion for the National Health Service (NHS) : • Increased Spending: The commitment is to continue to increase NHS spending above inflation every year in the next Parliament. • Workforce Expansion: By the end of the next Parliament, the goal is to have 92,000 more nurses and 28,000 more doctors in the NHS than in 2023, following the NHS’s first ever Long-Term Workforce Plan. • Training Places: They plan to deliver record increases in training places for other clinicians, such as midwives and paramedics, and boost training places for dentists and other dental care professionals by 40%. • Hospital Building: They commit to continuing to deliver 40 new hospitals by 2030 and investing proportionately more in out-of-hospital services over time. 2. Service Delivery and Access The plan aims to move care closer to patients, increase productivity, and improve access to specific services : • Pharmacy First: They plan to expand Pharmacy First, including for menopause support, contraception, and treatment for chest infections. This expansion is expected to free up 20 million GP appointments a year. • GP and Diagnostic Facilities: The party commits to build or modernise 250 GP surgeries, focusing on areas of new housing growth. They will also build 50 more Community Diagnostic Centres, including in underserved areas, resulting in an additional 2.5 million checks a year. • Waiting Times: They are committed to accelerating the NHS’s recovery from the pandemic, delivering safe and effective services, and ensuring ongoing improvements in waiting times for primary, elective, cancer, and emergency care. The goal is to return performance to the levels set out in the NHS Constitution by the end of the next Parliament. • Patient Choice: They will protect and promote patients’ right to choose the NHS service that is right for them, including extending this right to more NHS community services (like diagnostics and mental health services) over time. They will also fully roll out Martha’s Rule, giving patients the right to a second opinion. • Dental Care: The Dental Recovery Plan will unlock 2.5 million more NHS dental appointments. Reforms include a patient premium to encourage dentists to take on new NHS patients and ensuring newly qualified dentists must work in the NHS for a number of years or pay back their training costs. 3. Technology and Productivity A major element of the plan is technological investment to boost efficiency : • Tech Investment: They will invest £3.4 billion in new technology to transform the NHS for staff and patients. • NHS App: The NHS App will be made the single front door for NHS services, allowing patients to access medical records, order prescriptions, book vaccines, and manage hospital appointments. • AI and Digitization: They plan to use AI to free up doctors’ and nurses’ time for frontline patient care. This includes replacing outdated computers, digitizing NHS processes through the Federated Data Platform, and funding technology to read MRI and CT scans faster and more accurately. • Productivity Target: The NHS Productivity Plan aims to see NHS productivity grow by 1.9% a year from 2025-26, which is expected to unlock £35 billion of cumulative savings by the end of the decade. 4. Mental Health and Women’s Health Specific focus areas are highlighted for mental health and maternity care : • Mental Health Support: Mental health should have parity of esteem with physical health. Key commitments include: ◦ Expanding Mental Health Support Teams from 50% to 100% of schools and colleges in England by 2030. ◦ Opening early support hubs for those aged 11-25 in every local community by 2030. ◦ Increasing the planned expansion of NHS Talking Therapies by 50%. ◦ Passing a new law to provide better treatment and support for severe mental health needs in the first session of the next Parliament. • Women’s Health: They will bring forward a comprehensive national strategy for maternity care. They also plan to deliver additional funding for maternal safety, improve access to mental health services for new mothers, and expand women’s health hubs so that every integrated care system has at least one operating. 5. Social Care The manifesto addresses the need for reform and stability in social care : • Cost Cap Implementation: They will implement planned reforms to cap social care costs from October 2025. • Funding: Local authorities will be given a multi-year funding settlement at the next Spending Review to support social care. • Workforce: They will work to attract and retain a high-quality care workforce. 6. Specific Reforms and Commitments Further reforms focus on patient protection and public health: • Infected Blood Scandal: They have issued a "wholehearted and unequivocal apology" and will pay comprehensive compensation to those infected and affected by this scandal, committing to pay whatever it costs to deliver the scheme. • Tobacco and Vapes Bill: They will bring forward their landmark Tobacco and Vapes Bill in the first King’s Speech, and will legislate to restrict the advertising of products high in fat, salt and sugar to tackle obesity. • Transgender Healthcare: They commit to completing the implementation of the Cass Review, ensuring services follow evidence-based best practice, and will legislate to permanently prevent the private prescription and supply of puberty blockers for gender dysphoria. • Single-Sex Spaces: They will amend the NHS Constitution to recognize every patient’s right to request single-sex accommodation and same-sex intimate care.
Conservative and Unionist Party.housing: The Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2024 outlines its key policies on housing under "Our plan to build more houses in the right places", focusing on increasing housing supply, supporting first-time buyers, reforming planning laws, and ensuring fairness in the housing system. Here is a summary of the key policies on housing: 1. Housing Supply and Targets The overarching goal is to significantly increase the number of homes built: • Delivery Target: The party commits to delivering 1.6 million homes in England in the next Parliament. This follows a record of delivering over 2.5 million homes since 2010, including one million in the last Parliament. • Brownfield Land Focus: They will deliver a record number of homes each year on brownfield land in urban areas. • Fast-Track Planning: A fast-track route through the planning system will be implemented for new homes on previously developed land in the 20 largest cities. • Urban Regeneration: They plan to unlock new urban regeneration schemes by creating locally-led urban development corporations in partnership with the private sector. This includes regenerating major sites like Euston (which will see 10,000 new homes built), Old Oak Common, and Thamesmead. • London Density: They intend to raise density levels in inner London to match those of European cities like Paris and Barcelona, ensuring the London Plan delivers more family homes on brownfield sites and underused industrial land. • Support for Small Builders: Councils will be required to set aside land for local and smaller builders, and Section 106 burdens will be lifted on more smaller sites. 2. Planning and Land Use The manifesto includes immediate action on planning bureaucracy and long-term protection of the countryside: • Abolishing "Nutrient Neutrality" Rules: They plan to abolish the legacy EU "nutrient neutrality" rules immediately to unlock the building of 100,000 new homes where local consent exists. Developers will be required to pay a one-off mitigation fee to ensure there is no net additional pollution. • Protecting the Green Belt: They reaffirm a "cast-iron commitment to protect the Green Belt from uncontrolled development," maintaining national planning protections that prevent top-down requirements for councils to remove Green Belt protection. • Infrastructure Levy: Local authorities will be mandated to use the new Infrastructure Levy to deliver essential infrastructure required to support new homes, such as GP surgeries and roads. • Planning Simplification: They will simplify the planning process for people who want to build or commission their own home and support more community housing schemes. 3. Support for Buyers and Renters Policies are geared toward helping first-time buyers access the housing ladder and ensuring fairness for renters and leaseholders: • Stamp Duty Abolition for First-Time Buyers: They will make permanent the increase to the threshold at which first-time buyers pay Stamp Duty, permanently abolishing it for homes up to £425,000. • New Help to Buy Scheme: A new and improved Help to Buy scheme will be launched, offering first-time buyers an equity loan of up to 20% towards the cost of a new build home. Buyers will be able to get onto the ladder with a 5% deposit. The scheme will be partly funded by contributions from house builders. • Mortgage Guarantee Scheme: They will continue the Mortgage Guarantee Scheme and support more families to buy through shared ownership. • Leasehold Reform: They plan to complete the process of leasehold reform, which includes: ◦ Capping ground rents at £250, reducing them to a peppercorn over time. ◦ Ending the misuse of forfeiture so leaseholders do not unfairly lose their property and capital. ◦ Making it easier to take up commonhold. • Renters Reform: They will pass a Renters Reform Bill to deliver fairness in the rental market. This involves delivering the court reforms necessary to fully abolish Section 21 and strengthening other grounds for landlords to evict private tenants, particularly those guilty of anti-social behaviour. • Supporting Landlords (Tax Relief): They will introduce a two-year temporary Capital Gains Tax relief for landlords who sell to their existing tenants. 4. Fairness and Community Impact The manifesto addresses issues related to social housing and tax guarantees: • Social Housing Allocation: They will legislate for new "Local Connection" and "UK Connection" tests for social housing in England to ensure the resource is allocated fairly. • Anti-Social Behaviour in Social Housing: They will implement a "three strikes and you’re out" expectation for social housing landlords to evict tenants whose behaviour repeatedly disrupts neighbours. • Tax Guarantee: Under the Family Home Tax Guarantee, they will not increase the number of council tax bands, undertake an expensive council tax revaluation, cut council tax discounts, or increase the rate or level of Stamp Duty. They will also maintain Private Residence Relief to protect people’s homes from Capital Gains Tax. • Holiday Lets: Councils will be given the powers they need to manage the uncontrolled growth of holiday lets, which can cause nuisance and a "hollowing out" of communities (also applicable to rural areas). • Building Safety: They will require the continuation of developer-funded remediation programmes for mid- and high-rise buildings to support leaseholders affected by historic building safety problems, building on previous landmark laws that freed leaseholders from cladding bills.
Conservative and Unionist Party.immigration: The Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2024 sets out a clear plan for controlling both illegal migration and the overall level of legal migration, emphasizing securing the borders and reducing the impact on public services. The key policies on immigration and border security are summarized under the plan titled "Our plan to control immigration and stop illegal immigration". 1. Stopping Illegal Immigration (Stopping the Boats) The central focus is establishing a strong deterrent to illegal channel crossings: • Establishing a Deterrent (Rwanda): The party pledges to run a relentless, continual process of permanently removing illegal migrants to Rwanda. They plan to start regular flights every month this July, continuing until the boats are stopped. • Prioritizing Security over Foreign Courts: They assert that if they are forced to choose between the UK’s security and the jurisdiction of a foreign court, including the ECtHR, they will always choose security. • Ending the Legal Merry-Go-Round: They will stop illegal migrants from bringing "spurious challenges" to block their removal by bringing the Illegal Migration Act into force. • Asylum Backlog: They aim to clear the asylum backlog, with a target for all claims to be processed in six months, and promise to end the use of hotels for housing asylum seekers. • Organized Crime: They will crack down on organized immigration crime, utilizing the National Crime Agency and intelligence services to disrupt supply chains and tackle people smugglers. • Returns Deals: They commit to signing further returns deals, building on the one already agreed with Albania. • Reforming Asylum Rules: The party will hold an international summit and work with other countries to reform international laws to make them "fit for an age of mass migration". They will also restrict visa access from countries that do not cooperate on national priorities like illegal migration. • Safe and Legal Routes: With control of the borders, they promise to give Parliament control over how many places are offered on safe and legal routes (for refugees fleeing persecution), setting a cap based on the capacity of local areas. This is in addition to maintaining existing visa schemes for people fleeing Hong Kong, Ukraine, and their Afghan settlement schemes. 2. Controlling Legal Migration The manifesto acknowledges that immigration is currently too high and must be brought down to sustainable levels to reduce strain on public services and housing, and to restore public confidence. • Legal Cap: They will introduce a binding, legal cap on migration. This cap will be set on both work and family visas. • Falling Numbers: The cap will be set at a level that explicitly takes into account the costs and benefits of migration. Crucially, the cap is guaranteed to fall every year of the next Parliament and cannot be breached. • Parliamentary Vote: Parliament will have an annual vote on the level of the cap to ensure public confidence in immigration control. • Maintaining Existing Reforms: They note that changes already implemented mean 300,000 people who were previously eligible to come to the UK now could not. These changes include: ◦ Ending the ability of almost all international students and all care workers to bring dependents. ◦ Abolishing the 20% going rate salary discount for shortage occupations. ◦ Increasing the salary threshold for Skilled Worker visas by 48% to £38,700. ◦ Raising the minimum income for family visas to £38,700. • Inflation Link: Going forward, they will automatically raise the Skilled Worker threshold and Family income requirement with inflation to ensure they do not undercut UK workers. • No Free Movement: They explicitly state they "won’t allow any form of free movement to return". 3. Financial and Health Requirements for Migrants Policies are aimed at ensuring migrants do not become a burden on the NHS: • Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS): They previously required migrants to pay the IHS and increased it to £1,035. They plan to go further by: ◦ Removing the student discount to the IHS. ◦ Increasing all visa fees. ◦ Requiring migrants to undergo a health check in advance of travel. ◦ Increasing their IHS or requiring them to buy health insurance if they are likely to be a burden on the NHS. In essence, the manifesto treats immigration as a security and capacity issue, proposing a dual strategy: aggressive removal of illegal migrants to Rwanda and strict quantitative limits on legal migration through a binding, annual, legal cap.
Conservative and Unionist Party.defence: The Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2024 outlines its key policies on defence under "Our plan to secure our nation from global uncertainty", emphasizing increased spending, modernization, global leadership, and support for veterans. Here is a summary of the key defence and security policies: 1. Defence Spending and Capability The party commits to a significant increase in financial investment to secure national interests: • Defence Spending Target: They will boost defence spending to the new NATO standard of 2.5% of GDP by 2030. This is described as the largest strengthening of UK defence since the end of the Cold War and will protect British interests at home and abroad in an increasingly hostile world. • Nuclear Deterrent: They will always be steadfast in their support for the Trident nuclear deterrent and have invested in its modernization, including a nuclear skills package worth up to £763 million by 2030. • Modernization and Technology: They plan to accelerate the modernization of the Armed Forces and invest in technology advantageous on the modern battlefield. They will scale R&D funding to a minimum of 5% of the defence budget, with an additional 2% to exploit that R&D, through the new Defence Innovation Agency. • Defence Industrial Base: They will boost the UK defence industrial base by providing the industry with the multi-year certainty needed to produce equipment quickly, including at least £10 billion of investment in munitions production (with the majority spent in the UK over the next decade). They aim to become the largest defence exporter in Europe by 2030. 2. Strategic and Global Security The manifesto positions the UK as a force for peace and stability, focusing on international alliances and responding to conflicts: • NATO Campaign: They will launch a campaign to set a new baseline of 2.5% of GDP for all NATO allies by 2030. • Support for Ukraine: They guarantee Ukraine the support it needs for the long haul, assuring current levels of support for as long as required. They will secure additional military supplies and build international agreement to use immobilized Russian assets to support Ukraine. • Global Partnerships: They will strengthen relationships with key partners, including maintaining the special relationship with the United States and investing in collective security through groups like the G7, Five Eyes, and NATO. They will also build on partnerships like AUKUS (for nuclear-powered submarines) and the Global Combat Air Programme (with Italy and Japan). • Adversaries and Hostile States: They will take action to counter the axis of authoritarian states (including Russia, Iran, and China) and hostile actors, including strengthening protections within the Foreign Influence Registration Scheme. They commit to toughening cyber defences and national security laws. • National Resilience: They will deliver a National Defence and Resilience Plan for security, preparedness, and resilience, which will integrate defence and civilian planning based on the latest assessment of threats and risks. 3. Support for Veterans and Personnel The party commits to looking after those who serve or have served: • Office for Veterans Affairs (OVA): They will maintain the OVA’s position in the Cabinet Office, led by a dedicated Minister in Cabinet, and maintain its base operating budget at £10 million throughout the next Parliament. • Veterans’ Bill: They will pass the UK’s first-ever Veterans’ Bill to enshrine Veterans’ rights in law, including ensuring qualifications from Service are correctly recognized in civilian life and widening the scope of the Armed Forces Covenant. • Financial Protections: They will bring forward measures to ensure War Pensions and Armed Forces Compensation Scheme awards are not counted as income for benefits and pensions. • Accommodation: They will improve Service Family Accommodation, ensuring military families receive the support they deserve. Overall, the defence plan is framed as securing the nation from global uncertainty through major financial investment and maintaining a strong military and diplomatic presence on the world stage.
Conservative and Unionist Party.economy: The Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2024 sets out a plan for a secure, dynamic, and growing economy. This economic strategy is founded on reducing debt, backing businesses, cutting taxes, reforming the welfare system, and ensuring an affordable energy transition. The party notes that the UK economy is recovering after global challenges, with inflation down, real wages up, and growth returned, attributing this to sticking to their plan. Here is a summary of the key economic policies outlined in the manifesto: 1. Tax Cuts and Financial Security The party’s central fiscal commitment is reducing taxes for working individuals and protecting pensioners, with a long-term ambition to eliminate the "double tax on work". • National Insurance Cuts for Employees: They plan to cut employee National Insurance by another 2p, aiming to halve it from 12% at the beginning of the year to 6% by April 2027. This is forecast to be a total tax cut of £1,350 for the average worker earning £35,000. • Abolishing Self-Employed National Insurance: The party commits to abolishing the main rate of self-employed National Insurance entirely by the end of the next Parliament. This builds on the abolition of Class 2 contributions and simplifies the tax system for 93% of self-employed people. • Pensions Protection (Triple Lock Plus): They will introduce the new Triple Lock Plus, guaranteeing that both the State Pension and the tax-free allowance for pensioners always rise with the highest of inflation, earnings, or 2.5%. This is designed to ensure the new State Pension does not get dragged into income tax for the first time in history. • Tax Guarantees: They commit to not raising the rate of income tax, VAT, or Corporation Tax. They will also not increase Capital Gains Tax. Under the Pensions Tax Guarantee, they will not introduce any new taxes on pensions, maintaining the 25% tax-free lump sum and tax relief on contributions. • Child Benefit Reform: To address unfairness, they will move the withdrawal of Child Benefit to a household income basis, setting the combined household income threshold at £120,000. 2. Debt, Borrowing, and Welfare Reform The plan emphasizes maintaining fiscal stability and reforming welfare to reduce spending: • Fiscal Rules: They will continue to meet the fiscal rules of ensuring public sector net debt is falling and that public sector net borrowing is below 3% of GDP in the fifth year of the forecast. The measures proposed are stated to be fully funded and result in lower borrowing in 2029-30. • Tackling Tax Avoidance: They aim to raise at least a further £6 billion a year from tackling tax avoidance and evasion by the end of the Parliament. • Welfare System Reform: They aim to put the welfare system on a sustainable footing by tackling the unsustainable rise in benefit claims for working-age people with disabilities or health conditions. They project these reforms will save taxpayers £12 billion a year. Reforms include tightening up capability for work assessments from September 2025 and reforming disability benefits, considering whether services might be more appropriate than monthly cash payments for some mental health conditions. • Tougher Sanctions: They will introduce tougher sanctions, allowing benefits to be removed entirely for those who refuse suitable jobs after 12 months on benefits. 3. Business, Investment, and Trade The manifesto seeks to encourage investment, innovation, and global trade: • Business Tax Incentives: They will maintain the competitive tax system, including the "full expensing" policy, and look to extend it to leasing when fiscal conditions allow. They will also maintain key tax incentives such as the Enterprise Investment Scheme (EIS), Seed Enterprise Investment Scheme (SEIS), and Venture Capital Trusts (VCTs). • Supporting SMEs: They will deliver a ten-point plan to support Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs), including easing the burden of business rates, keeping the VAT threshold under review, and improving access to finance. They will also lift the employee threshold to take more companies out of burdensome reporting requirements. • Research and Development (R&D): They will increase public spending on R&D to £22 billion a year. They will also maintain R&D tax reliefs. • Trade Deals: They commit to seizing the benefits of Brexit by signing further trade deals, including completing agreements with India and the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC). They will not agree to anything in the review of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement (TCA) with the EU that infringes on UK legal sovereignty. • Reducing Bureaucracy: They plan to make government more efficient by returning the civil service to its pre-pandemic size, halving the money spent on external consultants, and requiring all Departments to deliver plans for 2% annual productivity growth. 4. Infrastructure and Energy Investments focus on local transport and securing domestic energy supply: • Infrastructure Investment: They will spend £36 billion of savings from cancelling the second phase of HS2 on transport projects that benefit more people, including a record £8.3 billion to fill potholes and resurface roads. • Energy Security: They will legislate to ensure annual licensing rounds for North Sea oil and gas production. Within the first 100 days, they will approve two new fleets of Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) to rapidly expand nuclear power. • Cost of Net Zero: They promise a pragmatic approach, guaranteeing no new green levies or charges and ensuring existing green levies on household bills are lower in each year of the next Parliament than they were in 2023. This set of policies aims to reward hard work through tax cuts, guarantee financial security for pensioners, stabilize public finances, and back business investment to foster economic growth.
Conservative and Unionist Party.education: The Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2024 outlines its key policies on education and skills development under the plan titled "Our plan to give young people the opportunities and skills they need". The focus is on driving up standards, reforming post-16 education, increasing apprenticeships, and ensuring safety and parental involvement in schools. Here is a summary of the key policies on education and skills: 1. Primary and Secondary School Standards The party aims to build upon progress made since 2010, noting that English children are now ranked as the best readers in the Western world and 11th globally for maths. • School Funding and Staffing: They will protect day-to-day schools spending in real terms per pupil. They note there are record numbers of teachers (27,000 more than in 2010) and will attract more talent by expanding recruitment and retention premiums and reducing workload. • Teacher Recruitment: New teachers in priority areas and key STEM and technical subjects will receive bonuses of up to £30,000 tax-free over five years. These payments will also be extended to eligible teachers in further education colleges. • Disadvantaged Children: They will continue the Pupil Premium, which allocates almost £3 billion next year to support disadvantaged children. • Phonics and Maths: They will support teachers in primary schools to use proven techniques, including the world-leading phonics programme and the mastery approach to maths, to ensure every child masters the basics before secondary school. • Mobile Phone Ban: They will legislate to require schools to ban the use of mobile phones during the school day. This policy is supported by providing funding for schools that need it and is intended to boost attainment, reduce bullying, and support good behaviour. • Physical Education: Schools will be mandated to deliver two hours of PE every week in primary and secondary schools. This will be supported by extending the PE and Sport Premium to secondary schools and increasing funding for School Games Organisers to promote competitive sport. • School Attendance: They will continue efforts to improve school attendance, including providing more mental health support, and will legislate to create a register of children not in school. • Infrastructure: They are committed to rebuilding over 500 schools through the School Rebuilding Programme, including addressing every school identified to have RAAC. 2. Post-16 Education and Skills A key element of the plan is transforming 16-19 education and prioritizing technical and vocational skills over poor-quality university degrees : • Advanced British Standard (ABS): They will transform 16-19 education by introducing the Advanced British Standard, which will build on the best of A Levels and T Levels. This aims to end the "artificial and damaging divide between academic and technical education". Under the ABS, young people will spend more time in the classroom and learn more subjects, including English and maths, up to age 18. • Apprenticeships: They will fund 100,000 more high-quality apprenticeships in England every year by the end of the next Parliament. • Funding Apprenticeships: This apprenticeship expansion will be funded by curbing the number of poor-quality university degrees. They will change the law to close university courses in England with excessive drop-out rates or that leave students financially worse off than if they had not gone to university. • University Accountability: They will work with universities to ensure students receive the contact hours they are promised and that their exams are marked. • Adult Skills: They will deliver the Lifelong Learning Entitlement from the 2025 academic year, giving adults access to loans for new qualifications for flexible training, retraining, and upskilling throughout their working lives. 3. Parental Rights and Sensitive Subjects The manifesto addresses concerns regarding parental oversight and the teaching of sensitive subjects: • Right to See Materials: They will bring forward new legislation to make clear that parents have a right to see what their child is being taught in school and that schools must share all materials, especially on sensitive matters like relationships and sex education. • Gender Identity: They have updated Relationships, Sex and Health Education Guidance to introduce clear age limits on content and guarantee that the "contested concept of gender identity is not taught to children". They will also pass legislation to ensure parents have a right to know if their child wants to be treated as the opposite sex, requiring schools to involve parents in these decisions. • School Choice: They will expand strong academy trusts, protect parents’ choice regarding independent and grammar schools, and lift the cap on faith schools. 4. National Service The manifesto also includes a major policy affecting school leavers: • Mandatory National Service: They will introduce mandatory National Service for all 18-year-old school leavers, offering a choice between a year-long competitive, paid placement in the armed forces or cyber defence, or civic service (25 days a year of volunteering). This initiative is intended to build life skills and strengthen national culture and will be designed by a Royal Commission, backed by funding rising to £2.5 billion in the final year of the Parliament. The overall plan seeks to ensure that every young person has access to a world-class education, whether through academic routes, technical apprenticeships, or the new National Service program.
Conservative and Unionist Party.environment: The Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2024 outlines its key policies on the environment, climate change, and energy under the plan titled "Our plan for an affordable and pragmatic transition to net zero". This approach is characterized by a commitment to reaching Net Zero by 2050 while prioritizing affordability, energy security, and protecting the countryside. Here is a summary of the key policies on the environment and related matters: 1. Net Zero Strategy and Affordability The manifesto commits to a pragmatic path to achieve Net Zero by 2050, emphasizing cost control for consumers. • Pragmatic Approach: The party will stick to a pragmatic, proportionate, and realistic approach that eases burdens on working people. They reject "dogmatic, top-down approach[es]" that would burden households with higher bills. • Cost Guarantees: They guarantee no new green levies or charges for consumers. • Lowering Levies: They will ensure that the annual policy costs and green levies on household energy bills are lower in each year of the next Parliament than they were in 2023. • Democratic Consent: They will guarantee a vote in the next Parliament on the next stage of the net zero pathway, ensuring that the adoption of any new target is accompanied by proper consideration of the plans and policies required to meet it, thus maintaining democratic consent. • Climate Change Committee Reform: They will reform the Climate Change Committee to give it an explicit mandate to consider cost to households and UK energy security in its future climate advice. • Ruling Out Taxes: They explicitly rule out creating further green levies, road pricing schemes, and any frequent flyer levy. • Household Support: They will invest £6 billion in energy efficiency over the next three years to make around a million homes warmer. They will also fund an energy efficiency voucher scheme for every household in England to support the installation of energy efficiency measures and solar panels. • No Forced Changes: They guarantee never forcing people to rip out their existing boiler and replace it with a heat pump. 2. Energy Security and Generation Securing domestic energy supply is a major priority, particularly following global shocks : • North Sea Oil and Gas: They will legislate to ensure annual licensing rounds for oil and gas production from the North Sea. They will maintain investment allowances for the sector. • Nuclear Power: They plan to scale up nuclear power, building on the work of Great British Nuclear. Within the first 100 days of the next Parliament, they will approve two new fleets of Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) to rapidly expand nuclear power. They will also deliver a new gigawatt power plant at Wylfa in North Wales. • Offshore Wind: They will aim to treble offshore wind capacity. They will provide a bonus, on top of contract payments, to reward energy firms that invest in manufacturing in the most disadvantaged places in the UK. • Gas Power Stations: They will support the building of new gas power stations to maintain a safe and reliable energy source for days when the weather does not power renewables, prioritizing keeping the lights on. • Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS): They will build the first two CCS clusters, based across North Wales, the North West of England, Teesside, and the Humber, while progressing a second tranche of projects in Aberdeenshire and the Humber. 3. Protecting Nature and Enhancing the Environment The manifesto commits to upholding and expanding protections for nature, countryside, and water resources : • Green Belt and Land Protection: They maintain a "cast-iron commitment to protect the Green Belt from uncontrolled development". They will also protect the best agricultural land from solar farms, changing planning rules to ensure solar is located on brownfield sites and rooftops instead. • Biodiversity and Nature Targets: They are committed to halting nature’s decline by 2030 and delivering Biodiversity Net Gain. • Water Quality and Reform: They will use fines from water companies to invest in river restoration projects and create a river recovery network. They will work with the regulator to further hold companies to account, including banning executive bonuses if a company commits a serious criminal breach. They will maintain record flooding funding to protect homes, farms, and businesses. • Planting and Peatland: They will deliver tree planting and peatland commitments through the Nature for Climate funding and cut red tape to streamline processes for tree planting in suitable areas. • Ocean Protection: They will continue the moratorium on deep sea mining and ratify the Global Oceans Treaty early in the next Parliament. They will consult UK overseas territories on expanding the Blue Belt programme. • Waste and Fly-Tipping: They will crack down on organized waste crime, enhance penalties for fly-tipping (giving councils new tools to tackle offenders), and prevent new waste incinerators from being built where substantial construction has not taken place. • Planning Reform: They will introduce reforms to outdated EU red tape to better protect nature while enabling the building of new homes and energy schemes, speeding up planning systems. 4. Supporting Farmers and Rural Life Policies also focus on supporting the rural economy and food security : • Food Security Target: They will introduce a legally binding target to enhance the UK-wide food security. • Agricultural Funding: They will increase the UK-wide farming budget by £1 billion over the Parliament, ensuring it rises by inflation every year. • Flood Defences: They will maintain record flooding funding to continue protecting homes, farms, and businesses. In summary, the party frames its environmental policies as a "pragmatic" pursuit of Net Zero by investing heavily in nuclear and domestic energy sources, ensuring energy bills are kept low, while simultaneously protecting agricultural land and tackling water pollution. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Analogy: The Conservative approach to the environment and energy is like managing a car journey with the goal of reaching a sustainable destination (Net Zero by 2050) while ensuring the family budget isn’t ruined and the tank never runs dry. They rely on "home-grown fuel" (North Sea oil, gas, and nuclear power) to keep the engine running reliably today, even while investing in "cleaner tech" (offshore wind and SMRs) for tomorrow. Crucially, they refuse to install expensive new components (green levies or forced heat pumps) unless they are confident the family can afford it, favoring gradual upgrades and cost-conscious planning.
Conservative and Unionist Party.brexit: The Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2024 frames its approach to Brexit as a means to seize opportunities, solidify the UK’s sovereignty, and drive economic benefits through new trade relationships and regulatory reforms. Here is a summary of the key policies on Brexit, drawing directly from the sources: 1. Seizing the Benefits and Economic Freedoms The party commits to leveraging post-Brexit freedoms to boost the economy and cut red tape: • Trade Deals: They plan to seize the benefits of Brexit by signing further trade deals. They aim to complete Free Trade Agreements with India and the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), which is home to some of the world’s biggest investors. They will also continue to pursue agreements with countries such as Israel and Switzerland. • Infrastructure and Housing: Brexit freedoms will be used to speed up infrastructure and unblock 100,000 homes. Specifically, they plan to abolish the legacy EU "nutrient neutrality" rules to immediately unlock 100,000 new homes. • Cutting Red Tape: They aim to cut red tape for business. They have already repealed or reformed over 2,000 EU laws and plan to have repealed or reformed over half of the entire stock of EU law inherited by July 2026. Their "Smarter Regulation approach" is projected to have already saved businesses an estimated £1 billion and 50 million hours of administrative time. • Tax Freedoms: Post-Brexit tax freedoms have been used, including introducing VAT-free installations of energy-efficient materials and replacing complex EU alcohol duty rates. They will also maintain the Brexit Pubs Guarantee that ensures the duty on draught drinks (like beer and cider) is less than in supermarkets. • Speeding up Infrastructure Planning: They will introduce reforms to outdated EU red tape to better protect nature while enabling the building of new homes, prisons, and energy schemes, speeding up local and national infrastructure planning systems. 2. EU Relationship and Sovereignty The manifesto clearly defines the limits of any future relationship or review of the current agreement with the EU: • Trade and Cooperation Agreement (TCA) Review: While they will build on the TCA, they state they "will not agree to anything in the forthcoming review of the TCA that would infringe our legal sovereignty or involve submission to the CJEU or dynamic alignment". • Standing Up to the EU: They promise to take a tough approach to ensure the EU meets its commitments under the TCA and does not discriminate against UK exporters. • No Free Movement: They explicitly commit to not allowing "any form of free movement to return". • Public Services Protection: They are clear that the NHS and the services it provides "are not on the table in trade negotiations". 3. Strengthening the Union (Northern Ireland) The manifesto addresses the need to secure Northern Ireland’s place within the UK internal market post-Brexit: • Windsor Framework: They commit to faithfully implementing all commitments in the Windsor Framework and the Safeguarding the Union Command Paper. • Unfettered Access: The Framework is credited with addressing fundamental problems with the old Protocol and providing Northern Ireland with unique advantages, including guaranteed unfettered access to the UK internal market and privileged access to the EU Single Market for goods. • No Checks (GB to NI): Goods moving from Great Britain to Northern Ireland that will only ever stay in the UK are subject to "no checks", except for risk-based checks conducted by UK authorities to tackle criminality, abuse, smuggling, and disease risks. • Intertrade UK: They will establish a new Intertrade UK body to promote trade within the United Kingdom. • Internal Market Protection: They will relentlessly protect the UK’s internal market to secure Northern Ireland’s place in it and protect consumers and businesses from unnecessary trade barriers. 4. Fisheries and Agriculture Specific sectors benefiting from leaving the EU are also prioritized: • Fishing Sector: They will continue to back the fishing sector after taking back control of UK waters post-Brexit. They aim to seek additional opportunities for the inshore fleet in the 2026 negotiations. • Agricultural Standards: All imported food and drink products, including those from countries with which the UK has trade agreements, must comply with the UK’s high standards. In short, the manifesto views Brexit as a successful completed project that has delivered a record of achievement, including securing major new trade and security deals , and enabling the UK to become the fourth biggest exporter in the world. The future policy focus is on maximizing the economic and sovereign advantages gained through leaving the EU.
Conservative and Unionist Party.entire manifesto: The Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2024, titled "Clear Plan Bold Action Secure Future", outlines a comprehensive plan spanning economic, social, and security policies, with an emphasis on achieving a secure future for the nation and families by sticking to a clear plan. The key policy proposals are structured around several core plans: 1. Economy, Taxes, and Pensions The party pledges to continue efforts to stabilize the economy after challenges like Covid and the Ukraine conflict, noting that inflation is down, and growth has returned. Key fiscal policies include: • Tax Cuts for Workers: A plan to cut employee National Insurance by another 2p, aiming to halve it from 12% at the beginning of the year to 6% by April 2027. This is part of a long-term ambition to end the double tax on work. • Self-Employed Taxes: Abolish the main rate of self-employed National Insurance entirely by the end of the next Parliament. This builds on the abolition of Class 2 contributions and benefits 93% of self-employed people. • Pensions Protection: Introduce the new Triple Lock Plus, guaranteeing that both the State Pension and the tax-free allowance for pensioners always rise with the highest of inflation, earnings, or 2.5%. This ensures the new State Pension is not dragged into income tax. • Business Taxes: They commit to not raising corporation tax or Capital Gains Tax and will maintain R&D tax reliefs. They also commit to not raising the rate of income tax or VAT. • Debt Management: Continue to meet fiscal rules of having public sector net debt falling and public sector net borrowing below 3% of GDP in the fifth year of the forecast. 2. National Security and Immigration Control The manifesto stresses securing the nation from global uncertainty and controlling borders. • Defence Spending: Boost defence spending to the new NATO standard of 2.5% of GDP by 2030. • Stopping Illegal Migration: Establish a deterrent by running a relentless, continual process of permanently removing illegal migrants to Rwanda, with regular flights starting this July. They will bring the Illegal Migration Act into force and aim to clear the asylum backlog, ending the use of hotels. • Legal Migration Cap: Introduce a binding, legal cap on migration (covering work and family visas) to guarantee that numbers fall every year, while still allowing the intake of skills needed by businesses and the NHS. Parliament will have an annual vote on the level of the cap. 3. Health and Social Care The plan focuses on increasing capacity, productivity, and shifting care closer to patients. • Funding and Staffing: Increase NHS spending above inflation every year. Recruit 92,000 more nurses and 28,000 more doctors by the end of the next Parliament. • Service Delivery: Expand Pharmacy First (including for menopause support, contraception, and chest infections), which is expected to free up 20 million GP appointments annually. They plan to build or modernize 250 GP surgeries and build 50 more Community Diagnostic Centres. • Technology: Invest £3.4 billion in new technology to transform the NHS, including using the NHS App as the single front door for services and using AI to free up clinician time. • Social Care: Implement planned reforms to cap social care costs from October 2025. 4. Families, Education, and Youth Opportunities Policies aim to support families, improve childcare, and enhance opportunities for young people. • Childcare: Deliver 30 hours of free childcare a week for working parents, from when their child is nine months old until they start school (full rollout by September 2025), saving eligible families an average of £6,900 per year. • Child Benefit Reform: End the unfairness in the Child Benefit system by moving to a household income basis for withdrawal, setting the combined household income threshold at £120,000. • National Service: Introduce mandatory National Service for all 18-year-old school leavers, offering a choice between a year-long competitive military placement or 25 days a year of civic service. • Education and Skills: Fund 100,000 high-quality apprenticeships for young people, paid for by curbing the number of poor-quality university degrees. Introduce the Advanced British Standard to transform 16-19 education. Require schools to ban the use of mobile phones during the school day. 5. Housing and Infrastructure The plan commits to building homes, supporting first-time buyers, and prioritizing local transport. • Housing Targets: Deliver 1.6 million homes in England in the next Parliament. • First-Time Buyers Support: Permanently abolish Stamp Duty for homes up to £425,000 for first-time buyers. Introduce a new Help to Buy scheme offering an equity loan of up to 20% on new build homes. • Planning Reform: Abolish legacy EU "nutrient neutrality" rules to immediately unlock 100,000 new homes. Commit to protecting the Green Belt. • Local Transport Investment: Invest £36 billion saved from cancelling the second phase of HS2 into local roads, rail, and buses. This includes a record £8.3 billion to fill potholes and resurface roads. • Backing Drivers Bill: Introduce legislation to stop road pricing, reverse the London Mayor’s ULEZ expansion, and require local referendums for new 20mph zones and Low Traffic Neighbourhoods. 6. Energy and Net Zero The party seeks an affordable and pragmatic path to net zero by 2050. • Energy Security: Legislate to ensure annual licensing rounds for North Sea oil and gas production. Scale up nuclear power, approving two new fleets of Small Modular Reactors within the first 100 days. • Cost Control: Guarantee no new green levies or charges and ensure green levies on household bills are lower than they were in 2023. • Efficiency: Invest £6 billion in energy efficiency over the next three years to make around a million homes warmer. 7. Safer Streets and Justice Policies are aimed at recruiting more police and imposing tougher sentencing. • Policing: Recruit 8,000 more full-time, fully warranted police officers dedicated to neighbourhood policing. • Anti-Social Behaviour: Roll out Hotspot Policing to cut anti-social behaviour. Legislatively ensure social tenants who repeatedly disrupt neighbours can be evicted. • Sentencing: Toughen sentencing for the worst offenders, including making life imprisonment without parole mandatory for more heinous murderers and requiring rapists and other serious sexual offenders to spend the whole of their sentences behind bars. • Counter-Terrorism: Urgently introduce Martyn’s Law to ensure premises are better prepared for terrorist attacks. 8. Welfare Reform The plan seeks to make the welfare system fairer and more sustainable, aiming to save taxpayers £12 billion a year. • Disability Benefits: Reform disability benefits, such as PIP assessments, to better target genuine needs and consider whether treatment or services, rather than a monthly cash payment, might be more appropriate for some mental health conditions. • Work Capability: Tighten up how the benefits system assesses capability for work from September 2025, ensuring those with moderate issues are given tailored support to engage with the world of work. • Sanctions: Introduce tougher sanctions so people who refuse to take up suitable jobs after 12 months on benefits can have their cases closed and their benefits removed entirely. Analogy The Conservative manifesto presents itself like a household financial plan: it focuses on cutting expenses (taxes and green levies), investing heavily in non-negotiable insurance (defence and NHS staffing), and strictly vetting who gets to live there (controlling immigration), all while aiming to quickly build enough infrastructure (1.6 million homes and local roads) to support its current residents.

Scottish National Party (SNP).crime: The SNP manifesto focuses on a few key areas related to crime, justice, and security, primarily through a public health lens for the drug crisis and in relation to international cooperation and safety measures. Here is a summary of the key policies on crime and justice: Drug Death Crisis and Public Health • The SNP plans to tackle the drug death crisis by adopting a radical public health approach. • This approach includes decriminalizing drugs for personal use. • The party will introduce a framework to allow Supervised Drug Consumption Facilities. • They also call for the devolution of powers to the Scottish Parliament to allow them to go further in reducing harm and improving lives in Scotland. International Justice and Security • The sources note that Brexit resulted in the loss of access to one of the world’s most sophisticated and integrated international justice and crime-fighting ecosystems. • Rejoining the EU would lead to a safer Scotland by allowing the country to work closely with police in the EU to help fight cross-border crime, serious organised crime, cyber crime, and terrorism. Domestic Safety and Security • The SNP MPs will press the UK Government to introduce "Martyn’s Law" without delay to ensure venues and councils have preventative plans in place against terror attacks. • They will also push the UK Government to focus on countering disinformation and misinformation and better protecting national critical infrastructure. • The party emphasizes the protection of people, particularly children, by ensuring the Online Safety Act comes into force on time. SNP MPs will press the UK Government to ensure tech firms cannot escape their responsibilities for the content on their platforms through full enforcement of the Act and prompt strengthening of these laws when required. Justice for Victims • The manifesto demands that the UK Government deliver justice for Post Office Horizon victims, ensuring compensation is paid at pace to all sub postmasters who suffered miscarriages of justice. The party specifies that the vast majority of payments should be made by the end of 2024. • They also pledge to work with the UK Government to provide justice for Infected Blood victims, ensuring any compensation scheme works effectively for everyone infected or affected and is delivered without delay. Funding Emergency Services • The SNP will call on the UK Government to refund the £175 million in VAT owed to Scotland’s emergency services so that this money can be invested in vital emergency services. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The SNP’s approach to the drug death crisis is akin to treating a complex illness—like a chronic condition requiring specialized medical care—rather than simply applying a punitive punishment. By advocating for decriminalization and Supervised Drug Consumption Facilities, the party aims to shift the focus from criminal justice to public health, mirroring strategies used successfully in certain medical interventions.
Scottish National Party (SNP).healthcare: The SNP manifesto emphasizes the protection and enhancement of Scotland’s National Health Service (NHS), positioning independence as the ultimate means to secure its future funding and operation. Here is a summary of the SNP’s key policies on healthcare and related public health matters: Protecting and Funding the NHS • Protecting the NHS from Privatization: SNP MPs will demand that the UK Government protect the NHS from Westminster privatization through their proposed "Keep the NHS in Public Hands" Bill. This Bill aims to ensure the health service remains a publicly owned and operated service and would prevent any UK government from undermining the NHS principles and protections as part of any future trade deals. • Increased UK Funding Demand: The SNP will demand significant financial investment from the UK Government into NHS England, which would subsequently boost the Scottish NHS budget via the Barnett formula. ◦ They call for a minimum £10 billion extra each year to address inflationary pressures and improve performance, which would generate an additional £1 billion annually for NHS Scotland. ◦ They demand the UK Government match Scotland’s NHS pay deals by increasing investment in NHS England staff pay and conditions by at least £6 billion. This would deliver around £600 million for Scotland to invest in pay deals for hardworking NHS staff. ◦ Combined, these funding increases would generate a £1.6 billion annual funding boost for Scotland’s NHS. • Reversing Capital Cuts: The party demands the reversal of the £1.3 billion cut to Scotland’s capital budget, which pays for hospitals, roads, and schools, enabling investment in new hospitals. • Current Performance and Investment: The SNP notes that funding for Scotland’s NHS has more than doubled under their administration, and NHS staffing is at a record high, with far more doctors and nurses per head in Scotland than in England. The SNP Scottish Government is determined to go further, including investing £300 million to drive down waiting times, despite constraints imposed by Westminster. Addressing Workforce Shortages • Standing up for the Workforce: SNP MPs will call for the reversal of the recent decision by the Conservatives to stop care workers from overseas bringing their families with them to the UK. This is due to concerns that these vital workers are necessary to prevent increased shortages and suffering among the most vulnerable. • Impact of Brexit: The manifesto highlights that the end of freedom of movement due to Brexit has made it much harder to recruit staff to work in the NHS, social care, and other vital sectors. Public Health and Social Care • Tackling the Drug Deaths Crisis: The SNP will take a radical public health approach to the drug deaths crisis. This includes advocating for the devolution of powers to the Scottish Parliament to reduce harm and improve lives. Specifically, they would decriminalize drugs for personal use and introduce a framework to allow Supervised Drug Consumption Facilities. • Abortion and Healthcare: The SNP is clear that all women should have access to abortion services safely and timely. They urge the UK Government to follow Scotland’s lead in reviewing the law on abortion to ensure it is treated primarily as a healthcare matter. • Smoking and Gambling: The manifesto calls for the reintroduction of UK-wide legislation to create a smoke free generation and a recommitment to banning single-use vapes, following the lead of the SNP Scottish Government. They also believe that problem gambling should be treated as a public health matter and call for the urgent introduction of a Gambling Levy. • Free Services: The SNP Scottish Government has supported households by protecting free prescriptions, personal care, and eye tests for all. • Infected Blood Victims: The SNP will work with the UK Government to ensure any compensation scheme for victims of infected blood works effectively for everyone infected or affected and is delivered without delay. Addressing Austerity and Westminster Decisions The overall context for the NHS policies is the party’s belief that the NHS faces twin threats of Westminster privatization and austerity. They argue that independence is the means to address concerns over the funding of the NHS by building a stronger economy. Until independence, SNP MPs will work to protect Scotland’s NHS and oppose further austerity imposed by Westminster.
Scottish National Party (SNP).housing: The SNP manifesto details several policies related to housing, focusing on mitigating the cost of living crisis, increasing affordable housing stock, and reversing Westminster cuts that impact infrastructure investment. Here is a summary of the key policies on housing: Addressing the Housing Emergency and Cost of Living • Tackling the Housing Emergency: The SNP identifies a housing emergency caused by decades of Westminster underinvestment, the consequences of a hard Brexit, and a £1.3 billion cut to the Scottish Government’s capital budget from the UK Government. • Reversing Capital Budget Cuts: The party demands that the UK Government restore the cut to the Scottish Capital Budget to help tackle the housing emergency. Investment and Construction • Affordable Housing Delivery: The SNP Scottish Government reports that it has already delivered over 128,000 affordable homes. Furthermore, the sources state that the SNP Scottish Government has built 40% more affordable homes per head than in England, and over 70% more than in Wales. • Construction VAT Reform: The SNP advocates for the reform of VAT to address the imbalance in VAT rates in the construction sector. This is intended to encourage the refurbishment and retrofitting of existing buildings. • RAAC Remediation Fund: The manifesto calls for the introduction of a RAAC Remediation Fund to make new capital money available. This fund would allow necessary action to be taken to tackle the problem of ageing Reinforced Autoclaved Aerated Concrete (RAAC) in the public sector. Rent and Housing Support • Mitigation of UK Policies: The SNP Scottish Government has taken actions within its limited powers, including supporting people with housing costs and introducing temporary rent cap controls. • Bedroom Tax: The SNP Scottish Government has mitigated the UK Government’s bedroom tax in full. SNP MPs will continue to call on the UK Government to scrap the cruel bedroom tax which penalizes people claiming Universal Credit or housing benefit if they have a spare room in their rented council or housing association home. • Local Housing Allowance (LHA): SNP MPs at Westminster will push for an annual uplift of the Local Housing Allowance, while ensuring rental costs are adequately taken into account. • Devolution of Housing Support: The party demands the devolution of Housing Benefit and Local Housing Allowance. This would allow the Scottish Government to adopt an innovative approach to tackling child poverty, expanding the delivery of social housing, and helping to fund and encourage investment in house building. Helping First-Time Buyers • Help to Buy ISA: The SNP proposes to reintroduce a simplified Help to Buy ISA scheme to assist first-time buyers. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- In essence, the SNP views housing provision as a priority that is currently being hampered by Westminster cuts to capital funding and by restrictive welfare policies like the bedroom tax. They aim to secure greater investment and devolved powers (like control over Housing Benefit) to enhance their ability to build affordable homes and better support tenants.
Scottish National Party (SNP).immigration: The SNP manifesto outlines several key policies concerning immigration, focusing on mitigating the negative effects of Brexit and demanding the devolution of powers to allow Scotland to implement a tailored migration system. Here is a summary of the policies on immigration: Devolution and Bespoke Migration System • The SNP demands the devolution of powers to create a bespoke migration system for Scotland. • This bespoke system would value those who choose to work, live, study, and invest in Scotland. • The goal of devolution is to allow Scotland to address its specific demographic and economic needs. • Until full devolution of immigration powers is achieved, including overseas workers’ employment visas, the UK Government must acknowledge the distinct demographic challenges Scotland faces. Addressing Labour Shortages and Brexit Impacts • The end of freedom of movement due to Brexit has made it much harder to recruit staff to work in the NHS, social care, and other vital sectors. • The SNP will push the UK Government to mitigate the harm of Brexit on productivity by reviewing immigration rules and expanding shortage occupation lists, ensuring businesses have access to the workforce they need. • Rural Visa Pilot Scheme: The party urges the UK Government to introduce a rural visa pilot scheme to mitigate against labour shortages caused by a hard Brexit and hostile immigration policies. • Care Workers: SNP MPs will call for the reversal of the recent decision by the Conservatives to stop care workers from overseas bringing their families with them to work in the UK, as these workers are vital to prevent increased shortages and suffering among the most vulnerable. Asylum and Refugee Policy • The SNP will scrap the morally repugnant Rwanda scheme. • The party will continue to strongly oppose the policy of no recourse to public funds. • SNP MPs will urge the UK Government to grant asylum seekers the right to work. • They also call for a fundamental change in the approach to housing asylum seekers, ensuring that accommodation is safe, suitable, and dignified. • The party supports extending the eligibility to vote to all residents, including international students and those with refugee status, as is the case in Scotland. International Cooperation and Free Movement • The SNP aims to rejoin the EU and reverse the damage of Brexit, which includes restoring free movement for EU citizens. • Rejoining the EU would deliver freedom of movement to live, visit, study, and work freely in any EU country. • It would also provide access to workers from across the EU, enabling many of Scotland’s industries to grow. • The SNP urges the UK Government to agree to an EU-wide youth mobility scheme, which both the Conservatives and Labour have previously rejected, to provide young people with opportunities to live, work, and study in the EU.
Scottish National Party (SNP).defence: The SNP’s policies regarding defence, as outlined in the sources, focus primarily on nuclear disarmament, investment in conventional forces and public services, and specific provisions for armed forces personnel and veterans. Key defence and security policies include: Nuclear Disarmament and Conventional Defence Funding • The SNP’s stance is to Scrap Trident (the UK’s nuclear deterrent). • They oppose the retention or renewal of Trident. • They will press the UK government to meet its international obligations on nuclear disarmament. • The billions spent funding these "immoral weapons" should be invested instead into adequately funding conventional defence and public services, such as the NHS and schools. Armed Forces and Personnel • The SNP will urge the UK Government to raise the military recruitment age to 18, phasing out the recruitment of people under 18 in line with international standards. • They prioritize the needs of the Armed Forces and Veterans community. • They have long campaigned for an Armed Forces Representative Body to accommodate the wide range of needs, concerns, and identities within the Forces Community. • They believe it is vital that the UK Government prioritize employment, social inclusion, health and wellbeing for veterans and their families. • Following the approach of the SNP Scottish Government, they support veterans by ensuring the War Disablement Pension is exempt from the assessment of income for veterans who require social care services. International Affairs and Security • The SNP seeks to strengthen Scotland’s security by pushing the UK to focus on countering disinformation and misinformation. • They also advocate for better protecting national critical infrastructure, improving supply chain resilience, and strengthening the UK’s ability to rebound from a shock or crisis. • They will press the UK Government to ensure "Martyn’s Law" is introduced without delay to ensure venues and councils have preventative plans in place against terror attacks. Regarding specific international conflicts: • Ukraine: The SNP continues to strongly oppose the Russian invasion. They will continue to back military support from the United Kingdom to Ukraine and press the UK Government to ensure the sanctions regime against Russia is effective. • Gaza/Israel: They demand an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, the release of hostages, and ending arms sales to Israel. They call on the UK Government to immediately recognise Palestine as an independent state, viewing this as the only path toward a just and durable long-term peace.
Scottish National Party (SNP).economy: The SNP manifesto frames its economic policies around achieving independence, reversing austerity, mitigating the damage caused by Brexit, and promoting investment in a fairer, greener economy. The core belief is that the Westminster economic system is broken and has failed the people of Scotland. Here is a summary of the SNP’s key economic policies: Independence, Brexit, and Economic Control • Core Goal: Independence is the vital necessity and means of addressing economic concerns, including the cost of living and funding for the NHS. With independence, all key decisions over the economy, taxes, and spending will transfer from Westminster to Scotland. • Failed UK Economy: The UK economy is described as broken, having delivered stagnant wages and low living standards compared with similar countries. Independent countries comparable to Scotland (like Denmark, Sweden, and Ireland) have used the decision-making powers of independence to achieve higher national income per head, lower inequality, higher productivity, and lower levels of poverty. • Reversing Brexit Damage: Brexit is viewed as an economic disaster that has wiped billions of pounds from the Scottish economy, pushed up prices on food and services, and worsened the cost of living crisis. ◦ The SNP aims to rejoin the EU and re-enter the single market, restoring free movement for EU citizens. ◦ Rejoining the EU would deliver cheaper and quicker trading for businesses and provide access to workers from across the EU, enabling many industries to grow. Ending Austerity and Public Spending • Ending Austerity: The SNP will deliver independence to strengthen the economy and end 14 years of austerity, reversing deep damaging cuts to public services. They will stand against the Westminster consensus on continued cuts. • Demanding Increased Investment: The party demands that the UK Government bring forward an immediate emergency budget after the election to reverse public spending cuts and deliver meaningful investment in economic growth. • Mitigating Cuts: The SNP notes that the Scottish Government has done all it can to mitigate the "callous cuts" imposed by Westminster, but is constrained by limited economic and financial levers. Fiscal Rules and Infrastructure Investment • Reversing Capital Cuts: The manifesto demands the UK Government reverse the £1.3 billion cut to the Scottish capital budget. This cut, coupled with high inflation, places unprecedented pressure on the infrastructure budget and has restricted the growth of the Scottish economy. ◦ Restoring this money is vital to invest in new hospitals, schools, rail, and road infrastructure, and to help achieve net zero. • Scrapping and Implementing New Fiscal Rules: The SNP calls on the UK Government to scrap its current fiscal rules that "choke off borrowing for investment". • Proposed New Fiscal Rules: The party proposes sensible alternative fiscal rules to enable increased capital investment: 1. A Public Sector Net Worth rule, recognizing the value of investing in infrastructure and public sector assets. 2. An Upper limit on debt servicing costs, to allow explicit consideration of the sustainability of the stock of debt. 3. Three-year detailed spending plans, to improve clarity for devolved administrations. Taxation Policy • Devolution of Tax Powers: The SNP demands the full devolution of tax powers to enable the creation of a fairer system that protects public services and invests in the economy. • Progressive Tax System: The SNP Scottish Government reports delivering the fairest and most progressive income tax system in the UK, raising an additional £1.5 billion to invest in public services. • Specific Devolution Demands: ◦ Devolution of National Insurance so that rates and thresholds fit Scotland’s progressive income tax rates. ◦ Devolution of windfall taxation for companies operating in Scotland to tackle the cost of living and climate crises. ◦ Devolution of road tax and fuel duty to develop a new approach to funding road travel. • Tax Reform: The SNP supports the reform of VAT to address current imbalances. Specific proposals include: ◦ Introducing a lower rate of VAT for hospitality and tourism sectors to drive economic growth. ◦ Addressing the imbalance in VAT rates in the construction sector to encourage the refurbishment and retrofitting of existing buildings. ◦ Removing VAT from on-street electric vehicle charging. ◦ Ending the VAT exemption for private schools (with full powers). Cost of Living and Welfare The SNP aims to tackle the cost of living crisis and improve living standards. Key actions include: • Essentials Guarantee: Legislate for an essentials guarantee to ensure everyone can afford basic necessities like food and utilities. • Benefit Caps: Scrap the two child benefit cap and the associated rape clause. • Support for Workers: Scrap exploitative zero hours contracts and ban callous "fire and rehire" practices. • Energy Costs: Press for a significant cut in standing charges for all and removal of standing charges for anyone with a prepayment meter. Green Economy and Energy • Green Economy Investment: The SNP demands the UK Government invest at least £28 billion a year in the green economy to deliver a step change in public and private investment. • Just Transition: Demand that the new UK Government match Scotland’s £500 million Just Transition Fund for the North East and Moray. • Energy Devolution: Demand the devolution of powers over energy regulation, pricing, and production to fully harness Scotland’s vast renewable energy sources and ensure they best serve the needs of the Scottish people. • Oil and Gas: Decisions on new oil and gas licenses must be made on a rigorously evidence-led, case-by-case basis, consistent with climate obligations and energy security considerations, through a robust climate compatibility assessment. • Grangemouth: Stress the need for the UK Government to invest in a sustainable future for the Grangemouth complex, recognizing its importance to Scotland’s economy and retaining the skilled workforce during the transition.
Scottish National Party (SNP).education: The SNP manifesto contains specific policies regarding education, primarily focusing on maintaining the current system in Scotland and leveraging EU cooperation for future generations. Here is a summary of the key policies on education: Defending Free Education • The SNP is the only party that will defend free university tuition in Scotland. • Protecting free education means that graduates in Scotland are thousands of pounds better off. Investment and Resources • The party demands the reversal of the £1.3 billion cut Westminster imposed on Scotland’s capital budget, which pays for schools, hospitals, and rail infrastructure. • The SNP will scrap Trident and invest the money into public services, including schools. • The SNP Scottish Government has extended free school meal provision and cancelled school meal debt. • The Scottish Government has also expanded free childcare, which is reported to save families £5,500 annually. International Opportunities (Rejoining the EU) • Rejoining the EU would lead to re-entry to the Erasmus+ scheme, which would widen educational opportunities for Scotland’s future generations. • The SNP urges the UK Government to agree to an EU-wide youth mobility scheme so that young people can benefit from the opportunities that living, working, and studying in the EU can bring. Democratic Access to Education • The SNP supports extending the eligibility to vote to all residents, including all international students, as is the case in Scotland.
Scottish National Party (SNP).environment: The SNP manifesto presents several policies focused on the environment, climate change, and the transition to a greener economy, often linking these goals to the benefits of independence and devolved powers.
