Here is a summary of the key policies on the environment: Climate Goals and Funding • Climate Ambition: The SNP’s commitment to tackling the twin crises of climate change and nature loss is unwavering, and they believe emissions reduction and economic prosperity go hand in hand. • Net Zero Target: Scotland must reach net zero by 2045 for the whole of the UK to reach net zero by 2050. • Green Economy Investment: The SNP demands that the UK Government invest at least £28 billion a year in the green economy to deliver a step change in public and private investment in net zero and major investment in the domestic supply chain. • Reversing Capital Cuts: The party demands the reversal of the £1.3 billion cut to the Scottish capital budget to enable investment in infrastructure and help to achieve net zero. Energy Policy and Devolution • Devolution of Powers: The SNP demands the devolution of powers over energy regulation, pricing, and production to fully harness Scotland’s vast renewable energy sources and ensure they best serve the needs of the Scottish people. ◦ With full powers, they could make changes to the electricity grid system, including reducing fees for Scottish producers to connect, which currently holds back renewable energy development. • Renewable Energy Focus: The SNP believes the best pathway to net zero and secure, affordable, and clean energy is through significant growth in renewables, storage, hydrogen, and carbon capture. • New Nuclear Power: The party will rule out new nuclear power plants in Scotland. • Hydrogen Potential: SNP MPs will press for the UK Government to secure progress with direct interconnection between Scotland and the continent and regulatory agreement to unlock Scotland’s hydrogen export potential. • Modernizing Support: They will push the UK Government to modernise the Contracts for Difference scheme to enable the stable deployment of Scotland’s renewable energy pipeline. • Equity Stake in Energy Projects: They demand the UK Government seek an equity stake in future energy projects. The return on this investment for the taxpayer would be used to directly benefit the Scottish people by protecting jobs, growing the green economy, and lowering energy bills. Just Transition and Fossil Fuels • Just Transition Fund: The SNP demands the new UK Government match Scotland’s £500 million Just Transition Fund for the North East and Moray to help build on the region’s expertise, create jobs, and deliver a fair and managed transition to net zero. • Oil and Gas Licensing: The UK Government, as the decision-maker on new oil and gas licenses, must ensure any further extraction is consistent with climate obligations and takes due account of energy security considerations. Decisions must be made on a rigorously evidence-led, case-by-case basis, through a robust climate compatibility assessment. • Grangemouth: The SNP stresses that the UK Government must invest in a sustainable future for the Grangemouth complex to retain the skilled workforce and protect jobs during the transition to greener technologies. • Coal: The manifesto states the party will ban new coal licences, following the lead of the SNP Scottish Government. Land, Biodiversity, and Resource Management • Fair Funding for Climate: The UK Government must ensure fair funding flows to devolved nations to enable climate ambition, especially considering Scotland has over two thirds of the UK’s peatland and currently plants over 60% of trees in the UK. • Marine Funding: The SNP demands that the UK Government give Scotland its rightful share of marine funding—specifically, the party claims Westminster shortchanged funding after Brexit, allocating only £14 million instead of the £62 million Scotland was entitled to. • Agriculture and Fishing: They call for the UK Government to increase funding for farming to at least pre-Brexit levels and provide multi-annual funding frameworks. They also prioritize Scotland’s unique fishing needs and call for meaningful engagement on the post-Brexit trade agreement review. Decarbonizing Transport • Zero-Emission Transport: SNP MPs will promote a fair and affordable transition to zero-emission transport fuels and ban the import and sale of new, non zero-emission buses by 2025. • Cleaner Vehicles: They will push the UK Government to establish a new Low Income EV Car Leasing Fund, backed by at least £500 million, to enable 50,000 EV leases a year for low-income families. • VAT Removal: They advocate for the removal of VAT from on-street electric vehicle charging. National Cooperation • The SNP calls for the establishment of a Four Nations Climate Response Group to agree on climate plans across the UK that deliver on net-zero targets and ensure the UK Government stops backtracking on climate ambition.
Scottish National Party (SNP).brexit: The Scottish National Party (SNP) holds strongly negative views on Brexit, asserting that it has been a "disaster for Scotland". Their policy goal is to reverse the damage caused by the UK’s departure from the European Union (EU). Here is a summary of the SNP’s views and policy commitments regarding Brexit: Core Stance and Consequences of Brexit • Opposition to Brexit: Scotland voted overwhelmingly to remain in the EU but was "dragged out against [its] will" and is currently "powerless to escape the consequences". • Economic Damage: Brexit has wiped billions of pounds from the Scottish economy compared with EU membership. It is cited as a factor that has made the cost of living crisis worse by pushing up food prices and other household costs. The UK economy is described as having failed. • Damage to Public Services and Recruitment: The negative consequences of Brexit include hitting the ability to fund vital public services such as the NHS. The end of freedom of movement has made it much harder to recruit staff for the NHS, social care, and other vital sectors. • Security Concerns: Scotland has lost access to one of the world’s most sophisticated and integrated international justice and crime-fighting ecosystems. • Democratic Overriding: Westminster’s imposition of Brexit undermined the Scottish Parliament, which the people of Scotland voted overwhelmingly for, while simultaneously imposing something they voted overwhelmingly against. The UK Internal Market Act, enacted post-Brexit, has reduced the powers of the Scottish Parliament and allowed the UK Government to override Scottish democracy. • Political Consensus: The SNP argues that the "Westminster conspiracy of silence between Labour and the Conservatives" on the damage of Brexit demonstrates why decisions about Scotland’s future should be taken in Scotland. They stress that ignoring Brexit is ignoring the cost of living, the economy, and the views of Scotland. Policy to Reverse Brexit and Rejoin the EU The SNP’s long-term goal for Scotland is to rejoin the EU as an independent country. They commit to: 1. Rejoin the EU and re-enter the Single Market: The SNP will push to reverse the damage of Brexit and re-enter the single market. 2. Restore Free Movement: They aim to restore free movement for EU citizens. 3. Independence as the Vehicle: The SNP champions the vision of an independent Scotland in the EU, stating that independence is the means to regain what has been lost as a result of a hard Brexit. Expected Benefits of Rejoining the EU Rejoining the EU would deliver several specific benefits, according to the SNP : • Trade and Business: Cheaper and quicker trading for businesses. • Labour and Migration: Access to workers from across the EU, enabling many industries to grow , and freedom of movement to live, visit, study, and work freely in any EU country. • Education: Re-entry to the Erasmus+ scheme, widening educational opportunities. • Rural Sectors: More funding for farming, fishing, and other rural sectors. • Security: A safer Scotland, working closely with police in the EU to help fight cross-border crime, serious organized crime, cyber crime, and terrorism. • Culture: Access to the Creative Europe scheme, supporting the culture sector and boosting the economic potential of creative industries. Mitigation Efforts (Until Independence) While working towards independence, SNP MPs at Westminster will push for specific measures to mitigate the immediate harms of Brexit: • Farming and Fishing: Demand increased funding for farming to at least pre-Brexit levels , agree a veterinary agreement with the EU to ease exports and imports, and demand Scotland’s rightful share of marine funding. • Immigration: They seek the devolution of powers to create a bespoke migration system for Scotland to address demographic and economic needs. They will also push the UK Government to introduce a rural visa pilot scheme to mitigate labour shortages resulting from a hard Brexit and hostile immigration policies. • Workers: Demand the UK Government review immigration rules and expand shortage occupation lists to give businesses access to the necessary workforce. • Young People: Press the UK Government to agree to an EU-wide youth mobility scheme, which they note was rejected by both the Tories and Labour. The SNP views Brexit as intrinsically linked to the current austerity measures and the cost of living crisis, concluding that only independence will free Scotland from these negative impacts and allow them to build a more successful economy comparable to independent European nations.
Scottish National Party (SNP).entire manifesto: The SNP manifesto centers its key policies around the belief that decisions about Scotland should be made in Scotland through independence, which they view as the means to address concerns over the cost of living and the funding of the NHS. Here is a summary of the manifesto’s key policy areas: Independence and Constitutional Goals • Independence: The core goal is for Scotland to become an independent country. If the SNP wins a majority of Scottish seats, the Scottish Government will be empowered to begin immediate negotiations with the UK Government to give democratic effect to Scotland becoming an independent country. • Devolution of Powers: Demand the permanent transfer of legal power to the Scottish Parliament to determine how Scotland is governed, including the power to legislate for a referendum. They also demand the devolution of new borrowing powers to invest in a just transition and the full devolution of tax powers. • Rejoining the EU: Rejoin the EU, reverse the damage of Brexit, re-enter the single market, and restore free movement for EU citizens. • Constitutional Reform: Support the abolition of the undemocratic House of Lords. • Defense: Scrap Trident and invest the money into conventional defense and public services, such as the NHS and schools. Economic Policy and Tackling Austerity • Ending Austerity: Deliver independence to strengthen the economy and end 14 years of austerity, reversing deep damaging cuts to public services. SNP MPs will stand against the Westminster consensus on cuts and demand increased investment in vital public services. • Capital Budget: Reverse the £1.3bn Westminster cut to the Scottish capital budget, enabling investment in new hospitals, schools, rail, and road infrastructure. • Fiscal Rules: Call on the UK Government to scrap their current fiscal rules to allow greater investment in infrastructure and public services. They propose new fiscal rules, including a Public Sector Net Worth rule and an upper limit on debt servicing costs. • Taxation: Demand the full devolution of tax powers to create a fairer system. They support reforming VAT, including introducing a lower rate for hospitality and tourism sectors, and removing VAT from on-street electric vehicle charging. They also advocate for the devolution of windfall taxation for companies operating in Scotland. Protecting the NHS and Public Services • NHS Protection and Funding: Protect Scotland’s NHS from the twin threats of Westminster privatization and austerity. They call on the UK Government to back their Bill to keep the NHS in public hands. • NHS Investment: Demand the UK Government boost NHS England funding by at least £16bn each year, which would provide an extra £1.6bn to NHS Scotland. They also call for matching Scotland’s NHS pay deals (generating around £600m for Scotland). • Education: Defend free university tuition in Scotland. • Justice: Tackle the drug death crisis by taking a radical public health approach, including decriminalizing drugs for personal use and introducing a framework to allow Supervised Drug Consumption Facilities. Cost of Living and Welfare • Essentials Guarantee: Legislate for an essentials guarantee ensuring that everyone can afford basic necessities like food and utilities. • Benefit Caps: Scrap the two child benefit cap, ending the suffering caused by the benefit cap on children and the associated rape clause. • Pensions and Compensation: Protect pensions by maintaining the triple lock and move to deliver a wellbeing pension. They will oppose any further increases in the state pension age. They also pledge to stand up for WASPI women by ensuring the UK Government delivers full, fast, and fair compensation for pension inequality. • Energy Costs: Press for a significant cut in standing charges for all and removal of standing charges for anyone with a prepayment meter. Workers’ Rights and Migration • Employment Rights: Demand the devolution of employment rights and the minimum wage. They will empower workers by scrapping exploitative zero hours contracts and banning callous "fire and rehire" practices. • Maternity/Parental Leave: Increase paid maternity leave to one year and increase shared parental leave from 52 to 64 weeks. • Migration: Demand the devolution of powers to create a bespoke migration system for Scotland to address specific demographic and economic needs. They will scrap the Rwanda scheme and stand firm against the demonization of migrants. They also propose a rural visa pilot scheme. Climate and Energy • Green Economy: Demand the UK Government match Scotland’s £500 million Just Transition Fund for the North East and Moray. • Renewables: Demand the devolution of powers over energy regulation, pricing, and production. They will rule out new nuclear power plants in Scotland. • Oil and Gas: Decisions on new oil and gas licences must be made on a rigorously evidence-led, case-by-case basis through a robust climate compatibility assessment. They stress the importance of securing a sustainable future for Grangemouth and retaining the skilled workforce. • Coal: Ban new coal licences. International Policy • Gaza/Palestine: Demand an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, the release of hostages, and the ending of arms sales to Israel. They call on the UK Government to immediately recognize Palestine as an independent state. • International Aid: Immediately restore and maintain the UK international aid budget to 0.7%. • Ukraine: Stand by Ukraine and continue to support Ukrainians who have settled in Scotland.

Plaid Cymru.crime: Plaid Cymru’s policies on crime and justice emphasize the full devolution of justice powers to Wales, proper funding for policing, prioritizing victims, and reforming approaches to drug use, women offenders, and protests. Here is a summary of the key policies regarding crime and justice: Devolution and Governance Plaid Cymru champions the transfer of full justice powers to Wales, arguing that it is necessary to create a distinct Welsh approach to policing and criminal justice. • Full Transfer of Justice Powers: Plaid Cymru supports the complete transfer of justice powers to Wales, a recommendation made by three independent commissions, including the Thomas Commission on Justice in Wales and the Independent Commission on the Constitutional Future for Wales. • Minister of Justice: Following devolution, a Minister of Justice would be created within the Welsh Government, who would be accountable to the people of Wales, not Westminster. • Abolish Police and Crime Commissioners: A Plaid Cymru government would review the governance of criminal justice in Wales and remove the role of elected Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs), as the Minister for Justice would assume accountability. • Justice for All: Plaid Cymru believes everyone should have access to justice within their local community, and supports piloting a "courts in the community scheme" to resolve local justice needs and help reduce the backlog of court cases. They would also provide additional help to prevent legal aid "deserts". • Devolution Benefits: Devolving the criminal justice system would enable better collaboration between prisons and services already devolved (such as health and housing), which could reduce homelessness upon release and improve health provision. Policing and Funding The party seeks to ensure Welsh police forces are properly funded and transparent: • Fair Police Funding: While policing remains under Westminster control, Plaid Cymru will argue that policing must be properly funded to prevent crime and convict criminals. They point out that Wales currently receives less than its fair share of police funding per head of population, which forces local people to increase the council tax policing element just to maintain services. • Cardiff Funding: Additional funding should be provided to Cardiff, recognizing its status as a capital city and the security arrangements required for higher profile events, as already happens in other UK capitals. • Transparency: Plaid Cymru supports legislation requiring police officers to declare memberships of clubs, societies, and organizations to ensure transparency and public confidence in policing. • Rural Crime: To address the rise in rural crime, the party would work to create a specialist all-Wales rural crime team, aiming to recruit officers from the farming community, building on work already done by PCCs in North Wales and Dyfed-Powys. • Compensation for Policing Costs: Plaid Cymru believes Dyfed-Powys Police should be compensated by Westminster for the cost (£1m+) of policing protests at Llanelli’s Stradey Park Hotel related to a misguided UK Government plan that was later dropped. Victims and Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG) Plaid Cymru places victims at the center of justice services: • Victims Commissioner for Wales: Plaid Cymru would create a Victims Commissioner for Wales to represent victims of crime, stand up for their rights, and prevent them from being forgotten. The Commissioner could also help increase the number of successful convictions for crimes against women and girls. • Preventing VAWG: The party recognizes the challenges in the criminal justice system to ensure women and girls are believed and receive justice. Measures include: ◦ Creating a Domestic Abuse Register to enable the early identification of abusive men, shifting responsibility away from potential victims (unlike Clare’s Law). ◦ Stopping abusers from harassing victims through court proceedings and strengthening restraining orders and sanctions for breaching them. ◦ Ensuring that convictions related to sexual images are always based on consent rather than intent to close legal loopholes. ◦ Increasing sentences for domestic violence and stalking offenses. ◦ Mandating specialist stalking training for all professionals dealing with stalking cases and a unified recording system across justice agencies. Prisons, Rehabilitation, and Female Offenders Wales has the highest imprisonment rate in Western Europe despite lacking control over criminal justice policy. Plaid Cymru seeks reform: • Opposing Private Prisons: Plaid Cymru does not support private prison provision, believing it is a state responsibility. They are alarmed by the deaths and criticisms at HMP Parc, a privately-run facility, and believe it should be brought back under full public control. • Focus on Rehabilitation: Sentencing policy should prioritize what prevents criminals from re-offending and being a danger to the public. This includes using community-based sentences for low-risk offenders and investing in community-based prevention and rehabilitation. • Fairness for Women in Justice: Most women serve short custodial sentences outside of Wales, which impacts family travel, Welsh language provision, and community connections. Plaid Cymru will focus on reducing crime by addressing the underlying reasons women become involved in criminal behavior and reviewing the effectiveness of short prison sentences for female offenders. • Women’s Centres: Plaid Cymru aims to establish four community-based women’s centers across Wales (north-west, north-east, south-west, and south-east) to support female offenders, working with Police and Crime Commissioners to achieve this. • Probation and Prison Staff: The party supports Napo’s calls for a strategic reduction program for the probation service, ensuring safe and manageable workloads. They will also address staff retention issues in the prison and probation services by reducing the prison officer pension age from 68. • Neurodiversity Support: Better support will be provided for people with ADHD transitioning through and leaving the prison system, including training for all prison staff in ADHD awareness and appropriate medication care plans. Drug Policy and Protest Rights Plaid Cymru supports treating drug policy as a public health issue and protecting non-violent protest: • Drugs Policing: Policing should focus on targeting supply lines and dealers in organized trade, rather than individual users who are not causing wider harm. Users should be supported to stop their addiction. • Public Health Approach: The party views drugs policy as a matter of public health and supports introducing drug consumption rooms across Wales to facilitate a more humane and sustainable approach to addiction. • Decriminalization: Plaid Cymru believes that introducing a policy of soft drugs decriminalisation could better target policing resources toward organized groups who profit from misery. • Criminal Records: They recommend the UK Home Office cleansing the criminal records of those cautioned or convicted of drug possession where there are no further aggravating factors. • Right to Protest: Plaid Cymru supports non-violent protest as an important democratic mechanism and the right to freedom of expression and assembly. They would repeal the Conservative UK Government legislation that unfairly restricts opportunities for non-violent protest, specifically mentioning the relevant parts of the Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Act 2022 and the Public Order Act 2023. They also support legislation that makes it a criminal offence for elected politicians to knowingly mislead the public. Plaid Cymru’s ambition for criminal justice is essentially to move the system’s locus of control from Westminster to Cardiff, enabling a tailored, needs-based approach—much like equipping a ship captain with navigational instruments and control over the rudder, rather than relying on distant headquarters, to better manage local waters.
Plaid Cymru.healthcare: Plaid Cymru’s policies on healthcare, outlined under the banner of "Fair Play for Patients," center on principles of funding the NHS according to Wales’s needs, expanding the workforce, establishing a National Care Service, and implementing specific strategies for public health challenges like cancer and neurodiversity. Here is a summary of the key healthcare policies: Funding and Principle of Care • Free at Point of Delivery: Plaid Cymru strongly believes in the principle of healthcare free at the point of delivery, funded through general taxation. • Opposing Privatisation: They oppose the privatization of services "by stealth through out-sourcing". They believe that profits currently made by private agencies should be re-invested into healthcare. • Needs-Based Funding: They will work to ensure the NHS is properly funded through a new fairer and needs-based funding model for Wales, replacing the outdated Barnett Formula. • Fair Funding from Westminster: They demand fair funding from Westminster to enable investment in the NHS workforce. Workforce and Recruitment The party prioritizes staff and aims to improve recruitment and retention: • GP Recruitment: Plaid Cymru will reverse the significant reduction in the number of GPs over the past decade. They plan to restore funding for GPs to 8.7% of the Welsh health budget and recruit an additional 500 GPs across Wales, noting this is a "two-term pledge" due to the time needed for recruitment and training. • Wage Restoration: They stand in solidarity with healthcare professionals taking industrial action on pay and wage restoration, believing these pledges must be implemented quickly to value staff and boost recruitment and retention. • Flexible Contracts: They would move toward an improved working contract for nurses, making contracts more flexible to reflect other responsibilities, such as caring and learning, and recruit more nurses. • Apprenticeships: They support increasing the availability of degree apprenticeships in the healthcare sector to provide greater opportunities for young people to enter the profession and remain working in Wales. • Agency Spending: They note that better workforce planning and recruitment to permanent posts will save money currently spent on high levels of agency staff. Social Care and Welfare Plaid Cymru aims to integrate social care with healthcare: • National Care Service: Plaid Cymru is committed to establishing a National Care Service for Wales. They believe social care, like health care, should be free at the point of use, viewing the distinction between the two as artificial. Ending this distinction is also intended to help reduce Delayed Transfers of Care (DToC). • Care Worker Pay: They will pay social care workers at least £1 above the Real Living Wage, and ensure this is index-linked, aiming to make the job more attractive and improve recruitment. • Ending Profit in Children’s Services: They are committed to consulting on the elimination of profit in children’s services provision, working towards the gradual expansion of direct provision in both children’s and adult services. • Family Carers and Visits: They advocate for the right of people to be supported by their family carers and seek clarity that it is a human right for family visits to care homes to support patients with dementia. • Visa Restrictions: They oppose restrictions on visas for care workers and dependents, viewing them as counter-productive to recruitment needs. Specific Health Strategies and Conditions Plaid Cymru proposes targeted action for various health issues: • Cancer Strategy: They would introduce a "Stop Cancer Strategy" to ensure cancers are caught and treated earlier. Key measures include: ◦ Ensuring no downgrading of urgent suspected cancer referrals. ◦ Lowering the sensitivity threshold for bowel cancer screening. ◦ Increasing rates of lung cancer screening. ◦ Investing in the workforce to recruit, train, and retain more oncology staff. ◦ Focusing on prehabilitation to better prepare people for treatment. ◦ Supporting the creation of a national register of Barrett’s oesophagus in Wales. • Neurodiversity: They would ensure that support is made available as soon as an individual presents themselves as neurodiverse (through referral or self-referral), to address long waiting lists for diagnosis. • Public Health: They believe public health should move toward becoming a "wellness service" geared toward keeping people healthy. This preventative strategy aims to rebalance resources to prevent people from becoming ill earlier than necessary. • Dental Care: Plaid Cymru would open a new dental school in Bangor as part of the new medical school to train more dentists and would scrap dental charge increases. • Long Covid: They recognize the significant number of people affected by Long Covid and state that appropriate support must be provided. • Gastrointestinal Conditions: They will reduce delays to diagnosis for Crohn’s and Colitis, coeliac disease, and IBS by implementing the national primary diagnostic pathway for lower gastrointestinal symptoms. • Respiratory Health: Noting that Wales has the highest level of respiratory deaths in Western Europe, they will deliver an improvement plan to improve the lives of people living with lung conditions. Governance, Safety, and Other Services • NHS Governance: Plaid Cymru will review NHS governance to strengthen oversight and accountability, focusing on small but significant cultural changes, streamlining targets, clarifying accountability, and recruiting specialist managers. They support a regulatory body for Senior Health Managers. • Covid Inquiry: They believe there should be a Wales-specific Inquiry into Covid to understand decisions made by the Labour Welsh Government and their impacts, as the UK-level Inquiry cannot cover this in necessary detail. • Patient Safety: They support the recommendations from the infected blood scandal Inquiry, including a duty of candour for all public servants and full compensation for those affected. They also support compensation and a duty of candour for mesh patients and those harmed by valproate, as proposed in the Hughes Report. • Air Ambulance: They want to see the continuation of the current Air Ambulance provision at Welshpool and Caernarfon, alongside a rapid response vehicle on the A55. • Community Pharmacies: They will support changes in legislation on drug tariffs to address rising prices and review the supply chain to ensure patients receive medication when needed. Plaid Cymru views healthcare reform as intrinsically linked to achieving full financial and constitutional control over Wales, believing that securing fair, needs-based funding (rather than relying on the Barnett Formula) is the necessary foundation to effectively invest in and improve health and social care services.
Plaid Cymru.housing: Plaid Cymru’s housing policies are rooted in the belief that every individual has the right to a safe and affordable home in their community, and they intend to introduce a Right to Adequate Housing to underpin this goal. The policies focus on significantly increasing housing supply, tackling homelessness, addressing the impact of second and holiday homes, and reforming the private rental sector and planning system. Here is a summary of the key housing and planning policies: Increasing Housing Stock and Supply The primary objective is to significantly expand the availability of suitable housing, particularly social housing, across Wales. • Significant Expansion of Stock: The manifesto calls for a significant expansion in the amount of social and municipal housing stock. Increasing this stock is also viewed as a policy that would help tackle private rental sector rent rises. • Building Council Housing: Plaid Cymru supported ending the Housing Revenue Account Subsidy Scheme, which led to local authorities being able to build council housing once again. They will support local authorities and housing associations to develop further housing as quickly as possible. • Delivery Plan: Plaid Cymru will develop a plan to deliver this significant expansion to meet local housing needs across all parts of the country, utilizing a mixture of public and private funding streams. • Community Needs: When planning new developments, they will ensure the needs of the local community for healthcare, education, and transport are factored in, along with sufficient green space and local play facilities. • Demand for Specific Properties: They recognize there is a huge demand for one and two-bed properties, as well as bungalows for an aging population, which developers currently fail to build. Tackling Homelessness The party aims to end homelessness by increasing housing stock and implementing proven models: • Ending Homelessness: Plaid Cymru has prioritized tackling homelessness in the Senedd and will look to end homelessness using the Housing First model and rapid rehousing. • Recognizing Hidden Homelessness: They recognize that the challenge extends beyond those sleeping rough or in temporary accommodation, including people staying with friends and family. • Empty Properties: They have campaigned to increase council tax premiums on long-term empty or unused properties. Funds raised from these premiums have been used to fund grants to increase the supply of affordable homes. They state there is "no good reason why so many properties are left empty". Addressing Second Homes and Holiday Homes Plaid Cymru advocates for measures to ensure local people can afford to live in the communities where they were raised. • Cap on Second Homes: They support a package of actions to tackle the challenge of second and holiday homes, including introducing a cap on the number of second and holiday homes within a community. • Registration and Change of Use: They support giving local authorities the power to require registration of a change of use for a property turning into a holiday home. • Closing Loopholes: They are looking to close loopholes that allow holiday homes to "pretend to be legitimate lettings businesses" to protect genuine self-catered accommodation. • Council Tax Premium: They note that many local authorities have already introduced a council tax premium on second homes, with the additional funds used towards developing social housing for local residents. Private Rental Sector and Planning Reform Plaid Cymru seeks to make renting affordable and overhaul the planning system to prioritize community needs over developer interests. • Fair Rents and Rent Control: Within the private rental sector, they believe in a system of fair rents and rent control so that housing is affordable to local people on local incomes. • Market Interventions: Their proposed Right to Adequate Housing Bill would include powers to introduce rent controls and other market interventions to make housing more affordable. • Planning System Reform: They believe the current planning system is outdated and often leaves communities "at the mercy of large developers who build executive homes for profit". • Prioritizing Local Needs: They will reform the planning system to be consistent with local needs and aspirations, ensuring that developments reflect up-to-date information on housing need. • Enforcement: They support funding packages to assist local government to robustly enforce planning decisions to ensure developers adhere to agreements. • Local Development Plans: They will ensure that Local Development Plans are not imposed upon local planning authorities without their support. Construction and Local Economy Plaid Cymru’s "Unnos" policy aims to link house-building with supporting the Welsh economy and skills: • Welsh Construction Industry: The "Unnos" policy aims to support the Welsh construction industry by creating centres of excellence in both new construction and retrofitting existing housing stock. • Local Supply Chains: They will work to develop Welsh local supply chains and skilled labour so that profits from the Welsh house-building industry are retained in Wales, rather than exported by large "volume" housebuilders. In essence, Plaid Cymru views housing as a fundamental right that requires government intervention, similar to how a public library system ensures equal access to books. By enforcing a "Right to Adequate Housing" and aggressively increasing affordable stock and regulating private markets, they aim to ensure the housing supply serves the social needs of Welsh communities rather than merely the profit interests of developers.
Plaid Cymru.immigration: Plaid Cymru’s policies on migration and asylum are focused on reversing what they describe as a "hostile environment" created by the Conservative UK Government, upholding international commitments, and seeking greater powers for Wales to manage its own migration needs. Here is a summary of the key policies on migration and asylum: Asylum and Refugee Policy Plaid Cymru strongly opposes the current UK Government’s approach and advocates for a humane and effective system: • Opposing Hostile Policies: Plaid Cymru strongly oppose the Conservative UK Government’s proposals and attitudes towards asylum seekers and refugees, including the deportation to Rwanda and the general "hostile environment" created. • Upholding Commitments: They believe the UK should uphold the commitments made when it signed up to the Refugee Treaty in 1951. • Repeal Hostile Legislation: They support the repeal of previous punitive legislation that forms part of the hostile environment, specifically mentioning the Nationality and Borders Act 2022 and the Illegal Migration Act 2023. • Safe and Humane Processing: They assert that the UK Government has failed to provide safe routes for asylum seekers and has deliberately failed to process claims quickly, effectively, and humanely, leading to deaths at sea and unnecessary misery. • Effective Management: Effective management of the asylum process could allow processing to take place prior to reaching the UK in a third country, or at British embassies or consulates abroad. A program showing the likely outcome of an asylum application would also help manage the process. • Proportionate Dispersal: The responsibility for asylum seekers and dispersal should be proportionate across the UK. • Family Reunification: They support a family reunification scheme for those caught up in the conflict in Gaza, with a clear right to return to their homeland when safe to do so. Wales as a Nation of Sanctuary Plaid Cymru aims to secure the ability for Wales to fully realize its ambition to be a Nation of Sanctuary: • Nation of Sanctuary: Wales should have the powers and resources to fulfill its pledge to become a Nation of Sanctuary. • Opposition to Increased Barriers: They oppose Conservative proposals to increase the skilled worker and family visa threshold, as well as fee increases. • Ending "No Recourse to Public Funds": Plaid Cymru believes changes should be made to the system, including the ending of the "No Recourse to Public Funds" clause and ending the inability to work while awaiting decisions, as these unnecessarily force people into poverty. • Welcoming Migrants: They emphasize that migrants play an important role in Welsh society, contributing to many occupations, especially social care and healthcare, and their contributions should be welcomed, not criticized. Devolution of Migration Powers The party seeks greater constitutional control over migration to meet Wales’s economic needs: • Greater Powers: Plaid Cymru believes that, similar to Quebec in Canada, Wales should have greater powers over migration. • Shortage Occupation List and Visa Schemes: This should include the ability for Wales to determine its own Shortage Occupation List and granting the Welsh Government the ability to manage its own visa schemes. • Retaining the Graduate Route Visa: They support the Migration Advisory Committees’ recommendation that the graduate route visa be retained. They are concerned that current proposals regarding this visa would detrimentally affect Welsh universities (such as Bangor and Aberystwyth) and local communities where universities are major employers. European Context • Freedom of Movement: Plaid Cymru believes that Wales would be best served by re-joining the European Union at an appropriate point in time, and notes that Freedom of Movement has been "damagingly denied" since leaving the EU. Plaid Cymru frames its immigration policy as a necessary correction to damaging Westminster policies, aiming to install a humane, efficient system that respects international law while simultaneously granting Wales the autonomy to manage migration flows in a way that supports its critical public services and higher education sector.
Plaid Cymru.defence: Plaid Cymru’s policies on defense and foreign affairs focus on promoting peace, opposing nuclear weapons, reforming arms sales, and ensuring better support for veterans. They also assert the need for the Senedd to have a consultative role in UK military decisions. Here is a summary of the key policies on defense: Nuclear Weapons and Spending • Opposition to Trident: Plaid Cymru opposes the Trident nuclear weapons system and its renewal. They note that the renewal is estimated to cost more than £200 billion. • Alternative Spending: They support the view that if defense spending is required, it should be better used on conventional defense and peaceful ends, rather than weapons of mass destruction. • Nuclear Treaty Support: They support the United Nations Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons. • Opposing Defence Increases: They oppose increasing defense spending. Military Action and Arms Sales • Consultation on Military Action: Plaid Cymru believes that the Senedd should be consulted before the UK Government decides to engage in military action. • Arms Export Review: They demand a review of the arms export control system and a clear statement of intent to withdraw from the international arms supply trade. • Withholding Licenses: They believe the UK should withhold licenses to sell arms to countries which have poor human rights records, or where there is credible evidence that the weapons will be used for the repression of their own populations or in violation of international law. • Promoting Peace: Plaid Cymru supports peaceful and negotiated outcomes to all conflict. Support for Veterans • Improved Support: Veterans require substantially improved support upon leaving armed service and returning to civilian life. • Medical Discharge Review: Plaid Cymru calls for an independent review of the medical discharge process. • Income Disregard: They propose introducing an income disregard for the War Pensions and Armed Forces Compensation Scheme so that these payments are not considered as income when calculating benefits and pensions.
Plaid Cymru.economy: Plaid Cymru’s economic policies are founded on the principle that Wales must secure full financial and economic control to move away from stagnation and widespread deprivationPlaid Cymru’s economic policies are founded on the principle that Wales must secure full financial and economic control to move away from stagnation and widespread deprivation caused by decades of Westminster rule. The manifesto sets out comprehensive plans for fair funding, tax reform, industrial strategy, devolution of key resources, and support for Welsh businesses and workers. Here is a summary of Plaid Cymru’s key economic policies: Fair Funding and Fiscal Control Plaid Cymru asserts that the UK Government’s economic policies have been "economically very damaging" for Wales. The party demands structural changes to how Wales is funded and governed: • Securing £4 Billion from HS2: Demand the £4 billion owed to Wales from the HS2 high-speed rail project, which is deemed an England-only project. This money would be invested in improving public transport across the country and reversing cuts to local bus services. • New Needs-Based Funding: Demand a fair funding system for Wales, replacing the outdated Barnett Formula, to fund the country according to its needs, rather than proportionate to spending on England’s needs. • Full Control of Economic Levers: Plaid Cymru believes Wales should have full control of economic levers to grow and "green our economy" in a way that positively impacts communities. • Tax Devolution: They want the Senedd to have powers to set income tax bands and thresholds, as is done in Scotland, to create a system that fits Wales’s circumstances. Tax Reform Plaid Cymru advocates for a fairer tax burden, primarily falling on those with the "broadest shoulders" : • Equalizing Capital Gains Tax: Plaid Cymru would equalize capital gains tax with income tax, which is estimated to raise between £12 billion and £15 billion. • Increased Windfall Taxes: They seek to increase windfall taxes on sectors that have substantially increased profits due to market conditions, such as oil and gas producers and energy companies, and will close existing loopholes used to avoid these taxes. They promote renewable energy investment as an alternative. • Wealth Tax and High Earners: They support investigating the introduction of a wealth tax and increasing National Insurance contributions for higher earners. • Closing Loopholes: They would crack down on tax evasion and avoidance, and abolish loopholes for non-doms. • Bankers’ Bonuses: They would re-introduce the cap on bankers’ bonuses. Industrial Strategy and Key Sectors The party supports interventionist policies to support key Welsh industries and transition to a green economy: • Port Talbot Steelworks: Plaid Cymru opposes Tata’s plans for closure and urges the UK Government to nationalise the Port Talbot steelworks. If the UK Government fails to act, the Welsh Government should explore compulsory purchase options while developing future options for green steel production. They believe Wales needs to retain the ability to produce primary steel. • Welsh Green New Deal: They will create a Welsh Green New Deal to generate rewarding, meaningful, and fair work in emerging sectors, including re-skilling Welsh employees. • Just Transition Commission: They will establish a Just Transition Commission as part of the move toward net-zero. • Measuring Success: In the run-up to the 2026 Senedd elections, they will set new targets for the Welsh economy to measure the impact of policy decisions through outcomes rather than process. Devolution of Natural Resources and Finance Plaid Cymru aims to take control of key Welsh assets to build domestic wealth and prosperity: • Crown Estate Devolution: They will ensure Wales takes full control over the Crown Estate in Wales, which has already been devolved to Scotland. • Sovereign Wealth Fund: Profits from the Crown Estate (especially from energy projects in Welsh waters) would be invested in a Sovereign Wealth Fund for Wales for future generations. • Control over Energy and Water: They seek "full control over energy powers" without UK Government limits, including expanding the national energy company, Ynni Cymru, to develop community-owned renewable energy. They also seek to fully align the Senedd’s legislative competence over water with the geographical boundary of Wales. • Development Agency for Wales: They will establish a fit-for-purpose National Development Agency for Wales. • Development Bank Reform: They will reform the Development Bank of Wales, aiming for it to take greater equity shares in emerging businesses and invest in infrastructure projects, acting more like a real national development bank. They will also ensure the Welsh Government has the power to develop a community bank. Supporting Welsh Business and Workers • Business Rates Reform: They support reforming Non-Domestic Rates (Business Rates) in Wales to better support small businesses, reversing reductions in support and amending the multiplier to help high street businesses like retail and hospitality. • Local Procurement: They will work towards a target of 75% of Welsh public sector spend being with companies located in Wales, promoting local supply chains and investment. • Co-operative Models: They will promote co-operative, employee, and community ownership models, particularly in green industries and communities where private capital is unwilling to invest. • Workers’ Rights: They support the devolution of employment law. At the UK level, they would reverse the Tories’ anti-strike legislation, outlaw "fire and re-hire" tactics, abolish compulsory zero-hours contracts, and establish the right to "disconnect" (not to be routinely contacted about work outside normal hours). They also propose an apprenticeship living wage and support for colleges to reduce financial burdens on students. • European Union: They believe the UK should re-enter the European Single Market and Customs Union at the earliest opportunity to mitigate the negative impact of Brexit on Welsh business. • Digital Infrastructure: They would seek to invest in digital infrastructure to guarantee a high-speed connection to every home and business in rural and valley areas, supporting flexible working and Welsh businesses in global markets. Plaid Cymru’s economic vision is centered on the transfer of power and resources to Wales, viewing the lack of self-governance as the primary inhibitor to economic success and fairness. Their plan aims to switch the national economy from one characterized by "all risk and no reward" under Westminster to one of controlled, needs-based investment and wealth retention.
Plaid Cymru.education: Plaid Cymru views education as the key to Wales’s future, aiming to create a system where both learners and the workforce can thrive. The policies focus on reducing the cost of education, investing heavily in the workforce, reforming post-16 learning, supporting the Welsh language, and ensuring fair funding. Here is a summary of Plaid Cymru’s key policies on education: Cost of Education and Access Plaid Cymru aims to eliminate financial barriers to learning: • Universal Free School Meals: Plaid Cymru will continue to campaign for universal free school meals for all secondary school learners (Years 7 to 11), building on the successful roll-out in primary schools which the party secured. This ensures all children receive a nutritious meal every day. • Reducing School Costs: They stress the importance of reducing the cost of the school day for families, including expenses related to transport, uniforms, and extra-curricular activities, ensuring no learner misses out on opportunities due to their family’s financial position. • Education Maintenance Allowance (EMA): The party helped secure the extension of the EMA. Workforce and School Investment The party plans to invest in teachers and support staff to enhance service delivery: • Securing Fair Funding: By securing fair funding for Wales, Plaid Cymru will ensure schools are resourced to provide the education and support learners need. • Recruitment and Retention: They will invest in the workforce, ensuring teachers and support staff are supported and valued to improve both recruitment and retention. Specifically, they aim to recruit and retain 5,000 teachers and support staff. • Teacher Incentives and Workload: This includes reviewing all bursary schemes to incentivize teachers and help fill recruitment gaps, and working with teaching unions to reduce bureaucracy and workload. • Support Staff: They would appoint more non-teaching staff to deal with pupil needs beyond education and develop a more attractive and formalized career pathway for teaching assistants. • Curriculum Review: They will conduct a review of Initial Teacher Education and Continuing Professional Development to assess their relevance to the demands of the new curriculum. • Specialist Support: Investment will be made in Additional Learning Needs (ALN) provision and mental health support. • School Safety: Prioritizing the safety of both learners and staff, they believe investment in the workforce will create a safer learning environment for all, actively working to stamp out bullying, racism, and homophobia. • Reviewing ALN Act and Curriculum: Reviewing the implementation of the new Curriculum for Wales and the Additional Learning Needs Act is essential to ensure consistency in education and support across Wales, which includes providing the necessary training and resources to the workforce. Private School Reform Plaid Cymru advocates for ending taxpayer support for private fee-paying schools: • Scrapping Charitable Status: They would scrap the charitable status of private fee-paying schools. • Taxation: They would charge VAT on fees and remove the exemption from business rates for these schools. Early Years and Welsh Language Education The party has an ambitious vision for Welsh-medium early years provision: • Vision for Meithrin Cymru: Their vision is for a national and free Welsh-medium early years education and childcare service, Meithrin Cymru, providing high-quality provision for children aged 12 months until they are eligible for full-time education. • Childcare Workforce: This requires investment in the childcare workforce, including offering free Welsh language learning opportunities in the English-medium sector so they can participate in the scheme. • Welsh Language Education Act: They believe there should be a Welsh Language Education Act working towards universal Welsh medium education. • Fluency Targets: They aim to ensure all children have access to quality Welsh language teaching to enable them to achieve fluency through their school life. • Multilingualism: They support the goal that all learners should leave school able to speak both Welsh and English fluently, as well as at least one other language. The decline in learners taking Welsh or modern languages at A level is a concern. Post-16 and Higher Education Plaid Cymru seeks to reform vocational training and increase university access: • Vocational Education: They will place vocational education on the same foundations as academic learning in school and university. • Lifetime Learning Allowance: They propose creating a Lifetime Learning Allowance for training or retraining, consisting of grants, loans, and a right to free provision. This includes offering a grant of £5,000 to the Personal Learning Accounts of every individual over 25 to train or retrain, with additional loans available to cover costs. They plan to trial this first with those who have been recently made redundant. • Free University Education: Their ambition remains to make University education free again for all. They will work with Universities to develop a plan to make them financially viable to achieve this goal. • Supporting Welsh Universities: They recognize the crisis in the higher education sector and warn it is in need of urgent support. They will work to expand the numbers studying at Welsh universities. • Coleg Cymraeg Cenedlaethol: They will continue to support and increase funding for the Coleg Cymraeg Cenedlaethol to fund and promote higher and further education through the medium of Welsh, and recruit and train a bilingual workforce. • Seren Programme: They will review the Seren programme to increase access for learners from disadvantaged backgrounds and better align it with opportunities offered by Welsh Higher Education Institutions. • R&D Funding: They seek to devolve Wales’s share of UK Research and Innovation expenditure and allocate a block grant based on population for investment in Research and Development. Plaid Cymru’s approach treats education not just as a service but as an investment, aiming to remove financial barriers (like school meal costs and future tuition fees) and bolster the workforce, similar to meticulously preparing the soil and providing proper tools to ensure every single seed can grow into a thriving plant.
Plaid Cymru.environment: Plaid Cymru’s policies on the environment and climate crisis prioritize constitutional change to gain full control over natural resources, ambitious net-zero targets, and an interventionist approach to energy generation and infrastructure, ensuring a "just transition" for Welsh communities. Here is a summary of the key policies on the environment and energy: Climate and Nature Emergency Commitments Plaid Cymru recognizes the gravity of the climate and nature crises and sets ambitious targets: • Net-Zero Target: Plaid Cymru reaffirms its commitment to reaching net-zero targets in Wales by 2035. • Reversing Biodiversity Decline: The party commits to reversing biodiversity decline by 2030. The Senedd, following a Plaid Cymru debate in 2021, was the first parliament in the UK to declare a nature emergency. • Science-Led Plan: They support a science-led plan aligned with the 2022 Kunming-Montreal: Plaid Cymru reaffirms its commitment to reaching net-zero targets in Wales by 2035. • Reversing Biodiversity Decline: The party commits to reversing biodiversity decline by 2030. The Senedd, following a Plaid Cymru debate in 2021, was the first parliament in the UK to declare a nature emergency. • Science-Led Plan: They support a science-led plan aligned with the 2022 Kunming-Montreal agreement to ensure that nature loss is firmly in reverse as soon as possible. • Planning Alignment: Planning projects must have regard to the two emergencies (climate and nature) to avoid situations like wind farms being built on landscapes that provide habitats for endangered species. • Curriculum: The school curriculum should equip young people with an understanding of climate challenges and encourage engagement with climate change and the natural world. Devolution of Natural Resources and Energy Control A central plank of Plaid Cymru’s environmental policy is securing full control over Wales’s natural assets: • Full Control of Natural Resources: They believe the people of Wales should have full control over all of their natural resources, waters, and lands. • Energy Independence: They seek energy independence for Wales to achieve a fair green transition on Wales’s own terms. • Devolution of Energy Powers: They demand full control over energy powers, without any upper limit or conditions set by the UK Government. The current 350MW limit results in two planning regimes, allowing major energy developments to be consented by Westminster without Welsh consent. • Crown Estate Devolution: Plaid Cymru will ensure Wales takes full control over the Crown Estate in Wales (which has already been devolved to Scotland). ◦ Profits from Crown Estate energy projects in Welsh waters should be returned to Wales and invested in a Sovereign Wealth Fund for Wales for future generations. ◦ These projects should be developed for the needs of Wales, rather than extraction, and align with local supply chains. • Water Control: Full control of water in Wales would allow the Senedd to set higher environmental targets on water quality and lower prices. They would enact Section 48(1) of the Wales Act 2017 to align the Senedd’s legislative competence over water with the geographical boundary of Wales, and formally request powers over the licensing of sewage. Energy Generation and Fossil Fuels Plaid Cymru advocates for renewable energy development and opposes harmful practices: • National Energy Company: They support expanding the role of the national energy company, Ynni Cymru, to develop community-owned renewable energy generation across Wales. This is intended to serve the needs of the Welsh people, help take control of natural resources, and lower energy bills. • Grid Reform: They would push for changes to how the National Grid is structured so communities can directly benefit from local energy projects. They note that underinvestment in the grid is creating bottlenecks and hindering carbon reduction targets. • Opposition to Fossil Fuels: Plaid Cymru opposes the development of new sites for nuclear power stations and oil and gas drilling. They would maintain the ban on fracking, oppose proposals for gas-fired peaking plants, and oppose new open cast coal mines. • Preserving Natural Landscape: Large-scale industrial energy generation developments should consider the preservation of Wales’s natural landscape. They insist on alternative methods for linking renewable energy to the national grid, such as the undergrounding of cables, instead of large-scale pylons. Dealing with the Legacy of Mining and Energy Costs • Coal Tip Clearance: They will push for Westminster to pay towards clearing the coal tips that litter the valleys, as they benefited from the mining industry before devolution. Site restoration should not be financed through further coal extraction. • Reducing Energy Charges: They note that Welsh households, despite Wales producing more energy than it uses, have higher standing charges than in England, and they would look to reduce these charges. • Social Tariff: They want to see the introduction of a Social Tariff for Energy. • Retrofitting and Efficiency: They support a plan for retrofitting existing properties to make them more energy efficient, reducing costs and carbon emissions. This requires government support and investment in a skilled workforce. • Alternative Heating: They support removing the tax on renewable liquid fuels (like Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil, which reduces carbon emissions by almost 90%) to make them more affordable for rural households where renewable technologies like heat pumps are unsuitable. Planning, Finance, and Enforcement • Community Voice: They would push for changes to planning policies to give local communities a greater voice and ownership in determining local developments. • Air Passenger Duty: They will increase Air Passenger Duty and kerosene tax for private jets. • Business, Human Rights and Environment Bill: They would introduce this bill to mandate that private companies conduct due diligence in their supply chains to prevent environmental harms (and human rights abuses). • Stronger Enforcement: There should be stronger enforcement for the protection of Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSIs) in Wales to prevent illegal dumping. Plaid Cymru’s environmental policy aims to seize control of Wales’s energy and water resources, much like a landowner taking back management of their estate’s forests and rivers to ensure sustainable, ethical, and locally beneficial usage, rather than allowing external actors to extract wealth and create long-term pollution burdens.
Plaid Cymru.brexit: Plaid Cymru’s policies on Brexit focus on recognizing the damage caused by the process and advocating for the UK to re-enter the European Single Market and Customs Union as soon as practical, while seeking eventual re-joining of the European Union. Here is a summary of the policies related to Brexit: • Recognition of Failure: Plaid Cymru campaigned in 2016 for Wales to remain in the European Union, recognizing the social and economic benefits of membership. However, the party respected the result of the referendum. They now explicitly recognize the failure of Brexit and assert that the hard Brexit pursued by both Theresa May and Boris Johnson undermined the UK’s international trade. • Re-entry to Single Market and Customs Union: Plaid Cymru believes that the UK should re-enter the European Single Market and Customs Union at the earliest opportunity. This move is intended to mitigate the impact of Brexit on Welsh business and reduce overheads and administrative costs. This will also help improve trade with European neighbors, including the Republic of Ireland, assisting Welsh ports such as Holyhead and Fishguard. • Re-joining the European Union: Plaid Cymru maintains the belief that Wales would be best served by re-joining the European Union at an appropriate point in time. • Freedom of Movement: They note that Freedom of Movement has been "damagingly denied" since leaving the European Union. • Participation in European Programmes: Wales should be enabled to participate in pan-European programmes to support its university and creative sectors in particular. • Governance and Consultation: Until the UK re-joins the Single Market and Customs Union, the Welsh Government should participate fully in the structures governing the current EU-UK relationship, established under the Withdrawal and Trade and Co-operation Agreements. Wales should be at the table whenever decisions are made about and for the nation. • Funding Replacement: Plaid Cymru demands that decisions around the distribution and use of the Shared Prosperity Fund, which replaced European Structural Funds, should be made by the Welsh Government, not by the UK Government at Westminster. • Trade Deals: They note that Westminster’s post-Brexit trade deals have allowed more cheap imports to undermine domestic markets (specifically affecting farming). Plaid Cymru will give Wales a veto over future trade deals that undermine Welsh agricultural communities.
Plaid Cymru.entire manifesto: The Plaid Cymru manifesto, "For Fairness, For Ambition, For Wales," sets out a vision for a fairer, more ambitious future for Wales, prioritizing self-governance, economic reform, and improved public services. The key policies focus on securing better funding from Westminster, addressing economic and social inequalities, and further devolution, with independence highlighted as the ultimate goal to achieve real fairness and ambition. Here is a summary of the manifesto’s key policy areas: Fair Funding and Constitutional Reform Plaid Cymru advocates for Wales to have full control over its own affairs, ultimately as an outward looking independent nation. Key constitutional and financial demands include: • Securing £4 Billion from HS2: Demand the £4 billion owed to Wales from the HS2 high-speed rail project (which is deemed an England-only project) to invest in improving public transport across the country and reversing cuts to local bus services. • New Needs-Based Funding Model: Demand a fair funding system for Wales, replacing the outdated Barnett Formula, to fund the country according to need, not population. This is necessary to invest in public services. • Devolution: Support the transfer of further powers to the Senedd, including criminal justice, broadcasting, natural resources (water and energy), railway infrastructure, the Crown Estate, and welfare. • Abolishing the Secretary of State for Wales: Remove this role, transferring remaining powers to the Welsh Government, as the role currently acts as "Westminster’s voice in Wales, not Wales’s voice in Westminster". • Senedd Referendum Power: Believe that the power to call a referendum on the constitutional future of Wales should lie with the Senedd, not the UK Government. Economy and Taxation The party aims to redress economic unfairness and gain full control of economic levers : • Tax Reform: Seek to introduce a fairer tax system by equalising capital gains tax with income tax (raising between £12bn and £15bn), investigating introducing a wealth tax, increasing higher earners’ National Insurance contributions, closing tax loopholes, and abolishing non-dom status. • Windfall Tax: Increase windfall taxes on companies that have substantially increased profits due to market conditions (such as oil and gas producers and energy companies), while promoting renewable energy investment. • Crown Estate Devolution: Ensure Wales takes full control over the Crown Estate in Wales (already devolved to Scotland), creating a Sovereign Wealth Fund for Wales to invest profits in future generations. • Port Talbot Steelworks: Oppose Tata’s plans for closure and urge the UK Government to nationalise the Port Talbot steelworks. Failing this, the Welsh Government should explore compulsory purchase. • European Union: Re-enter the European Single Market and Customs Union at the earliest opportunity to mitigate Brexit’s impact on Welsh business. • Supporting Welsh Business: Reform Non-Domestic Rates (Business Rates) to better support small businesses. Work towards a target of 75% of Welsh public sector spend being with companies located in Wales. • Workers’ Rights: Reverse the Tories’ anti-strike legislation, outlaw "fire and re-hire" tactics, abolish compulsory zero-hours contracts, and establish the right to "disconnect". Health and Social Care Plaid Cymru prioritizes a principle of healthcare free at the point of delivery and advocates for a needs-based funding model : • Recruitment and Funding: Secure fair funding to invest in the NHS workforce, including recruiting 500 additional GPs into Wales. Restore funding for GPs to 8.7% of the Welsh health budget. • Cancer Strategy: Introduce a new Cancer Strategy ("Stop Cancer Strategy") to ensure cancers are caught and treated earlier, including increasing lung cancer screening and lowering the sensitivity threshold for bowel cancer screening. • National Care Service: Commit to establishing a National Care Service for Wales so that social care, like healthcare, is free at the point of use. • Social Care Pay: Pay social care workers at least £1 above the Real Living Wage, index-linked, to improve recruitment and retention. • Neurodiversity: Ensure support is available as soon as an individual presents as neurodiverse, addressing long waiting lists for diagnosis. Welfare and Tackling Poverty The manifesto targets the reduction and eventual abolition of child poverty as a major goal : • Child Benefit Increase: Help 330,000 Welsh families by increasing Child Benefit by £20 per week, aiming to lift 60,000 children out of poverty. • Benefit Cap/Two-Child Limit: Abolish the Conservative policy of the two-child limit on Universal Credit payments and end the benefit cap. • Essentials Guarantee: Support an Essentials Guarantee level to ensure all individuals and families receive at least the minimum amount required for daily life (calculated at £120/week for an individual). • Pensions: Maintain the Triple Lock pension increase and increase the income tax personal allowance for pensioners in line with the triple lock. • Benefit Sanctions: Oppose benefit sanctions and shorten the timetable for the first payment of Universal Credit. Education and Skills Plaid Cymru focuses on creating an environment where both learners and the workforce can thrive : • Free School Meals: Continue campaigning for universal free school meals for all secondary school learners (Years 7 to 11). • Workforce Investment: Recruit and retain 5,000 teachers and support staff. • Private Schools: Scrap the charitable status of private fee-paying schools and charge VAT on their fees, removing their exemption from business rates. • Early Years: Vision for a national and free Welsh-medium early years education and childcare service, Meithrin Cymru, for children aged 12 months until they are eligible for full-time education. • Higher Education: Ambition remains to make University education free again for all. Introduce a Lifetime Learning Allowance for training/retraining, providing a grant of £5,000 to the Personal Learning Accounts of every individual over 25. Environment and Energy The party reaffirms its commitment to reaching net-zero targets in Wales by 2035 and reversing biodiversity decline by 2030. • Energy Control: Seek full control over energy powers without UK Government limits and expand the role of the national energy company, Ynni Cymru, to develop community-owned renewable energy. • Fossil Fuels: Oppose the development of new nuclear power sites, oil and gas drilling, gas-fired peaking plants, and new open cast coal mines. • Coal Tip Clearance: Push for Westminster to pay towards clearing the coal tips that litter the valleys, as they benefited from the mining industry before devolution. • Energy Bills: Look to reduce high standing charges on energy bills in Wales. Introduce a Social Tariff for Energy. Criminal Justice and Housing Plaid Cymru supports the full transfer of justice powers to Wales : • Justice Devolution: Support the full transfer of justice powers to Wales, as recommended by independent commissions, and create a Minister of Justice in the Welsh Government. • Victims Commissioner: Create a Victims Commissioner for Wales to represent victims of crime. • Housing Right: Introduce a Right to Adequate Housing which underpins the goal that everybody has the right to a safe and affordable home in their community. • Social/Municipal Housing: Significant expansion in the amount of social and municipal housing stock. • Rent Control and Second Homes: Introduce a system of fair rents and rent control in the private rental sector. Support measures to tackle second and holiday homes, including a cap on numbers and closing loopholes. Plaid Cymru’s overall approach is one of demanding control and investment for Wales, believing that many of the nation’s problems stem from its subordinate relationship with Westminster. Like a specialized mechanic asking for the right tools and budget to fix a custom-made engine, Plaid Cymru is demanding the specific economic and legislative powers—and the outstanding financial resources—needed to address Wales’s unique challenges effectively.

Liberal Democrat Party.crime: The Liberal Democrat manifesto section dedicated to "Crime and Policing" outlines several key policies focused on crime prevention, improving police responsiveness, strengthening the criminal justice system, and supporting victims. Here is a summary of the core policies on crime and policing: 1. Restoring Community Policing and Investigation The Liberal Democrats aim to make communities safer by ensuring police are visible, trusted, and effective at solving crimes. Key actions include: • Community Policing: Restoring proper community policing, where officers are visible, trusted, and focused on preventing and solving crimes, particularly rape and other violent crime. • Investigating Burglaries: Creating a new statutory guarantee that all burglaries will be attended by the police and properly investigated. • Addressing Staff Shortages: Urgently drawing up a national recruitment, training, and retention strategy to tackle the shortage of detectives. They will also ensure fair pay rises for police officers by reforming the Police Remuneration Review Body to make it properly independent of government. 2. Addressing Specific Crimes and Vulnerabilities The policies include targeted actions against fraud, violence against women and girls (VAWG), youth violence, and modern slavery. • Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG): Ensuring survivors of VAWG are properly supported in the criminal justice process, including through mandatory training for police and prosecutors in understanding the impact of trauma on survivors. They also plan to embed domestic abuse specialists in every police force and 999 operator assistance centre. • Youth Violence: Adopting a public health approach to the epidemic of youth violence, focusing on identifying and treating risk factors rather than just symptoms. This involves police, teachers, health professionals, youth workers, and social services working closely together. They will also invest in youth services and make youth diversion a statutory duty across the country. • Online Crime and Fraud: Creating a new Online Crime Agency to effectively tackle illegal content and activity online, such as personal fraud, revenge porn, and threats and incitement to violence on social media. They will also combat the rise of fraud and scams by naming and shaming the banks with the worst records, requiring banks to reimburse victims of automated push payment scams (unless the victim is clearly at fault), and launching a public awareness campaign. • Modern Slavery and Trafficking: Reversing Conservative rollbacks of modern slavery protections and transferring responsibility for identifying modern slavery victims from the Home Office to local safeguarding agencies. 3. Judicial System Reform and Reducing Reoffending The manifesto pledges to clear court backlogs and improve the effectiveness of prisons and rehabilitation. • Tackling Court Backlogs: Investing in the criminal justice system to tackle the backlog of court cases and ensure swift justice. They will set a clear target of halving the time from offence to sentencing for all criminals. • Prison Reform: Breaking the cycle of reoffending by improving rehabilitation in prisons and on release. This includes ending prison overcrowding, recruiting more prison officers, and improving the provision of training, education, and work opportunities in prisons. • Rehabilitation: Introducing a National Resettlement Plan to improve the rehabilitation of people leaving prison and cut reoffending. • Transparency: Improving transparency by enabling all victims to request a transcript of court proceedings free of charge. 4. Police Accountability and Operations Policies are included to address public trust and improve specialized police responses. • Scrapping PCCs: Scrapping Police and Crime Commissioners and replacing them with local Police Boards made up of councillors and representatives from relevant local groups, investing the savings in frontline policing. • Improving Standards: Drawing up an urgent plan to implement the recommendations of the Baroness Casey Review to tackle sexism, racism, and homophobia, and encouraging other police forces to do the same. • Hillsborough Law: Introducing the Hillsborough Law, which establishes a statutory duty of candour on police officers and all public officials. • Mental Health Response: Improving the police response to mental ill-health by introducing a target of one hour for handover of people suffering from mental health crisis from police to mental health services, and ensuring a mental health professional is in the control room at all times. • Drug Policy: Moving the departmental lead on drugs policy from the Home Office to the Department of Health and Social Care. They propose diverting people arrested for possession of drugs for personal use into treatment where appropriate. They also plan to introduce a legal, regulated market for cannabis, restricted to over-18s, to tackle criminal gangs and remove "skunk" from the streets. 5. International Cooperation The manifesto stresses the importance of working with European neighbours to address cross-border crime. • International Crime: Improving cooperation with European neighbours on tackling cross-border crime, such as human trafficking, the illegal drug trade, cybercrime, and terrorism. • Data Sharing: Restoring direct, real-time access for UK police to EU-wide data sharing systems to identify and arrest traffickers, terrorists, and other international criminals. In essence, the policy summary indicates an overarching strategy of shifting resources to frontline community policing and rehabilitation while enhancing accountability and modernizing the handling of complex issues like mental health crises, fraud, and cross-border crime. The Liberal Democrats see these changes as necessary because the current Conservative approach has "failed even to get the basics right," resulting in rising unsolved crimes and systemic crises in courts and prisons.
Liberal Democrat Party.healthcare: The Liberal Democrat manifesto details an extensive plan to address the crisis in the National Health Service (NHS) and social care, emphasizing the importance of universal, high-quality healthcare that is free at the point of use. The party states that the crisis is currently characterized by long waiting times, staff retention issues, and failures in emergency services, arguing that the Conservative Government has "plunged the NHS into crisis". The overall strategy is aimed at tackling the crisis at the "front door" (early access) and the "back door" (social care) of the NHS, believing that fixing social care is essential to save the NHS. Here is a summary of the key policies on healthcare: 1. Improving Access and Targets The manifesto introduces specific rights and targets to improve immediate patient access: • GP Appointments: Giving everyone a new right to see a GP within seven days, or within 24 hours if they urgently need to. This will be delivered by increasing the number of full-time equivalent GPs by 8,000 (half through recruitment and half through retaining experienced GPs). • Named GPs: Everyone aged 70 or over, and anyone with long-term health conditions, will receive access to a named GP. • Dental Care: Guaranteeing access to an NHS dentist for everyone needing urgent and emergency care to end "DIY dentistry and ‘dental deserts’".
