Policies include fixing the broken NHS dental contract, providing supervised toothbrushing training for children, and scrapping VAT on children’s toothbrushes and toothpaste. • Cancer Treatment: Boosting cancer survival rates by introducing a guarantee that 100% of patients will start treatment within 62 days from urgent referral. They plan to recruit more cancer nurses and replace ageing radiotherapy machines. 2. Mental Health and Early Intervention The plan focuses heavily on improving mental health services, especially for young people: • School Professionals: Placing a dedicated, qualified mental health professional in every primary and secondary school. • Community Hubs and Check-ups: Opening walk-in hubs for children and young people in every community and offering regular mental health check-ups at key vulnerable points in people’s lives. • Young People’s Services: Extending young people’s mental health services up to the age of 25 to end the drop-off when transitioning to adult services. • Medication Costs: Making prescriptions for people with chronic mental health conditions free on the NHS. • Mental Health Act Reform: Modernising the Mental Health Act, strengthening people’s rights, and creating a statutory, independent Mental Health Commissioner. 3. Fixing Social Care to Relieve the NHS The Liberal Democrats acknowledge that "fixing the crisis in social care to stop so many people being stuck in hospital beds" is crucial for saving the NHS. • Free Personal Care: Introducing free personal care based on the model used in Scotland, ensuring provision is based on need, not ability to pay. • Workforce Support: Establishing a social care workforce plan, creating a Royal College of Care Workers, and introducing a higher Carer’s Minimum Wage. 4. Staffing, Ambulance Services, and Infrastructure To address the high number of staff vacancies and crumbling infrastructure : • Ambulance Service: Fixing the life-threatening crisis in ambulance services by ending excessive handover delays, primarily by increasing the number of staffed hospital beds and addressing the social care crisis. • NHS Staffing: Establishing a properly independent pay review body and implementing a ten-year retention plan. The party will also exempt NHS and care staff from the Immigration Skills Charge to help recruitment. • Infrastructure Investment: Implementing a ten-year plan to invest in hospitals and primary care estate to resolve the issue of crumbling buildings, dangerous concrete, and life-expired buildings. 5. Public Health and Prevention Policies are included to promote better long-term health and prevention: • Health Target: Setting a goal to help people spend five more years of their life in good health by investing in public health. • Tobacco Levy: Introducing a new levy on tobacco company profits to help fund healthcare and smoking cessation services. • Vaping and Food: Introducing regulations to halt the dangerous use of vapes by children, banning the sale of single-use vapes , and extending the soft drinks levy to juice-based and milk-based drinks high in added sugar. • Policy Lead: Moving the departmental lead on drugs policy from the Home Office to the Department of Health and Social Care. 6. Patient Rights and Accountability The party plans to enhance patient rights and tackle previous health scandals: • Patients Charter: Creating a new "Patients Charter" that includes a new legal right to a second opinion and a legal right to maintain contact in all health and care settings. • Infected Blood Inquiry: Committing to implement the recommendations of the Infected Blood Inquiry in full, delivering full and fair compensation to all victims in a timely manner. The Liberal Democrats argue that by investing in public health, early access to community services (GPs, dentists), and fixing social care, fewer people will need to go to the hospital, saving taxpayers’ money in the long run.
Liberal Democrat Party.housing: The Liberal Democrat manifesto outlines a comprehensive strategy to tackle the housing crisis, focusing on increasing housing supply, reforming tenancy and ownership laws, and ending homelessness. Here is a summary of the key policies on housing, primarily found in Chapter 14 of the manifesto : 1. Increasing Housing Supply and Planning Reform The central aim is to boost housebuilding to meet the high demand and provide more affordable options. Key policies include: • Building Target: Increasing the construction of new homes to 380,000 a year across the UK. This ambitious target includes specifically building 150,000 social homes a year. • New Developments: Delivering new housing through the creation of ten new garden cities and community-led development of cities and towns. • Land Acquisition Reform: Allowing councils to buy land for housing based on current use value rather than "hope-value" by reforming the Land Compensation Act 1961. • Funding Planning: Properly funding local planning departments to improve planning outcomes and ensure housing is not built in high flood risk areas without adequate mitigation, by allowing local authorities to set their own fees. • Encouraging Development: Encouraging the development of existing brownfield sites with financial incentives, ensuring that affordable and social housing is included in these projects. They also plan to introduce "use-it-or-lose-it" planning permission for developers who refuse to build. • Infrastructure: Ensuring that all new development has appropriate infrastructure, services, and amenities in place, integrating public service delivery into the planning process. 2. Fair Deal for Renters and Tenants The manifesto aims to deliver a "fair deal for renters" by reforming tenancy agreements and increasing protections. Key policies include: • No-Fault Evictions: Immediately banning no-fault evictions. • Tenancy Default: Making three-year tenancies the default agreement. • Landlord Register: Creating a national register of licensed landlords. • Social Renter Rights: Proactively enforcing clear standards for socially rented homes, including strict time limits for repairs, and fully recognizing tenant panels. • Second Homes/Short-Term Lets: Giving local authorities new powers to control second homes and short-term lets in their areas, including allowing them to increase council tax by up to 500% and imposing a stamp duty surcharge on overseas residents purchasing such properties. 3. Ownership, Leasehold, and Building Safety Policies are proposed to simplify ownership and protect individuals from high costs associated with their properties. Key policies include: • Abolishing Leaseholds: Abolishing residential leaseholds and capping ground rents to a nominal fee. • Right to Buy: Giving local authorities, including National Park Authorities, the powers to end Right to Buy in their areas. • Building Safety: Committing to remove dangerous cladding from all buildings, ensuring that leaseholders do not have to pay towards it. • Rent to Own: Introducing a new Rent to Own model for social housing, where rent payments give tenants an increasing stake in the property, leading to outright ownership after 30 years. • Energy Efficiency: Ensuring all new homes are zero-carbon and implementing a ten-year emergency upgrade programme to make existing homes warmer and cheaper to heat, starting with free insulation and heat pumps for low-income households. 4. Tackling Homelessness The party commits to ending rough sleeping and providing support for those most at risk. Key policies include: • Ending Rough Sleeping: A goal of ending rough sleeping within the next Parliament. • Vagrancy Act: Immediately scrapping the archaic Vagrancy Act. • "Safe to Stay" Duty: Introducing a "somewhere safe to stay" legal duty to ensure that everyone at risk of sleeping rough is provided with emergency accommodation and a needs assessment. • Financial Support: Exempting groups of homeless people, and those at risk of homelessness, from the Shared Accommodation Rate, and ensuring sufficient financial resources for local authorities to deliver the Homelessness Reduction Act. In essence, the Liberal Democrats’ housing plan aims to overhaul the system by prioritizing rapid construction of social homes, protecting renters from exploitative practices, and ensuring vulnerable individuals have access to safe shelter.
Liberal Democrat Party.immigration: The Liberal Democrat manifesto addresses immigration and asylum under Chapter 18, stating that the current system is "broken" due to the Conservatives’ policies, which have hindered recruitment, separated families, caused the asylum backlog to soar, and shattered public confidence. The party is fighting for a fair, effective immigration system that treats everyone with dignity and respect. Here is a summary of the key policies on immigration and asylum: ###, effective immigration system that treats everyone with dignity and respect. Here is a summary of the key policies on immigration and asylum: 1. Reforming the Asylum System and Addressing Channel Crossings The Liberal Democrats propose a major shift in how the UK handles asylum claims, prioritizing legal routes and speedy processing: • Scrapping Conservative Schemes: They will Scrap the Conservatives’ Illegal Migration Act and their Rwanda scheme. • Providing Safe and Legal Routes: The party commits to upholding the Refugee Convention and providing safe and legal routes to sanctuary for refugees, which aims to prevent dangerous Channel crossings. ◦ This includes expanding and properly funding the UK Resettlement Scheme. ◦ They plan to create new humanitarian travel permits that would allow asylum seekers to travel to the UK safely to proceed with their claims. ◦ They will establish a new scheme to resettle unaccompanied child refugees from elsewhere in Europe and reunite them with family members in the UK, expanding the scope of refugee family reunion. • Asylum Backlog: They will tackle the asylum backlog by establishing a dedicated unit to improve the speed and quality of asylum decision-making. ◦ A service standard of three months will be introduced for processing all but the most complex asylum claims. ◦ They will invest the savings from cancelling the Rwanda scheme into clearing the asylum backlog. • Right to Work: They propose to lift the ban on asylum seekers working if they have been waiting for a decision for more than three months, enabling them to support themselves and contribute to the economy. • Detention: They will end the detention of children for immigration purposes and reduce detention for adults to an absolute last resort, implementing a 28-day time limit. • International Cooperation: They will work closely with Europol and the French authorities to stop the smuggling and trafficking gangs behind dangerous Channel crossings. • LGBT+ Asylum Seekers: They commit to offering asylum to people fleeing violence because of their sexual orientation or gender identification, ending the "culture of disbelief" for LGBT+ asylum seekers. • Move-on Period: The "move-on" period for refugees will be increased to 60 days. 2. Reforming the Work and Skills Visa System The party aims to make the work visa system more flexible and responsive to the UK’s economic needs, especially to address labor shortages resulting from the "botched deal with Europe". • Transfer of Responsibility: Policy-making over work visas and overseas students will be transferred out of the Home Office and into other relevant departments. • Skills Charge Exemption: NHS and care staff will be exempted from the £1,000-a-year Immigration Skills Charge. • Visa Thresholds: They will replace the Conservatives’ arbitrary salary threshold with a more flexible merit-based system for work visas, with the relevant department coordinating with employers to address sector-specific needs. • Care Workers: They will reverse the Conservatives’ ban on care workers bringing partners and children. • Family Visas: They will reverse the Conservatives’ unfair increase to income thresholds for family visas to prevent families from being "torn apart". 3. Expanding Youth Mobility and Student Visas Policies are included to facilitate cultural exchange and attract young talent: • Youth Mobility Scheme (YMS) Expansion: They plan to expand the Youth Mobility Scheme by: ◦ Negotiating with the EU to extend it on a reciprocal basis. ◦ Increasing the age limit from 30 to 35. ◦ Abolishing the fees for these visas. ◦ Extending the length of visas from two to three years. • International Students: They will report international student flows separately to estimates of long-term migration. 4. Ending the Hostile Environment and Improving Accountability The Liberal Democrats promise to dismantle the "Hostile Environment" policies and ensure greater oversight and compensation for victims of past scandals. • Ending Hostile Environment: They will End the Conservatives’ Hostile Environment and instead invest in resources to tackle smuggling, trafficking, and modern slavery. • Windrush Compensation: They commit to implementing the Windrush Lessons Learned Review in full without delay and making the compensation scheme independent of the Home Office. • Firewall: They will establish a firewall to prevent public agencies from sharing personal information with the Home Office for immigration enforcement purposes and repeal the immigration exemption in the Data Protection Act. • Right to Rent: They will repeal the Conservatives’ discriminatory "Right to Rent" scheme which compels landlords to act as border guards. • Independent Oversight: They will strengthen the powers of the Independent Chief Inspector of Borders and Immigration. • EU Settled Status: They will automatically grant full Settled Status to all those with Pre-Settled Status and provide them with physical proof of their right to stay. • British Citizenship Fees: They will reduce the fee for registering a child as a British citizen from £1,214 to the cost of administration. This set of policies aims to create a system that is efficient in processing claims, humane in its treatment of vulnerable people, and practical in meeting the needs of the UK economy. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The Liberal Democrat approach can be seen as attempting to repair a leaky dam while simultaneously building new, secure channels. They are focused on stopping the dangerous flow (Channel crossings) by fixing the underlying issues (ending the asylum backlog and establishing safe, legal routes), while also stabilizing the structure of the economy by addressing labor shortages through managed migration (e.g., exempting care staff from fees and reforming the visa system).
Liberal Democrat Party.defence: The Liberal Democrat manifesto, under Chapter 21, outlines policies aimed at strengthening the Armed Forces, increasing defense spending, securing a fair deal for service personnel, and bolstering international cooperation, particularly within Europe, to counter threats like Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. The party asserts and bolstering international cooperation, particularly within Europe, to counter threats like Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. The party asserts that the Conservative Government has been negligent in its approach to defense, citing irresponsible cuts to troop numbers and failures in procurement and service personnel welfare. Here is a summary of the key defense policies: 1. Strengthening the Armed Forces and Resources The Liberal Democrats commit to increasing the capability and size of the Armed Forces: • Troop Numbers: They will reverse the Conservative Government’s cut to the Army, with a longer-term ambition of increasing regular troop numbers back to over 100,000. • Defense Spending: They commit to increasing defence spending in every year of the Parliament, with an ambition to spend at least 2.5% of GDP on defence. • Nuclear Deterrent: They plan to maintain the UK’s nuclear deterrent with four submarines providing continuous at-sea deterrence, while simultaneously pursuing multilateral global disarmament. • Procurement Reform: They will tackle long-standing problems in defense procurement by ensuring it is part of a comprehensive industrial strategy to secure a reliable long-term pipeline of equipment procurements, which will strengthen the Army, Royal Air Force, Royal Navy, and Strategic Command. 2. Support for Service Personnel and Veterans A significant portion of the defense plan focuses on securing a fair deal for the armed forces community, which the party argues the Conservatives have failed to look after properly, especially regarding housing and mental health support. Key policies include: • Armed Forces Covenant: They will strengthen the Armed Forces Covenant by placing a legal duty on the Defence Secretary and government departments to give it due regard. • Housing and Welfare: They will improve the standard of Ministry of Defence housing, including by reviewing maintenance contracts. • Compensation: They will ensure that military compensation for illness or injury does not count towards means-testing for benefits. • Fair Deal Commission: They will establish a "Fair Deal for Service Personnel, Veterans and Families Commission". • Women in the Armed Forces: They will accept the recommendations of the Atherton Report on women in the armed forces. • Recruitment and Retention: They will waive application fees for indefinite leave for members of the armed forces on discharge, and their families, to improve recruitment, retention, and resettlement. 3. International Cooperation and Security The party emphasizes leading within Europe on security, particularly given global threats and potential shifts in US policy (such as the "spectre" of Donald Trump returning to power). Key policies include: • NATO Support: They will maintain the UK’s support for NATO. • European Security: They will work collaboratively with democratic European partners to promote security and deterrence by: ◦ Strengthening cooperation with Nordic and Baltic allies via the Joint Expeditionary Force. ◦ Building on existing UK-French cooperation arrangements. ◦ Developing closer cooperation with EU agencies and member states over defence, intelligence, and cyber-security. ◦ Seeking a defence and security agreement with the EU and its member states. ◦ Prioritizing interoperability with NATO allies. • Ukraine: They will continue to stand with the people of Ukraine and provide them with the support they need in the face of Putin’s illegal invasion. 4. Accountability and Human Rights Policies also cover the ethical use of military force and oversight of intelligence and arms sales: • Military Action Approval: They will legislate to ensure there is a parliamentary vote before engaging in military action, while preserving the government’s ability to act in emergencies with a retrospective vote or under treaty obligation. • Arms Exports: They will control arms exports to countries with poor human rights records. They will introduce a "presumption of denial" for arms exports to governments listed as human rights concerns in the Foreign Office’s annual human rights report. • Intelligence Oversight: They will strengthen the Intelligence and Security Committee by giving it the power to decide what it publishes and when, and enabling the Houses of Parliament to elect its members. • Modern Warfare: They will support and promote the development of international treaties on the principles and limits of the use of technology in modern warfare. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The Liberal Democrat defense strategy positions the UK as a stronger, more reliable European security leader, focused on internal investment in personnel and external cooperation with allies, while ensuring ethical oversight of military actions.
Liberal Democrat Party.economy: The Liberal Democrat manifesto, "For a Fair Deal," outlines an economic strategy aimed at achieving stability, fostering investment, supporting businesses, and addressing the cost-of-living crisis, arguing that the Conservatives have "badly mismanaged the economy and recklessly damaged the public finances". The overarching economic goal is to build a strong, fair economy that benefits everyone in the UK by supporting people back to work, improving long-term productivity, and delivering stability for investment, particularly in future industries like renewables, digital, and bioscience sectors. Here is a summary of the key economic policies: 1. Fiscal Responsibility and Taxation The party emphasizes responsible management of public finances and strategic tax adjustments. Key policies include: • Fiscal Management: Managing public finances responsibly to ensure the national debt falls as a share of the economy and that day-to-day spending does not exceed tax revenue. They will also ensure all fiscal events are accompanied by independent forecasts from the Office for Budget Responsibility. • Targeted Tax Increases: Reversing the Conservatives’ tax cuts for big banks, restoring Bank Surcharge and Bank Levy revenues to 2016 levels in real terms. • Windfall Tax: Implementing a proper, one-off windfall tax on the super-profits of oil and gas producers and traders. • Digital Services Tax: Increasing the Digital Services Tax on social media firms and other tech giants from 2% to 6%. • Capital Gains and Share Buybacks: Fairly reforming capital gains tax to close loopholes exploited by the super wealthy, and introducing a 4% tax on the share buyback schemes of FTSE-100 listed companies to incentivize productive investment, job creation, and economic growth. • Tax Cut Priority: When public finances allow, their priority for tax cuts will be to raise the tax-free personal allowance to benefit the vast majority of families and take more low-paid workers out of paying income tax altogether. • Tax Evasion: Giving HMRC the resources it needs to properly tackle tax avoidance and evasion. 2. Addressing the Cost of Living and Energy Prices The policies seek to provide long-term help with soaring household costs : • Energy Bills: Providing long-term help by cutting energy bills through an emergency Home Energy Upgrade programme. This program includes free insulation and heat pumps for those on low incomes. • Food Prices: Tackling rising food prices through a National Food Strategy. • Mortgage Rates: Aiming to get mortgage rates under control through careful economic management. • Energy Decoupling: Decoupling electricity prices from the wholesale gas price and eliminating unfair regional differences in domestic energy bills. • Social Tariff: Introducing a social tariff for the most vulnerable to provide targeted energy discounts. 3. Business Support and Industrial Strategy The party intends to create a stable business environment, focusing on innovation and high streets. Key policies include: • Industrial Strategy: Launching an ambitious industrial strategy focused on the skills the future UK economy will need (from renewables to bioscience) to incentivize businesses to invest, create good jobs, and tackle the climate crisis. They plan to re-establish the Industrial Strategy Council and put it on a statutory footing. • Business Rates Reform: Abolishing business rates and replacing them with a Commercial Landowner Levy to help high streets and boost small businesses. • Green Investment: Increasing investment in green infrastructure, innovation, and skills to boost growth and create jobs, giving a clearer zero-carbon remit to the UK Infrastructure Bank. • Access to Capital: Expanding the British Business Bank to perform a more central role, ensuring small and medium-sized businesses have access to capital, particularly for zero-carbon products and technologies. • Local Banking: Working with major banks to fund the creation of a local banking sector dedicated to meeting the needs of local small and medium-sized businesses. 4. Fixing the Relationship with Europe Repairing the relationship with Europe is identified as core to stability and growth, as the Conservatives’ "botched Brexit deal has badly damaged the economy". • Trade Barriers: Immediately fixing the broken relationship with Europe and moving to conclude a new comprehensive agreement that removes as many barriers to trade as possible. • Long-Term Goal: The longer-term objective remains EU membership. • Cooperation: Restoring direct, real-time access for UK police to EU-wide data sharing systems and seeking a defence and security agreement with the EU. 5. Skills, Work, and Employment Rights The manifesto includes significant reforms to training and employment laws to boost productivity. Key policies include: • Skills Grants: Creating new Lifelong Skills Grants of £5,000 for adults to spend on education and training throughout their lives, with an ambition to increase them to £10,000 when finances allow. • Apprenticeships: Replacing the broken apprenticeship levy with a broader and more flexible skills and training levy and boosting the take-up of apprenticeships, including guaranteeing they are paid at least the National Minimum Wage. • Parental Leave: Overhauling parental leave by doubling Statutory Maternity and Shared Parental Pay to £350 a week and introducing an extra use-it-or-lose-it month for fathers and partners, paid at 90% of earnings. These will be day-one rights and extended to the self-employed. • Worker Status: Establishing a new "dependent contractor" employment status between employment and self-employment, with entitlements to basic rights such as minimum earnings and sick pay. • Zero-Hour Contracts: Setting a 20% higher minimum wage for people on zero-hour contracts at times of normal demand to compensate for uncertainty. • Sick Pay: Fixing Statutory Sick Pay by aligning the rate with the National Minimum Wage, making it available from the first day of missing work, and extending eligibility to those earning less than £123 a week. • Living Wage: Establishing an independent review to recommend a genuine living wage across all sectors. The Liberal Democrats summarize their approach as one of economic stability achieved through responsible public finance management and strategic investment in green infrastructure and skills, underpinned by repaired international trade relationships and strengthened employee protections.
Liberal Democrat Party.education: The Liberal Democrat manifesto dedicates Chapter 8 to Education, asserting that it is the "best investment we can make in our children’s potential and our country’s future," and criticizing the Conservatives for neglecting schools and failing to address the impact of the Covid pandemic on children’s learning and mental health. The core policies focus on mental health support, increasing funding, addressing attainment gaps, and reforming the curriculum and inspections. Here is a summary of the key education policies: 1. Mental Health and Wellbeing A major priority is integrating mental health support directly into schools: • School Mental Health Professionals: They will put a dedicated, qualified mental health professional in every primary and secondary school. • Funding Mechanism: This policy will be funded by increasing the Digital Services Tax on social media firms and other tech giants. • Student Mental Health: They plan to introduce a statutory Student Mental Health Charter and require universities to make mental health services accessible to their students. 2. Funding, Infrastructure, and Attainment Policies target financial investment, infrastructure repair, and closing the gap between disadvantaged and other pupils: • Funding Increases: They commit to increase school and college funding per pupil above the rate of inflation every year. • Crumbling Buildings: They aim to end the scandal of crumbling school and college buildings by investing in new buildings and clearing the backlog of repairs. They will also redirect capital funding for unnecessary new free schools to help clear the backlog of school repairs. • Early Years Support: They will invest in high-quality early years education and close the attainment gap by giving disadvantaged children aged three and four an extra five free hours a week and tripling the Early Years Pupil Premium to £1,000 a year. ◦ In the future, when finances allow, they plan to give disadvantaged two-year-olds an extra five free hours of early years education a week, working towards a universal, full-time entitlement for all two- to four-year-olds. • Tutoring Guarantee: They will introduce a "Tutoring Guarantee" for every disadvantaged pupil who needs extra support. • Young People’s Premium: They plan to introduce a Young People’s Premium, extending Pupil Premium funding to disadvantaged young people aged 16-18. • Free School Meals: They will extend free school meals to all children in poverty, with an ambition to extend them to all primary school children when finances allow. • Students in Care: They will support the education of children in care, extend Pupil Premium Plus funding to children in kinship care, and guarantee any child taken into care a school place within three weeks. 3. Teaching Workforce and Curriculum Reform The manifesto addresses teacher shortages, pay, professional development, and the content of education: • Teacher Recruitment and Pay: They will tackle the crisis in teacher recruitment and retention by creating a teacher workforce strategy to ensure every secondary school child is taught by a specialist teacher. They will also reform the School Teachers’ Review Body to make it properly independent of government, able to recommend fair pay rises for teachers, and fully fund those rises every year. • Teacher Training: They will fund teacher training properly so that all trainee posts in school are paid. • Curriculum Review: They will urgently establish a standing commission to build a long-term consensus to broaden the curriculum and make qualifications at 16 and 18 fit for the 21st century, drawing on best practice like the International Baccalaureate and ensuring children learn core skills such as critical thinking and creativity. • Arts Subjects: They will include arts subjects in the English Baccalaureate. • Vocational Education: They will improve the quality of vocational education, including skills for entrepreneurship and self-employment, and strengthen careers advice and links with employers in schools and colleges. 4. Special Educational Needs (SEND) and Local Authority Powers Policies aim to end the "postcode lottery" in SEND provision and decentralize authority: • SEND Funding: They will give local authorities extra funding to reduce the amount schools pay towards a child’s Education, Health and Care Plan. • National Body for SEND: They will establish a new National Body for SEND to fund support for children with very high needs. • Strategic Education Authorities: They will give local authorities with responsibility for education the powers and resources to act as Strategic Education Authorities, handling places planning, exclusions, admissions, and SEND functions. 5. Adult and Higher Education The plans extend support beyond compulsory schooling: • Lifelong Skills Grants: They will create new Lifelong Skills Grants, giving all adults £5,000 to spend on education and training throughout their lives, with an ambition to increase this to £10,000 when finances allow. • Student Maintenance Grants: They plan to reinstate maintenance grants for disadvantaged students immediately to ensure living costs do not prevent university study. • Student Mobility: They will expand opportunities for young people to study, teach, and volunteer abroad by returning to the Erasmus Plus programme as an associated country. • Higher Education Finance Review: They will establish a review of higher education finance in the next Parliament to consider necessary reforms concerning access, participation, and quality. 6. Accountability and School Culture The party seeks to reform oversight and ensure better school environments: • Ofsted Reform: They will reform Ofsted inspections and end single-word judgements so parents get a clearer picture of a school’s strengths and weaknesses, and schools receive the guidance needed to improve. • Tackling Bullying: They will tackle bullying in schools by promoting pastoral leadership and delivering high-quality relationships and sex education. • Parental Engagement: They will implement a new parental engagement strategy, including a regular, published parent survey. The education policies are characterized by a focus on early intervention, particularly in mental health and disadvantaged children’s attainment, combined with systemic reform aimed at improving teacher status and funding infrastructure. This approach mirrors the broader strategy of investment to improve long-term national health and prosperity.
Liberal Democrat Party.environment: The Liberal Democrat manifesto outlines a comprehensive plan for environmental action, focusing on urgent climate action, ending the sewage crisis, restoring nature, and holding large companies accountable. The party emphasizes that climate change is an existential threat that requires bold, urgent action. The policies related to the environment, climate change, and the natural world are summarized below, drawing primarily from Chapters 5 (Climate Change and Energy) and 12 (Natural Environment) of the manifesto. 1. Ending the Sewage Scandal and Protecting Waterways The manifesto identifies the sewage scandal as a clear failure of the Conservative Government and proposes significant regulatory and financial changes to water companies. Key policies include: • Water Company Reform: Transforming water companies into public benefit companies. • Bonus Ban: Banning bonuses for water bosses until sewage discharges and leaks end. • New Regulator: Replacing Ofwat with a tough new regulator equipped with new powers to prevent sewage dumps. • Sewage Tax: Introducing a Sewage Tax on water company profits. • Enforcement and Targets: Enforcing existing laws to ensure storm overflows only function in exceptional circumstances. They will set legally binding targets to prevent sewage dumping into bathing waters and highly sensitive nature sites by 2030. • Water Standards: Strengthening the powers of local authorities to monitor the health of rivers, lakes, and coastlines. They will also introduce a "blue corridor" programme for rivers, streams, and lakes, and set new "blue flag" standards. • Transparency: Mandating all water companies to publish accessible real-time data on any sewage they dump. 2. Climate Change and Energy Transition The party is committed to achieving net zero and transitioning to clean energy sources to cut emissions and energy bills. Key policies include: • Net Zero Target: Committing to cutting greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2045 at the latest. • Emissions Reduction: Meeting the UK’s commitment under the Paris Agreement to reduce emissions by at least 68% from 1990 levels by 2030. • Home Energy Upgrade Programme: Launching a ten-year emergency upgrade programme to make homes warmer and cheaper to heat. This program starts with free insulation and heat pumps for those on low incomes. New homes must immediately be built to a zero-carbon standard. • Renewable Energy: Investing in renewable power so that 90% of the UK’s electricity is generated from renewables by 2030. They plan to remove unnecessary restrictions on new solar and wind power and support tidal and wave power investment. • Rooftop Solar Revolution: Driving a rooftop solar revolution by expanding incentives and guaranteeing a fair price for electricity sold back to the grid. • Fossil Fuels: Implementing a proper, one-off windfall tax on the super-profits of oil and gas producers and traders. They will maintain the ban on fracking and introduce a ban on new coal mines. • Government Structure: Appointing a Chief Secretary for Sustainability in the Treasury to ensure the economy is zero-carbon and establishing a new Net Zero Delivery Authority to coordinate action across government. • Transport: Restoring the requirement that every new car and small van sold from 2030 is zero-emission and investing in electrifying Britain’s railways. 3. Nature Restoration and Biodiversity The manifesto commits to reversing the decline of the natural environment and boosting biodiversity. Key policies include: • "Double Nature" Target: Setting meaningful and binding targets to "double nature" by 2050. This includes: ◦ Doubling the size of the Protected Area Network. ◦ Doubling the area of most important wildlife habitats. ◦ Doubling the abundance of species. ◦ Doubling woodland cover by 2050. • Tree Planting: Planting at least 60 million trees a year. • Protecting Land and Sea: Protecting at least 30% of land and sea areas by 2030 for nature’s recovery. • Nature-Based Solutions: Restoring peatlands as a carbon store, banning the use of horticultural peat, and protecting and enhancing temperate rainforest. • Biodiversity Net Gain: Ensuring new developments result in significant net gain for biodiversity, with up to a 100% net gain for large developments. 4. Holding Businesses Accountable and Regulatory Reform The Liberal Democrats intend to strengthen legal mechanisms and regulators to enforce environmental protection. Key policies include: • Duty of Care: Introducing a general duty of care for the environment and human rights in business operations and supply chains. • Corporate Reporting: Requiring all large companies listed on UK stock exchanges to set targets consistent with achieving the net zero goal and report on their progress. • Climate-Friendly Investment: Regulating financial services to encourage climate-friendly investments, including requiring pension funds and managers to ensure their portfolio investments align with the Paris Agreement. • Air Quality: Passing a Clean Air Act, based on World Health Organization guidelines, and enforced by a new Air Quality Agency. • Environmental Regulators: Strengthening the Office for Environmental Protection and providing more funding to the Environment Agency and Natural England. • Waste and Plastics: Aiming for the complete elimination of non-recyclable single-use plastics within three years. They will also introduce a deposit return scheme for food and drink containers. • International Leadership: Restoring international development spending to 0.7% of national income, making tackling climate change a key priority for development spending. These policies reflect the party’s belief that environmental protection must be integrated with economic strategy, including a new industrial strategy focused on clean technologies.
Liberal Democrat Party.brexit: The Liberal Democrat manifesto outlines a clear strategy for addressing the consequences of the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union, focusing on repairing the relationship and ultimately aiming for future EU membership. The party views the Conservatives’ "botched Brexit deal" as having severely damaged the economy, trade, and the UK’s international influence. The core policies regarding Brexit are summarized below, predominantly found under the themes of the economy, business, and international relations: 1. Immediate Action to Fix the Broken Relationship The party commits to immediate action to stabilize the UK’s international and trade standing: • Repairing Relations: The Liberal Democrats will immediately fix the broken relationship with Europe. The new partnership will be built on cooperation, not confrontation. • Trade Barriers: They commit to concluding a new comprehensive agreement that removes as many barriers to trade as possible. Fixing this broken trading relationship is described as core to improving stability and growth in the economy. • Economic Rationale: They argue that the "botched Brexit deal has badly damaged the economy," leading to reduced economic growth, fewer jobs, and less tax revenue. Repairing this relationship is a core element of their plan for the economy. 2. The Four-Stage Roadmap to Partnership The party proposes a detailed four-stage roadmap to formalize the UK-EU relationship and improve cooperation: 1. Initial Steps: This involves taking unilateral steps to rebuild the relationship, starting by declaring a fundamental change in the UK’s approach and improving channels for foreign policy cooperation. 2. Rebuilding Confidence: This stage focuses on agreeing to partnerships or associations with EU agencies and programmes such as the European Aviation Safety Agency, Erasmus Plus, scientific programmes, climate and environment initiatives, and cooperation on defence, security and crime. 3. Deepening Trade: This involves negotiating critical agreements for the British economy, including comprehensive veterinary and plant health agreements and mutual recognition agreements. Such agreements would help farmers and food manufacturers trade with European neighbours with minimal need for checks. 4. Formal and Stable Footing: Once trust has been renewed and trade damage is repaired, the party would aim to place the UK-EU relationship on a more formal and stable footing by seeking to join the Single Market. 3. Longer-Term Objective: EU Membership The manifesto states that the long-term objective remains EU membership. The policies laid out in the four-stage roadmap are described as essential steps on the road to achieving this goal. 4. Specific Sectoral and Rights Policies Related to Europe The policies also address specific areas impacted by the UK’s withdrawal: • Trade Deals and Standards: They will renegotiate the Australia and New Zealand trade agreements if they cannot be aligned with the UK’s objectives for health, environmental, and animal welfare standards. They aim to ensure that the UK has the highest possible standards of environmental, health, labour, and consumer protection, at least matching EU standards. • Cross-Border Crime: They plan to improve cooperation with European neighbours on tackling cross-border crime and restore direct, real-time access for UK police to EU-wide data sharing systems to identify and arrest traffickers, terrorists, and other international criminals. • Culture and Travel: They will negotiate free and simple short-term travel arrangements for UK artists to perform in the EU, and European artists to perform in the UK. • Youth Mobility: They plan to expand the Youth Mobility Scheme by negotiating with the EU to extend it on a reciprocal basis. They will also seek to return to the Erasmus Plus programme as an associated country to expand opportunities for young people to study, teach, and volunteer abroad. • Defense and Security: They will seek a defence and security agreement with the EU and its member states. • EU Settled Status: They will automatically grant full Settled Status to all those with Pre-Settled Status and provide them with physical proof of their right to stay. They will also extend the right to full participation in civic life (including voting in UK referendums and elections) to all EU citizens with settled status. • Northern Ireland: They commit to fixing the UK’s broken relationship with Europe to reduce barriers to trade between Great Britain, Northern Ireland, and the Republic of Ireland. The Liberal Democrats position themselves as the only party that will fix the UK’s broken relationship with Europe by following their four-stage roadmap, believing this is vital for economic restoration and security.
Liberal Democrat Party.entire manifesto: The Liberal Democrat manifesto, titled "For a Fair Deal," outlines five key policy themes aimed at transforming British politics and addressing what the party describes as crises in the economy, public services, climate, and the housing market. The five core themes and their associated key policies are summarized below: 1. A Fair Deal on the Economy The Liberal Democrats aim to build a strong, fair economy by fostering stability, supporting businesses, and encouraging investment. Key policies include: • Taxation and Revenue: Reversing the Conservatives’ tax cuts for big banks and implementing a proper, one-off windfall tax on the super-profits of oil and gas producers and traders. When public finances allow, they prioritize cutting income tax by raising the tax-free personal allowance. • Cost of Living: Providing long-term help by cutting energy bills through an emergency Home Energy Upgrade programme and tackling rising food prices via a National Food Strategy. • Business Support: Abolishing business rates and replacing them with a Commercial Landowner Levy to support high streets and small businesses. • Skills: Investing in more apprenticeships and creating new Lifelong Skills Grants for adults to spend on education and training throughout their lives. • Europe: Fixing the broken relationship with Europe and tearing down damaging barriers to trade. 2. A Fair Deal on Public Services The manifesto emphasizes strengthening public services, especially health, care, and the safety net, arguing that this provides the freedom necessary for people to live their lives as they choose. Key policies include: • NHS Access: Giving everyone a new right to see a GP within seven days, or 24 hours if urgent, supported by 8,000 more GPs. • Dental Care: Guaranteeing access to an NHS dentist for everyone needing urgent and emergency care. • Social Care: Introducing free personal care, modeled on the system introduced in Scotland, so provision is based on need, not ability to pay. They also propose creating a Royal College of Care Workers and establishing a higher Carer’s Minimum Wage. • Mental Health and Education: Placing a dedicated, qualified mental health professional in every primary and secondary school. • Pensions and Safety Net: Protecting the triple lock for pensions. To tackle child poverty, they propose removing the two-child limit and the benefit cap. • Policing and Crime: Restoring proper community policing and creating a statutory guarantee that all burglaries will be attended by the police and properly investigated. 3. A Fair Deal on the Environment The Liberal Democrats commit to urgent action to achieve net zero and tackle the climate crisis, focusing heavily on holding companies accountable and improving energy efficiency. Key policies include: • Sewage Scandal: Ending the scandal by transforming water companies into public benefit companies, banning bonuses for water bosses until discharges and leaks end, and replacing Ofwat with a tough new regulator. They also propose a Sewage Tax on water company profits. • Climate Targets: Committing to cutting greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2045 at the latest. • Energy and Insulation: Launching a ten-year emergency Home Energy Upgrade programme, starting with free insulation and heat pumps for those on low incomes. • Renewable Energy: Driving a rooftop solar revolution by expanding incentives and investing so that 90% of the UK’s electricity is generated from renewables by 2030. • Nature Recovery: Setting meaningful and binding targets to "double nature" by 2050, which includes doubling the Protected Area Network, doubling wildlife habitats, and planting at least 60 million trees a year. 4. A Strong United Kingdom and a Fair International Order The party promotes internationalism and seeks to restore the UK’s influence on the world stage, particularly by repairing relationships within Europe. Key policies include: • Europe Relations: Immediately fixing the broken relationship with Europe and moving to conclude a new comprehensive agreement to remove as many barriers to trade as possible. The longer-term objective remains EU membership. • Defense Spending: Maintaining support for NATO and increasing defence spending every year, with an ambition to spend at least 2.5% of GDP on defence. • Armed Forces: Reversing the Conservative cut to the Army, with a long-term goal of increasing regular troop numbers back to over 100,000. • International Aid: Restoring international development spending to 0.7% of national income. • International Law: Championing the liberal, rules-based international order. 5. A Truly Fair Democracy The Liberal Democrats aim to transform the nature of British politics by increasing representation, enhancing accountability, and shifting power away from Westminster. Key policies include: • Electoral Reform: Introducing proportional representation (Single Transferable Vote) for electing MPs and local councillors in England. • Accountability: Enshrining the Ministerial Code in law to demand higher standards of behaviour from Government Ministers. • Political Funding: Taking big money out of politics by capping donations to political parties. • Voting Rights: Giving 16- and 17-year-olds the right to vote in UK general elections and referendums, and local elections in England. • Rights Protection: Championing the UK’s Human Rights Act and scrapping the Conservatives’ draconian anti-protest laws. Additionally, key policies address Housing, including increasing building to 380,000 new homes a year (including 150,000 social homes) , immediately banning no-fault evictions, and abolishing residential leaseholds. On Immigration and Asylum, they plan to scrap the Conservatives’ Illegal Migration Act and the Rwanda scheme, lift the ban on asylum seekers working after three months, and provide safe and legal routes to sanctuary.

Alliance Party.crime: The Alliance Party’s policies related to crime and justice, as detailed in their 2024 Westminster Manifesto, focus heavily on upholding the rule of law, reforming legacy mechanisms, addressing issues related to immigration exploitation, and funding the justice system adequately. Upholding the Rule of Law and Civil Liberties • Alliance champions human rights and the rule of law both domestically and internationally. They assert that human rights, equality, and the rule of law are cornerstones of safety and stability and must be defended robustly. • They advocate for reforming UK democracy by scrapping the Tories’ anti-protest laws. They will also demand the repeal of the Illegal Migration Act. • The party commits to restoring the rule of law, civil liberties, and equal access to justice. • They support the implementation of a Statutory Duty of Candour. Dealing with the Past (Legacy Justice) • Alliance believes that justice should have no time limit. • They advocate for the replacement of the Legacy Act with an alternative framework co-designed with local political parties and victims and survivors’ groups. They regard the current Legacy Act as a betrayal of previous agreements and at odds with justice and the rule of law. • They note that the criminal justice system should always be available to those seeking justice. • They support the campaign for a payment for those bereaved during the Troubles and previously supported the introduction and implementation of the Troubles Permanent Disablement Pension Scheme. Policing and Justice Funding • Alliance notes that the capacity to sustain and transform Northern Ireland’s justice system is hindered because Northern Ireland is not adequately funded to reflect relative need. • They identify policing and justice as key areas of public concern that require sufficient funding. • Alliance is committed to securing a base-lined fiscal floor for Northern Ireland set above 124% (relative to England), noting that the current calculation used to assess funding related to policing and justice needs may be inadequate because the period used for assessment was characterized by continuing cuts to the Department of Justice budget. Combating Exploitation and Trafficking • As part of their policy to overhaul the asylum system, Alliance commits to establishing safe, legal routes for asylum seekers to reduce exploitation and trafficking. • They argue that the current restrictive government approach has resulted in people being vulnerable to modern slavery, human trafficking, and exploitation. They believe the inability of asylum seekers to work causes vulnerability to criminal exploitation. • They support making changes to the visa system to end employer-dependent visas, so workers can change jobs or leave an exploitative employer. • They also aim to continue supporting the fight against modern slavery, human trafficking and criminal, labour, and sexual exploitation across the world. Specific Crime and Justice Reforms • Drug Policy: They will advocate for a Royal Commission on drug policy to ensure the adoption of evidence-based interventions, particularly those related to harm-reduction. • Animal Cruelty: Alliance seeks to tackle cruelty against animals and states that those who show brutality to animals are potentially a danger to society as a whole. They will continue to pursue high welfare standards and extend the ban on hunting mammals with dogs to Northern Ireland. • Online Safety: They call for better regulation of AI and social media and the establishment of a watchdog for child safety online. International and Economic Crime • Alliance seeks to implement the most robust economic crime legislation to prevent oligarchs from corrupt regimes from channeling money through the UK, with proceeds from seized Russian assets repurposed to support Ukraine. • They also support tackling tax-dodging which harms economies globally. • They seek deeper policing and justice co-operation between the UK and the EU, provided there is ongoing adherence to the European Convention on Human Rights.
Alliance Party.healthcare: The Alliance Party’s policies on healthcare, as presented in the 2024 Westminster Manifesto, are primarily focused on addressing the systemic underfunding of public services in Northern Ireland (NI) and securing necessary investment to sustain and transform the region’s health system. Here is a summary of their key policies relating to health and care: Financial Support and Service Quality The party emphasizes that the ability to sustain and transform public services, including the health system, is severely hindered because Northern Ireland is not adequately funded to reflect its relative need. • Addressing Underfunding: Alliance seeks to secure an improved financial settlement for Northern Ireland that properly reflects relative need and allows for investment in public services. • Health Waiting Lists: They note that in the current fiscal climate, public services have been "squeezed beyond recognition," leading to rising health waiting lists. • Fiscal Reform: They advocate for reforming UK fiscal rules to recognize the impact of public spending on the UK’s overall asset base, arguing this would help unlock vital investment in struggling public services. • Fairer Funding Floor: Alliance is committed to securing a base-lined fiscal floor set above 124% (relative to England) at the next UK Spending Review, believing the current funding level does not adequately reflect NI’s needs for areas like health, education, and justice. Specific Health and Care Policies • Health and Care Worker Visas: Alliance aims to support the health and social care sectors by reforming immigration policy. They seek to scrap the ban on dependents for those on a Health and Care Worker visa. • Infected Blood Scandal: They advocate for urgent, just compensation for all those affected by the Infected Blood Scandal, including scrutinizing the operation of the recently created Government compensation scheme. • Public Health Cooperation: They see opportunities to further develop cooperation in the area of public health through the British-Irish Council (East-West cooperation). • Duty of Candour: Alliance supports the introduction of a statutory Duty of Candour. Pandemic Preparedness Drawing lessons from recent outbreaks, Alliance advocates for better readiness for future health crises: • Mitigation and Management: They will advocate for better global cooperation from the next UK Government to mitigate and manage disease outbreaks with pandemic potential. • Health Service Support: They seek to ensure the health service and other key workers are better prepared and supported to meet the challenges of another pandemic. • Scientific Advice: They value expert scientific advice and believe it should inform government policy to help protect the population’s health during outbreaks. Overall, the Alliance Party aims to use its influence at Westminster to secure the necessary financial resources for Northern Ireland to ensure the stabilisation and subsequent transformation of its health and public service sectors.
Alliance Party.housing: The Alliance Party’s Westminster Manifesto for July 2024 does not contain a dedicated section on housing policy. However, several commitments outlined in the document have direct implications for housing, particularly concerning energy efficiency, fuel poverty, and social housing provision, primarily within the context of Northern Ireland (NI) and the broader Green New Deal and migration policies. Here is a summary of the Alliance Party’s policies that relate to housing: 1. Retrofitting and Fuel Poverty A major commitment under the Alliance Party’s Green New Deal focuses on improving the energy efficiency of homes to tackle both climate change and the cost of living crisis. • Emergency Retrofitting Programme: They call for a UK-wide emergency retrofitting programme to reduce emissions and tackle fuel poverty. • Net Zero Carbon Buildings Standard: They support the continued development of the UK Net Zero Carbon Buildings Standard. • Reducing Energy Consumption: They commit to supporting a UK-wide emergency programme to reduce energy consumption from all buildings. This includes providing insulation to cut emissions and fuel bills, retrofitting homes, and increasing energy efficiency of private rented sector homes and social housing, with the goal of ultimately ending fuel poverty for good. • Addressing the Energy Crisis: The party notes that an estimated 45% of homes in Northern Ireland may be living in fuel poverty, which they deem unacceptable, underscoring the need for massive investment in renewables and properly insulating homes. 2. Housing for Armed Forces and Asylum Seekers The manifesto touches on housing in the context of specific vulnerable groups: • Armed Forces Housing: Alliance commits to ensuring the provision of quality housing for armed forces personnel and their families. • Asylum Accommodation: As part of overhauling the asylum system, Alliance MPs will work to end the use of hotels and privatization of accommodation for those seeking asylum, moving instead to a not-for-profit-based system that is integrated into communities and works alongside social housing. • Homelessness Prevention: They advocate for making providers of asylum accommodation subject to a statutory duty to refer people leaving asylum support accommodation who are at risk of homelessness to the local housing authority. 3. Taxation and Wealth In the context of fiscal reform, Alliance advocates for property taxes on the super-rich as a way to raise public funds to support the transition to Net Zero, which would ultimately fund policies like the retrofitting programme affecting housing. To solidify understanding: Alliance’s approach to housing is like trying to fix an old, leaky ship (the current housing stock) by sealing up the holes and giving it a new engine (the Green New Deal). By focusing on energy efficiency and retrofitting, they aim to make the homes cheaper to run and environmentally sustainable, while also addressing specific acute needs for those in temporary accommodation or public service roles.
Alliance Party.immigration: The Alliance Party’s Westminster Manifesto for July 2024 presents a clear and comprehensive agenda for migration, advocating for a fair, welcoming, and effective immigration system that both upholds human rights and meets the needs of the economy. The party unequivocally rejects the current anti-migrant rhetoric and the "hostile environment" approach, arguing that migration is a normal part of human life that enriches culture and significantly improves the economy. They note that key Northern Ireland sectors, such as retail, hospitality, agri-food, and social care, rely heavily on migrant workers, and the current restrictive policies have caused major job shortages. Alliance’s policies are divided into three main areas: reforming the visa system, overhauling the asylum system, and protecting the Common Travel Area (CTA). 1. Overhauling the Asylum System Alliance seeks to restore the universal right to seek asylum, arguing that the UK takes only a tiny fraction of the world’s refugees and that restrictive policies merely embolden smuggling gangs and expose people to exploitation. Key commitments include: • Repealing Legislation: Restoring the right to seek asylum by repealing the Illegal Migration Act 2023, the Nationality and Borders Act 2022, and the Safety of Rwanda (Asylum and Immigration) Act 2024. • Abolishing Forced Resettlement: Abolishing the Rwanda Scheme and any other third-country forced resettlement agreements. • Establishing Safe Routes: Creating safe, legal routes to claim asylum in the UK, and expanding resettlement schemes to reduce the incentive for treacherous small boat journeys and subsequent exploitation and trafficking. • Right to Work: Granting asylum seekers the right to work in any job after three months so they can support themselves and their families and become active community members. • Accommodation: Ending the use of hotels and the privatization of accommodation, moving to a not-for-profit-based system that is integrated into communities and works alongside social housing. They also demand that accommodation providers have a statutory duty to refer people leaving asylum support who are at risk of homelessness to the local housing authority. • Processing: Ensuring asylum claims are processed fairly and quickly in a trauma-informed way. • Alternatives to Detention: Supporting a trial in Northern Ireland to explore community-based Alternatives to Detention (ATDs). 2. Reforming the Visa System Alliance MPs will campaign for changes to the visa system to make it more affordable and responsive to economic needs, particularly given the impact of current high thresholds on lower salary levels in Northern Ireland. Key reforms include: • Salary and Fees: Reversing the increased minimum threshold salary requirements for family visas and cutting extortionate visa fees. • Dependents and Families: Scrapping the ban on dependents for those on Health and Care Worker visas and student visas. • Ending Punitive Policies: Ending the punitive policy of No Recourse to Public Funds (NRPF). • Economic Visa System: Repealing the Immigration Act 2020 to scrap the shortage occupation list and points-based system, replacing it with a system based on the real needs of the Northern Ireland economy and society. • Worker Protection: Ending employer-dependent visas to allow workers to change jobs or leave an exploitative employer. • Settlement and Students: Capping routes to settlement at five years of residence and granting overseas students two years to find work after graduation. 3. Protecting the Common Travel Area (CTA) Alliance seeks to preserve and enhance the free movement and reciprocal rights across the UK and Ireland under the CTA, noting that Brexit has placed it under growing stress. Their aims include: • Treaty Basis: Placing the CTA on a formal treaty basis by the UK and Irish Governments. • Non-EU/EEA Residents: Ensuring essential cross-border services and "deemed permission" to cross the border are provided to all lawfully resident non-EU/EEA citizens in Northern Ireland. • Tourism and Travel: Abolishing the requirement for non-EU/EEA citizens to carry passports when crossing the border and seeking an exemption for Northern Ireland tourism under the UK’s Electronic Travel Authorisation (ETA) scheme. • Labour Mobility: Creating a labour mobility scheme on the island of Ireland.
Alliance Party.defence: The Alliance Party’s policies on defence, as outlined in their 2024 Westminster Manifesto, are focused on supporting the armed forces, promoting international cooperation, reviewing defence spending, and adhering to international security norms. The policies fall under the chapter "International Affairs and Defence". Support for the Armed Forces Alliance respects and values the difficult work that our armed forces undertake and believes they must be properly remunerated and rewarded for their efforts. Specific commitments include: • Equipment Audit: Conducting an audit of the equipment and training provided to the armed forces to ensure they are adequately prepared for the various types of missions they face and that they have appropriate equipment for the changing natures of deployments. • Quality Housing: Ensuring the provision of quality housing for armed forces personnel and their families. • Armed Forces Covenant: Supporting the continuing implementation of the Armed Forces Covenant in Northern Ireland, including regular monitoring of the scheme. Defence Spending and International Cooperation Alliance commits to strengthening international security frameworks and ensuring defence policy reflects modern security challenges. Key points include: • NATO: Continuing to support NATO as the cornerstone of the defence of the UK and Europe. • Defence Review: Recognizing the need for the UK and other countries to increase defence spending and supporting a full defence review in this regard. • Cooperation with the EU: Advocating for stronger defence co-operation between the UK and the European Union and pushing for a formal agreement to be reached early in the forthcoming Parliament. • Defence Posture: Believing that changing the UK’s defence posture can yield savings. They suggest that other approaches, reflecting the security challenges of the future rather than the nuclear standoff of the Cold War era, can be used to ensure the UK’s security. • Nuclear Proliferation: Supporting the UK combating nuclear proliferation by leading by example in reducing nuclear weapons as part of agreed-upon multilateral efforts. Defence Procurement (Northern Ireland) Alliance specifically addresses how defence spending affects Northern Ireland: • Defence Contracts: They note that Northern Ireland currently receives the lowest share per capita in the United Kingdom of defence contracts. • Lobbying for Opportunities: Alliance will continue to lobby the Ministry of Defence to ensure that Northern Ireland-based companies have proper opportunities to compete for contracts and that the local SME sector can access related opportunities in both Northern Ireland and Great Britain. Military Intervention and Arms Exports In the broader context of international affairs, Alliance outlines principles for military engagement and arms control: • Military Intervention: They support military intervention only as a last resort. Any such intervention must be legal, have defined aims and an exit strategy, and be accompanied by non-military attempts at tackling the problem. They also accept that the “Responsibility to Protect” doctrine must be a factor in decision-making about intervention. • Arms Exports: They advocate for the creation of much higher scrutiny and restrictions on UK arms exports, ending exports to countries that engage in aggression against others and repression domestically. Alliance’s defence policy emphasizes that the UK’s security strategy should be modern, cooperative, and guided by international law, while ensuring that the armed forces are well-supported and that Northern Ireland businesses receive a fair share of defence opportunities.
Alliance Party.economy: The Alliance Party’s economic policies, detailed in their 2024 Westminster Manifesto, center on securing fairer funding for Northern Ireland (NI), implementing a progressive taxation system, promoting a Green New Deal, and leveraging NI’s unique position under the Windsor Framework to foster an innovative and dynamic regional economy. Here is a summary of Alliance’s key economic policies: 1. Reforming UK Public Finances and Fiscal Policy Alliance argues that the current UK fiscal policy is inhibiting investment, reinforcing climate inaction, and hindering the capacity to sustain and transform public services. • Fiscal Rules Reform: They advocate for revising UK Fiscal Rules to account for the costs of environmental inaction and to enable necessary investment in climate action. They believe the rules should recognize the impact of public spending on the UK’s overall asset base (or wealth) rather than solely focusing on debt and deficit. This reform is seen as fiscally prudent if the spending creates additional net wealth, and it would unlock significant investment for public services, the economy, and the environment. • Progressive Taxation: Alliance calls for a progressive taxation system where the super-wealthy pay their fair share. They suggest revising the tax system to ensure it adequately captures and reflects wealth, noting that loopholes currently facilitate significant tax avoidance for the super-wealthy. They believe that increasing tax on the super-wealthy could allow for increased personal income tax allowances for hard-working individuals. • Carbon Taxes and Share Buybacks: They support the phased and proportionate implementation of carbon taxes in sectors like aviation and transport to incentivize emission reduction. Additionally, they seek a tax on share buybacks (such as those by oil and gas giants and big banks) to incentivize productive business investment, support the transition to Net Zero, and raise approximately £1.4 billion annually for public services. 2. Fairer Funding for Northern Ireland Alliance asserts that NI is currently structurally underfunded relative to its needs, harming public services and economic growth. • Improved Financial Settlement: A key priority is delivering an improved financial settlement for Northern Ireland that accurately reflects its relative need and allows for investment in public services and the economy. • Fiscal Floor: They are committed to securing a base-lined fiscal floor set above the current UK Government figure of 124% (relative to England) at the next UK Spending Review, believing this figure does not capture NI’s true relative need. • Cost of Division: Alliance advocates for new UK Government-funded research into the updated costs of division in NI (previously estimated between £400m and £800m annually) so that savings can be channeled back into public services. 3. Green New Deal and Economic Transformation Alliance views tackling the climate emergency and achieving economic transformation as interconnected goals. • Decarbonization and Jobs: They aim to create a Green New Deal to decarbonize the economy, protect workers, tackle fuel poverty, and create thousands of new jobs. • Investment Funding: The Green New Deal should be partly funded through tax increases on fossil fuel giants and the super-rich, property taxes, and long-term green bond issuance. • Retrofitting Programme: They call for a UK-wide emergency retrofitting programme to reduce emissions, tackle fuel poverty (affecting an estimated 45% of NI homes), and increase the energy efficiency of private rented and social housing. • Fossil Fuels: They commit to ending the use of fossil fuels, banning fracking, and prohibiting the opening of new coalmines and pits. 4. Northern Ireland Economy and Trade Alliance believes NI can become Europe’s most innovative and dynamic regional economy, capitalizing on its dual market access. • Dual Market Access: They will work to promote and exploit the opportunity of dual market access afforded by the Windsor Framework, which grants unfettered access to both the Great Britain and the Irish/EU markets for goods. • Regional Equality: They seek a legal duty placed on the UK Government to ensure its economic policies are assessed on their likelihood of reducing regional inequality and accelerating "levelling up". • SME Support: They advocate for supporting regional industries by boosting research, innovation, skills, infrastructure, and access to finance across the UK. They also want to see the expansion of the British Business Bank and the UK Infrastructure Bank to support viable small and medium-sized businesses (SMEs) in NI. • Apprenticeship Levy: Alliance supports a review of the Apprenticeship Levy and ensuring that any levy raised from Northern Ireland is ring-fenced for re-investment in skills. • Levelling Up Funds: They seek a fundamental review of the Levelling Up and Shared Prosperity Funds, arguing that resources and responsibility for these funds should be transferred to the NI Executive, as current funds are reduced and misaligned with local priorities. • Defence Contracts: They commit to lobbying the Ministry of Defence to ensure NI-based companies receive proper opportunities to compete for defence contracts, noting NI currently receives the lowest share per capita of these contracts. 5. Social Security and Welfare Alliance seeks a radical overhaul of the social security system to address the cost of living crisis. • Ending Punitive Measures: They support ending the Benefits Cap, Bedroom Tax, and the two-child limit on Child Benefit on a UK-wide basis. • Childcare Investment: They view childcare as key infrastructure to unlock current and future economic potential. They demand more generous tax relief through improvements to the UK’s Tax-Free Childcare scheme (e.g., increasing relief from 20% to 35%) and supporting a new childcare strategy for NI. • Carer’s Support: They support delivering a Carer’s Allowance Supplement and extending the Carer’s Allowance earnings threshold to recognize the contribution of unpaid carers. Alliance’s economic plan is essentially an "invest-to-save" strategy , aiming to address structural underfunding and climate risk through progressive taxation and fiscal reform, thereby stabilizing public services and maximizing Northern Ireland’s unique post-Brexit economic opportunities.
Alliance Party.education: The Alliance Party’s policies on education, as outlined in their 2024 Westminster Manifesto, are focused primarily on securing funding for integrated and early years education in Northern Ireland (NI), and ensuring overall public services, including schools, are adequately funded. They also touch upon specific aspects of higher education and skills training. Here is a summary of Alliance’s key policies relating to education: 1. Funding for Shared and Integrated Education Alliance strongly advocates for policies that help build a "shared future" and reduce division in Northern Ireland. • Successor to Fresh Start Fund: They prioritize securing dedicated funding for integration, early years, and early intervention projects as a successor to the Fresh Start capital fund. • Expansion of Investment: This new fund should encompass the remaining integrated school projects that did not receive Fresh Start funding. Crucially, they propose expanding its scope to include investment in early years and early intervention. • Transformative Goal: This fund is intended to be transformative, collaborative, and focused on shared outcomes through trauma-informed projects, and would be additional to other funding streams like PeacePlus [41. • Transformative Goal: This fund is intended to be transformative, collaborative, and focused on shared outcomes through trauma-informed projects, and would be additional to other funding streams like PeacePlus. • Reducing Division Costs: They believe funding key projects such as integrated schools will help build a shared future. They also seek UK Government funding for research into the updated costs of division in NI (previously cited between £400m and £800m annually) so that savings from tackling division can be funneled back into public services. 2. General Public Service Funding Alliance maintains that the education system in Northern Ireland is facing significant financial constraints. • Inadequate School Budgets: They note that in the current fiscal climate, school budgets are inadequate to meet needs. • Fairer Financial Settlement: They commit to delivering an improved financial settlement for Northern Ireland that properly reflects its relative need, which is essential to sustain and transform the education system, alongside health and justice. • Fiscal Floor: They are committed to securing a base-lined fiscal floor for NI set above 124% (relative to England) to ensure equivalent funding based on relative underlying needs for public services like education. 3. Skills, Higher Education, and Apprenticeships Alliance addresses the connection between education, skills, and economic growth. • Review of Investment: They will advocate for a review of investment levels in skills, the funding model for colleges, universities, and apprenticeships, and student finance for England, noting that revised outcomes in these areas may have beneficial outcomes for Northern Ireland. • Apprenticeship Levy: They support a general review of the Apprenticeship Levy across the UK, and ensuring that any levy raised from Northern Ireland is ring-fenced for re-investment in skills. • Economic Strategy: They want strategic investment to ensure Northern Ireland has the skills and ability to attract greater levels of funding from projects like UK Research Councils and meet emerging labour market skills demands. • Migration and Qualifications: They commit to ensuring that migrants’ and refugees’ qualifications and prior learning are recognized to reflect need in the local economy and to ensure they can continue their education. • International Programmes: They support rejoining the Erasmus Plus programme so young people have full restored access to study, teach, and volunteer abroad. 4. Digital Safety and Child Welfare Alliance commits to protecting children and young people in the online space. • Online Safety Watchdog: They call for better regulation of AI and social media, including the establishment of an independent advocacy body for child safety online. • UN Convention: They support the incorporation of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child into UK law. • Global Education Rights: Alliance notes the importance of access to education, particularly for women and girls across the world, as a priority in their international affairs policy. Alliance’s overall education policy acts as a dual approach: campaigning at Westminster for structural financial reform to adequately fund existing services (like school budgets), while aggressively pursuing dedicated funds to break down sectarian barriers through integrated and early years provision.
Alliance Party.environment: The Alliance Party’s environmental policies are central to their platform, structured around a comprehensive Green New Deal aimed at achieving Net Zero, tackling fuel poverty, and ensuring economic transformation. They advocate for significant fiscal and legislative reforms at the Westminster level to prioritize climate action. Here is a summary of Alliance’s key policies on the environment: 1. Fiscal and Economic Reform for Climate Action Alliance believes that current UK fiscal policy is reinforcing climate inaction and storing up environmental, social, and financial crises. • Revising Fiscal Rules: They prioritize revising UK Fiscal Rules to formally account for the costs of environmental inaction and to enable necessary investment in climate action. Alliance argues that the rules should recognize the impact of spending on the UK Government’s overall asset base (wealth), not just debt and deficit.
