This reform is intended to unlock significant investment for a Green New Deal and provide resilience against external risks like climate change. • Funding the Green New Deal: The Green New Deal should be funded through several progressive revenue streams, including: ◦ Tax increases on fossil fuel giants and the super-rich. ◦ Wealth and property taxes on the super-rich. ◦ Phased and proportionate carbon taxes in sectors like aviation and transport to incentivize emission reduction. They prefer a clear linkage between environmental taxes levied and investment in environmental improvement and tackling climate change. ◦ Long-term green bond issuance, ISAs, and pension funds. • Economic Strategy: Alliance seeks a legal duty placed on the UK Government to ensure its economic policies are assessed on their likelihood of reducing regional inequality. This strategic, targeted investment could unlock new skills, jobs, and technologies necessary for a greener economy. 2. Key Green New Deal Commitments The Alliance Green New Deal seeks to urgently decarbonize the economy, protect workers, and create jobs while upholding Net Zero targets. • Ending Fossil Fuels: They demand ending the use of fossil fuels. This includes an immediate ban on fracking and the opening of new coal mines and pits. They also support reversing new oil and gas licenses. • Decarbonizing Buildings and Tackling Fuel Poverty: They call for a UK-wide emergency retrofitting programme to reduce emissions and tackle fuel poverty. This includes: ◦ Providing insulation to cut emissions and fuel bills. ◦ Increasing energy efficiency of private rented sector homes and social housing, with the ultimate goal of ending fuel poverty for good. ◦ Supporting the continued development of the UK Net Zero Carbon Buildings Standard. ◦ Alliance notes that up to 45% of homes in Northern Ireland may be in fuel poverty, underscoring the urgency of investment in renewables and insulation. • Renewable Energy and Infrastructure: They will support massive investment in renewable energy to guard against price precarity, boost the industry in Northern Ireland, and ensure resilient infrastructure. 3. Regulatory, Transparency, and Conservation Measures Alliance policies extend to strengthening regulation, ensuring transparency, and tackling environmental harm. • Air Quality: They commit to introducing UK air quality limits in line with World Health Organisation levels to guarantee and monitor the right to breathe clean air both indoors and outdoors. • Enforcement: They call for enhanced funding for the Office of Environmental Protection (OEP) to ensure adequate enforcement and on-ground presence. • Transboundary Issues: They ensure the UK Government recognizes transboundary issues related to agriculture and the environment, including marine planning. • Emissions Trading: They want to ensure Northern Ireland receives its fair share of funding raised under the UK’s Emissions Trading Scheme. They also support merging of UK and EU emissions trading regimes (ETSs) and Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanisms (CBAMs). • International Agreements: They support the UK’s urgent ratification of the UN Global Ocean Treaty and a ban on deep-sea mining. They also advocate for an ambitious UN Global Plastics Treaty. • Sustainable Supply Chains: They seek to prevent environmental and human rights abuses in supply chains by establishing due diligence obligations on UK companies. 4. International Climate Justice Alliance views climate change as a global justice issue, particularly affecting the Global South. • International Aid: They support restoring the commitment to spend 0.7% of the UK’s gross national income on Official Development Assistance. • Fossil Fuel Phaseout: They demand an end to all fossil fuel expansion globally and support a just transition to renewables, with high-income countries like the UK moving fastest. They also oppose all aid spending on fossil fuel production overseas, redirecting it toward international climate aid. • Loss and Damage: They support the establishment of the Loss and Damage Fund under the UNFCCC, ensuring the UK and fossil fuel companies pay their fair share. • Climate Finance: They commit to sustaining the UK’s pledge of £11.6 billion for climate finance, ensuring these funds are new and additional sources. Alliance’s environmental strategy is like tackling climate change with a financial hammer: by restructuring the UK’s fundamental economic rules to recognize environmental costs, they aim to generate the multi-trillion-pound investment needed to transition the UK economy to Net Zero, starting with making homes energy efficient and ending reliance on fossil fuels.
Alliance Party.brexit: The Alliance Party’s policies on Brexit are rooted in their fundamental opposition to the decision, viewing it as "fundamentally destructive" for the UK as a whole, particularly posing challenges for Northern Ireland’s economy, environment, society, and political stability. Their strategy centers on repairing the UK-EU relationship, improving the implementation of the Windsor Framework, and ultimately advocating for the UK to return to the European Union. Here is a summary of Alliance’s policies on Brexit: 1. Position on Brexit and Future Relationship • Fundamental Opposition: Alliance was firmly opposed to Brexit, recognizing that some problems resulting from the UK’s departure "will either persist or not be fully solvable". • Ultimate Goal (Reversal): It remains Alliance’s policy that Northern Ireland and the UK should return to the European Union at an early opportunity. They believe only a full reversal of Brexit can resolve all the associated tensions, contradictions, and limitations. • Interim Alignment: In the interim, they seek closer alignment with the EU under the Trade and Co-operation Agreement, including considering rejoining the Single Market and Customs Union, arguing that this would ease the interface across the Irish Sea and soften the overall impact of Brexit. They also support the UK voluntarily aligning with the European Single Market pending formal agreements. 2. Implementing and Improving the Windsor Framework Alliance supports the special arrangements provided for under the Windsor Framework as a mitigation measure but acknowledges it is an imperfect solution, particularly as it fails to address the free movement of labour, services, and capital. Key actions to improve implementation include: • Veterinary Medicines Agreement: Negotiating a comprehensive Veterinary Medicines Agreement (or Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) Agreement) between the UK and the EU to significantly reduce the nature and level of related checks across the Irish Sea. Pending this agreement, they seek a grace period extension for the current Veterinary Medicines grace period, which ends on December 31, 2025. • Promoting Dual Market Access: Better promoting the opportunity of dual market access under the Windsor Framework, which gives NI unfettered access for goods to both the Great Britain and the Irish/EU markets. • "Not for EU" Labelling: Seeking a grace period to defer the next phase of goods labelling pending the conclusion of a comprehensive UK-EU Veterinary Agreement. • GB Business Support: Encouraging the UK Government to provide improved information and assistance to businesses based in Great Britain regarding trading with Northern Ireland to minimize trade friction. • Addressing the Democratic Deficit: Ensuring early and enhanced engagement between Northern Ireland’s elected representatives, Executive departments, and other stakeholders in the development of relevant EU law, as the Stormont Brake and Applicability Motions are "blunt instruments" that come at the end of the process. • Safeguarding Rights: Continuing to defend Article 2 of the Windsor Framework, which protects rights under the Good Friday Agreement and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), from any attack. They also commit to continuing the Windsor Framework in the forthcoming Democratic Consent vote. 3. Enhancing Cooperation Alliance advocates for stronger cooperation between the UK and the EU across various sectors: • North-South and East-West Cooperation: Enhancing cooperation through the Strand Two and Three institutions of the Good Friday Agreement, such as the North-South Ministerial Council (NSMC) and the British Irish Council (BIC). They believe the NSMC could meaningfully drive cooperation on areas not covered by the Windsor Framework, such as services, capital, and the free movement of people. • Security and Justice: Seeking deeper policing and justice co-operation between the UK and the EU, provided there is ongoing adherence to the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR). • Mobility and Professional Recognition: Advocating for a progressive return to freedom of movement, starting with specific cohorts like performers and a youth mobility scheme, and supporting Mutual Recognition of Professional Qualifications. They also support rejoining the Erasmus Plus programme. • Emissions Trading: Supporting the merging of UK and EU emissions trading regimes (ETSs) and Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanisms (CBAMs). Alliance’s position is that stability in Northern Ireland depends on reconciling its deep interconnections with both Ireland (North-South) and the UK (East-West), and that maximizing flexibilities within the current arrangements requires continuous engagement and negotiated, legal changes agreed upon by both the UK and the EU.
Alliance Party.entire manifesto: The Alliance Party’s Westminster Manifesto for July 2024 sets out a comprehensive agenda focused on institutional stability, economic fairness, climate action, and democratic reform, particularly emphasizing issues affecting Northern Ireland (NI). The manifesto identifies ten key policy priorities : 1. Reforming the Assembly and Executive so that no single party can hold the institutions "to ransom". 2. Delivering an improved financial settlement for Northern Ireland that accurately reflects the region’s relative need and allows investment in public services and the economy. 3. Revising fiscal rules to account for the costs of environmental inaction and to enable necessary investment in climate action. 4. Creating a Green New Deal to decarbonise the economy, protect workers, tackle fuel poverty, and generate thousands of new jobs. 5. Repairing the UK-EU relationship, which includes negotiating a comprehensive Veterinary Agreement and better promoting the opportunity of dual market access under the Windsor Framework. 6. Securing dedicated funding for integration, early years, and early intervention projects as a successor to the Fresh Start program, helping to build a shared future. 7. Supporting families with childcare costs by demanding more generous tax relief and the creation of a new childcare strategy for Northern Ireland. 8. Advocating for a fair, welcoming, and effective immigration system that upholds human rights and meets the needs of the economy. 9. Reforming UK democracy by scrapping the Tories’ anti-protest laws, abolishing the First Past the Post electoral system, and introducing votes at 16. 10. Championing human rights and the rule of law both domestically and internationally. Key Policy Areas in Detail Leading Change for Northern Ireland (Institutional and Legacy Reform) The Alliance Party believes that NI’s institutions must evolve, as they are currently held back by failures that lead to division and deadlock. • Institutional Reform: They aim to reform the process of nominating First and deputy First Ministers (to pass the entitlement to the next largest party if the largest is unwilling). They advocate replacing "parallel consent" in the Assembly with a weighted majority for cross-community votes and reforming the Petition of Concern mechanism. They also recommend changing the titles of the First and deputy First Ministers to "Joint First Minister" to acknowledge their co-equal offices, and ultimately abolishing the system of designations. • Legacy: The manifesto calls for the replacement of the Legacy Act with an alternative co-designed with local political parties and victims and survivors’ groups, asserting that justice should have no time limit. UK Public Finances and Taxation Alliance seeks major changes to the UK’s fiscal approach, arguing that current policy inhibits investment and reinforces climate inaction. • Fiscal Rules: They propose changing the UK Fiscal Rules to recognize the impact of spending on the overall asset base and wealth, rather than merely focusing on debt and deficit. This would unlock investment, particularly in areas mitigating environmental costs. • Taxation: They advocate for a progressive taxation system, where the super-wealthy pay their fair share, and the phased implementation of carbon taxes. They also support a tax on share buybacks to incentivize productive business investment. • Welfare: Alliance seeks a radical overhaul of the social security system. They support ending the Benefits Cap, Bedroom Tax, and the two-child limit on Child Benefit on a UK-wide basis. Economy and the Green New Deal Alliance seeks to position NI as Europe’s most innovative and dynamic regional economy, capitalizing on its unique dual market access. • Green New Deal: They support an urgent decarbonisation of the economy. Key commitments include ending the use of fossil fuels, banning fracking and new coal mines, funding the Green New Deal through taxes on fossil fuel giants and the super-rich, and launching a UK-wide emergency retrofitting programme to reduce emissions and tackle fuel poverty. • Economic Policy: They call for a legal duty on the UK Government to assess economic policies based on their likelihood of reducing regional inequality. They also seek a review of the Apprenticeship Levy, ensuring funds raised in NI are ring-fenced for re-investment in skills. Migration and Asylum Alliance rejects the current anti-migrant rhetoric and supports a compassionate, fair system. • Visa System Reform: They seek an overhaul of the visa system to make it more affordable, including removing cruel minimum threshold salary requirements for family visas. They also advocate scrapping the shortage occupation list and points-based system in favour of one based on NI’s real economic and societal needs. • Asylum: They commit to abolishing the Rwanda Scheme and restoring the universal right to seek asylum by repealing related legislation. They demand the creation of safe, legal routes for asylum seekers and granting asylum seekers the right to work in any job after three months. Relationship with the European Union Alliance was opposed to Brexit but is committed to making the Windsor Framework work better. • Fixing the Relationship: They believe the UK should ultimately return to the European Union (EU) to resolve the tensions of Brexit. Immediately, they seek closer alignment with the EU, including the negotiation of a comprehensive Veterinary Medicines Agreement to reduce checks across the Irish Sea. International Affairs Guided by liberal internationalist values, Alliance supports the rules-based international order. • International Development: They advocate for reinstating the Department for International Development (DFID) as a standalone department and restoring the commitment to spend 0.7% of the UK’s gross national income on Official Development Assistance. • Conflict: They support a two-state solution in the Middle East, based on international law, including the recognition of Palestine as a sovereign state. They also maintain full support for Ukraine’s fight against Russian aggression and the ongoing provision of aid. The manifesto can be understood as a blueprint for change, seeking to unlock fairer funding and secure stable institutions to deliver a more sustainable and prosperous future for everyone in Northern Ireland.

Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP.crime: The key policies outlined in the SDLP Manifesto regarding crime, justice, and related issues focus on reversing the UK Government’s Legacy Act, undertaking systemic reforms of the justice system, strengthening policing, tackling paramilitarism, and addressing Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG). 1. Justice, Legacy, and Victims The SDLP’s overarching priority in this area is to ensure justice, truth, and accountability for victims. • Repeal the Legacy Act: The SDLP views the UK government’s toxic Legacy Act as an "abhorrent amnesty" and an act of serious bad faith . They successfully lobbied the UK Labour Party to commit to repealing this Act in the next Parliament, and SDLP MPs will hold the Labour Party accountable for that commitment. • Systemic Reforms: They advocate for substantive reforms to the criminal justice system to deliver faster, fairer justice with increased accountability. ◦ Focus on Rehabilitation: They call for further structural and staff reforms of the prison service to enhance rehabilitation, as well as the safety and dignity of both prison staff and prisoners. ◦ Community Mediation: They continue to call for a progressive approach, including support for community mediation methods and non-court approaches of dispute resolution. ◦ Reduce Re-offending: They support establishing a 12-month post-release supervision program, following international best practice models, to help reduce re-offending. ◦ Protect Victims’ Rights: Systemic reforms should be introduced to protect the rights of victims, including an effective communication strategy to raise awareness of the Victim and Witnesses Charters and access to support services and entitlements. ◦ Historical Institutional Abuse (HIA): They support the full implementation of the remaining recommendations from the HIA Inquiry and the release of redress payments and other required support to survivors. 2. Policing and Paramilitarism The manifesto details commitments to visible policing, combating specific crimes, and greater cooperation across the island. • Visible Police Presence: SDLP MPs will always lobby for a visible police presence in communities, which they state has been hollowed out by a decade of Tory austerity. They aim to ensure that no community is managed by "gatekeepers" who exercise undue influence. • Police Representation: They will continue to challenge the PSNI on recruitment, retention, and promotion policies, particularly concerning underrepresented groups. They believe the recruitment of officers and civilian staff from the Catholic tradition is a pressing challenge that requires the deployment of every measure, including affirmative action. • Combating Cybercrime: They will work with relevant authorities, including the PSNI’s Chief Constable and the Northern Ireland Policing Board, to ensure that the police service is modern and equipped to combat online crime, including cybercrime, economic crime, and fraud . • Tackling Paramilitarism: They seek to end paramilitarism and associated criminality. ◦ They will ensure the Paramilitary Disbandment Strategy Panel is provided with necessary support and information from organizations including the PSNI, An Garda Síochána, and other stakeholders [8LP:82]. ◦ They advocate for greater cooperation between the PSNI and An Garda Síochána to deal with crime associated with the border. ◦ They call for stronger collaboration between relevant agencies to deliver a specific anti-corruption strategy for Northern Ireland and a significant uplift in resources, having fought for local oversight and robust accountability protections for the National Crime Agency. 3. Ending Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG) The SDLP is committed to the full implementation and funding of the new Ending Violence Against Women and Girls Strategy. • Reverse Cuts to Women’s Aid: They will lobby the Executive Office repeatedly to reverse the cut to Women’s Aid NI, describing the current situation—where Women’s Aid NI is the only part of Women’s Aid across the UK without state funding—as "totally indefensible". • Legislation Implementation: They will hold the Department of Justice responsible for the limited provision of implementation, training, or monitoring for new legislation on areas like domestic abuse and stalking, and will press for the implementation of all recommendations from the Gillen Review. • Family Courts Review: They believe a review of the family courts system is required, similar to the one undertaken in England, and will work to ensure this review is delivered urgently. 4. Hate Crime and Disability Rights • Hate Crime Legislation: They support robust standalone hate crime legislation to end these crimes, as recommended by the Marrinan Review, and will seek to hold the Justice Minister accountable for a previous commitment to this. • Disability Hate Crime: They will continue to campaign against the negative attitudes and discrimination that affect disabled people, including through addressing disability hate crime. • Asylum Seekers: They commit to standing against hate crime and discrimination wherever it occurs in any community.
Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP.healthcare: The SDLP Manifesto for Westminster 2024 emphasizes the urgent need to rescue public services, particularly the health service, which is described as being "on life support" and already collapsing due to years of austerity and governmental instability. The key policies focused on healthcare are: 1. Saving the Health Service The manifesto states that the health service in Northern Ireland is under immense strain. • Marshall Plan Intervention: The North’s Health Service needs a "Marshall Plan style intervention," acknowledging the scale of underinvestment and the urgency of transformation. • Dedicated Transformation Intervention: SDLP MPs commit to making representations directly to the Treasury for a health service transformation intervention. • Reducing Waiting Lists: They will seek dedicated resource to reduce waiting lists, which are currently out of control. Over half a million people—more than 1 in 4 of the entire population—are waiting for an appointment, and over half of those people are likely to wait for more than a year for a first outpatient session. • Workforce Conditions: They will argue for terms and conditions for health service staff that reflect their contribution to society and address significant workforce retention challenges. This includes supporting health service staff in their campaign for fair pay and safe staffing levels by making representations directly to the Treasury. • GP Support: They will argue for a government-backed indemnity scheme for GPs in Northern Ireland to avert the unnecessary closure of local practices. • Multi-Disciplinary Teams (MDTs): They will fight for the expansion of Multi-Disciplinary Teams across Northern Ireland. • Stalled Transformation Agenda: The manifesto notes that the Transformation agenda has stalled due to the constant collapse of government, a failure to fund strategic change, and a lack of political will, leading to service withdrawal and eroded confidence in the transformation program. 2. General Public Service Funding The SDLP recognizes that broader fiscal policies are necessary to rescue the health service and other public services. • Ending Austerity: They seek to put an end to the politics of austerity. They will press for real investment in public services to undo the impact of austerity. • Improved Financial Settlement: SDLP MPs will advocate for an improved financial settlement that recognizes decades of underfunding. • Comprehensive Spending Review: They will press for a comprehensive spending review which allows the Executive to deliver a multi-year, costed public service recovery plan. • Public Sector Pay: They will fight for a fair deal for public sector workers, acknowledging years of underinvestment. 3. Related Social and Welfare Policies The party also focuses on surrounding issues that impact community health and well-being: • Childcare: They commit to lobbying the Department of Health to establish a time-bound taskforce to address the issue of unregistered childminding and progress the Review of Minimum Standards. • Carers’ Support: They support the introduction of at least five days of paid carers’ leave. They note that without unpaid carers, the health and social care system would simply collapse. • Mental Health: They include Health, Mental Health & Well-Being as one of the 12 key policy areas for long-term development via the New Ireland Commission. • Disability Rights: They support full and equal access to public services, including healthcare, for disabled people and call for investment to address the impact of the cost-of-living crisis and the pandemic on disabled individuals. • Asylum Seekers: They commit to promoting equal opportunities for integration, including access to health, education, housing, and fair employment for all in the community. The overall objective is to move beyond the current crisis, where people have been forced to take out loans for private healthcare , and deliver a plan to rescue public services.
Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP.housing: The key policies and related issues on housing and infrastructure are: Addressing the Housing Crisis and Poverty • Growing Waiting Lists: The collapse of the Northern Ireland Executive for five of the last seven years has led to an "unprecedented decline in public services," resulting in growing housing waiting lists. • Housing and Poverty: The costs associated with rent and mortgages have forced more and more people into poverty in recent years. The SDLP notes hearing first-hand accounts of young people who cannot afford to buy their first home and those on the property ladder struggling with "sky high mortgage prices". • Accountability for Delivery: The SDLP will hold the Minister for Communities responsible for the failure to build the appropriate level of housing, including social homes. • Funding the Crisis: Although housing is a devolved matter, SDLP MPs commit to fighting to ensure that appropriate funding is made available to the Northern Ireland Executive to address the housing crisis. Infrastructure and Planning Related to Housing • Water Infrastructure Constraint: The construction of 19,000 homes across Northern Ireland is currently at risk due to a lack of necessary water and sewerage infrastructure. This issue has placed a "stranglehold" on the economy and the building of homes. ◦ The SDLP recognizes the urgent need to address the legacy of underfunding in NI Water. ◦ They are opposed to water charges and argue that the Executive must prioritize investment in critical water infrastructure through alternative means, rather than imposing further hardship on families. • Planning Reform: The SDLP will seek to reform the planning system by: ◦ Prioritizing and expediting large-scale housing developments. ◦ Streamlining the planning process and addressing current backlogs. ◦ Ensuring alignment of planning policies with broader economic, social, and environmental objectives to promote balanced and sustainable development. • Associated Infrastructure: The manifesto notes that the completion of the A6 road is a critical infrastructure project, particularly given the additional plans for housing developments in the region. • Flood Risk: Approximately 45,000 properties in Northern Ireland are at risk of flooding, a number expected to increase significantly due to climate change. The SDLP believes the Executive has failed to manage this situation and calls for improved warning systems to ensure communities are better prepared. • Integration: The SDLP promotes equal opportunities for the integration of asylum seekers and refugees, including access to health, education, and housing. • Disability Access: They call for investment to ensure that the built environment of local communities is fully accessible to disabled people, which includes homes.

International Cooperation The party emphasizes the need for international cooperation to address the root causes of displacement : • They commit to international cooperation with other countries in order to properly deal with the root causes of displacement, including conflict, climate change, and persecution. • They support the establishment of a Palestinian Visa Scheme to help displaced Palestinian people, viewing this resettlement scheme as the only way Palestinians will be provided with safe passage out of the devastation in Gaza.

Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP.economy: The SDLP Manifesto for Westminster 2024 prioritizes achieving a Fairer Economy for All. The party advocates for putting an end to austerityThe SDLP Manifesto for Westminster 2024 prioritizes achieving a Fairer Economy for All. The party advocates for putting an end to austerity, maximizing Northern Ireland’s unique trading position, supporting businesses and workers, tackling poverty, and investing significantly in skills and infrastructure. Here is a summary of the key economic policies: 1. Fiscal Strategy and Funding The SDLP seeks a substantial overhaul of the financial relationship between Westminster and Northern Ireland to reverse the damage caused by 14 years of austerity. • Improved Financial Settlement: SDLP MPs will advocate for an improved financial settlement that recognizes decades of underfunding and begins the work of rescuing public services. • Comprehensive Spending Review: They will press for a comprehensive spending review to allow the Northern Ireland Executive to deliver a multi-year, costed public service recovery plan and set priorities over the long term. • Fiscal Framework: They commit to working with other parties to secure a strong and clearer fiscal framework for Northern Ireland. • Fiscal Devolution: They seek the devolution of further fiscal powers to the NI Assembly, specifically: ◦ Tourism and Hospitality VAT. ◦ The Apprenticeship Levy. ◦ Air Passenger Duty. • Revenue Raising: They stress the need for close scrutiny of the revenue raising package that Executive parties agreed to in return for debt forgiveness with the Treasury. • Public Sector Pay: They will fight for a fair deal for public sector workers, acknowledging years of underinvestment, and support an above-inflation pay increase for teachers and school support staff. 2. Maximizing Economic Advantages The SDLP aims to capitalize on Northern Ireland’s unique trading status. • Dual-Market Access: They will work to maximize the competitive advantages of the Protocol/Windsor Framework, which uniquely places Northern Ireland at the crossroads of two major markets. • Tailored Strategy: They support creating a strategy tailored to sectors that benefit most from the Framework, co-developed with funding from the Irish and British governments and the European Union. • European Investment Hub: They press for the creation of a new "European Investment Hub" for Northern Ireland and increased funding for InterTrade Ireland. • Invest NI Reform: They will hold the Economy Minister accountable for implementing the damning Lyons Review findings on Invest NI, including publishing a meaningful Sub-Regional Economic Action Plan. • Devolution of "Levelling-Up": They will seek the devolution of the "levelling-up" agenda to Northern Ireland with commensurate funding and governance arrangements to rebalance oversight and decentralize management. 3. Supporting Businesses and Workers The manifesto details specific actions for small businesses and workers’ rights. • Small Business Support: SDLP MPs will work to: ◦ Increase the VAT threshold to £100,000. ◦ Support the automatic uprating of the Employment Allowance in line with National Living Wage increases. ◦ Ensure Westminster and devolved government departments commit to and implement prompt payments for small businesses. ◦ Commit to reducing the use of unnecessary personal guarantees in small business lending. ◦ Establish a "Banking Hub Setup Fund" funded by high street banks. • Workers’ Rights: The SDLP supports the growing of a strong economy through defending workers’ rights. They will: ◦ Support an end to zero-hour contracts. ◦ Campaign for an equal minimum wage to prevent discrimination against young people in pay. ◦ Ensure flexible working is a day one right. ◦ Support expanding trade union rights. ◦ Support the implementation of legislation on gender pay gap reporting. ◦ Seek reform of maternity leave and ensure the Real Living Wage is used as a baseline for Statutory Maternity Pay from weeks 7–52. 4. Tackling Poverty and Cost of Living The party stresses that poverty is a "moral outrage" exacerbated by the Conservative government. • Windfall Tax: SDLP MPs have consistently called for, and will support, a new government’s plan to levy a windfall tax on oil and gas giants. • Anti-Poverty Strategy: They will lobby for the publication and funding of a robust and cross-cutting Anti-Poverty Strategy. • Universal Credit (UC): They demand the next UK government ensures an Essentials Guarantee within Universal Credit, so the basic rate covers life’s essentials. • Housing Crisis: They commit to fighting to ensure appropriate funding is made available to the Executive to address the housing crisis, which has pushed people into poverty due to high rents and mortgages. • Pension Justice: They will seek to reverse the punitive decision on WASPI women and reduce the State Pension Age. • Paid Carers’ Leave: They support the introduction of at least five days of paid carers’ leave. 5. Investment in Skills and Education Skills are seen as the "engine of our economy". • Magee Campus: They will fight for a full-size university campus at Magee of at least 10,000 students as a critical lever for economic development in the North West. • Student Numbers: They will fight to lift the Maximum Student Numbers (MaSN) cap in Northern Ireland, which they view as a barrier to skills development. • Apprenticeships: They are committed to properly funding apprenticeships and ensuring employers in Northern Ireland can draw from the Apprenticeship Levy, which they seek to devolve. • Lifelong Learning: They will fight to ensure age is never a barrier to learning through legislation for a Lifelong Learning Guarantee. 6. Industry and Sectoral Support • Arts and Culture: They support a meaningful increase in arts funding to catch up with other jurisdictions and the delivery of a new Arts, Culture and Heritage Strategy. • Tourism: They will work to secure an ambitious and fully funded Tourism Strategy, including extending initiatives like the Wild Atlantic Way into the North. • Financial Services: They will push for a Westminster inquiry into the state of financial services in Northern Ireland, including the cost of insurance, branch closures, and cross-border challenges. • Green Economy: They will press a new government to include the SDLP’s proposals for a green jobs levy on large corporations to fund a just transition to new green technology roles. In essence, the SDLP’s economic policies are structured to leverage Northern Ireland’s unique market access while seeking significant financial investment from Westminster to repair public services, address regional inequalities, and create a sustainable, high-skill economy. This contrasts with the "politics of austerity, isolation and division" that they believe have plagued the region for 14 years.
Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP.education: The SDLP Manifesto identifies that the education system requires urgent investment and reform to ensure young people receive the best start in life. The key policies on education coverThe SDLP Manifesto identifies that the education system requires urgent investment and reform to ensure young people receive the best start in life. The key policies on education cover funding, curriculum reform, special needs provision, language support, and university investment. Here is a summary of the key policies on education: 1. Primary and Secondary Education The SDLP’s policies focus on securing resources, improving staff pay, reducing costs for families, and supporting inclusive education models: • Fair Pay for Staff: The SDLP believes that teachers have not been appreciated by successive Education Ministers. They argue for an increase in pay above inflation for teachers and school-based support staff. They also support pay parity between Further Education Lecturers and school teaching staff. • Addressing Underachievement: They will continue to fight for proper resourcing for the delivery of plans to address educational underachievement and fully implement the recommendations of the A Fair Start report. • SEN System Overhaul: The SDLP recognizes that the Special Educational Needs (SEN) system needs a complete overhaul. Their three-point plan to improve SEN provision includes: ◦ A streamlined assessment process. ◦ An increase in staff to process applications. ◦ A Children’s Champion to act as an advocate on behalf of parents and children. ◦ They also seek to reform post-19 Special Educational Needs provision. • School Uniform Costs: They support action to cap school uniform costs for families, alongside an expansion of eligibility for financial support for students. • Restrictive Practices: They call for statutory guidance and appropriate training for school staff and governors regarding the use of restrictive practices (restraint and seclusion) in an educational setting. • Review of the Education Authority: The SDLP is unconvinced that the Education Authority is fit for purpose and would support a review of the Authority’s remit and structures. • Integrated Education: The SDLP has a long history of supporting integrated education. They support the recent Integrated Education Act and will continue to promote integrated education, including holding the Executive accountable for the implementation of that legislation. They previously led the opposition to the Executive and UK Government’s decision to remove £150 million of ringfenced funding for integrated education. 2. Language and Curriculum Support • Irish Language Sector: The SDLP strongly supports the Irish language sector, including ensuring that Irish-medium education is fully supported. • Irish Language Rights: They support the development of a Bill for Irish Medium Education to clarify and strengthen the current statutory duty and ensure policies and services are in place to meet the needs and growth of the sector, including supporting workforce development and recruitment. • Languages in School: They support the inclusion of languages as a compulsory subject for study at GCSE level to reverse the decline in pupils studying languages in school. • LGBTQIA+ Education: They support promoting age-appropriate and expert-guided LGBTQIA+ inclusive relationships and sexuality education for schools. • Arts and Culture: They support the delivery of a new Arts, Culture and Heritage Strategy and will specifically lobby Westminster to provide additional funding to the Executive for the Arts Council NI to provide Artsmark accreditation in Northern Ireland. 3. Higher and Further Education (Skills Investment) The SDLP views skills as the "engine of our economy" and is committed to defending education as a public good. • Magee University Expansion: They will fight for a full-size university campus at Magee of at least 10,000 students. The SDLP has already secured funding for expansion and development of the Medical School in the North West and supports specific financial incentives for students to study at Magee. They seek to establish a cross-border oversight body for higher education in the North West, in line with the recommendations of the Royal Irish Academy. • Lifting the Student Cap: They will fight to lift the Maximum Student Numbers (MaSN) cap in Northern Ireland, viewing it as an arbitrary cap on ambition and a barrier to skills development. • Higher Education Funding Review: They support a fundamental review of Higher Education funding, including student fees and teaching grants, to ensure no student is disadvantaged because of costs, including at postgraduate level. • Further Education (FE): They support a new approach to third-level education that creates a skills pipeline and ensures parity of esteem between the further and higher education sectors. They commit to properly funding apprenticeships and ensuring FE colleges are supported in tandem with universities. • Apprenticeship Levy Reform: They will ensure that employers in Northern Ireland are no longer expected to contribute to the Apprenticeship Levy fund without being able to draw from it (a fund they seek to devolve). • Lifelong Learning: They will fight for legislation for a Lifelong Learning Guarantee to ensure age is never a barrier to learning. 4. Early Education and Childcare The SDLP campaigns for childcare to be recognized as a public good and economic infrastructure, noting the system is "completely broken". • Strategy Publication: They push for the publication of a new, bold, and ambitious Early Education and Childcare Strategy. • Affordability and Funding: They advocate for a cap on costs for parents and will lobby a new UK government to increase the rate of tax-free childcare to 35% and lift the annual cap. • Support for Providers: They advocate for a new longer-term funding scheme for providers, conditional on increased pay and qualifications for workers. • Cross-Border Collaboration: They support the acceleration and expansion of cross-border collaboration on early education and childcare. • Unregistered Childminding: They will lobby the Department of Health to establish a time-bound taskforce to address the issue of unregistered childminding and progress the Review of Minimum Standards.
Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP.environment: The SDLP Manifesto places significant focus on environmental protection, tackling the climate crisis and biodiversity loss, ensuring a just transition to a low-carbon economy, and prioritizing infrastructure necessary for ecological health, particularly concerning water quality. Here is a summary of the key policies on the environment: 1. Climate Legislation and Governance The SDLP is committed to supporting ambitious environmental and climate legislation at Westminster and establishing dedicated independent agencies in Northern Ireland. • Support for Ambitious Legislation: SDLP MPs will always support ambitious climate legislation at Westminster. They previously supported the Climate & Nature Bill, which aims to rapidly reduce greenhouse gas emissions, reverse biodiversity loss, and build consensus for a just transition. • Net Zero and Green Levy: Colum Eastwood tabled pioneering climate legislation in the last Westminster mandate that would have introduced tougher net zero commitments and created a new green jobs levy on large corporations to fund climate mitigation and a just transition to a low carbon economy. SDLP MPs will press a new government to include these proposals in a new Green Prosperity Plan. • Well-being of Future Generations Bill: They will support a "Well-being of Future Generations Bill" aimed at improving the social, economic, environmental, and cultural well-being of people in Northern Ireland. • Independent Environmental Protection Agency (EPA): The SDLP will campaign for an Independent Environmental Protection Agency to be established, as recommended in 2007 and agreed in the New Decade New Approach agreement in 2020. The SDLP also secured support in the Assembly in May 2024 for the establishment of an independent EPA by the end of this Assembly mandate. A key role of this EPA would be to prioritize improvement in the status of rivers, lakes, transitional, and coastal water bodies. 2. Water Quality and Natural Environment Addressing water pollution and risks to natural habitats is a central plank of the SDLP’s environmental agenda. • Lough Neagh Recovery Plan: They demand a properly funded plan of action to address the ecological crisis in Lough Neagh. Steps in this plan must include: ◦ Upgrading the Wastewater Treatment Works around Lough Neagh. ◦ Introducing unannounced sampling of water. ◦ Enforcing existing regulation on pollution with fines when necessary. ◦ Increasing inspections of farms. • Water Infrastructure: They require adequate investment to upgrade water infrastructure to prevent the risk of overspill and pollution into the environment. The current system is not fit for purpose and cannot meet new environmental standards or public demand. • Opposition to Water Charges: The SDLP is opposed to water charges and prevented their introduction in government. They argue that the Executive must prioritize investment in critical water infrastructure through alternative means, rather than imposing domestic charging. • Water Risk to Housing: They are deeply concerned that the construction of 19,000 homes is currently at risk due to a lack of water/sewerage infrastructure. 3. Climate Adaptation and Transition Policies focusing on fair transitions, clean air, and managing climate risks: • Just Transition: The SDLP will continue to hold government at Stormont and Westminster responsible for the delivery of a Just Transition. This includes ensuring it is a central tenet of all climate action plans by Executive Departments. ◦ They note that a Just Transition Fund for Agriculture has yet to be established. ◦ A Just Transition Commission is still to be established to support all sectors of the economy in meeting greenhouse gas reduction targets. • Sustainable Farming: They will work to ensure that new funding streams properly support farmers and are used to encourage the development of environmentally sustainable farming methods that support biodiversity. • Clean Air Act: They will support an ambitious new Clean Air Act with clear goals to reduce particulate matter to 10 micrograms per cubic metre as soon as possible, but no later than 2030, with stretch targets for further reduction in PM2.5 levels. They will also advocate for clean air filtration guidance for the public sector. • Flood Risk: Recognizing that 45,000 properties are at risk of flooding, a number expected to increase significantly due to climate change, they call for improved warning systems to ensure communities are better prepared. • Animal Cruelty Register: They support the introduction of an all-island animal cruelty register to prevent known animal abusers from buying or owning animals in another part of the island. 4. Sustainable Infrastructure and Planning • Public Transport: Investing in the public transport network is seen as a crucial lever to help combat the climate emergency and create sustainable communities. They have a strong record of investment in zero-emission buses. • Electric Vehicles (EV): They will push for the delivery of the EV Infrastructure Action Plan being developed by the Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Taskforce, ensuring equitable access within the network. • Planning Reform: They will seek to ensure that planning policies are aligned with broader environmental objectives to promote sustainable development. They also advocate for planning reform to prioritize climate change adaptation/projects. The SDLP views unchecked global temperature increases, climate breakdown, and the biodiversity crisis as an urgent necessity and a generational injustice. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The SDLP’s environmental policy can be viewed as tackling two main pillars simultaneously: mitigation (through promoting green jobs levies, net zero, and climate legislation) and adaptation/restoration (through addressing failing infrastructure, water quality, and biodiversity loss, particularly in sensitive areas like Lough Neagh).
Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP.brexit: The SDLP Manifesto views the UK’s departure from the European Union (EU) as a major failure of the Conservative government, stating that a "pathological obsession with leaving the European Union has severed our links to one of the world’s largest markets leaving people, community groups and businesses far worse off". The party’s key policies on Brexit focus on leveraging Northern Ireland’s unique trading status, restoring a voice in Europe, and planning for future re-accession in the context of unification. Here is a summary of the key policies on Brexit and the European Union: 1. Maximizing Dual-Market Access (The Protocol/Windsor Framework) The SDLP advocates for maximizing the competitive advantages of Northern Ireland’s unique status, which places it at the crossroads of two major markets (the UK and the EU). • Tailored Strategy: The party supports creating a strategy tailored to the sectors that have the most to gain from the Protocol/Windsor Framework. • Funding and Buy-in: This strategy should be co-developed with buy-in and funding from the Irish and British governments and the European Union. • European Investment Hub: The SDLP presses for the creation of a new "European Investment Hub" for Northern Ireland and increased funding for InterTrade Ireland to support a strong all-island economy. • European Commission Office: They will lobby for an office of the European Commission in Belfast to deepen economic and social ties between the European Union and Northern Ireland. • Trade Compliance: They commit to ensuring compliance with Article 2 of the Windsor Framework on the non-diminution of human rights following the UK’s departure from the EU. 2. Restoring Northern Ireland’s Voice in Europe The party seeks to address the democratic deficit caused by the UK’s withdrawal from the EU. • MEPs Restoration: The SDLP supports the restoration of Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) for Northern Ireland to help address the democratic deficit. They note this move is supported by a large majority (over 70%) of the NI public. • Representation Agreement: They will work towards an agreement for elected representation from Northern Ireland in the European Union to restore its voice. • Assembly Structures: They support enhancing representation through new structures, including: ◦ A new dedicated European Affairs Committee in the Northern Ireland Assembly, with powers to take evidence from UK Ministers and EU officials. ◦ Annual meetings in Belfast of the EU-UK Parliamentary Assembly. ◦ An enhanced role for the North-South Ministerial Council (NSMC) in EU affairs. • Voting Rights: They support the right of Irish citizens living in other countries to vote for Irish candidates in European elections. 3. Planning for Re-accession in the Context of Unification The SDLP is a proudly pro-European and internationalist party that believes the centrality of the European Union is vital to the peace process. They affirmed that the only viable route back into the EU is a new and agreed Ireland. • New Conversation: The SDLP affirms that now is the time for a new conversation on the future of the island in Europe. • Dedicated Process: The party is calling for a dedicated process to be put in place by the European Union to plan for Northern Ireland’s re-accession into the European Union in the context of unification. • Good Friday Agreement Commitment: They aim to fulfill the commitment in the Good Friday Agreement to "develop still further the unique relationship between their peoples and the close cooperation between their countries as friendly neighbours and as partners in the European Union". The SDLP has historically been among the most ardent opponents of the decision to leave the EU in 2016. They believe that more people across Northern Ireland have reflected on a shared European identity since the vote.
Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP.entire manifesto: The SDLP Manifesto for Westminster 2024 outlines several priorities for change, focusing broadly on ending austerity, strengthening public services, reforming governance, and advocating for specific international and economic goals. The manifesto identifies the following seven key priorities: 1. A New Start – Remove the Conservative Government from power. 2. Better Public Services for All – Reduce hospital waiting lists with additional investment in health. 3. Improved Funding Model for NI. 4. Repeal the Legacy Act. 5. A Fairer Economy for All. 6. Recognise the State of Palestine and end arms exports to Israel. 7. Restore nature and support a just transition. Detailed Policy Areas 1. Governance and Political Reform (A New Start) The SDLP MPs commit to using their votes to ensure there is no Conservative Government. They also seek reform of the devolved institutions to prevent the veto of government and the decline in public services. Key reforms include: • Seeking to initiate a review of the operation of devolution under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement. • Pressing for reform that prevents one party from collapsing devolution and removes the veto while maintaining power-sharing principles. • Supporting the return of joint nomination and election of the First Ministers. • Changing the election of the Speaker to a two-thirds majority rather than a double majority. 2. Rescuing Public Services (Health, Funding, and Pay) The manifesto advocates for an improved financial settlement for Northern Ireland to undo the impact of austerity and recognize decades of underfunding. • Financial & Fiscal Policy: They will press for a comprehensive spending review allowing the Executive to deliver multi-year, costed public service recovery plans. They seek the devolution of further fiscal powers, specifically Tourism and Hospitality VAT, the Apprenticeship Levy, and Air Passenger Duty. • Cost of Living: SDLP MPs will support a new government’s plan to levy a windfall tax on oil and gas giants. They previously introduced legislation for a green jobs levy on large corporations to fund a just transition. • Public Sector Pay: The SDLP will fight for a fair deal for public sector workers, supporting above-inflation pay increases for teachers and school support staff, and seeking pay parity between Further Education Lecturers and school teaching staff. • Health Service: They will make representations to the Treasury for a health service transformation intervention. They will seek dedicated resources to reduce waiting lists, which currently affect over half a million people (more than 1 in 4 of the population). They also argue for a government-backed indemnity scheme for GPs. • Education: They advocate for fair pay for teachers and staff, proper resourcing to tackle Educational Underachievement, and a complete overhaul of the Special Educational Needs (SEN) system. They support a cap on school uniform costs and continued progress on integrated education. 3. A Fairer Economy For All The SDLP seeks a prosperous, world-leading, and regionally equitable economy. • Dual-Market Access: They intend to maximize the competitive advantages of the Protocol/Windsor Framework by developing a tailored strategy with funding from both the Irish and British governments and the European Union. • Poverty and Welfare: They will lobby for the publication and funding of a robust Anti-Poverty Strategy. They demand that the next UK government ensures an Essentials Guarantee within Universal Credit. They also seek to reverse the punitive decision on WASPI women (Women Against State Pension Inequality) and reduce the State Pension Age. • Small Business Support: They will work to increase the VAT threshold to £100,000 and support the automatic uprating of the Employment Allowance. • Skills and Education: They will fight for a full-size university campus at Magee of at least 10,000 students and support lifting the Maximum Student Numbers (MaSN) cap in Northern Ireland. • Workers’ Rights: The SDLP supports an end to zero-hour contracts, a campaign for an equal minimum wage (to prevent discrimination against young people), and ensuring flexible working is a day-one right. They also support the introduction of at least five days of paid carers’ leave. 4. Justice, Equality, and Rights The overriding priority in the area of Justice is to Repeal the Legacy Act, which they opposed as an abhorrent amnesty. • Systemic Reforms: They call for structural and staff reforms of the prison service to enhance rehabilitation. • Policing and Paramilitarism: They will lobby for a visible police presence. They seek greater cooperation between the PSNI and An Garda Síochána to deal with border-associated crime and support the implementation of the Paramilitary Disbandment Strategy Panel. • Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG): They will lobby the Executive Office to reverse the cut to Women’s Aid NI. • Rights: They commit to ensuring a comprehensive ban on conversion practices and providing gender-affirming healthcare services for the LGBT+ population. They also support the full implementation of the UN Convention on the Right of Persons with Disabilities. • Irish Language Rights: They will work to ensure the appointment of Commissioners and establishment of bodies provided for under the Identity and Language Act 2022. 5. Climate and Infrastructure The SDLP will support ambitious climate legislation at Westminster. • Environment: They will campaign for an independent Environmental Protection Agency and fight for a Lough Neagh Recovery Plan, including upgrading Wastewater Treatment Works and enforcing pollution regulations. They also advocate for an all-island animal cruelty register and a new Clean Air Act. • Infrastructure: They will fight to ensure funding for the delivery of the A5 and advocate for the completion of the A6. They will push for progress on the delivery of the All Island strategic Rail Review. The SDLP is opposed to water charges and advocates that the Executive prioritize investment in critical water infrastructure through alternative means. 6. Our Place In The World The SDLP is a proudly internationalist party and a member of the Party of European Socialists. • Gaza: They are appalled at the ongoing situation in Gaza. They will continue to call for an Immediate Ceasefire, Recognition of the State of Palestine, and an end to the funding of Israeli arms. They support a Palestinian Visa Scheme for safe passage out of Gaza. • Refugees and Asylum: They commit to transforming the asylum system, including by repealing anti-asylum seeker legislation introduced by the Conservative government (like the Safety of Rwanda Act). They will lobby to end the ban on asylum seekers working. • Europe: They affirm the time is right for a new conversation on the future of the island in Europe. They are calling for a dedicated process to be put in place by the European Union to plan for Northern Ireland’s re-accession into the EU in the context of unification. They also support the restoration of Members of the European Parliament for Northern Ireland. The SDLP sees this election as a chance to end the politics of austerity, isolation, and division that they claim have driven governments for 14 brutal years.

Ulster Unionist Party (UUP).crime: The Ulster Unionist Party’s manifesto outlines several key policies focused on reforming the justice system, strengthening policing, addressing serious crime, and dealing with legacy issues stemming from the Troubles. Policing and Administration of Justice The party asserts that the Policing and Justice system in Northern Ireland has been mismanaged, poorly resourced, and badly understood since devolution in 2010. • Police Headcount and Recruitment: They are steadfast in their support for delivering a police officer headcount of 7,500. They propose recruiting 500 additional police officers over the next 3 years, beyond normal replenishment. • Officer Attestation: Police Officers should attest at the start of their training, becoming legally appointed from their first day, aligning with practices in the rest of the United Kingdom. • Speeding Up Justice: They note that justice takes twice as long through Northern Ireland courts compared to the rest of the UK, which detrimentally affects victims and witnesses. They will work to speed up the administration of justice and reduce the time between arrest and sentencing. • Addressing Race-Related Intimidation: The UUP will support the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) and civic society to address and end race-related intimidation and discrimination. • Zero-Tolerance for Hate Crimes: They commit to implementing a zero-tolerance approach to hate crimes. Sentencing and Offenders The party believes sentencing structures are broken, leading to a lack of public confidence in the justice system. • Stronger Sentences: They will press for stronger sentences, particularly for habitual, violent re-offenders. • Review of 50/50 Sentences: They will campaign for a review of the near mandatory practice of giving serious offenders a 50/50 custodial sentence (allowing only half of the sentence to be served). • Guilty Pleas and Reduced Sentences: They propose that the practice of a perpetrator admitting guilt on the last day of a trial to receive a reduced sentence must be stopped, meaning longer time spent behind bars. • Prison Resources and Remand: They want the Prison Service to be given the resources it needs, including a workforce that is fit for purpose. They will also seek to reduce the number of people held on remand by speeding up justice and introducing alternative methods like electronic tagging (as used in England). Victims and Legal System Reform • Standing By Victims: They believe victims are often regarded as an afterthought and need a change in culture within the justice system where the State is seen to fulfill its duty of protecting law-abiding citizens. They stress that witnesses must be kept engaged to ensure continuity of evidence and maximize positive outcomes. • Legal Aid and Lawfare: They aim for more progress in reducing the legal aid bill, which costs over £90 million a year. The UUP has called for a comprehensive review of legal aid in Northern Ireland (which they state is the most generous in the UK). They suggest all reform options, including capping the legal aid bill, should be considered. Organized Crime and Illegal Immigration • Challenging Organized Crime: The party commits to challenging organized criminal gangs (including those regarded as paramilitary or terrorist in nature) which plague communities with serious criminal activity, such as drug dealing. They demand a concerted effort against the leadership of such groups, focusing on arrests and seizure of assets to reassure the public that "crime really does not pay". • Illegal Immigration: The UUP will implement a zero-tolerance policy on illegal immigration. They will support government measures to target people traffickers through cooperation with other European countries. Legacy Issues (Troubles-Related Crime) The UUP remains dedicated to achieving justice and accountability for victims of Troubles-related crimes. • Opposition to Legacy Act: They remain opposed to the Northern Ireland Troubles (Legacy and Reconciliation) Act because it denies justice for victims and grants amnesty to perpetrators. They also oppose any return to the Stormont House Agreement Legacy proposals. • PSNI Legacy Investigation Branch (LIB): They support the funding and expansion of the PSNI Legacy Investigation Branch to deal with all Troubles-related crime, including murder, attempted murder, sexual crimes, and assaults. They propose this branch be enhanced by increasing qualified homicide investigators, funded by Westminster. • Public Prosecution Service (PPS) Split: They advocate for splitting the Public Prosecution Service into two sections: one for normal workload and a second dealing purely with legacy issues, with the latter funded by Westminster.
Ulster Unionist Party (UUP).healthcare: The Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto outlines its commitments for the health and social care system, aiming to build a responsive, accessible,The Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto outlines its commitments for the health and social care system, aiming to build a responsive, accessible, quality system, despite facing severe financial challenges. Current State and Financial Challenges • The UUP states its overall aim is to build a world-leading health and social care system that is responsive, accessible and delivers quality care. • While the system is fortunate to be free at the point of delivery, just as the NHS was originally envisioned, the system is currently not functioning as it should. • Key issues include wholly unacceptable waiting times, demand outstripping capacity, and challenges in the recruitment and retention of sufficient Health and Social Care (HSC) workers. • The party demonstrated its commitment to making health and well-being its number one priority by taking on the Department of Health, which is described as undoubtedly the most difficult job in the Northern Ireland Executive. • The system is currently facing unprecedented challenges due to the devastating financial implications of the 2024/25 Budget allocation, which is delivering a record £184m cut in funding. • The UUP Minister of Health has sought to deliver stability and is working to implement difficult savings, but a shortfall in the budget remains. The party will not take drastic actions, such as making thousands of health workers redundant or closing the equivalent of a large hospital, as this would inflict suffering and harm on patients. • The health service needs sustainable multi-year investment to deliver intended benefits for patients and the wider system. Key Policy Commitments for Health and Social Care The UUP’s commitments are centered on transforming service delivery, supporting staff, and empowering primary care: 1. Service Transformation and Elective Care: ◦ The party commits to continuing to transform services to meet population needs. ◦ This transformation includes the identification of the next Elective Overnight Stay Centre. ◦ They will continue to commission activity in Day Procedure Centres and support the continued expansion and utilisation of mega-clinics. ◦ These efforts will be supported by the publication of a HSC reconfiguration blueprint, a multi-year plan, and the ongoing implementation of the elective care framework, mental health strategy, and cancer strategy. ◦ While waiting times remain intolerable, the manifesto notes tangible improvements have begun across many specialties, including noticeable reductions in treatment waiting times for General Surgery (-21%), Trauma and Orthopaedic surgery (-8%), ENT (-16%), Gynaecology (-22%), and Urology (-10%). 2. Workforce Support and Pay Parity: ◦ The UUP commits to its long-standing policy of maintaining pay parity for health and social care staff. ◦ They will continue to engage with Executive colleagues to ensure that independent pay recommendations are funded and delivered as quickly as possible. ◦ To achieve savings, they will accelerate progress in reducing the most expensive forms of agency staff and will introduce a new framework to limit hugely expensive off-contract medical and locum costs, following the successful ban on off-contract nursing. ◦ They also plan to stabilize Trust non-clinical banks and place greater emphasis on exit surveys to address staff turnover. 3. Primary Care and MDT Rollout: ◦ Acknowledging the pivotal role of primary care (which handles over 90% of all health contacts), the UUP will continue to empower primary care to deliver a broader range of services, including elective services. ◦ They commit to the further rollout of the Multidisciplinary Team (MDT) programme. 4. Social Care and Fair Work: ◦ The party is committed to long-term sustainability and strengthening of the social care system. ◦ They will drive through the work of the Fair Work Forum to develop proposals aimed at improving terms and conditions and career prospects for social care staff. They emphasize that wages must climb well beyond the lowest levels for the sector to achieve sustainability. 5. Health Inequalities: ◦ The UUP has a renewed determination to drive improvements in population health and address health inequalities, with a new targeted and innovative health inequalities initiative slated for announcement in the autumn. The importance of the National Health Service (NHS), which delivers universal healthcare free at the point of use, is also highlighted as one of the most cherished benefits of Northern Ireland’s Union with Great Britain.
Ulster Unionist Party (UUP).housing: The Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto highlights the severity of the ongoing housing crisis and outlines a singular key policy commitment to address it.The Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto highlights the severity of the ongoing housing crisis and outlines a singular key policy commitment to address it. Recognition of the Crisis The sources state that the United Kingdom is currently experiencing a pressing housing crisis, which has led to a significant number of citizens lacking a secure place to call home. This situation has caused an alarming surge in property prices and rental costs, pushing many into housing insecurity or even homelessness. The UUP recognizes that the housing crisis is a multi-faceted issue, impacting critical areas of life such as health, education, and the justice system. It is deemed imperative that all regions of the UK, including Northern Ireland, collaborate to develop and implement comprehensive housing strategies to tackle this crisis. Key Policy Commitment on Housing The UUP pledges: • To press the next Government to collaborate with the devolved administrations to develop and finance a robust strategy to tackle the housing crisis effectively. In essence, the party’s focus at Westminster is to ensure the UK Government works jointly with the devolved governments and provides the necessary funding for a strong, effective strategy to resolve the housing crisis.
Ulster Unionist Party (UUP).immigration: The Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto outlines its key policies on immigration, which focus on controlling illegal immigration while welcoming and supporting genuine asylum seekers and necessary skilled workers. Policy Commitments on Immigration The UUP’s core commitments regarding immigration are: • Zero-Tolerance Policy on Illegal Immigration: The party will implement a zero-tolerance policy on illegal immigration while simultaneously being responsive to genuine asylum seekers. • Targeting People Traffickers: They will support government measures aimed at targeting people traffickers through cooperation with other European countries. The sources note that the market in people trafficking and illegal immigration has become "big business" which is cruel and exploitative and must be challenged and brought to a halt. • Expediting Asylum Applications: To ensure genuine asylum seekers are dealt with in a timely manner, the UUP will press to increase the number of staff working on asylum applications threefold. ◦ They commit to fast-tracking asylum applications for vulnerable individuals, specifically families with children, single mothers, or those who have protected professions such as doctors or pharmacists. • Integration and Support: For those who wish to make Northern Ireland their home and contribute, the UUP emphasizes the need to make them welcome and support their integration into society through education and health systems, absorbing values of tolerance, hard work, and civic responsibility. Context and Rationale The manifesto provides context for its stance on immigration: • Positive Contribution of Immigration: Controlled immigration is recognized as important to the UK, helping to create a skilled workforce. Northern Ireland specifically relies on people from other countries for doctors, nurses, other health care professionals, and for highly intensive manual jobs within the agri-food industry. • Impact of Illegal Immigration: The party notes that illegal immigration undermines established systems, places a burden on public services, and prevents genuine asylum seekers from being dealt with in a timely manner. • Multicultural Society: Northern Ireland is described as having moved away from "the old binary labelling of Orange and Green" and is now a multi-cultural society with a variety of ethnic minorities whose culture is celebrated and seen as enriching, welcoming, and positive. • Addressing Intimidation: A minority of people in Northern Ireland reportedly feel threatened by multi-cultural diversity, leading to intimidation. The UUP views this as unacceptable and will work across civic society and support the police to address and end race-related intimidation and discrimination. • Supporting Ethnic Minorities: They commit to supporting a Racial Equality Strategy for Northern Ireland, promoting a multicultural society, and ensuring fair and proportionate funding for ethnic minority and religious groups, including cultural events. The overall aim is to have an immigration system that is open, transparent, and fair.
Ulster Unionist Party (UUP).defence: The Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto outlines several key commitments regarding defence and security, emphasizing increased investment, bolstering the UK’s strategic capabilities, and enhancing Northern Ireland’s role in the UK’s defence infrastructure. Strategic Context and Increased Spending • The UUP views the world as less secure than it has been since the Cold War, citing multiple conflicts globally, including those in Ukraine, Syria, Southern Sudan, Mali, Yemen, and the Middle East. • They acknowledge the genuine threat Russia poses to the wider European region, noting that its invasion of Ukraine has drawn battle lines between NATO and the Russian Federation and its allies (China, North Korea, and Belarus). • The party commits to voting to increase UK Defence Spending beyond the NATO Target of 2% of national GDP to 2.5%. • They recognize that the UK is a permanent member of the UN Security Council, a major contributor to NATO, and holds multi-lateral and bi-lateral defence agreements globally. Collective Defence is identified as the UK’s greatest asset, allowing it to defend freedom and democracy where threatened. Northern Ireland’s Role in Defence The UUP insists that the UK must take Northern Ireland’s strategic position seriously in defence planning, especially given the current "pre-war world" as described by the Secretary of State for Defence. • Integration into Command Structures: It is important that Northern Ireland is brought into the UK’s "National Defence Command" structures. • Naval Base: The party will support the establishment of a Naval Base in Northern Ireland. This would allow NATO assets to be deployed from Northern Ireland to increase patrolling of the UK’s western approaches. • RAF Presence: They support Aldergrove Military Base reverting back to an RAF station. This would enable the forward mounting of airframes, alleviating the burden on Scottish bases and allowing them to focus on the UK’s Northern approaches. An enhanced RAF presence is also needed to enable the quick interception of hostile aircraft. • Defence Industry: The UUP will lobby to increase Northern Ireland’s share of the defence industry manufacturing base, which includes research and development. Northern Ireland already plays a part in defence output through the manufacturing of NLAW missiles (anti-armour weapons used by Ukrainian armed forces) and surface-to-air missiles like HVM. • Armed Forces Personnel: They commit to maintaining the Armed Forces in Northern Ireland, both Regular and Reserve, not below 3,000 personnel. • Nuclear Deterrent: The party will continue to support the UK’s independent nuclear deterrent. Addressing Irish Defence and UK Security The manifesto highlights concerns regarding the UK’s western defences and the Republic of Ireland’s lack of defence maturity: • Western Approaches: Limited ability to react to Russian intelligence shipping and warships operating in the "Greenland-Iceland-UK Gap" undermines UK and Europe’s defences. • Ireland’s Preparedness: The UUP notes that the Irish Government’s ability to protect its underseas cabling is "non-existent," and its general preparedness is "abysmal" and "unsustainable," relying on others. • Encouraging Irish Cooperation: They will encourage the Republic of Ireland to take defence seriously and either enhance their Partnership and Cooperation Programme or join NATO and commit to spending 2% of GDP on defence. • Airheads: Enhanced Naval and RAF platforms in Northern Ireland could assist with the protection of rapid deployments of military assets from the US and Canada via Shannon or Aldergrove airports, creating two important airheads that allow for redundancy if Ireland were to regress further from providing support to deploying US assets. The UUP is grateful for the protection provided by the UK’s Armed Forces, who guarantee Northern Ireland’s defence and security, and notes that the people of Northern Ireland are over-represented in the Armed Forces by share of population.
Ulster Unionist Party (UUP).economy: The Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto, "Making Northern Ireland Work," emphasizes economic growth, utilizing the benefits of the Union, and implementing targeted tax and investment policies. The goal of growing the economy is central to the manifesto’s underlying framework of the "5Ps" (people, place, prosperity, public services, and peace). Key economic policies outlined in the manifesto include: Investment and Regional Growth • City Deals and Growth Deals: The UUP affirms its commitment to supporting City Deals and Growth Deals across Northern Ireland, including the Belfast Region City Deal and others in Derry-Londonderry/Strabane, Mid South West, and Causeway Coast and Glens. These initiatives, supported by potential investment of £1.3 billion funded by Westminster and Stormont, are intended to foster global centres of innovation excellence by harnessing the expertise of universities and businesses. • Foreign Direct Investment (FDI): The party aims to see the economy grow through Foreign Direct Investment and by utilizing and promoting Small, Medium, and Micro enterprises. • Key Sectors: The party recognizes agriculture as Northern Ireland’s largest industry (feeding around 10 million people across the UK and EU). They also note the importance of healthy fintech, cybersecurity, aerospace, and defence sectors. Taxation and Business Competitiveness • Corporation Tax Reduction: Ulster Unionists aim to work with Westminster to gradually reduce Corporation Tax in Northern Ireland to 15%. This reduction, coupled with implementing necessary reforms, is intended to enhance competitiveness, attract investment, and drive economic growth. • Hospitality VAT Reduction: Recognizing that Northern Ireland’s tourism and hospitality sector faces unfair competition from the Republic of Ireland (RoI), the party will work at Westminster to seek commitment to lower Leisure and Hospitality VAT in Northern Ireland to match the rate in the Republic of Ireland. This is designed to allow local businesses (hotels, restaurants, and leisure) to compete on a level playing field. Trade and Regulatory Advantage • Freeport Northern Ireland: The UUP will lobby in Parliament to establish a "Freeport Northern Ireland," capitalizing on UK government policy.
