Given Northern Ireland’s unique geographical circumstances, they advocate for designating all ports and airports (including Londonderry, Aldergrove, Warrenpoint, Belfast, and Larne) as freeports to extend benefits across the entire region. • Trusted Trader Scheme: They will also argue for the creation of a "Trusted Trader" scheme to enable businesses outside secure port zones to access processing relief at zero tariff rates, maximizing economic benefits. Workforce and Energy • Job Skills Fund: The party pledges to invest in skills development through the establishment of a Northern Ireland Job Skills Fund, similar to successful programmes in Scotland and the RoI. This fund would involve government, business, and trade unions collaborating with educational institutions to provide targeted skills training. • Skills Investment: The UUP commits to dedicating funding equivalent to the UK Apprenticeship Levy paid by Northern Ireland firms, ensuring a minimum annual investment of no less than £35 million into the Skills Fund. • Energy Market Integration: The party renews its pledge to review energy security and prices, advocating for the creation of an All-Islands (UK & Ireland) energy market. This is intended to leverage the benefits of greater integration with Great Britain’s energy markets, enhancing energy security, reducing prices, and streamlining regulatory oversight. Pensions and General Taxation • Pensions Triple Lock: Ulster Unionist MPs firmly believe in maintaining the UK’s "triple lock" for state pensions, ensuring the financial security and dignity of the elderly population. • Progressive Taxation: They advocate for a progressive approach to taxation, ensuring the burden is distributed equitably.
Ulster Unionist Party (UUP).education: The Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto outlines its key policies on education, driven by the belief that the future of Northern Ireland depends on the potential of its children and young people. The overall commitment is to build a world-class education system that is inclusive, supportive, and high-quality for all children, regardless of ability, disability, or support needs. The party’s commitments in education are summarized across four main areas: 1. Establishing a Single Education System The UUP plans to establish a single education system that aims to : • Value every child equally, ensuring tailored support and resources are provided to meet individual needs. • Integrate children of all abilities, thereby fostering a culture of mutual respect and inclusivity. • Promote early support and intervention, recognizing the critical role of early education and childcare in a child’s holistic development and the well-being of families. 2. Early Education and Childcare To ensure every child receives the best start in life, the UUP will focus on : • Advocating for high-quality early education and childcare services that are accessible and affordable for all families. • Supporting initiatives that enhance the early learning experience, which lays a strong foundation for future academic and personal success. • Enabling families to thrive by providing flexible childcare solutions that support parents and caregivers. 3. Therapeutic Learning Environments and Resources The party recognizes that a well-resourced educational environment is vital for fostering learning and development. They commit to: • Securing adequate funding to create and maintain therapeutic learning environments that cater to the diverse needs of all students. • Ensuring that schools are equipped with the necessary resources, including modern facilities and learning materials, to support every child’s educational journey. 4. Support for Educators and Students with Disabilities The success of the system relies on dedicated staff and support for all students, especially those with disabilities. • Valuing Educators: They will advocate for fair and competitive pay for teachers, classroom assistants, childcare staff, and the entire multidisciplinary team involved in education. They aim to recognize and reward the invaluable contributions of all education professionals, ensuring they are supported and appreciated. • Supporting Young People with Disabilities: They are committed to creating equal opportunities for young people with disabilities. This includes securing funding and resources for post-secondary education and training for these young people. • The party will work to develop pathways to further learning and employment opportunities that are on par with those available to mainstream school leavers. The overarching goal is to ensure all young people in Northern Ireland have access to the support and opportunities they need to succeed, regardless of their abilities.
Ulster Unionist Party (UUP).environment: The Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto outlines its key policies on the environment, focusing on climate change mitigation, sustainable agriculture, andThe Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto outlines its key policies on the environment, focusing on climate change mitigation, sustainable agriculture, and addressing urgent regional issues like the crisis at Lough Neagh. Climate Change and Emissions Targets • The UUP has a strong commitment to addressing the climate emergency in Northern Ireland. • While disappointed that their proposal for Northern Ireland’s "fair contribution" to the UK Net Zero greenhouse gas target was not fully incorporated into the final Bill, the UUP remains dedicated to achieving substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. • They embrace the recommendation of the independent Climate Change Committee for an 82% reduction in greenhouse gases by 2050 compared to 1990 levels. • The party will continue to strive for an 82% or better reduction in greenhouse gases by 2050 as part of a comprehensive climate mitigation strategy, rather than the 100% target currently legislated. • The UUP is committed to ensuring that Northern Ireland makes a fair contribution to the goal of UK Net Zero. • They support the UK’s Ten Point Plan for a Green Industrial Revolution, which seeks to mobilise public and private investment in clean technologies such as wind, carbon capture, and hydrogen. They believe investing in these technologies will enable Northern Ireland to contribute to a New Green Industrial Revolution and lead the world in combating climate change. • They emphasize that leveraging Northern Ireland’s position within the UK is necessary to access the resources, expertise, and collaborative opportunities required to accelerate the transition to a low-carbon economy. Lough Neagh Crisis • The UUP understands the urgent need for a collaborative effort to address the pressing issues affecting Lough Neagh’s water quality and long-term sustainability. • They stress the necessity of establishing a management task force inclusive of all stakeholders to oversee ongoing monitoring, management, and the formulation of future plans for the Lough. • Collaboration among Stormont Executive departments, arms-length bodies, and stakeholders is vital to charting a viable path forward. • The party will continue to press NI Water for an urgent assessment of the proximity to a critical tipping point where Lough Neagh water may become unusable for drinking. • The UUP is resolute in its commitment to preserving the ecological integrity of Lough Neagh through collaborative, cross-departmental efforts to mitigate pollution, protect wildlife, and ensure the availability of clean drinking water. Woodland and Rural Environment • Ulster Unionists commit to planting more of the right trees in the right places and doing more to look after existing trees and woods, as trees capture carbon and woodlands provide habitats for wildlife. • This will help Northern Ireland make a fair contribution to the UK’s efforts to tackle climate change, assist nature recovery, reduce the risk of flooding, create new green jobs, and improve access to woods for everyone. • They will also safeguard the natural environment and biodiversity of the countryside, working closely with farmers as the stewards of the land. Agriculture and Sustainability In relation to agriculture, the manifesto commits to supporting sustainability across the sector: • They will increase funding for research, development, and knowledge transfer to drive innovation, productivity, and sustainability across the agri-food sector. • They will work in partnership with farmers to develop a comprehensive, long-term strategy for the future of Northern Ireland agriculture. Overall, the UUP’s environmental policies seek a balanced approach, integrating climate action with economic and rural considerations, and relying heavily on collaboration and leveraging Northern Ireland’s place within the UK to secure necessary resources and expertise.
Ulster Unionist Party (UUP).brexit: The Ulster Unionist Party’s policies concerning Brexit primarily center on their commitment to safeguarding Northern Ireland’s position within the United Kingdom while addressing the complexities and ongoing challenges created by the Northern Ireland Protocol and its successor, the Windsor Framework. The key policies are summarized under the following headings: The Union and Challenging Divergence • Safeguarding the Union: The UUP stands firm in its commitment to safeguarding Northern Ireland’s integral position within the United Kingdom. They will continue to fight for the preservation of the Union. • Challenging Erosion of Sovereignty: The party will work with a new government at Westminster to challenge any attempts to erode Northern Ireland’s sovereignty or undermine the integrity of the Union. • Challenging Divergence: They will challenge the outworkings of the Windsor Framework that cause further divergence between Great Britain (GB) and Northern Ireland. • Economic Benefits: The UUP highlights that the Union allows Northern Ireland to trade with the rest of the UK and provides access to global markets through the UK’s extensive network of trade agreements. Stance on the Northern Ireland Protocol and Windsor Framework • Opposition to the Protocol: The UUP has consistently campaigned against the Northern Ireland Protocol since it was imposed on the region. • Windsor Framework as a Stepping-Stone: The party views the Windsor Framework as a stepping-stone in addressing the challenges posed by the Protocol. • Vigilant Scrutiny: While acknowledging progress, the UUP remains vigilant in scrutinising the outworking of the Framework, as well as future negotiations between Westminster and the EU. • Restoring the Internal Market: The ultimate goal of this scrutiny is to ensure that Northern Ireland’s place within the UK internal market is fully restored. • Need for Further Reform: The party recognizes the complexities and nuances of the Framework and acknowledges that further reforms will be necessary to address constantly developing concerns. Democratic Scrutiny Mechanisms • Reviewing Scrutiny Processes: The UUP will campaign to have the existing scrutiny processes of the Windsor Framework reviewed and replaced with structures that guarantee necessary safeguards. • Committee Concerns: They have already highlighted concerns that the Windsor Framework Democratic Scrutiny Committee of the Northern Ireland Assembly is "not fit for purpose," as its ability to effectively assess EU legislation and policies impacting Northern Ireland is greatly reduced by its inability to act collegiately. Trade and Economic Measures • "Freeport Northern Ireland": Capitalizing on UK government policy, the UUP will lobby for the establishment of a "Freeport Northern Ireland," specifically addressing Northern Ireland’s "unique geographical circumstances and the impact of the Northern Ireland Protocol". They advocate for designating all ports and airports (including Londonderry, Aldergrove, Warrenpoint, Belfast, and Larne) as freeports. • "Trusted Trader" Scheme: They will argue for the creation of a "Trusted Trader" scheme to allow businesses outside secure port zones to access processing relief at zero tariff rates, thereby maximizing economic benefits.
Ulster Unionist Party (UUP).entire manifesto: The Ulster Unionist Party’s 2024 Westminster Manifesto, titled "Making Northern Ireland Work," is underpinned by "The 5Ps": people, place, prosperity, public services, and peace, with a focus on growing the economy. The key policies across major areas of the manifesto are summarized below: The Union and Windsor Framework • The party stands firm in its commitment to safeguarding Northern Ireland’s integral position within the United Kingdom. • It pledges to actively engage in parliamentary debates, committees, and legislation at Westminster, advocating for policies that benefit Northern Ireland. • The party acknowledges the Windsor Framework as a stepping-stone in addressing the challenges of the Northern Ireland Protocol but remains vigilant in scrutinizing its outworking. • The UUP will work with a new government at Westminster to challenge attempts to erode Northern Ireland’s sovereignty or undermine the integrity of the Union. • They will campaign to have the existing scrutiny processes of the Windsor Framework reviewed and replaced with structures that guarantee safeguards. Economy and Taxation • The UUP affirms commitment to supporting City Deals and Growth Deals across Northern Ireland, including the Belfast Region City Deal, with a potential investment of £1.3 billion. • They will work at Westminster to seek commitment to lower Leisure and Hospitality VAT in Northern Ireland to match the rate in the Republic of Ireland (RoI), enabling local businesses to compete on a level playing field. • The party will lobby to establish a "Freeport Northern Ireland," advocating for the designation of all ports and airports in Northern Ireland as freeports. They will also argue for a "Trusted Trader" scheme. • Ulster Unionists aim to work with Westminster to gradually reduce Corporation Tax in Northern Ireland to 15%. • They pledge to invest in skills development by establishing a Northern Ireland Job Skills Fund, committing a minimum annual investment of no less than £35 million. • In taxation and pensions, they firmly believe in maintaining the UK’s "triple lock" for state pensions to safeguard the financial security of the elderly. Health and Social Care • The party is committed to transforming health services to meet population needs. • This includes identifying the next Elective Overnight Stay Centre and continuing the expansion and utilization of Day Procedure Centres and mega-clinics. • They commit to their long-standing policy of maintaining pay parity for health and social care staff and ensuring independent pay recommendations are funded. • Savings will be accelerated by reducing the use of expensive agency staff and introducing a new framework to limit off-contract medical and locum costs. • The UUP will continue to empower primary care to deliver a broader range of services and commit to the further rollout of the Multidisciplinary Team (MDT) programme. • For social care, they will drive through the work of the Fair Work Forum to improve terms and conditions and career prospects for staff. A Fairer Society and Education • The UUP supports providing accessible, affordable childcare and promoting flexible working and parental leave for both parents. They will also promote the widely accepted definition of a woman as an adult female and protect women’s spaces. • They support banning the practice of conversion therapy, aiming for zero new HIV diagnoses by 2030, and implementing a zero-tolerance approach to hate crimes. • Ulster Unionist MPs will press the next UK government to abolish the Universal Credit two-child limit. • They advocate for increasing the value of Carer’s Allowance and raising the earnings cap to allow unpaid carers to remain in the labour market. • The party will press for the incorporation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities into UK law and oppose any scaling back of support such as Personal Independence Payment (PIP). • In education, they commit to establishing a single education system that values every child equally and integrates children of all abilities. They will secure funding for therapeutic learning environments and advocate for fair pay for all educators and support staff. Agriculture and Environment • They commit to maintaining and enhancing Direct Payments to farmers , cutting bureaucracy, and increasing funding for research and development in the sector. • The party is dedicated to achieving an 82% or better reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, rather than the 100% target currently legislated. • The UUP supports the establishment of a multi-agency management task force for Lough Neagh to address water quality and long-term sustainability. Justice and Legacy • The manifesto commits to delivering a police officer headcount of 7,500 (recruiting 500 additional officers over the next 3 years). • They will press for stronger sentences for habitual, violent re-offenders and work to speed up the administration of justice. • They will campaign for a review of the near mandatory practice of giving serious offenders a 50/50 custodial sentence. • The party will work to reduce the Legal Aid bill, which costs over £90 million a year, and calls for a comprehensive review of the system. • Regarding legacy issues, the UUP remains opposed to the Northern Ireland Troubles (Legacy and Reconciliation) Act. • They support the funding and expansion of the PSNI Legacy Investigation Branch (LIB) to deal with all Troubles-related crime , and splitting the Public Prosecution Service into two sections, with one section dedicated solely to legacy issues, funded by Westminster. Defence, Security, and Veterans • The UUP commits to voting to increase UK Defence Spending beyond the NATO Target of 2% of national GDP to 2.5%. • They will lobby to increase Northern Ireland’s share of the defence industry manufacturing base. • They support the establishment of a Naval Base in Northern Ireland and Aldergrove Military Base reverting back to an RAF station. • For veterans, they will advocate for the retention of the Office for Veterans’ Affairs (OVA) with a cabinet attending Minister and a properly resourced presence in devolved regions. • They will commission an independent review of the medical discharge process and advocate for the inclusion of chronic pain as a compensable condition within the Armed Forces Compensation Scheme. Immigration and Artificial Intelligence • The party will implement a zero-tolerance policy on illegal immigration while being responsive to genuine asylum seekers. • They will increase the number of staff working on asylum applications threefold and fast-track applications for vulnerable individuals (families with children, single mothers) and those in protected professions. • On Artificial Intelligence (A.I.), the UUP commits to increased public and private investment in A.I. research and development. • They will work in Parliament to establish robust ethical and regulatory frameworks governing the development and deployment of A.I. technologies.

Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV).crime: The TUV Manifesto outlines several key policies related to policing, justice, legacy issues, and the treatment of criminals, particularly focusing on Northern Ireland’s specific constitutional challenges and alignment with the Reform UK platform on immigration. 1. Policing and Justice in Northern Ireland The TUV notes a huge crisis of confidence in the PSNI within the Unionist community. Their policies in this area demand significant changes: • End Two-Tier Policing: They insist that blatant two-tier policing must end. • Merit-Based Recruitment: They demand an end to the "anti-Protestant discrimination of 50/50" and affirm that recruitment must be based on merit. • Investigating Historic Crimes: TUV finds the equivocation of the DOJ and PSNI over who investigates the non-terrorist criminality of the IRA to be intolerable. This fuels their belief that a "blind eye approach" exists regarding the extra-curriculum activities of Provisionals under the "peace process," a matter TUV will continue to pursue. • Policing Board Exclusion: TUV supports banning convicted criminals (citing Gerry Kelly as an example) from holding positions on the Policing Board. Jim Allister drafted a Private Members Bill to achieve this, though it was defeated by the combined efforts of Sinn Fein, the SDLP, and Alliance. 2. Legacy and Victims Issues TUV seeks a radical change to the whole approach to legacy and victims : • Changing the Definition of Victim: The definition of "victim" needs to change to exclude victim makers so that "the innocent must reclaim the word ’victim’". • No Amnesty and Legacy Act Opposition: TUV maintains there can be no amnesty for historic crimes, as many victims continue to demand justice. Consequently, TUV is opposed to the Legacy Act which has "shut the door on justice". • Rejecting "Truth Commissions": Any form of "truth commission" should be rejected because terrorists have already proved they have no interest in the truth. • Serious Criminal Investigations: The PSNI should get serious about criminal investigations of historic crimes where evidence exists, ensuring political considerations play no part. • Glorification of Terrorism: Legislation on the glorification of terrorism needs to be revisited and applied equally across the UK regardless of the terror group being celebrated. • Role of the Republic of Ireland: The Republic of Ireland should be made to face up to its historic role in facilitating terrorism in Northern Ireland by providing a safe haven for terrorists. 3. Immigration and Foreign Criminals TUV supports the robust migration policies aligned with Reform UK across the whole of the UK. Key measures related to foreign criminality and illegal migration include: • Deportation of Foreign Criminals: TUV supports the policy to deport foreign nationals immediately after their prison sentence ends. • Citizenship Withdrawal: They advocate for withdrawing citizenship from immigrants who commit crime, with the exception of some misdemeanor offenses. • Illegal Migration/The Protocol: The manifesto highlights that the UK Government’s Rwanda Bill cannot apply in Northern Ireland due to the supremacy of EU law imposed by the Protocol, making Northern Ireland a potential "magnet for illegal migrants". • Stopping Illegal Migrants: The plan to "Stop the Boats" includes securing the immediate detention for all illegal migrants and ensuring zero illegal immigrants are resettled in the UK.
Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV).healthcare: The TUV Manifesto outlines several key policies regarding health and the NHS, emphasizing constitutional issues that affect the health service, alongside demands for increased funding, better staffing, and a defense of the sanctity of life. Constitutional Threat to the NHS The TUV views the constitutional subjugation of Northern Ireland to EU law via the Protocol as a direct threat to the functioning of the NHS in the region. • Foreign Law Supremacy: The Northern Ireland Protocol/Windsor Framework means that the UK is "ruled in significant part by its foreign laws and court". • Specific Example (Dental Care): TUV highlights that Northern Ireland has no say in over 300 areas of law decided by the EU. For example, the EU is currently proposing to ban the use of amalgam in dental fillings from January 1, 2025. The TUV notes that if this ban proceeds in Northern Ireland, the NHS Dental services are likely to become unsustainable here, even as they continue in Great Britain, because current NHS funding barely covers the cost of amalgam procedures, and alternatives are much more expensive. TUV considers it "absurd" and "completely intolerable" that a foreign Parliament should consider imposing legislation that places an aspect of the NHS in jeopardy. Investment and Service Provision TUV criticizes the current administration for failing to prioritize the health service, noting that the budget passed by Stormont was down by 2.3% compared to what was actually spent by the end of last year. • Sustained Investment: Sustaining long term investment in health is a TUV priority. • Prioritizing Frontline Resources: TUV argues that money should be put into providing more nurses, doctors and beds in hospitals, rather than squandering millions on schemes like the Irish language, north/south structures, or "rights agendas". They stress that the NHS needs more doctors and nurses, not more deputy directors. • Opposing Closures: They are opposed to the closure of minor injuries units and other local facilities, noting that closures should not be the default position to save money. • Restoring GP Services: A readily accessible GP service must be restored, which TUV notes will help ease the burden on Emergency Departments (A&Es). Getting an appointment with a GP should not be a challenge. Staffing and Workforce TUV recognizes that appalling waiting lists are due, in large measure, to Stormont’s failure to prioritize health, leading to the removal of hundreds of beds and associated staff. • Disincentivize Agency Reliance: The drift to agencies must be disincentivised and loyalty to the NHS rewarded to address the "haemorrhaging of skilled nurses and realignment to agencies". • Nursing Reserve Service: TUV continues to campaign for the creation of a Nursing Reserve Service, akin to the Army Reserve. This service would enlist retired and former nurses, requiring them to keep up with relevant training, receive modest remuneration as reserves, and be available to be called upon in an emergency. Mental Health and Specific Care Needs • Mental Health Funding: TUV recognizes the importance of facing up to the mental health problem and supports increased funding for Community Mental Health services. This funding would support people experiencing mental ill-health in their recovery and promote early intervention strategies to help prevent the need for hospital admissions. • Acute Beds: They believe there is a need for adequate acute psychiatric beds so that any patient requiring one can access it within their Trust area. They argue that no patient should be forced to travel outside their Trust area, as proximity to family and friends is vital for mental wellbeing. • Cancer Services: TUV stresses that strenuous efforts are now required to make up the lost ground in meeting general needs, particularly in respect of cancer. Pro-Life Stance TUV affirms its position on social issues concerning the sanctity of life: • Opposition to Abortion: TUV is unashamedly pro-life. They oppose the full commissioning of abortion services (demanded by Sinn Fein and Alliance MLAs). Halting the "pandemic of destruction of the unborn" is a key TUV goal. • Opposition to Euthanasia: They believe in the sanctity of life and oppose euthanasia at the end-of-life stage.
Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV).housing: The TUV Manifesto addresses housing policy with a focus on ensuring suitable, decent accommodation for all citizens, alongside specific proposals for maintenance, development, and social policy concerning housing allocation. Here is a summary of the key policies on housing: 1. Ensuring Decent Housing and Maintenance The TUV believes that everyone is entitled to decent housing. A key priority is addressing the common request of Housing Executive and Housing Association tenants: repairs to be carried out in a timely manner. • Proactive Funding for Basics: TUV argues that adequate funding can be found for basics like proactive maintenance and addressing issues like mould, especially given that others propose expenditure on items that deliver "no tangible day to day benefit" (such as Casement Park). 2. Housing Supply and Development • Dereliction: The manifesto states that the dereliction of housing in working class areas cannot continue. • Urban Renewal: TUV proposes a policy of one house down and at least one house up in urban areas. • Boosting Housebuilding (Economic Policy): In alignment with the Reform UK platform, TUV supports policies designed to substantially boost housebuilding. This includes cutting Residential Stamp Duty to 0% below £750k (2% from £750k - £1.5m and 4% over £1.5m). • Planning Reform: They also support reforming the planning system to fast-track new housing on brownfield sites. • Relieving Pressure (Immigration): TUV notes that strict limits on immigration are necessary to relieve pressure on the housing supply. 3. Housing Policy Reform and Social Issues • Housing Points System: TUV believes there is an urgent need for reform of the housing points system. For example, they highlight that the current arrangement, which only awards homeless points 28 days prior to the termination of a tenancy agreement, does not give people adequate time to secure alternative accommodation. • Opposing Social Engineering: TUV states that social engineering should play no part in housing policy. • Supporting Local Communities: They acknowledge that the "change wrought by an open border policy with the EU" has left a legacy of issues, and where assimilation has not occurred, it is often the indigenous community that feels uncomfortable. TUV commits to ensuring that local communities are supported and their rights and interests respected. The TUV manifesto connects pressure on housing directly to immigration levels and the constitutional issue of the Protocol, which prevents UK-wide measures like the Rwanda Bill from applying to Northern Ireland, potentially making it a "magnet for illegal migrants".
Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV).immigration: The TUV Manifesto’s key policies on immigration are explicitly linked to the party’s core constitutional concern regarding the Northern Ireland Protocol and are largely adopted through their common platform with Reform UK. Here is a summary of the key policies on immigration: 1. Constitutional Issues and Northern Ireland The TUV emphasizes that the Northern Ireland Protocol prevents UK-wide immigration policies from fully applying in the region, creating a significant constitutional and practical problem. • Rwanda Bill Exclusion: A High Court judgment ruled that the UK Government’s Rwanda Bill cannot apply in Northern Ireland. • Supremacy of EU Law: This ruling occurred because of the supremacy of EU law bestowed by Article 2 of the Protocol, which subjects Northern Ireland alone in the United Kingdom to its laws and rights. • Magnet for Illegal Migrants: The TUV warns that the consequence of this constitutional distinction is that Northern Ireland will now become a magnet for illegal migrants, who will flood in to escape the potential consequences of the Rwanda scheme applied elsewhere in the UK. • Protocol Link: TUV states that for as long as the Sea Border remains, Northern Ireland will not be covered by potential tougher measures to curb immigration, even if the next government is forced to introduce them. • Vote for Robust Policy: A vote for TUV is presented as a vote for a robust migration policy across the whole of the UK. 2. Core Immigration Policies (Shared with Reform UK) The TUV agrees with the position of Reform UK, stating that "Uncontrolled mass immigration has pushed the UK to breaking point" and must be curtailed to protect wages, public services, and British culture and values. The policies include: • Freeze Non-Essential Immigration: Strict limits on immigration are necessary to relieve pressure on housing, public services, and to increase wages and protect culture, identity, and values. ◦ The only exception for migration must be essential skills, mainly around healthcare. • Stopping Illegal Immigration ("Stop the Boats"): TUV supports a four-point plan to stop illegal migrants : 1. Leave the European Convention on Human Rights. 2. Establish a new Department of Immigration with the policy of zero illegal immigrants to be resettled in the UK. 3. Pick up illegal migrants out of boats and take them back to France. 4. Implement secure detention for all illegal migrants. • Asylum Seekers: ◦ Secure Detention for all Asylum Seekers who arrive illegally from safe countries. ◦ Processing should be rapid, offshore if necessary. ◦ Those entering from a safe country will be barred from claiming asylum or citizenship. ◦ There will be no legal aid for non-citizens, and those rejected will be returned. 3. Measures on Foreign Workers and Criminals • Employer Immigration Tax: The National Insurance (NI) rate will be raised to 20% for foreign workers. ◦ The goal is to incentivize businesses to employ British citizens, whose NI rate would stay at 13.8%. ◦ Essential foreign health and care workers, and businesses employing five staff members or fewer, would be exempt from this tax. ◦ This measure is projected to raise more than £20 billion over five years to fund apprenticeships and training for young British people. • Immediate Deportation for Foreign Criminals: Foreign nationals should be deported immediately after their prison sentence ends. • Withdrawing Citizenship: TUV advocates for withdrawing citizenship from immigrants who commit crime, with the exception of some misdemeanor offenses. • Student Dependents and Health Tourism: ◦ New visa rules for international students will bar dependents. ◦ Only international students with essential skills can remain in the UK, and TUV seeks to close down fake courses and immigration schemes that abuse the rules. ◦ They aim to stop Health Tourism. ◦ TUV will impose a requirement of 5 years residency and employment to claim any benefits in the UK. The TUV’s immigration platform is positioned as a remedy for the "uncontrolled mass immigration" nationally, while simultaneously demanding the removal of the constitutional "Sea Border" to ensure NI can be fully included in these robust UK-wide controls.
Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV).defence: The TUV Manifesto addresses defense policy, primarily focusing on the treatment of the armed forces, their equipment, and the application of the Military Covenant across the United Kingdom, while also linking defense and foreign affairs to the broader constitutional issue of the Protocol. Here is a summary of the key policies on defense: , while also linking defense and foreign affairs to the broader constitutional issue of the Protocol. Here is a summary of the key policies on defense: 1. Support for Armed Forces and Veterans The TUV expresses strong support for the UK Armed Forces, while criticizing political decisions affecting their operational readiness and welfare. • Recognition and Valor: The sources state that the UK has some of the best and bravest Armed Forces in the world. • Criticism of Equipment and Cuts: TUV criticizes politicians for sending service members abroad with poor equipment. They also highlight that the Army has been cut to its smallest size in 300 years. • Military Covenant Reform: TUV believes the Military Covenant should be reformed so that those who put their lives on the line receive the support they deserve both during and after service. • Substandard Housing: Military housing is described as substandard. • Abandonment of Veterans: TUV notes that the wounded and veterans are often abandoned. • Unjust Legal Claims: TUV highlights that some veterans and service members still face unjust legal claims. 2. Legal and Constitutional Application TUV advocates for ensuring that the support mechanisms for the military are legally binding and applicable in Northern Ireland: • Amending the Northern Ireland Act: TUV believes that the 1998 Northern Ireland Act should be amended to give full effect to the Military Covenant in all parts of the UK. 3. Defence and Foreign Affairs in Context of the Protocol TUV connects the broader constitutional issues of the Protocol to the UK’s ability to maximize its global potential in foreign affairs and defense: • Global Opportunities: TUV believes that the whole of the UK should be able to benefit from Brexit and the global opportunities it presents. • Sea Border Constraint: They state that the Sea Border prevents Northern Ireland from taking advantage of these global opportunities when it comes to foreign affairs and defense. • Sending a Message: Voting TUV is presented as a way to send a message that the Sea Border constraint on foreign affairs and defense is unacceptable.
Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV).economy: The TUV Manifesto’s key policies on the economy are divided into two main areas—personal finances (Cost of Living) and business taxation/regulation—and are fundamentallyThe TUV Manifesto’s key policies on the economy are divided into two main areas—personal finances (Cost of Living) and business taxation/regulation—and are fundamentally framed by the constitutional effects of the Northern Ireland Protocol. The economic policies detailed are explicitly based on the common platform agreed upon with Reform UK. 1. Constitutional and Economic Constraints (The Protocol) The TUV views the constitutional subjugation of Northern Ireland (NI) as the core obstacle preventing the region from benefiting economically. • Splintered Union and Loss of Market: The Protocol has "splintered our union with GB" and cut NI off from the UK Single Market for goods, which was previously a fully integrated economy of nearly 70 million people. • Increased Costs and Supply Disruption: The Protocol imposes a customs and SPS (Sanitary and Phyto-Sanitary) border across the Irish Sea, necessitating a "huge increase in the amount of customs and SPS paperwork". This disrupts the supply chain from Great Britain and drives up prices for the consumer, thus adding to the cost of living crisis in Northern Ireland. • EU Law and VAT: Because of the Protocol, Northern Ireland is tied to EU rules which insist on at least 5% VAT on energy bills. • Economic Alignment: The Protocol promotes the restructuring of supply chains and encourages the alignment of Northern Ireland with the Republic. TUV states that the Protocol is a "dynamo for Irish unity" through "dynamic economic alignment" in key areas like agri-food, goods, and trade. • The Solution: TUV demands the removal of the Sea Border to ensure the "completion of a full Brexit so that the United Kingdom in all its parts enjoys full independence and economic freedom". 2. Personal Economy and Cost of Living TUV shares the Reform UK approach to the personal economy, aimed at making work pay and easing the cost of living crisis. • Income Tax Reform (Make Work Pay): ◦ Lift the Income Tax Start Point to £20,000 Per Year. This policy is designed to free up to 7 million people from paying Income Tax and save every worker almost £1,500 per year. ◦ The basic tax rate is to remain at 20%. ◦ The higher tax rate should begin at £70,000. • Energy Cost Reduction: TUV policies aim to save households over £500 per year. This would be achieved by: ◦ Scrapping VAT on energy bills. ◦ Scrapping environmental levies. ◦ Lowering fuel duty by 20p per litre for both residential and business users. • Housing Market Stimulation: TUV proposes cutting Residential Stamp Duty to 0% below £750k. This is intended to substantially boost economic activity and housebuilding. • Tourism: Abolish the VAT Tourist Tax, referring to the stopped VAT refund scheme for tourist shopping, which they claim has cost the economy over £10 billion and deterred up to 2 million tourists. 3. Business Economy and Taxation TUV supports policies aimed at backing risk-takers and wealth creators, making Britain "open for business". • Corporation Tax Cuts: ◦ Raise the minimum profit threshold to £100k to free over 1.2 million small and medium-sized businesses from Corporation Tax. ◦ Reduce the main Corporation Tax Rate from 25% to 20%, and further reduce it to 15% from Year 3. • Support for Small and Medium Sized Enterprises (SMEs): ◦ Abolish Business Rates for high street based SMEs. ◦ Offset this by introducing an Online Delivery Tax at 4% for large, multinational enterprises, aiming to create a fairer playing field for high streets. ◦ Cut entrepreneurs’ tax to 5%. • Support for Self-Employed: ◦ Abolish IR35 Rules to support sole traders. ◦ Raise the VAT Threshold to £150,000 to free up small entrepreneurs from red tape. • Reform and Red Tape: ◦ Slash Red Tape to boost industry and exports by scrapping thousands of laws that hold back British business and damage productivity. ◦ Major simplification of the tax system is needed, as the UK’s tax code is over 21,000 pages. ◦ Reform the Planning System to fast-track new housing on brownfield sites and infrastructure projects to boost businesses. 4. Fair Funding and Financial Prudence TUV stresses the need for prudent government spending and a fair funding deal for Northern Ireland. • Opposing Squander: TUV promotes smaller government to keep taxation down and opposes politically motivated schemes that cost the taxpayer, citing Casement Park as a prime example of squander. • Fair Funding Deal: TUV will fight for a fair financial funding deal for Northern Ireland in Westminster, ensuring the funding formula is updated to account for local needs. • Senior Citizens: TUV will work to maintain the triple lock on state pensions. The economic vision is one of low taxation, reduced regulation, and maximized financial integration with the rest of Great Britain, which TUV argues is fundamentally obstructed by the Protocol.
Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV).education: The TUV Manifesto details several key policies regarding education, focusing primarily on addressing educational underachievement, supporting academic selection, curriculum reform, and improving conditions for teachers and classroomThe TUV Manifesto details several key policies regarding education, focusing primarily on addressing educational underachievement, supporting academic selection, curriculum reform, and improving conditions for teachers and classroom assistants. Here is a summary of the key policies on education: Core Priorities and Equality • Tackling Underachievement: The TUV sees tackling educational underachievement as its number one priority, specifically highlighting the need to address this for the Protestant working class. • Addressing Inequality: The manifesto aims to address the shortage of funding and the imbalance between sectors, noting that this disparity is "hitting the controlled sector particularly hard". Specific Policy Proposals TUV proposes the following measures to achieve better educational outcomes : 1. Academic Selection: A commitment to academic selection is maintained. 2. School System: They aim to create a more equal system encompassing both exceptional Grammar and non-selective schools. 3. Curriculum Overhaul: TUV advocates for an evidence-informed curriculum overhaul. 4. Staffing and Pay: The party supports investment in teacher recruitment and fair teacher pay. 5. Pathways to Success: They propose the creation of a system in which children can find different paths to successful outcomes. 6. Vocational Training: Support is given to vocational training for those seeking apprenticeships, commencing at school and continuing into Further Education (FE) with employer support. 7. Culture of Achievement: TUV seeks the creation of a culture of "celebration" for hard work and achievement across all aspects of school life. 8. Job Market Connection: They emphasize helping children see value in education by ensuring it connects them to a job market that harnesses their skills and talents. 9. Community Connection: The manifesto supports schools connecting with their communities, parents, and external agencies. 10. Teaching Profession: They propose developing a culture of trust in and respect for the teaching profession, noting that this trust has been eroded. Support for Classroom Assistants TUV states its belief in a fair deal for classroom assistants, including greater job security and holiday pay. Social Issues in Schools In relation to social issues affecting education, TUV emphasizes its stance on traditional family values and gender identity: • Opposing Progressive Agenda: TUV states it will actively oppose the "progressive" agenda regarding gender identity in schools. • Gender Determination: They assert that gender is determined at birth.
Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV).environment: The TUV Manifesto addresses environmental policies primarily through the lens of protecting the agricultural economy and opposing measures related to climate change mandates. Here is a summary of the key policies on the environment: 1. Opposition to Anti-Farming Ideology and Net Zero The TUV views the pursuit of certain environmental goals as a direct threat to Northern Ireland’s vital agricultural sector: • The future of Northern Ireland’s £5 billion farming and food sector must not be jeopardized by the pursuit of an anti-farming ideology associated with climate change activists. • TUV considers the pursuit of net zero Climate Change demands to be "utter folly" because it will reduce food production capacity in Northern Ireland. • TUV was clear and determined in opposing the Green Party’s Private Member’s Bill (which was supported by Sinn Fein, SDLP, Alliance, and the UUP) and commits to continue to protect farming interests. 2. Reducing Environmental Levies As part of their policy to cut energy taxes and alleviate the cost of living crisis, TUV proposes removing certain financial burdens linked to environmental policy: • TUV seeks to Scrap environmental levies on energy bills. This action is intended to save households over £500 per year.
Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV).brexit: The sources, which are excerpts from the TUV Manifesto 2024, focus heavily on the impact of the Brexit arrangements on Northern Ireland, particularly the Northern Ireland Protocol (or Windsor Framework), and outline the TUV and Reform UK joint policies aimed at addressing these consequences. Core Stance and Constitutional Goals The primary goal of the TUV is to restore the Union and achieve the reunification of the UK, which they assert has been "splintered by the Protocol". The TUV—who are campaigning with Reform UK under a Memorandum of Understanding—are committed to a common platform on Brexit : • Upholding and strengthening the Union between Great Britain and Northern Ireland, including the full restoration of Article 6 of the Act(s) of Union. • The rejection of the Irish Sea border and the subjection of Northern Ireland to EU law and the ECJ. • The completion of a full Brexit so that the United Kingdom in all its parts enjoys full independence and economic freedom. The TUV manifesto urges a vote of "No Sea Border". Criticisms of the Protocol and Windsor Framework The TUV regards the current arrangements as a profound constitutional crisis and affront to national politics : 1. Loss of Sovereignty and Rule by EU Law: Westminster is no longer sovereign over Northern Ireland. NI is partitioned by a border in the Irish Sea, and unaccountable rule from Brussels dictates many aspects of life. Northern Ireland is now a "condominium," ruled partly by UK laws and partly by foreign EU laws. 2. Disenfranchisement: Northern Ireland is subject to foreign EU laws in over 300 areas of law where its citizens have no say. This is described as the "Great Vote Robbery"—the disenfranchisement of 1.9 million people. 3. Economic Disruption: The Protocol denied Northern Ireland the Brexit enjoyed by Great Britain. It is prioritizing the protection of the integrity of the EU’s Single Market, which caused the imposition of the Irish Sea Border as a Customs and SPS (Sanitary and Phyto-Sanitary) border. This border has cut NI off from the UK Single Market for goods, replacing the previously integrated UK economy with two separate economies, which promotes alignment with the Republic of Ireland. 4. Failed Solutions: ◦ The Windsor Framework is criticized for perpetuating the Irish Sea border. It is described as "worse than the original Northern Ireland Protocol" and means NI is still in the EU’s single market for goods. Even the less demanding Green Lane still involves the imposition of a customs and international SPA border because Northern Ireland is subject to the EU’s Customs Code. ◦ The DUP’s "Safeguarding the Union" or Donaldson-Robinson Deal is claimed to have been a "sleight of hand," as the proposed UK Internal Market System was just "another name for the Green Lane," resulting in no actual changes. 5. Driver for Irish Unity: The Protocol is viewed as a "dynamo for Irish unity" because the 300 areas of law now under EU/Republic of Ireland control lead to dynamic economic alignment with the Republic, establishing an all-Ireland through economic fusion. 6. Specific Policy Impacts: ◦ Cost of Living: The Protocol contributes to the cost of living crisis by adding paperwork, disrupting supply chains from GB, driving up prices , and requiring NI to adhere to EU rules insisting on at least 5% VAT on energy bills. ◦ Immigration: EU law supremacy, bestowed by Article 2 of the Protocol, overruled the UK Government’s Rwanda Bill’s applicability in Northern Ireland, making NI a potential "magnet for illegal migrants". ◦ Agriculture: NI farmers are betrayed by being subject to EU law concerning veterinary medicines, which causes a "mammoth problem" for the agri-food industry as 85% of medicines traditionally come from GB. Proposed Solutions and Action TUV and Reform UK propose the following actions to resolve the Brexit issues affecting Northern Ireland: 1. Abandon the Windsor Framework: Reform UK’s manifesto commitment, which TUV welcomes and reproduces, is to Abandon the Windsor Framework. 2. Mutual Enforcement: TUV advocates for Mutual Enforcement as a means of protecting the integrity of the EU single market while avoiding a hard border across the island of Ireland and avoiding the disenfranchisement of NI citizens. This involves the UK enforcing its legislation to ensure UK-made goods destined for the Republic meet ROI standards, and the Republic doing the same for Irish goods entering the UK. 3. Restoration of Consent: TUV stresses the need to restore the basic principles of cross community consent as it affects the Protocol. The removal of the need for cross-community assent in the upcoming vote on the Protocol is called an "egregious assault" on unionism and the Stormont system’s equilibrium. 4. Campaigning Strategy: TUV Reform MPs would relentlessly argue that the current arrangement is politically unsustainable, especially since the EU has alternative options (Mutual Enforcement) that do not involve disenfranchising 1.9 million people.
Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV).entire manifesto: The TUV Manifesto for 2024 focuses heavily on constitutional matters, particularly the Northern Ireland Protocol, alongside economic, social, and public service policies, many of which are aligned with their common platform with Reform UK. Here is a summary of the manifesto’s key policies: 1. The Union and the Protocol (Core Mission) The overriding mission of the TUV is the reunification of the UK and the restoration of the Union. • Rejection of the Sea Border: TUV campaigns against the Irish Sea border and the subjection of Northern Ireland (NI) to EU law and the ECJ (European Court of Justice). They assert that the Protocol has "splintered our union with GB" and makes NI a "condominium," ruled partly by UK laws and partly by foreign EU laws. • Constitutional Sovereignty: The manifesto states that Westminster is no longer sovereign over NI due to the surrender of powers to a foreign parliament. They note that NI citizens have no say in over 300 areas of law decided by the EU. • Protocol as a Catalyst for Unity: TUV believes the Protocol is a dynamo for Irish unity through dynamic economic alignment with the Republic of Ireland. • Full Brexit: They advocate for the completion of a full Brexit so that the United Kingdom in all its parts enjoys full independence and economic freedom. • The Solution: Mutual Enforcement: TUV proposes "Mutual Enforcement" as a means of protecting the integrity of the EU single market without imposing a hard border on the island of Ireland or disenfranchising NI citizens. • Consent and Devolution: TUV demands the restoration of consent and cross-community consent as it affects the Protocol, arguing that the removal of this requirement is an egregious assault on the Stormont modus operandi. • Immigration Sovereignty: They highlight that because of the Protocol and the supremacy of EU law, the UK Government’s Rwanda Bill cannot apply in Northern Ireland, making NI a potential "magnet for illegal migrants". 2. Economy and Cost of Living (Shared with Reform UK) TUV shares the Reform UK approach to the economy. Personal Economy: • Income Tax: Lift the Income Tax Start Point to £20,000 per year, freeing up to 7 million people from paying Income Tax and saving every worker almost £1,500 annually. The higher tax rate should begin at £70,000. • Energy Costs: Cut Energy Taxes to save households over £500 per year by lowering fuel duty by 20p per litre, and scrapping VAT on energy bills and environmental levies. • Housing Market: Substantially boost housebuilding and economic activity by cutting Residential Stamp Duty to 0% below £750k. • Tourism: Abolish the VAT Tourist Tax (stopping the VAT refund scheme for tourist shopping). Business Economy: • Corporation Tax: Free over 1.2 million small and medium-sized businesses from Corporation Tax by raising the minimum profit threshold to £100k. Reduce the main Corporation Tax Rate from 25% to 20%, then to 15% from Year 3. • SME Support: Abolish Business Rates for high street based SMEs and offset this by introducing an Online Delivery Tax at 4% for large, multinational enterprises. • Self-Employment and Tax: Abolish IR35 Rules to support sole traders and raise the VAT Threshold to £150,000. 3. Immigration (Shared with Reform UK) TUV supports a robust migration policy across the whole of the UK. • Freeze Non-Essential Immigration: Strict limits on immigration, with essential skills (mainly healthcare) as the only exception. • Stop the Boats: Implement a four-point plan, including leaving the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), ensuring zero illegal immigrants are resettled in the UK, returning illegal migrants to France, and secure detention for all illegal migrants. • Benefits Access: Impose a requirement of 5 years residency and employment to claim any benefits in the UK. • Employer Immigration Tax: Raise the National Insurance rate to 20% for foreign workers (exempting essential foreign health/care workers and businesses with five staff or fewer) to incentivize employing British citizens. 4. Health and Social Services TUV emphasizes sustaining long-term investment in health, prioritizing it over spending on items like Casement Park or "rights agendas". • Staffing and Investment: Fund more nurses, doctors, and beds. • NHS Loyalty: Disincentivize the reliance on agency staff and reward loyalty to the NHS. • Nursing Reserve: Campaign for the creation of a Nursing Reserve Service (akin to the Army Reserve) using retired and former nurses available in emergencies. • Accessibility: Oppose the closure of minor injuries units and local facilities. They seek to restore a readily accessible GP service. • Mental Health: Support increased funding for Community Mental Health services and ensuring adequate acute psychiatric beds are available within patients’ Trust areas. • Pro-Life Stance: TUV is unashamedly pro-life and opposes the full commissioning of abortion services, aiming to halt the destruction of the unborn. 5. Education and Childcare • Educational Underachievement: TUV’s number one priority is tackling educational underachievement, particularly for the Protestant working class. • Academic Selection: Commitment to academic selection while also creating a more equal system of exceptional Grammar and non-selective schools. • Curriculum: Proposals include an evidence-informed curriculum overhaul and investment in teacher recruitment and fair pay. • Childcare Funding: TUV demands that the money allocated by Westminster for childcare (Barnett Consequentials) be spent on childcare, noting that over £32 million allocated for 2024-25 is currently being spent elsewhere. 6. Justice, Policing, and Legacy • Policing: They demand an end to blatant two-tier policing and insist on PSNI recruitment based on merit, with no return to 50/50 practices. • Legacy: TUV believes the definition of "victim" must be changed to exclude victim makers. • Amnesty: There can be no amnesty for historic crimes, and TUV opposes the Legacy Act. • Terrorism Glorification: Legislation on the glorification of terrorism needs to be revisited and applied equally across the UK. 7. Social and Fundamental Freedoms TUV stands up for traditional family values. • Gender and Identity: TUV believes that gender is determined at birth and actively opposes the "progressive" agenda regarding gender identity in schools. • Women’s Rights: They oppose biological males being permitted to access women’s only spaces, using "gender-neutral" changing areas, or competing in female sports events. • Sanctity of Life: TUV is pro-life and opposes abortion on demand and euthanasia. • Religious Freedom: TUV will oppose moves to dilute fundamental human rights such as religious belief, teaching, and practice, and defends freedom of expression and conscience. 8. Other Key Policies • Stormont Reform: Given minimal faith in Stormont’s ability to deliver, TUV’s default position is British rule from Westminster over Sinn Fein rule from Stormont. • Fair Funding: TUV will fight for a fair financial funding deal for Northern Ireland, ensuring the funding formula is updated to account for local needs. • Agriculture: TUV opposes the EU threat to veterinary medicines. They will continue to protect farming interests by opposing the pursuit of anti-farming ideology associated with climate change activists and net zero demands. • Senior Citizens: TUV will work to maintain the triple lock on state pensions. • Sport and Tourism: TUV opposes the use of public funds for the Casement Park project. They will fight for the right of NI athletes in all sports to compete for the United Kingdom and contend in favour of the playing of the National Anthem at major sporting events. They also seek to remove constraints that prevent Tourism NI from promoting Northern Ireland in Great Britain. The core thrust of the manifesto is the defense of the Union and democratic accountability, framing the constitutional issues—particularly the existence of the Sea Border—as the underlying factor impacting NI’s economy, immigration policy, and the cost of living.

Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).crime: The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) Manifesto sets out key policies on crime under the commitment "Standing Up for Victims of Crime". These policies focus on addressing online harm, tackling the legacy of the Troubles, ensuring adequate policing resources, and strengthening sentences for serious offenses. Key Policies on Crime and Justice: 1. Standing Up for Victims of Crime and Legacy Issues The DUP strongly advocates for a victim-centered approach to addressing the Troubles and is committed to repealing the Northern Ireland Troubles (Legacy and Reconciliation) Act 2023. The party argues that this Act grants an "amnesty in all but name" to perpetrators, extinguishing the flame of justice for many innocent victims. Specific actions include: • Supporting efforts to repeal the Legacy Act and urging UK Ministers to repeal it within the first 100 days of the next Parliament. • Prioritizing a victim-centred and victim-led approach to investigating the past. • Guaranteeing continued funding for the Troubles victims’ pension, ensuring no money is given to perpetrators. • Seeking a UK-wide definition of a victim that rejects any equivalence between the perpetrator and the victim. • Pressing for further progress by the Omagh Public Inquiry and challenging the Irish Government to launch its own public inquiry into the Omagh atrocity. • Supporting stronger custodial sentences for murder and terror offenses in Northern Ireland, bringing sentencing in line with other UK regions. 2. Online Harm and Social Media Regulation The DUP seeks to "end the ‘Wild West’ of social media" and protect all internet users, particularly children, from harm, abuse, and misinformation. The party supported key aspects of the Online Safety Act, including age verification for certain sites, duties on platforms to remove harmful content, and new criminal offenses for actions like trolling and cyber-flashing. Future policy proposals include: • Campaigning to ensure smaller and emerging social media platforms and sites hosting harmful content are subject to regulatory controls and Ofcom oversight. • Opposing a lower minimum age for social media use. • Promoting strategies to reduce the risks of end-to-end encryption for children. • Seeking a statutory definition of grooming. • Supporting a rapid review of emerging risks from Artificial Intelligence (AI), including chatbots. • Supporting the ring-fencing of receipts from fines levied on social media companies for online harm prevention and reduction. 3. Policing and Security The DUP highlights the need for a fully staffed and properly resourced police service in Northern Ireland (NI), noting a "steady decline" in policing budgets compared to the health and education sectors. They stress that the current number of 6,400 police officers is unsustainable and that the next Government must prioritize safety through a fair fiscal framework. Specific policies on policing and security include: • Advocating for an uplift in Government funding for Northern Ireland’s Additional Security needs and the Tackling Paramilitarism Programme. • Seeking a statutory definition of Child Criminal Exploitation (CCE) to better target paramilitaries and crime gangs who prey on children. • Campaigning to strengthen the role of the National Crime Agency in NI. • Seeking to protect neighborhood policing resources. • Regarding Northern Ireland-Related Terrorism, they support ensuring security forces have the necessary powers and autonomy to defeat dissident republican groups. They also want to address lengthy delays in trying terrorism cases. 4. Justice System and Court Reform The DUP is pushing for measures to streamline the justice system and ensure consistent sentencing across the UK. Justice policies include: • Pressing for stronger custodial sentences for murder and terror offences in NI, ensuring consistency with other UK regions. • Seeking to try terrorism cases faster, which would reduce costs related to suspects spending long periods on remand. • Supporting the establishment of a Royal Commission into the effectiveness of the criminal justice system across the UK. • Promoting tougher sentencing for physical assaults on retail staff. • Supporting robust animal welfare legislation, including voting for stronger custodial sentencing for animal cruelty in England and Wales to align with the five-year maximum penalty already in place in Northern Ireland. 5. Violence Against Women & Girls (VAWG) The DUP commits to addressing gaps in funding for specialist support for survivors of domestic abuse, supporting robust and up-to-date vetting in police forces, and seeking an improved response to trolling and other forms of technology-facilitated abuse against women online. They also call for a review of policies affecting migrants with "No Recourse to Public Funds" (NRPF) who suffer domestic abuse. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The DUP’s focus on crime and justice reflects a dual commitment: ensuring Northern Ireland has a functional, well-funded modern police and court system, and maintaining a firm stance against attempts to minimize accountability for Troubles-era crimes. This is evident in their push to repeal the Legacy Act while simultaneously advocating for better resources to combat current threats like paramilitary crime and online harm.
Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).healthcare: The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) details its key healthcare policies under its commitment "Putting You First - Delivering Fair and Equitable Funding for our NHS, and other Public Services". The party views the National Health Service (NHS) as the "jewel in the crown of the Union" and stresses the need to prioritize it across the United Kingdom. The DUP’s healthcare strategy focuses heavily on securing equitable funding, tackling waiting lists, supporting healthcare staff, and maintaining a pro-life stance. Key Policies on Healthcare: 1. Fair and Equitable Funding for the NHS The DUP asserts that chronic underfunding from Westminster has systematically damaged Northern Ireland’s capacity to provide fit-for-purpose frontline services. The party has campaigned extensively for a new needs-based funding model for Northern Ireland. The DUP commits to pressing the next Government to ensure that funding for Northern Ireland’s public services, including the NHS, cannot drop below the definition of assessed need, which they define as £124 for every £100 spent in England. They also campaign for Northern Ireland’s baseline funding to be increased proportionally by the same amount above need as was applied to Wales, which included a new needs-based factor and a 5% transitional uplift. 2. Improving Access and Driving Down Waiting Lists A major focus is improving patient access to NHS services and treatments across the UK, which has historically included campaigning on rare diseases and securing access to treatments like the drug Orkambi for Cystic Fibrosis sufferers. Going forward, DUP MPs will campaign to: • Drive waiting lists down by fostering large-scale partnerships between health and social care in Northern Ireland and national independent providers or not-for-profit organizations. • Ensure accessible and portable health information throughout a patient’s life. • Establish clusters of universities, business, and clinicians throughout the UK to harness and accelerate the use of new medical technology and diagnostics. 3. Supporting Healthcare Professionals The DUP recognizes the need to end disparities in arrangements benefitting health staff in Northern Ireland compared to the rest of the UK, which is essential for primary care delivery and skills retention. Specific proposals for supporting GPs and public sector staff include: • Providing fellowships for young GPs in substantive posts. • Commissioning a practitioner health scheme. • Providing a permanent state-backed scheme for indemnity for GPs. • Ensuring a fair and equitable approach to pensions and residence for qualified GPs seeking to live and work in the United Kingdom. • Campaigning for recurrent funding to provide decent pay awards for public sector staff, including nurses and doctors, noting that public sector pay has not kept pace with other parts of the UK due to chronic underfunding. • Supporting strategies to improve occupational support and attract, recruit, train, and retain frontline staff. • Seeking to make it easier for international students qualifying in primary care roles, such as GPs, to gain permanent residence, helping the Health Service benefit from increased training places. 4. End-of-Life Care and Terminal Illnesses The DUP is committed to improving care and support for those with a terminal illness. DUP MPs have supported: • A change in the law to allow those with a life expectancy of up to 12 months to get faster and easier access to certain benefits and pensions. • Promoting better quality and better access to palliative care. • Continuing to press for enhanced provision for families affected by terminal diagnoses. 5. Moral and Social Health Issues The DUP maintains an "unashamedly pro-life stance" and commits to firmly opposing efforts to legalize assisted suicide. They have consistently opposed the commissioning of, and funding for, abortion services in Northern Ireland. They also oppose regulations that mandate the inclusion of abortion in the Relationships and Sexuality Education curriculum in schools. The party also supports measures to tackle the harm caused by smoking and vaping, including exploring options such as raising the age of sale to 21, while adding that any restriction on the right of adults to make choices must always be justified. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- In essence, the DUP views increased and stable UK funding for Northern Ireland’s NHS as the critical foundation for solving persistent issues like staff retention and excessive waiting lists, while simultaneously advocating for better care and maintaining their moral stance on life issues.
Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).housing: Based on the provided sources from the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) Manifesto, the party’s key policies on housing are primarily framed within the context of their delivery record in the Northern Ireland Assembly and their commitment to supporting families and vulnerable people. While housing is not one of the ten core policy commitments at the General Election , the manifesto highlights specific achievements and proposals related to housing and home ownership in Northern Ireland, mainly through the actions of the DUP Department for Communities Minister at the Assembly. Key Policies and Delivered Outcomes on Housing: 1. Affordable Housing Supply The DUP Minister for Communities announced measures to increase the supply of affordable housing for rent in Northern Ireland. • Intermediate Rent Product: The DUP launched the "Intermediate Rent" product. This involves offering a long-term low-interest loan to an operator to develop a new supply of affordable homes for rent at a 20% discount off market value. 2. Supporting Home Ownership The party aims to support more people in achieving home ownership: • Co-Ownership Housing: The DUP introduced a measure to support people into home ownership by increasing the upper property value limit for Co-Ownership Housing. 3. Protection for Homeowners (Defective Premises) The DUP has focused on ensuring legal protections for homeowners regarding defective premises: • Defective Premises Legislation: Legislation was introduced by accelerated passage to ensure homeowners in Northern Ireland enjoy the same protections offered elsewhere in the UK, citing the case of Victoria Square apartments as a highlight. 4. Addressing Building Safety (Post-Grenfell) In their record of delivery at Westminster, DUP Parliamentarians successfully lobbied the Department for Levelling Up and Department for Communities to fund and launch a scheme to address Non-ACM (Aluminium Composite Material) cladded buildings in Northern Ireland, post-Grenfell. 5. Support for Vulnerable People Beyond housing construction, the party allocated additional funding in 2023/24 for the Supporting People Programme, which helps vulnerable people to live independently. 6. Managing Housing Demand (Immigration) The DUP also notes a policy focus related to the impact of immigration on housing needs: • They support a review of the impact of the Asylum Accommodation and Support Services Contracts on housing need and public services in all UK regions. 7. Promoting Jobs and Growth (Supporting Construction) While not exclusively a housing policy, the DUP supports the creation of a national database of public land. A major benefit of this database would be to help smaller businesses in the construction industry identify future projects earlier.
Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).immigration: The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) addresses its key policies on immigration and asylum within its commitment to "A Strategic Role for UK Defence and Security". The party’s stance emphasizes achieving a single, controlled immigration system that applies uniformly across the United Kingdom, specifically protecting Northern Ireland from becoming a destination for illegal migrants due to the impact of the Northern Ireland Protocol. Key Policies on Immigration and Asylum: 1. Uniform Application of UK Immigration Policy The DUP supports a firm, fair, and controlled immigration system where rules are governed solely by the UK Parliament and are fully applicable in all parts of the United Kingdom. • The party will fight to ensure national immigration and asylum policy applies equally across the United Kingdom by restoring Parliamentary sovereignty over the law in Northern Ireland. • The DUP points out that courts have ruled the Government’s policy on sending illegal migrants to Rwanda cannot extend to Northern Ireland due to Article 2 of the Protocol, which the DUP argues risks making Northern Ireland a magnet for asylum seekers seeking to escape enforcement. 2. Addressing Illegal Immigration and Asylum Claims The DUP supports an approach that allows those fleeing war or persecution to find refuge in the UK, provided it is underpinned by effective measures to deter illegal activity and improve processing efficiency. • The party advocates for renewed efforts to smash and deter crime gangs who profit from illegal and unsafe transports across the Channel. • They call for speedier and more efficient processes for dealing with asylum claims. • They also support reviewing the impact of the Asylum Accommodation and Support Services Contracts on housing need and public services in all UK regions. • The DUP continues to call on the Government to ensure that all Afghan citizens who risked their lives to assist the Armed Forces against the Taliban are urgently resettled in the UK and do not face deportation while seeking asylum. 3. Agile and Responsive Migration System for Labour Needs The DUP acknowledges that the current system of work visas has proven ineffective in responding to the pressing needs of businesses, particularly in Northern Ireland where there are concerns about labour shortages in key industries like agri-food and hospitality. The party supports promoting a more agile and responsive migration system. Specific proposals to address labour needs include: • Seeking a review of the structure and operation of the Migration Advisory Committee (MAC), including considering formal representation from the devolved regions. A reformed MAC should work with a new Independent Skills Commission to map and meet labour shortages across the UK. • Seeking to ensure fair minimum salary thresholds for skilled overseas workers to protect sectors like food production, manufacturing, hospitality, and health and social care. The current threshold of £38,700 is highlighted as being "well above the average salary in NI". • Advocating for a multi-year rolling seasonal workers scheme for agriculture with a suitable length visa. • Seeking to make it easier for international students qualifying in primary care roles, such as GPs, to gain permanent residence, ensuring the Health Service can benefit from increasing training places. In summary, the DUP’s immigration policy is driven by two main priorities: ensuring Northern Ireland is fully integrated into and protected by a robust, national UK immigration policy, and reforming the migration system to be more responsive to the specific labour market needs of the local economy.
Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).defence: The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) views UK defence and security as a strategic necessity, emphasizing the need to strengthen military capabilities, significantly increase spending, and fully integrate Northern Ireland into the national defence structures and supply chains. The DUP’s stance on defence, drawing directly from the sources, can be summarized under several key areas: Defence Strategy and Spending The DUP stresses that defence expenditure must be viewed as a benefit rather than a burden : • Need for Strength: The party believes there is a critical need to strengthen the United Kingdom’s defence industrial base and grow the Armed Forces. • Geopolitical Threats: The DUP cites global threats, including Putin’s invasion of Ukraine and the proliferation of cyber threats from China, Iran, and North Korea, as demonstrating the importance of the UK being equipped with military and intelligence capabilities to protect national interests. • Spending Target: They advocate that the UK should immediately increase defence spending and commit to allocating 3.0% of GDP on defence by 2035. • NATO and Sovereignty: They support the UK’s unshakeable commitment to NATO and continued cooperation with key strategic partners (like supporting Ukraine). However, they also emphasize the need for the UK to be able to stand on its own feet and retain sovereign strategic and operational independence. • Nuclear Deterrent: The DUP supports increased spending to safeguard the UK’s nuclear deterrent. Integrating Northern Ireland into UK Defence A primary objective is to fully integrate Northern Ireland into the UK’s defence network, capitalizing on the region’s industrial base: • Integration: DUP MPs will pursue the greater integration of Northern Ireland into national defence structures, networks, and operations, consistent with the principle of consent and the Belfast Agreement. • Presence and Deterrence: They support calls for an increased RAF and Royal Navy presence in Northern Ireland to fortify the northwestern naval and air patrol presence. This presence would act as a deterrent against threats, such as attempts by Russia to target critical western undersea infrastructure. • Defence Industry Investment: The aerospace, defence, security, and space sectors in Northern Ireland (including companies like Spirit AeroSystems, Thales, and Harland & Wolff) thrive and are vital for jobs. DUP MPs have highlighted that Ministry of Defence (MoD) expenditure per person in Northern Ireland (£100) is disproportionately low compared to other regions (e.g., £380 regional average). • Specific Industrial Goals: The party aims to increase the number of major MoD contracts placed in Northern Ireland and encourage MoD support for the creation of an official defence and security cluster in the region. They also push for the government to expedite a review into public and commercial awareness of the Northern Ireland defence sector. • Skills Pipeline: The DUP seeks to ensure future skills policies prioritize a steady pipeline of apprenticeships and highly-qualified graduates in STEM subjects to generate military and security capabilities. They want Northern Ireland’s industrial base to benefit from economic opportunities provided by investment in the nuclear deterrent. Armed Forces and Veterans Support The DUP is a consistent advocate for veterans and serving personnel from Northern Ireland : • Armed Forces Covenant: DUP MPs supported the Armed Forces Act 2021 to ensure the Armed Forces Covenant was legally protected in Northern Ireland. They also insisted on the appointment of a Northern Ireland Veterans’ Commissioner. • Future Support: They intend to explore the potential expansion of the Armed Forces Covenant Duty to cover employment, pensions, social care, and criminal justice. • Compensation: They call for the government to consider disregarding War Pensions and Armed Forces Compensation Scheme as income from benefits and pensions. • Afghan Citizens: They continue to call on the Government to ensure that all Afghan citizens who assisted the Armed Forces are urgently resettled in the UK.
