Combating Northern Ireland-Related Terrorism The DUP emphasizes the necessity of a strong focus on countering domestic threats: • Sustained Focus: They note the enduring threat posed by dissident republicans and welcome the national intelligence community’s role in eroding the capabilities of splinter groups like the New IRA. • Security Funding: They will advocate for an uplift in funding provided by the Government for Northern Ireland’s additional security needs. • Justice and Sentencing: The party aims to address lengthy delays in trying terrorism cases. They believe sentences for serious terror offences in Northern Ireland should be brought into line with higher tariffs elsewhere in the United Kingdom to ensure consistency of sentencing principles throughout the UK. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The DUP’s view on defence is akin to demanding that all the strategic components of a sophisticated national shield are equally sourced and supported across the entire country. They argue that Northern Ireland is a critical manufacturing, strategic, and personnel hub that has been historically underutilized and underfunded by the Ministry of Defence, and they are committed to ensuring it receives equitable status and investment in the national security framework.
Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).economy: The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) details its economic vision under the core commitment "Unleashing our Full Economic Potential," aiming for an ambitious approach to creating more and better jobs and generating greater prosperity for the people of Northern Ireland. The DUP seeks to consolidate Northern Ireland’s place as a global destination for investment within the United Kingdom. The economic policies focus on supporting Small and Medium Sized Enterprises (SMEs), reforming the tax system, promoting key sectors like advanced manufacturing and hydrogen technology, addressing skills shortages, and improving access to finance. Key Policies on the Economy: 1. Taxation and Fiscal Policy The DUP seeks tax policies that protect incomes, ensure fairness, and leave more money with working people. • Income and National Insurance: The party campaigns to oppose the freeze on the personal tax allowance and higher rate income tax threshold. They also seek further reductions in national insurance, building on recent cuts, and support an increase in the starting age for employee national insurance. • VAT: The DUP seeks to abolish VAT on domestic electricity bills. They also continue to campaign for a reduction in VAT for hospitality across the United Kingdom to address the competitive disadvantage faced by local businesses due to a reduced rate in the Republic of Ireland. • Fuel Duty and Vehicle Tax: They commit to maintaining the freeze on fuel duty and freezing Vehicle Excise Duty. • Corporation Tax: Although they maintain that the necessary capacity does not exist for the devolution of additional fiscal powers at this time , lowering the rate of corporation tax in Northern Ireland is a longstanding DUP policy. They advocate for a reduction in corporate tax across the United Kingdom. The current minimum effective rate of 15% in the Irish Republic is noted as placing Northern Ireland firms at a competitive disadvantage. 2. Supporting Small and Medium Sized Enterprises (SMEs) The DUP aims to address challenges threatening the survival of SMEs and help them reach their full potential. • VAT Threshold: Campaigning to increase the VAT threshold for SMEs to £100,000 and then uprate it in line with inflation. • Support and Procurement: Driving up the number of SMEs benefiting from government procurement spend, tax reliefs, and business support. • Late Payments and Insurance: Protecting cash flow by tackling late payments to small suppliers in government contracts. They will support a market review into professional indemnity insurance (PII). • Online Sales Tax: Exploring the potential introduction of an online sales tax targeting online corporates and marketplaces to address the issue of online giants undercutting high street shops. • Access to Finance: Supporting the extension of the Growth Guarantee Scheme for the duration of the next Parliament, which provides a 70% guarantee to lenders on finance provided to SMEs. They also support a review of small business lending, assessing the impact of unnecessary personal guarantees on SME investment. 3. Strategic Sector Growth and Investment The DUP is focused on maximizing the potential of key economic sectors. • Advanced Manufacturing: Pressing for a new national industrial strategy that prioritizes advanced manufacturing, engineering, digital, agri-tech, life and health sciences, and fintech. They also press the Government to retain the Full Expensing rules for capital investment. • Hydrogen Technology: Committed to maximizing economic and social opportunities associated with hydrogen technology, in which Northern Ireland is seen as an innovator. They will seek a dedicated Hydrogen Innovation Strategy, support a new green hydrogen apprenticeship programme, and consider funding streams and incentives for SME innovation in this sector. • Research and Development (R&D): Backing proposals to increase the official UK R&D spend target to at least 3.0% of GDP by 2027 and to expand R&D tax relief for SMEs to include capital expenditure. 4. Skills and Labour Market The party believes a failure to invest in skills holds the economy back. • Skills Commission: Supporting the establishment of an Independent UK Skills Commission with representation for Northern Ireland, tasked with assessing current and future labour needs and scrutinizing policy. • Apprenticeships: Committed to replacing the Apprenticeship Levy with a new system that ensures contributions are ringfenced and reinvested in skills. They seek to deliver more all-age, public sector, and SME-led apprenticeships. • Migration System: Promoting a more agile and responsive migration system to address labour shortages in key industries like agri-food and hospitality. They seek fair minimum salary thresholds for skilled overseas workers to protect these sectors, noting the current threshold of £38,700 is "well above the average salary in NI". 5. Infrastructure and Connectivity The DUP highlights high-quality infrastructure as the foundation of future growth. • Union Connectivity Review (UCR): Pursuing the full implementation of the UCR to improve links between Great Britain and Northern Ireland. This includes secured commitments to improving journeys on the A75 in Scotland and boosting port connections and infrastructure between NI and GB. • Air Travel: Advocating for the abolition of domestic air passenger duty to boost the competitiveness of Northern Ireland’s airports. • Broadband and 5G: Building on their record of securing full-fibre broadband, the DUP seeks to accelerate the roll-out of 5G coverage in Northern Ireland. The DUP’s economic policy is anchored in the idea that Northern Ireland’s economic potential is best realized through its role as an integrated part of the UK, arguing that the UK needs all its constituent parts to flourish. Their policy platform attempts to use tax breaks and strategic investment to boost local businesses and highly productive sectors like advanced manufacturing.
Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).education: The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) Manifesto outlines several key policies and highlights recent achievements in the education sector, focusing on improving conditions for teachers and support staff, increasing investment in infrastructure, addressing special educational needs, and supporting early learning and childcare. These policies are predominantly detailed under the "Delivering for Northern Ireland in the Assembly" section, reflecting the party’s work in the devolved government. Key Policies and Outcomes on Education: 1. Teacher and Staff Compensation The DUP has focused on resolving long-running disputes regarding pay and grading to improve recruitment and retention: • Teacher Pay: The DUP settled the long-running industrial action by teachers and successfully increased the starting salary for teachers in Northern Ireland to £30,000. • Support Staff Pay: The party committed to resolving the pay and grading review for educational support staff, including classroom assistants. • Public Sector Pay: More broadly, the DUP campaigns for recurrent funding to provide decent pay awards for public sector staff like teachers, arguing that pay awards have not kept pace with other parts of the United Kingdom due to chronic underfunding. 2. Capital Investment and Infrastructure The DUP has secured and announced significant investment for school facilities: • Capital Funding: An additional £80 million of capital funding for education was announced for the current year. This will allow fifteen important new build, extension, and refurbishment projects for schools across all sectors to proceed to construction. A new programme of curriculum-led investment was also launched. • Strule Shared Education Campus: Secured Executive agreement to provide £150 million of earmarked additional funding over the next three years to deliver the Strule Shared Education Campus in Omagh. This project aims to bring together 4,000 children and young people from all community backgrounds on a vibrant and dynamic education campus. 3. Special Educational Needs (SEN) The DUP announced a major step change in planning and investment for children with special educational needs: • Investment Programme: They announced an ambitious and far-reaching programme of investment in facilities for children with special educational needs, intended to transform the education and lives of these vulnerable children and their families. 4. Early Learning and Childcare Recognizing that the lack of affordable childcare negatively impacts parental employment, the DUP is addressing this through a package of measures: • Funding Package: An interim £25 million package of measures was announced to support children, parents, and providers with early learning and childcare starting in September. • Pre-School Education: The measures aim to offer all children 22.5 hours of pre-school education per week. • Childcare Subsidy: The package is designed to reduce childcare bills for working parents through a Northern Ireland Childcare Subsidy Scheme. • Tax-Free Childcare: At Westminster, DUP MPs will support increasing the Tax-Free Childcare allowance from 20% to 35% and removing the cap on Tax Free Childcare above £2,000. 5. Other Education-Related Policies • School Uniforms: A consultation on improving the affordability of school uniforms was launched, and DUP MPs have proposed scrapping VAT on school uniforms. • Curriculum and Achievement: A £20 million programme of investment was announced to deliver innovative and community-informed approaches to raise achievement and reduce educational disadvantage in Northern Ireland. • Religious Freedom/RSE: The DUP has opposed regulations foisting abortion on the Relationships and Sexuality Education curriculum in schools across Northern Ireland. • Educational Opportunities: DUP MPs will campaign to deliver increased economic and educational opportunities for young people by building relationships across the UK, including through the UK East-West Council. • British Sign Language: DUP MPs supported plans to consult on the introduction of British Sign Language as a GCSE qualification in schools in England, while campaigning for similar steps to be considered in Northern Ireland. • School Management: A new way forward on how controlled schools are managed by the Education Authority was announced. Overall, the DUP’s education policies emphasize increased funding and investment to stabilize the sector, address long-standing pay issues, and ensure vulnerable children and families have access to necessary educational support and affordable childcare.
Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).environment: The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) outlines its key environmental policies under the commitment "Leading a Fairer - Not Faster - Path Towards Net-Zero". The party supports the UK’s long-term net-zero ambitions but emphasizes that the transition must be fair, inclusive, and should not lead to disproportionate costs for families and businesses. Summary of Key Policies on the Environment: 1. Fairer Transition to Net-Zero and Climate Policy The DUP is concerned that recent climate legislation, including in Northern Ireland, has been rushed and conflicts with independent scientific advice. Their primary focus is on mitigating the economic impact of environmental policy: • Fair Transition: They will press for a truly fair transition that is inclusive of all communities, households, and industries. • Cost Mitigation: They aim to address the threat of increased costs for basic goods and services and the looming impact of changes to emissions trading schemes and the EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism on trade between Great Britain and Northern Ireland. • National Approach: They believe a national approach to the co-design, delivery, and monitoring of climate policy is crucial, along with an enforcement approach that provides a level playing field across the United Kingdom. 2. Protecting Rivers and Lakes (Lough Neagh Crisis) The DUP acknowledges the ecological crisis engulfing Northern Ireland’s rivers and lakes, asserting that the natural environment cannot be ignored. • Pollution and Water Quality: There must be a concerted effort to tackle the sources of pollution, protect habitats, prevent biodiversity loss, and preserve water quality in Lough Neagh and rivers throughout Northern Ireland. • Action Plan: DUP MPs will support: ◦ A multi-agency response and approach to the ecological crisis in Lough Neagh. ◦ Targeted initiatives to prevent pollutants from entering waterways. ◦ Enforcement action against those who repeatedly or deliberately pollute rivers or lakes. 3. Green Growth and Low-Carbon Economy The DUP integrates environmental progress with economic opportunity, supporting policies that foster green, clean, and inclusive growth. • Economic Goals: They support the ambition of creating more local green jobs and aim to double the size of Northern Ireland’s low carbon and renewable energy economy to more than £2 billion turnover. • Hydrogen Technology: Northern Ireland is recognized as an innovator in hydrogen technology. The DUP commits to maximizing opportunities associated with hydrogen through a dedicated Hydrogen Innovation Strategy, supporting a new green hydrogen apprenticeship programme, and seeking funding streams and incentives for SME innovation in this sector. 4. Energy and Transportation The DUP supports a transition to cleaner energy but seeks pragmatic approaches to manage the shift, especially regarding personal vehicles and heating: • Energy Security: They remain committed to phasing out fossil fuels, acknowledging that two-thirds of homes in Northern Ireland are still heated by oil. They support a strategic national approach to transforming the production of clean and renewable energy in all parts of the UK. • Petrol/Diesel Ban Review: The DUP supports pushing back the ban on new petrol and diesel vehicles to at least 2035. They believe there should be a further review of these plans to account for the high upfront costs for families, the practical impact on businesses, and the lack of electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure availability. • Active Travel: They will support improved, structured working among government levels to enhance active travel infrastructure. 5. Waste and Circular Economy The party supports policies that promote a circular economy by keeping waste within the economy and out of the landscape, but opposes overly complex household sorting schemes. • Waste Collection: The DUP opposes a costly move to require households to sort waste into as many as six bins. Instead, they support a uniform method for household waste collection in Northern Ireland to keep it simple, maximize recycling volumes, and promote innovation in sorting technology. • Funding and Support: They will work with the next Government to unlock funding for the circular economy in Northern Ireland through the National Interdisciplinary Circular Economy Research (NICER) programme and encourage businesses to adopt circular business models. 6. Farming and Environmental Policy The DUP links environmental regulation to agricultural policy, stressing the protection of local food production: • Trade Risks: They express concern that unfair and unworkable environmental targets levied on local farm businesses may lead to a reliance on foreign, cheaper produce that may have been farmed under lower environmental standards. • Trade Protection: They will seek protection for sensitive food and animal products in trade negotiations. • Planning Policy: They seek a national review of planning policy and law to unlock greater levels of on-farm investment, including ensuring rules around permitted development and ammonia emissions adopt a long-term approach to delivering more sustainable farming practices. The DUP generally accepts the goal of Net-Zero but insists that the implementation must be tempered by economic practicality, avoiding burdensome costs on households and businesses, especially in Northern Ireland.
Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).brexit: The sources, which are excerpts from the Democratic Unionist Party’s (DUP) 2024 Manifesto, primarily focus on the negative impacts of the Northern Ireland Protocol and the party’s ongoing campaign to remove internal barriers within the United Kingdom post-Brexit. The DUP’s core views on Brexit arrangements, particularly concerning Northern Ireland, can be summarized as follows: Stance on the Northern Ireland Protocol and EU Law The DUP strongly opposes the Northern Ireland Protocol and views its imposition as a catastrophic political failure: • The Northern Ireland Protocol was imposed without the support of any elected unionist representative. • The Protocol wrecked the settled political balance within Northern Ireland and led directly to a loss of unionist confidence. • The DUP voted against the imposition of the NI Protocol in both the UK national Parliament and the European Parliament. • The party states that some of the greatest harm inflicted on Northern Ireland has been a consequence of choices made by the Conservative Party and endorsed by the national Parliament. • A key objective is to remove the application of EU law in Northern Ireland and to eliminate the internal Irish Sea border that the Protocol created. • The DUP is campaigning to send a strong message to the next Government that they will continue to fight to fully restore Northern Ireland’s place within the United Kingdom. • They will continue to argue for the full primacy of the United Kingdom internal market and will reject its undermining. View of the Windsor Framework and Negotiations While the DUP acknowledges some progress was made in subsequent negotiations, they did not endorse the resulting deal: • The DUP did not support the Windsor Framework, despite recognizing that some progress had been secured. • The party decided to return to Stormont on the basis of the roadmap set out in the Government’s Command Paper, but noted that this paper did not secure all of their negotiating objectives and failed to remedy a number of the long-term problems born out of the Protocol. • Important gains secured through negotiations included: ◦ Parliament legislating for mutual recognition of standards on goods through a goods guarantee throughout the United Kingdom. ◦ The creation of the new U.K East-West Council to foster deeper connections across trade, transport, education, and culture. ◦ The establishment of Intertrade UK to boost trade and remove internal barriers throughout the United Kingdom. ◦ Securing the Stormont Brake mechanism, which the DUP states they pushed for and will use to full effect. Future Action and Commitments The DUP remains committed to overturning the current arrangements: • The party plans to use the inbuilt review mechanisms and will not hesitate to vote against the continued application of the current arrangements in the NI Assembly vote in October. • They are committed to securing a practical and ongoing demonstration from future UK Governments of their commitment to promoting and developing British culture, heritage, and traditions, recognizing that the Protocol has acutely impacted confidence in unionist and loyalist communities. • The DUP secured a government commitment to improving connections between Northern Ireland and Great Britain, including through the A75 in Scotland and £10 million for port infrastructure development. Related Post-Brexit Policy Positions The DUP also notes specific areas where UK sovereignty post-Brexit is relevant: • Immigration: The party supported an end to the free movement of people from European countries and seeks a fair and controlled immigration system governed solely by the UK Parliament and equally and fully applicable in all parts of the United Kingdom. They specifically highlight that Article 2 of the Protocol prevents the Government’s policy on illegal migrants (like the Rwanda plan) from extending to Northern Ireland, risking making the region a "magnet for asylum seekers". • Fisheries: Northern Ireland fishermen have benefited from leaving the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which ended discrimination that saw quotas effectively "stolen" from Northern Ireland fishermen and awarded to competitors in the Irish Republic. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- To understand the DUP’s stance, imagine trying to unite a room that has been cut in half by a temporary, unpopular wall. The DUP’s view is that the wall (the Protocol/Irish Sea border) should never have been built, they oppose the compromises made to reduce its height (the Windsor Framework), and their primary goal is to dismantle the wall entirely to fully reconnect the two halves of the room (Northern Ireland and Great Britain).
Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).entire manifesto: The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) Manifesto for the 2024 General Election, titled Making NI Work, sets out ten core policy commitments aimed at ensuring Northern Ireland can thrive as a secure and vibrant part of the United Kingdom. The DUP states that these commitments are focused on building on the party’s record of delivery in Westminster and the Northern Ireland Assembly. Summary of Main Policy Commitments: 1. Promoting the Union and Removing Barriers Within the United Kingdom The DUP will continue to fight to fully restore Northern Ireland’s place within the United Kingdom, specifically by working toward removing the application of EU law in the country and the internal Irish Sea border that it creates. They will argue the case for the full primacy of the UK internal market and reject the undermining of its integrity. Furthermore, the party is committed to securing a long-term demonstration from future UK Governments of their commitment to promoting and developing British culture, heritage and traditions in Northern Ireland. The DUP also plans to use the Stormont Brake mechanism and will not hesitate to vote against the continued application of current arrangements in October. 2. Putting You First - Delivering Fair and Equitable Funding for Our NHS, and Other Public Services The DUP campaigns for a new needs-based funding model for Northern Ireland, arguing that chronic underfunding has systematically damaged public services. They will press the next Government to ensure that funding cannot drop below the definition of assessed need, which they define as £124 for every £100 spent in England. Key health policies include: • Driving down waiting lists by fostering partnerships between health and social care in NI and national independent providers. • Providing fellowships for young GPs and establishing a permanent state-backed scheme for indemnity for GPs. • Firmly opposing efforts to legalise assisted suicide. • Campaigning for recurrent funding to provide decent pay awards for public sector staff like nurses, doctors, and teachers. 3. Campaigning to Protect Family Incomes The party seeks to protect incomes, ensure fair taxation, and lift more people out of poverty. Key proposals include: • Opposing the freeze on the personal tax allowance and seeking further reductions in national insurance. • Seeking to abolish VAT on domestic electricity bills and maintaining the freeze on fuel duty. • Maintaining the Triple Lock on state pensions and opposing any further rise in the state pension age. • Supporting measures to ease the burden on families, such as scrapping VAT on school uniforms and removing the two-child limit on Universal Credit for 3- and 4-child households. • Campaigning to reverse the scrapping of free BBC licence fees for over 75s and seeking the eventual abolition of the BBC licence fee in favour of a subscription-based service. 4. Unleashing our Full Economic Potential The DUP is committed to growing the Northern Ireland economy and creating better jobs. Economic policies include: • Increasing the VAT threshold for Small and Medium Sized Enterprises (SMEs) to £100,000 and uprating it in line with inflation. • Exploring the potential introduction of an online sales tax targeting online corporates and marketplaces. • Advocating for a reduction in corporate tax across the United Kingdom, noting that the minimum 15% rate in the Republic of Ireland places NI firms at a competitive disadvantage. • Seeking to prioritize Northern Ireland’s advanced manufacturing and engineering sectors, and maximizing economic opportunities associated with hydrogen technology. 5. A Strategic Role for UK Defence and Security The DUP believes the UK should commit to spending 3.0% of GDP on defence by 2035. They will pursue the greater integration of Northern Ireland into national defence structures, networks, and operations. • They will work to increase the number of major Ministry of Defence (MoD) contracts placed in Northern Ireland and address historically low levels of MoD expenditure in the region. • Regarding Immigration, they will fight to ensure national policy applies equally across the United Kingdom and that Northern Ireland is fully protected in law against illegal immigration. • They advocate for an uplift in funding provided by the Government for Northern Ireland’s Additional Security needs to counter the enduring threat posed by dissident republicans. 6. Backing our Farmers and Food Security The DUP seeks an increased, ring-fenced, and multi-annual farm support and development budget that is inflated to match the impact of inflation since 2020. • They believe food production should be recognized as a strategic national asset and that the needs of farmers cannot be sacrificed for other policy objectives. • They support a commitment by the Government to source 50% of food into the public sector from British farms. • They will support robust Bovine TB eradication policies, including targeted badger culling, with the aim of moving to a vaccination-only approach as soon as possible. 7. Leading a Fairer - Not Faster - Path Towards Net-Zero While supporting the UK’s long-term net-zero ambitions, the DUP is concerned that recent legislation has been rushed and conflicts with scientific advice. They will press for a truly fair transition that is inclusive and addresses the threat of increased costs for basic goods and services. • They support pushing back the ban on new petrol and diesel vehicles to at least 2035 and seek a further review due to high upfront costs and the lack of EV charging infrastructure. • They commit to a concerted effort to tackle the pollution sources contributing to the ecological crisis in Lough Neagh and other waterways, supporting a multi-agency response. 8. Defending Our Most Vulnerable The DUP maintains an unashamedly pro-life stance, opposing the commissioning of, and funding for, abortion services in Northern Ireland. They will seek a review of legislation that they feel criminalizes prayer, including silent prayer, and oppose the application of regulations related to abortion in the Relationships and Sexuality Education curriculum. They also commit to ensuring that people with disabilities have better access to and provision of vital services. 9. Investing More in National Infrastructure The DUP will pursue the full implementation of the Union Connectivity Review. • They secured commitments to improve journeys on the A75 between Gretna and Stranraer and boost port connections between NI and GB. • They advocate for the abolition of domestic air passenger duty to boost competitiveness. • They will work to accelerate the roll-out of 5G coverage and build on their success in securing full-fibre broadband across Northern Ireland. 10. Standing Up for Victims of Crime The DUP will support efforts to repeal the Northern Ireland Troubles (Legacy and Reconciliation) Act 2023 (which offers an amnesty in all but name) and urge UK Ministers to repeal this legislation within the first 100 days of the next Parliament. They prioritize a victim-centred approach to investigating the past and guarantee continued funding for the Troubles victims’ pension. • They will campaign to end the "Wild West" of social media, supporting robust regulation under the Online Safety Act and seeking a statutory definition of grooming. • They will press for stronger custodial sentences for murder and terror offences in Northern Ireland, bringing NI in line with other regions of the UK.

Sinn Féin.crime: Sinn Féin’s policies on crime, policing, and justice are detailed primarily in the section titled "Policing and Justice" under "Protecting and Investing in Communities". The manifesto asserts that the legacy of recent governments has resulted in a crisis of recruitment and morale within An Garda Síochána, lengthy court delays, and prison overcrowding, leading to public order issues and communities feeling unsafe. Sinn Féin’s approach aims to ensure proper resourcing and planning across the entire Justice portfolio to restore public safety through evidence-based policies, harm reduction, and shared responsibility for combating the causes of crime across government. Here is a summary of Sinn Féin’s key policies on crime and justice: Policing and Public Safety Sinn Féin plans to address the crisis in Garda recruitment and retention and increase the visibility of policing. • Garda Recruitment Drive: Commence the largest Garda recruitment drive in the history of the state, aiming to recruit between 900 and 1,000 Gardaí each year, rising to 1,500 annually once a second college is operational. The goal is an eventual force of 16,000-strong. • Training Capacity: Establish a second Garda Training College with an annual intake capacity of 500 recruits to increase the number of officers. • Retention Measures: Introduce retention measures, including increasing the Garda trainee allowance to €397 per week. They would also establish a Garda Recruitment and Retention Taskforce to investigate the underlying reasons for the crisis. • Rural Crime: Address rural crime by increasing Garda numbers in rural areas. • Community Policing: Support restorative justice efforts to respond to crime in communities. They also plan to legislate to reform Joint Policing Committees (JCPs) to grant them greater powers, functions, and resources to address rural policing priorities. • Community CCTV: Introduce legislation concerning Community CCTV schemes to clarify responsibility for administration and data management. Combating Financial Fraud and Scams The manifesto addresses the alarming increase in financial fraud and scams, noting that inaction has left citizens vulnerable. • Strategy and Taskforce: Establish a multi-annual strategy and taskforce to tackle financial fraud and scams. • Shared Fraud Database: Introduce legislation to establish a Shared Fraud Database to enable banks and An Garda Síochána to share real-time information for detecting fraud and protecting consumers. • Holding Platforms Accountable: Hold online platforms and social media companies accountable for hosting fraudulent adverts by classifying such content as harmful online material and imposing financial penalties against platforms that knowingly fail to remove it. • Bank Accountability: Require banks to introduce a name-checking system to prevent fraudsters from receiving money under false identities, and mandate banks to compensate victims of fraud where this required action fails. • Regulatory Powers: Empower the Communications Regulator to prevent fraudsters from abusing mobile and telephone networks. Justice System and Rehabilitation Sinn Féin views public safety as a "whole of government responsibility" and plans to significantly invest in the justice system. • Youth Diversion: Increase new Youth Diversion Projects and expand their age eligibility. • Restorative Justice: Double investment in Restorative Justice Programmes and implement Sinn Féin’s Criminal Justice (Promotion of Restorative Justice) (Amendment) Bill 2023. • Funding: Increase funding for the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), the Courts Service, and for Legal Aid. Funding would also be increased for the prison service. • Historic Injustice: Commit to addressing historic injustices, including issuing a state apology to the family of Captain James Kelly, and establishing judicial inquiries into cases like Shane O’Farrell, Sallins, and Terence Wheelock. Domestic and Gender-Based Violence (DSGBV) The manifesto refers to violence against women as an "epidemic" requiring urgent action and a zero-tolerance approach. • Rape Crisis Centres: Ensure a Dedicated Rape Crisis Centre (including SATU, helpline, court accompaniment, and counselling services) is available for every 200,000 of the population. • Flee Fund: Establish a Statutory Flee Fund with grants ranging from €500 to €2,500 to assist victims in leaving abusive situations and setting up new homes. • Legal and Medical Support: Raise the disposable income threshold for legal aid in Domestic Violence cases and ensure every Domestic Violence Service that provides accommodation has access to a medical card for clients staying there. • Shelters: Provide €75 million in Capital funding beyond pre-committed amounts for domestic violence shelters. Hate Crime Legislation Sinn Féin explicitly states its opposition to the current government’s approach to hate crime legislation. • Repeal of Act: Sinn Féin would repeal the Criminal Justice (Hate Offences) Act. • Freedom of Speech: They believe the government’s legislation sought to undermine the right to free speech and protest and was not legally sound. Sinn Féin voted against the bill, arguing that vulnerable groups must be protected, but not through measures that could lead to censorship. Analogy for Understanding Sinn Féin’s policy on crime is analogous to approaching a leaking public pool by not only patching the leaks (crimefighting and rehabilitation) but also increasing the flow of water (recruitment/resources) and installing a better filtration system (anti-fraud taskforces) to make the whole environment safer and more functional.
Sinn Féin.healthcare: Sinn Féin’s healthcare policies, outlined in the section titled "Health Sláinte" and detailed in their standalone plan, A Prescription for Change, focus on "Taking Big Bold Steps towards Universal Healthcare" and transforming the health service to improve access, reduce waiting lists, and tackle crises like emergency department overcrowding. The plan is described as ambitious, realistic, practical, and deliverable, developed in close consultation with healthcare workers, patients, and other key stakeholders. Sinn Féin aims to transition towards a publicly funded healthcare system for Ireland by 2035, recognizing physical and mental health as a human right. Here is a summary of Sinn Féin’s five key priorities in Health and Social Care: 1. Taking Big Bold Steps towards Universal Healthcare Sinn Féin plans to immediately introduce measures to reduce the cost of healthcare for households. • Free Medicines and Cards: Deliver free prescription medicines for all households. • Medical Card Expansion: Upgrade every GP visit card to a full medical card, and provide full medical card cover to all workers up to the median income. • Cost Abolition: Abolish prescription charges for medical card holders and abolish prescription and car-parking charges. • Commitment to Universal Care: Enact "Healthcare for All" legislation within the first 100 days to commit the state to achieving full public health cover by 2035. 2. Upgrading and Expanding Local Health Services The party commits to realizing the Sláintecare goal of delivering the right care in the right place at the right time, focusing on primary and community care. • GP and Dental Services: Develop a landmark public GP contract, employ 250 public GPs, and hire public dentists and dental care teams. They would also increase GP training capacity by 60% and dental training places by 32%. • Pharmacy First Model: Implement a "Pharmacy First" model for common conditions, expanding the role of pharmacists in primary care. • Home Care: Pursue a "home first" approach to care, prioritizing the public delivery of five million additional home care hours through a modern home care scheme. They plan to ensure access to GP services and dental services for communities. 3. Driving Major Reform of Hospital Care Sinn Féin plans to tackle the hospital crisis by significantly increasing bed capacity and investment. • Bed Targets: Deliver 5,000 new hospital beds by 2031. This includes 4,000 additional acute beds and replacing 1,000 existing unsafe beds. • Overcrowding: Implement a zero-tolerance approach to hospital trolleys and overcrowding. • Elective Hospitals: Accelerate the delivery of public-only elective hospitals. The plan includes estimates for four new elective-only public hospitals and regional surgical centers to tackle waiting lists. • Community Beds: Deliver 2,000 community beds, including short and long-stay residential care, nursing, and rehabilitation beds. • Capital Funding: Utilize €2 billion from the Apple Tax money for immediate funding certainty for the 5,000 acute hospital beds. The total health capital investment program would be €15 billion over the next term of government. 4. Revolutionising Youth Mental Health The manifesto singles out mental health, particularly for young people, as an area requiring transformation. • New Service: Establish a new Child and Youth Mental Health Service to replace CAMHS. • Early Intervention: The new service would provide integrated early intervention services for children and young people up to the age of 25. • Counselling and Teams: Expand access to Jigsaw, primary care mental health services, deliver universal counselling, and deliver twenty more early intervention in psychosis teams. 5. Delivering a Rights-Based Approach to Disability Services Sinn Féin commits to a decade-long investment to ensure rights are delivered for disabled people. • Investment: Implement a 10-year investment programme for disability services, with €829 million in additional current expenditure and €659 million additional capital allocated for the first five years. • Personal Assistance (PA) Hours: Commit to doubling the number of Personal Assistance hours over a term of government, and providing an additional 1.5 million disability home care hours. • Residential Care: Provide over 3,000 additional appropriate residential places and deliver on de-congregation commitments. • Assessment and Review: Develop a common, compliant, and efficient process for assessment of need under the Disability Act. They would also conduct an evidence-based, independent review of the service delivery model for Children’s Disability Services (CDNTs) and fully staff the teams. Workforce Planning and Accountability The plan requires significant staffing increases and financial reform. • Recruitment: Plan to recruit 40,000 healthcare and social care workers over five years. This involves giving a job guarantee to Irish health graduates, doubling CAO entry places for medicine and health courses, and attracting Irish workers home. • Efficiency and Savings: Propose a total package of new measures valued at €5.4 billion, partially funded by a minimum target of €1 billion in savings and efficiencies across the health service by 2030, including major reductions in reliance on expensive agency workers and management consultants.
Sinn Féin.housing: Sinn Féin’s housing strategy, titled A Home Of Your Own, is a core component of their General Election Manifesto 2024, emphasizing the delivery of affordable and social housing on an unprecedented scale. The party contends that the housing crisis is a result of years of inadequate policy and that affordable housing is key to solving broader issues, including recruitment crises in public services. Here is a summary of Sinn Féin’s key policies on housing: 1. Housing Supply and Targets Sinn Féin plans to launch the largest social and affordable building program in the history of the state. • Overall Targets: The party would deliver 300,000 new homes between 2025 and 2029 to keep pace with projected future need and address the existing shortage. They also intend to continue delivery into 2030, bringing the six-year total to 370,000 homes. • Public Housing Programme: This massive target includes 125,000 public homes over the five-year period (2025-2029), consisting of: ◦ 75,000 social housing units for those on waiting lists or in insecure private rental accommodation. ◦ 25,000 affordable rental homes for people saving for deposits or currently paying high private rents. ◦ 25,000 affordable purchase homes for people currently locked out of homeownership. • Private Market Targets: The plan also includes 115,000 private market homes for working people to buy, and 60,000 homes for private rent and self-build, ensuring a well-balanced market. 2. Affordability and Accessibility A central goal is making homeownership and renting affordable for ordinary workers and families. • Affordable Prices: Affordable homes for purchase would start from €250,000. • Affordable Rent: Affordable rental homes would be priced at an average of €1,000 per month or lower. • Rent Freeze: To protect renters immediately, Sinn Féin would implement a ban on rent increases for three years, providing certainty while affordable homes are built. • Renter Support: They would provide a refundable tax credit equivalent to one month’s rent back in renters’ pockets, with a minimum payment of €1,000 for each adult renter. 3. Reform and Delivery Mechanisms Sinn Féin’s plan details how they intend to fund and accelerate the delivery of this building programme. • Funding: Delivering 125,000 public homes over five years is estimated to cost an average of €7.4 billion per year, financed through a combination of exchequer funding, Housing Finance Agency borrowing, and other lenders. • Apple Tax Allocation: Sinn Féin commits to using €7.6 billion of the Apple Tax money specifically towards their public housing programme. • Constitutional Right: They would hold a referendum to enshrine the right to housing in the Constitution. • Land Management: The current Land Development Agency (LDA) would be transformed into an Active Land Management Agency to secure an adequate pipeline of land for public housing. • Streamlining Processes: They would reform and resource the planning system, overhaul the public spending code, and streamline procurement by using multi-annual framework agreements instead of single project tendering to speed up delivery and provide certainty to builders. • Vacant/Derelict Homes: Maximizing the use of new building technologies and vacant and derelict properties is a priority, as these methods are faster and more sustainable. • Ending Wasteful Schemes: Sinn Féin would eliminate "wasteful and inflationary schemes" such as Croí Conaithe Cities, the First Home Scheme, and the Local Infrastructure Housing Activation Fund. The Help to Buy Scheme would be phased out over five years. • Builder Support: They would support small- and medium-sized builders by providing low-cost finance, efficient site servicing, and timely planning. 4. Water and Defects Addressing underlying infrastructure and building defects is included in the housing plan. • Public Water Ownership: A referendum would be held to enshrine the public ownership of the water and wastewater system and utility in the Constitution. • Water Investment: Investment in water and wastewater services would be increased by at least an additional €1.5 billion over five years to meet the needs of the housing plan. • Building Defects Redress: Sinn Féin would ensure 100% redress for all homeowners impacted by building defects and defective materials through an end-to-end scheme. They would allocate €1 billion of the Apple Tax money to supplement existing capital available for defects redress.
Sinn Féin.immigration: Sinn Féin’s policies on immigration are centered on managing migration effectively, ensuring fairness, and safeguarding social cohesion through the establishment of a dedicated agency and changes to current accommodation practices. Their approach is guided by principles of equality, justice, sovereignty, and anti-racism. Here is a summary of Sinn Féin’s key policies on immigration and international protection: 1. Establishment of an Immigration Management Agency (IMA) The core proposal is to create a single, centralized body to address the current fragmented and under-resourced system. • Creation of the Agency: Sinn Féin would set up a new Immigration Management Agency under the Department of Justice and Home Affairs. This is proposed at an additional cost of €5.5 million. • Centralized Responsibility: The IMA would assume responsibility for several functions currently spread across multiple departments and bodies, including: ◦ Processing of International Protection (IP) applicants in a fair and efficient manner. ◦ Enforcement of rules, including the investigation of illegal immigration and the enforcement of deportation orders. ◦ Registration of individuals. ◦ Accommodation for IP applicants. ◦ Proper planning of the migration system. • Resourcing: The new agency would be properly resourced, with plans to treble staffing across the system at a cost of €82 million to ensure fast and fair decisions are made. • Border Management: The party believes that every state must be able to control its borders and that robust bi-lateral arrangements with Britain are necessary to manage immigration while protecting the free movement of citizens across the land border. This includes agreeing on arrangements with Britain for managing immigration at airports and ports to ensure IP applicants who should be processed in Britain are returned there. 2. Accommodation and Community Engagement Sinn Féin addresses the chaos and lack of public confidence resulting from the current government’s mismanagement of international protection accommodation. • Location Criteria: New International Protection Accommodation Services (IPAS) centers would be managed based on criteria such as the availability of services and levels of economic and social disadvantage. This means that new centers would only be placed in more affluent areas that have the existing capacity and services to support them, protecting working-class communities already under severe pressure. • Accommodation Model: They propose transitioning the IP accommodation system to greater use of purpose-built, state-owned beds, while reducing reliance on profit-driven commercial providers often criticized for poor quality and unsuitable locations. • Consultation and Oversight: A standard, transparent, and consistent approach to community consultation would be created, including opportunities for submissions. They would also invite the Children’s Ombudsman and HIQA to periodically report on the standards of all International Protection accommodation. • Ending Two-Tier System: The party would end the two-tier system to ensure all those seeking international protection are treated equally, irrespective of where they come from. 3. Measures Related to Residence and Enforcement • Registration Requirements: Sinn Féin would examine the registration requirements and models in operation in other EU countries regarding EU, EEA, and Swiss citizens to enable authorities to be more fully aware of population movements for service planning and law enforcement purposes. • Enforcement: They plan for greater implementation of legal provisions for fines on airlines and other carriers transporting passengers with no documents, and for prosecutions of individuals. 4. Temporary Protection Directive (Ukrainian Refugees) Sinn Féin views the continuous extension of temporary measures as unsustainable and problematic. • Orderly Conclusion: The special status of Ukrainians under the Temporary Protection Directive should come to an end no later than March 2026. • Transition to Permanent Rules: After this period, they advocate for a return to ordinary, permanent immigration rules. • Assisted Return: If a beneficiary is from a safe part of Ukraine, assisted return should be provided, save for exceptional cases. Those from unsafe areas can apply for International Protection, and others wishing to stay can apply for work-based permits. • Ending Payment Scheme: Sinn Féin would end the Accommodation Recognition Payment scheme for Ukrainian beneficiaries so that new applicants cannot join, arguing that the current scheme disadvantages other families seeking to rent private accommodation. Sinn Féin’s overall goal is to achieve a system that works well and quickly, applying rules fairly, treating people with dignity, and ensuring local communities are respected.
Sinn Féin.defence: Sinn Féin’s policies on defense are primarily focused on protecting Irish neutrality, resisting further militarization within the European Union, and urgently investing in and reforming the Defence Forces to address crises in recruitment, retention, and equipment deficits. Here is a summary of Sinn Féin’s key defense policies: 1. Protecting and Upholding Neutrality Sinn Féin views military neutrality as having served Ireland well and commits to its protection. • Triple-Lock Protection: Sinn Féin would maintain the triple-lock neutrality protection. The party notes that proposals to abandon this mechanism breach commitments previously given to the Irish people. • Constitutional Referendum: They would bring forward a referendum to enshrine military neutrality and non-alignment in the Irish constitution. If successful, they would then engage with EU institutions to recognize the integrity of neutral states in the EU treaties. • Opposition to Militarization: Sinn Féin opposes any attempts to transfer decision-making powers on Foreign Affairs and Defence to the European Union, including opposing Qualified Majority Voting (QMV) on such matters, and opposes any prospects for the formation of an EU army. • Deployment Policy: While maintaining neutrality, Sinn Féin would prioritize participation in UN peacekeeping missions. They would seek to reverse the government’s decision to withdraw from the United Nations Disengagement Observe Force (UNDOF) mission to the Golan Heights. • Oireachtas Oversight: They commit to ensuring comprehensive Oireachtas oversight and scrutiny of all proposals for Irish participation in international military missions and exercises. 2. Investing in the Defence Forces The manifesto highlights that the Defence Forces are at a "critical juncture" due to years of underfunding, issues with pay and conditions, and a severe recruitment and retention crisis. • Increased Numbers: Sinn Féin plans to increase Defence Force member numbers to rebuild the force to a baseline figure of 11,500 members, which is the Level of Ambition (LOA) 2 requirement. As of August 2024, the strength stood at 7,426. • Capital Investment: They propose providing an additional €295 million in capital expenditure by 2030 to meet the LOA 2 capital spending targets by 2032. • Key Equipment: They would prioritize the acquisition of primary radar and subsea capabilities. • Funding Commitment: Sinn Féin proposes increasing annual current funding for the Defence Forces by €206.9 million over and above existing pre-committed funding. • Working Time Directive: They commit to improving conditions of members through the urgent implementation of the Working Time Directive. • Support for Members: They would allocate funding to healthcare and medical supports for those whose health was unduly negatively impacted through their service (referencing issues raised by the Women of Honour). They would also increase funding for Veterans Associations. The party maintains that strong, adequately equipped Defence Forces are necessary to uphold Ireland’s status as a neutral state and to carry out duties, including assistance in civil duties such as dealing with natural disasters.
Sinn Féin.economy: Sinn Féin’s economic policies, framed under the section "Economic and Regional Development" and detailed in "Funding Change," propose a fundamental shift toward increased public investment, prioritizing domestic growth, and ensuring a fairer distribution of wealth and resources, often contrasting their approach with the "failures" of previous governments. The overall strategy is built upon four principles for public spending: increased investment in public services; a fair tax system benefiting low and middle-income workers; reducing national debt as a proportion of the economy; and investing a portion of windfall corporate tax revenues in housing and infrastructure. Here is a summary of Sinn Féin’s key economic policies and strategies: 1. Funding Strategy and Public Finances Sinn Féin proposes a substantial increase in public expenditure, funded primarily through leveraging windfall corporate tax receipts and increasing taxes on high earners and wealth. • Increased Investment: Provide an additional €14.3 billion in current spending and €41.8 billion in capital investment over and above pre-committed expenditure for existing services, demographics, and the National Development Plan (NDP). • Capital Investment Target: Increase average capital investment to 6% of GNI* over the period 2025–2030 to address infrastructure deficits, up from the current government’s failure to meet the 5% target. • Budgetary Surplus: Commit to running a budgetary surplus every year, targeting an accumulated surplus of €14.8 billion by 2030, with surpluses invested in state funds to maintain strong public finances and reduce debt. • Apple Tax Allocation: Utilize the €14.1 billion Apple Tax money for targeted capital investment in critical areas, including: ◦ €7.6 billion for the public housing programme. ◦ €2.5 billion to establish a new Renewable Energy Fund to invest in the energy grid and facilitate renewable energy. ◦ €2 billion for immediate funding certainty for the delivery of 5,000 acute hospital beds. ◦ €1 billion for a new Community Investment Fund to invest in working-class communities. ◦ €1 billion to supplement capital available for defective building materials redress, ensuring a guaranteed tripling of funding. 2. Taxation Strategy and Cost of Living Relief Sinn Féin’s tax strategy aims to benefit low- and middle-income earners while increasing contributions from those with higher incomes and wealth. • Abolish USC: Abolish the Universal Social Charge (USC) on the first €45,000 of every worker’s income, resulting in over €1,100 extra a year for average workers, and ensuring the average worker pays no USC. • Solidarity Tax: Introduce a 3% solidarity tax on individual incomes above €140,000 and reform tax credits for individual incomes above €100,000. • Local Property Tax (LPT): Abolish the Local Property Tax and replace it with direct funding for Local Authorities. • Carbon Tax and Excise: Stop all planned increases to the carbon tax from 2025–2030, and reverse the two most recent hikes to excise duty on petrol and diesel for 12 months. • Wealth and Housing Taxes: Establish a Wealth Tax Commission to advise on implementing a net wealth tax. Increase stamp duty to end the bulk purchasing of residential property by institutional investors, and abolish stamp duty for first-time buyers on properties up to €450,000. • Corporate Tax: Maintain the corporation tax rate at 12.5% and defend Ireland’s tax sovereignty. They would restrict corporation tax relief for the banking sector and increase the banking levy to €400 million. 3. Enterprise, Employment, and Regional Development The economic policy focuses on rebalancing the economy away from excessive reliance on Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) toward a stronger, indigenous industrial base rooted across all regions of Ireland. • FDI Focus: Continue to attract FDI, but direct investment into key knowledge-intensive sectors (e.g., cleantech/renewables and artificial intelligence) and ensure it is distributed across the country to alleviate pressure on Dublin. • Domestic Enterprise: Establish "Mol Gnó", a new Irish Enterprise Agency, with an annual budget of almost €10 million, focused on scaling existing Irish businesses and supporting non-export-focused start-ups and established companies. • Regional Rebalancing: Invest substantially in infrastructure to eliminate deficits throughout the country, supporting the development of regions outside urban centers. • VAT Reduction: Introduce a reduced 9% rate of VAT for parts of the Hospitality sector (excluding accommodation), costing €605 million. • Workers’ Rights: Strengthen workers’ rights, legislating for the Right to Organise and a legal right to collective bargaining. Increase the minimum wage by €1.10 per hour in 2025 to move towards the Living Wage. • Community Business Models: Allocate funding to support the expansion of the workers’ co-operative model (€2m/year) and the Community Wealth Building Fund (€1m/year) to develop community-driven businesses and recirculate wealth locally. 4. Infrastructure and Transport Investment Sinn Féin aims to significantly improve infrastructure delivery by increasing investment and reforming oversight. • Capital Project Oversight: Develop increased expertise in the Department of Public Expenditure under the National Investment Office to avoid delays and overruns on large capital projects, giving the office a clear oversight and assurance role. • PPP Contracts: Move away from the use of controversial Public Private Partnerships (PPP) contracts for public infrastructure. • Transport Infrastructure: Prioritize the progression of major transport projects, including the Western Rail Corridor (WRC) to Collooney, the Navan rail line reopening, and the Metrolink project in Dublin. Increase funding for public transport (by €126 million annually) and allocate €102 million capital funding to make all public transport wheelchair accessible. Economic Metaphor Sinn Féin’s economic plan is like remodeling a national house: instead of just patching up the leaky roof (windfall taxes) for temporary comfort, they plan to build new, affordable wings (300,000 homes), install efficient, public-owned utilities (energy independence), and ensure everyone contributes fairly to the construction costs (tax reforms on wealth and high income), ultimately making the entire structure sound and accessible to all families, rather than just the wealthiest investors.
Sinn Féin.education: Sinn Féin’s education policies are aimed at making education truly free and inclusive, covering all levels from primary school up to further and higher education, with a strong emphasis on addressing costs, special educational needs, and staffing shortages. Here is a summary of Sinn Féin’s key policies on education: 1. Reducing the Cost of Education A central commitment is to ensure education is free and affordable, tackling the significant financial burden on parents. • Phasing Out Student Fees: They plan to completely phase out third level student fees (the contribution charge) within three years, starting by halving them in 2025. • Voluntary Contributions: They will end schools’ reliance on "voluntary contributions" by increasing annual core capitation funding and the ancillary services grant to schools by €150 million and legislating to end the contributions. • School Meals and Books: ◦ Expand the hot school meals scheme to all primary schools and commence rollout to secondary schools. ◦ Extend the free schoolbooks scheme to senior cycle in secondary schools from September 2025 and increase the School Book Grant for primary school children from €80 to €110. • Uniforms and Devices: Introduce measures via an Affordable School Uniform Bill to ensure schools make uniforms affordable, and introduce a scheme to alleviate the cost of digital devices starting with DEIS secondary schools. • Grants and Supports: Increase SUSI grants by 15% (adjacent and non-adjacent) and expand the availability of SUSI for qualifying Postgraduate students. 2. Prioritizing Special Educational Needs (SEN) Sinn Féin aims to address the challenges faced by children with SEN, moving away from crisis-response toward adequate planning and rights implementation. • Legislation and Rights: They would enact a new rights-based Education Bill and provide the resources to implement it. They would also require the Department of Education’s Inspectorate to report on the implementation of Individual Education Plans (IEPs). • Planning and Appeals: Provide the National Council for Special Education (NCSE) with greater powers to ensure sufficient and appropriate school places and classes are provided, and establish robust appeals mechanisms for resource allocation decisions. • Staffing: Provide funding for the recruitment of 1,000 additional Special Education Teachers and 1,300 additional Special Needs Assistants (SNAs) on average per annum. • Psychologists: Recruit additional educational psychologists and provide greater administrative support to make better use of their time. • Summer Programmes: Commit to improving and reversing cuts to the Summer Programme to alleviate parents’ stress and prevent regression for children with SEN. 3. Tackling Educational Disadvantage and Staffing Shortages Policies focus on redirecting resources and addressing recruitment and retention issues among teaching staff. • Private School Subsidies: Phase out the state subsidy to private fee-paying schools over the term of government (saving €131 million annually) and redirect that funding into public schools. • DEIS+ Scheme: Introduce a DEIS+ scheme to target additional resources at the DEIS schools with the greatest level of need. • Guidance Counsellors: Increase the number of guidance counsellors by 10%. • Teacher Recruitment/Retention: Address staffing shortages by ensuring full-time, permanent posts are more quickly available to teachers and reviewing teacher contracts. They would also award full incremental credit for experience teaching abroad in equivalent jurisdictions. • PME Review: Undertake a comprehensive review of the Professional Master of Education (PME) course structure, which is often cited as a major cost and duration barrier. 4. Further and Higher Education (Excluding Costs) Sinn Féin addresses issues related to funding, employment, and accommodation in the third level sector. • Core Funding: Aim to close the core funding gap in the Higher Education sector and ensure the National Training Fund (NTF) fulfills its purpose. • Precarious Employment: Remove the Employment Control Framework to allow universities greater flexibility to determine staffing and commit to ending precarious employment and the use of short-term insecure contracts. • Student Accommodation: Allocate €300 million capital expenditure to fast-track purpose-built student accommodation (PBSA) projects where planning has been granted. They would also amend regulations to move away from overly high-spec requirements (like mandatory en suite bathrooms) toward more communal and cost-effective designs. They would also progress legislation to provide greater protections for students in "digs" (Rent-a-Room scheme). • Apprenticeships: Abolish fees for apprentices and increase the rates of allowances for craft apprentices by 50%. They would also introduce a special allowance (€10,000) for craft apprenticeship instructors. 5. School Transport The party plans significant reform and expansion of the school transport system. • Expansion Targets: Reform and expand the system to provide an additional 100,000 pupils with transport services by 2030. • Eligibility Criteria: Reduce the distance criteria to 1km for primary and 2km for secondary school pupils, and facilitate routes to schools other than the nearest one where demand exists. 6. Irish Language in Education Sinn Féin seeks a culture shift to promote the Irish language and increase access to Irish-medium education. • Policy Focus: Develop and implement an evidence-based state policy rooted in the principle of not only meeting but actively growing demand for Irish-medium schooling and treating access to it as a right. • Gaelscoil Targets: Set progressively increasing targets for attendance, aiming to double provision at primary level within a decade and work toward delivering a Gaelcholáiste in every county. • Teaching Reform: Increase focus on spoken Irish at Junior Cert by introducing an oral exam worth at least 40% of the overall mark. They would also replace the current framework for Irish exemptions with a new inclusive approach tailored to student needs. • Third Level: Double Irish Medium Education funding at the third level and increase the range and uptake of Irish medium courses. Sinn Féin’s approach to education, particularly its proposal to eliminate student fees and end voluntary school contributions, mirrors a belief that public services should be fully accessible and publicly funded, reducing barriers to participation for young people, akin to treating education as a foundational public utility that the state must fully subsidize, similar to water infrastructure.
Sinn Féin.environment: Sinn Féin’s environmental, climate, and energy policies are outlined under the heading "Environment, Climate and Energy," emphasizing a shift "From Eco-Austerity to Climate Justice". The party aims to accelerate the green transition, achieve energy independence, and tackle the biodiversity crisis, while ensuring the transition is fair and does not disproportionately burden low- and middle-income households. Here is a summary of Sinn Féin’s key policies on the environment, climate, and energy: 1. Accelerating the Green Transition and Energy Independence Sinn Féin plans significant public investment to transform Ireland’s reliance on imported fossil fuels to energy independence through renewables. • Renewable Energy Investment Fund: Establish a new €2.5 billion Renewable Energy Investment Fund using part of the Apple Tax money. This fund would be used to substantially increase investment in the energy grid to facilitate renewable energy potential. • Grid Constraints: Increase investment in grid expansion and upgrades to connect existing and new renewable projects. • Public Ownership: Expand the role of state ownership in the renewable energy system by enabling the state to take equity investments in joint-venture projects using the Renewable Energy Investment Scheme. This is intended to reorient the market away from excessive private profiteering. • Offshore Wind Infrastructure: Invest in strategic port development to facilitate the construction and maintenance of offshore wind farms at scale, recognizing that currently, only Belfast Port has this capacity. They would provide at least €80 million from the Renewable Energy Investment Fund to kickstart this investment. • Planning Reform: Review workforce planning and increase resourcing for state bodies involved in environmental planning (e.g., MARA, ABP) to address the slow, adversarial planning system that delays renewables projects. 2. Retrofitting and Affordability The party commits to overhauling the national retrofit program to make it accessible for ordinary households and tackle energy poverty. • Tiered Grants: Radically reform how retrofitting is funded, targeted, and delivered by establishing a new tiered grants-based retrofit scheme. • Targeting Funding: Direct 75% of the funding to those on low and modest incomes. • Investment: Invest €7 billion to expand retrofitting. This includes €1.5 billion in capital investment for the deep retrofit of over 100,000 homes and €850 million for the deep retrofit of over 44,000 social homes. • Solid Fuel Homes: Establish a dedicated scheme, with €750 million capital investment, for the retrofitting of solid fuel homes. 3. Climate Justice and Taxation Sinn Féin advocates for a climate justice approach, rejecting "eco-austerity" and focusing on the greatest emitters. • Carbon Tax and Excise Duties: They would not proceed with the annual increases to the carbon tax scheduled from 2025–2030. They would also reverse the two most recent hikes to excise duty on petrol and diesel for 12 months. • Pollution Tax: Target environmental taxes on excessive consumption, specifically introducing a pollution tax on private jets. • PSO Levy Reform: Reform the PSO levy (which subsidizes renewables and is charged to consumers) to make it a progressive charge levied on total energy demand rather than peak demand, to shift the burden away from households. 4. Biodiversity and Natural Resources The manifesto addresses the crisis in biodiversity, committing to greater funding and restoration efforts. • Nature Restoration Fund: Establish a dedicated €300 million nature restoration fund. This funding would assist farmers in taking action to meet environmental and biodiversity targets. • National Parks: Expansion and restoration of national parks and native woodlands. • Marine Protected Areas (MPA): Expedite the delivery of a Marine Protected Areas Bill. They would involve fishermen and their representatives in co-creating MPA spaces to minimize disruption. • Destructive Practices: Seek a complete ban on huge factory vessels registering and fishing within the EU and waters under the Common Fisheries Policy, citing damage to marine biodiversity. 5. Circular Economy and Waste Management Sinn Féin seeks to overhaul waste management practices, reducing privatization and increasing accountability. • Waste Collection: Bring bin collection back under public control via a franchise model starting with a pilot scheme in Dublin City Council. • Corporate Accountability: Introduce measures to hold corporations accountable, including legislating for large retailers to be compelled to donate unsold food rather than dumping it, and banning the dumping of new and unused goods. • Construction Waste: Establish a task force to minimize construction and demolition waste. Infrastructure Investment The plan includes significant capital investment in areas that mitigate climate change impacts : • Flood Defences: Provide €100 million in additional capital funding to the OPW (Office of Public Works) to improve flood defenses. • Water Services: Increase investment in water and wastewater services by at least an "additional €1.5 billion over five years".
Sinn Féin.brexit: Sinn Féin’s policy stance regarding the changes stemming from the United Kingdom’s departure from the European Union (often referred to as Brexit) is intrinsically linked to its goals for Irish reunification and its strategy for managing cross-border relations and the all-island economy. Here is a summary of Sinn Féin’s policies related to post-Brexit challenges and the resulting focus on the island of Ireland: Constitutional Change and Anglo-Irish Relations The party positions the constitutional future of the island as a key objective in government, driven by the provisions of the Good Friday Agreement. • Reunification Planning: Sinn Féin would commence planning for and actively working toward holding referendums on Irish reunification by the end of this decade. • Dublin-London Relationship: The party stresses the need for a mature, confident and pragmatic approach to managing constitutional change between Dublin and London. Both the British and Irish governments are acknowledged as having a responsibility to work together as co-guarantors of peace, reconciliation, and the realization of a new future. • Political Strength: Sinn Féin aims to strengthen and enhance the peace process by being in government both North and South. • Political Sentiment: The manifesto highlights recent polling suggesting that the proportion of people in the North supporting the union with Britain is now below 50%. The All-Island Economy and Cooperation Sinn Féin emphasizes leveraging the interconnectedness of the island’s economy to ensure future prosperity. • Maximizing Benefits: They commit to maximizing the benefits of the all-island economy to ensure prosperity and growth, delivering social, environmental, and economic benefits across the island. • North-South Cooperation: They plan to continue the work of the North South Ministerial Council in maximizing benefits for all citizens and, where possible, expand cooperation in areas such as education, health, and the all-island economy. Border Management and Immigration Sinn Féin acknowledges the challenge of maintaining the borderless nature of the island while controlling migration. • Bilateral Arrangements with Britain: They state that robust bi-lateral arrangements with Britain are necessary in order to protect the free movement of citizens across the land border on the island while simultaneously managing immigration. • Immigration Returns: They propose agreeing on revised bilateral arrangements with Britain for managing immigration at airports and ports. This would ensure that International Protection (IP) applicants who should be processed in Britain are returned there. European Engagement Sinn Féin maintains that Ireland’s place is within the European Union. • Advocacy for Unity: They commit to initiating a diplomatic offensive to promote Irish unity through international forums and bodies, including the European Union. They would actively work to ensure that the EU and countries outside the EU economically and actively support Irish reunification. • Sovereignty: They oppose the removal of the Irish veto on matters of Foreign Policy at the European Council and oppose any attempts to transfer decision-making powers on Foreign Affairs and Defence to the European Union, or the removal of unanimity on these matters.
Sinn Féin.entire manifesto: The Sinn Féin General Election Manifesto 2024 outlines a wide array of policies across numerous sectors, emphasizing "The Choice for Change" and prioritizing building homes, transforming health services, delivering affordable childcare, and achieving a United Ireland. Here is a summary of the manifesto’s key policy areas and commitments: Housing and Infrastructure Sinn Féin plans to tackle the housing crisis by delivering the largest social and affordable building program in the history of the state. • Housing Targets: Deliver 300,000 new homes between 2025 and 2029. This includes 125,000 public homes (social, affordable purchase, and affordable rental). • Affordability: Affordable homes for purchase would be available from €250,000 and affordable rental homes at an average of €1,000 per month or lower. • Constitutional Right: Hold a referendum to enshrine the right to housing in the Constitution. • Land Management: Transform the Land Development Agency into an Active Land Management Agency. • Water Services: Hold a referendum to enshrine the public ownership of the water and wastewater system and utility in the Constitution. Increase investment in water and wastewater services by at least an additional €1.5 billion over five years. Cost of Living, Taxation, and Economic Policy The manifesto addresses the cost-of-living crisis through tax cuts, price controls, and support for families. • Income Tax: Abolish the Universal Social Charge (USC) on the first €45,000 of everybody’s income , which would increase the take-home pay of average workers by over €1,100 a year. • Energy Costs: Do not proceed with the annual increases to the carbon tax. Reverse the two most recent hikes to excise duty on petrol and diesel for 12 months. Empower the Commission for the Regulation of Utilities (CRU) to tackle anti-competitive practices in the energy sector. • Rent/Mortgage: Protect renters by banning rent increases for three years. Provide temporary and targeted Mortgage Interest Relief. • Economic Support: Introduce a reduced 9% rate of VAT for parts of the Hospitality sector (excluding accommodation). Ramping-up capital investment to 6% of GNI* to address infrastructural deficits. Health and Disability Sinn Féin seeks to take "Big Bold Steps towards Universal Healthcare". • Universal Healthcare: Deliver free prescription medicines for all households, upgrade every GP visit card to a full medical card, and abolish prescription and car-parking charges. Enact "Healthcare for All" legislation to commit the state to full public health cover by 2035. • Hospital Capacity: Deliver 5,000 new hospital beds by 2031 (4,000 acute and 1,000 replacement of unsafe beds). Pursue a zero-tolerance approach to hospital trolleys and overcrowding. • Local Services: Deliver a landmark public GP contract, employ 250 public GPs, and hire public dentists. • Mental Health: Revolutionize mental health care, especially for those aged under 25, by establishing a new Child and Youth Mental Health Service to replace CAMHS. • Disability Services: Implement a 10-year investment program for a rights-based approach to disability services. Double the number of Personal Assistance (PA) hours over a term of government. Education The manifesto commits to ensuring education is truly affordable. • Third Level: Completely phasing out student fees (the contribution charge) within three years, starting by halving them in 2025. Increase SUSI grants by 15%. • School Costs: End schools’ reliance on "voluntary contributions". Expand the hot school meals scheme to all primary schools and commence rollout to secondary schools. Extend the free schoolbooks scheme to senior cycle in secondary schools. • Special Educational Needs: Provide the NCSE with greater powers to ensure sufficient school places. Fund the recruitment of 1,000 additional Special Education Teachers and 1,300 additional Special Needs Assistants (SNAs) per year. • School Transport: Reform and expand the school transport system to provide an additional 100,000 pupils with transport services by 2030. Family and Social Supports • Childcare Affordability: Introduce €10 per day childcare through subsidies to providers. • Parental Leave: Invest over €100 million to ensure that 52 weeks of leave is covered, enabling children to be with a parent for the first year of their life. • Carers: Abolish the means test for Carers Allowance over a term of government. Increase the annual Carer’s Support Grant by €50 each year. • Pensions: Restore the right to retire on a state pension at 65 years of age. Justice, Policing, and Community Investment • Gardaí: Commence the largest Garda recruitment drive in the history of the state, aiming for a 16,000-strong force. Establish a second Garda Training College. • Community Investment: Establish a €1 billion Apple Tax Community Investment Fund to invest in working class communities. • Financial Fraud: Establish a multi-annual strategy and taskforce to tackle financial fraud and scams. Introduce legislation for a Shared Fraud Database among banks and An Garda Síochána. Environmental and Climate Action • Funding the Transition: Establish a new €2.5 billion Renewable Energy Investment Fund. • Retrofitting: Overhaul the National Retrofit plan using tiered grants to direct 75% of funding to low and modest income households. • Biodiversity: Establish a dedicated €300 million nature restoration fund. A United Ireland and Political Reform • Reunification: Commence planning for referendums on Irish reunification by the end of this decade. Produce a government "Green Paper" in the first 100 days setting out a vision for a New and United Ireland. Appoint a Minister of State for Reunification and One Ireland. • Accountability: Establish a new independent Standards and Anti-Corruption Commission to investigate and sanction corruption. Reduce the salary top-ups of An Taoiseach, Tánaiste, Ministers, and Ministers of State by 50%. • Immigration: Establish a new Immigration Management Agency under the Department of Justice and Home Affairs responsible for planning, processing, enforcement, registration, and accommodation. Ensure new IPAS centers are only placed in more affluent areas with adequate services. Foreign Affairs and Defence • Neutrality: Maintain the triple-lock neutrality protection. Bring forward a referendum to enshrine neutrality in the Irish constitution. • Defence Forces: Increase Defence Force member numbers to a baseline of 11,500. Prioritize the acquisition of primary radar and subsea capabilities. • International Stance: Be a leading voice to end the genocide against the Palestinian People. Commit to increasing Official Development Aid to 0.7% of GNI over the lifetime of the next government. The key policies outlined represent a concerted effort to increase public investment (an additional €14.3 billion in current spending and €41.8 billion in capital investment over and above pre-committed expenditure) , largely funded by targeted taxes on high earners and corporations, and the use of the Apple Tax money for strategic capital projects.
